Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot



Chapter 1



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A virgin is married on Wednesday and a widow on Thursday, for in smaller towns court convenes two times per week, on Monday and Thursday, so if he has a complaint about virginity he can quickly go to court<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This reason, explored at length (and rejected) in the Halakhah, refers only to the marriage of the presumed virgin. For the widow, both Talmudim explain that the groom will have three days, the day of the wedding, Friday, and the Sabbath, to spend with his new wife. If he marries any other day, the groom might be expected to go to work the next day. In a metropolis one might expect to have the court available every working day.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A virgin is married on Wednesday,” etc. Bar Qappara said, because a blessing is written there. But a blessing in only written on the Fifth and the Sixth days! On the Fifth for birds and fish<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The days of the week, which in Hebrew are simply numbered from 1 to 6, are identified with the Days of Creation. Fish and birds, created on the Fifth Day (Thursday) are blessed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:22" href="/Genesis.1.22"><i>Gen</i>. 1:22</a>.</i>, on the Sixth for Adam and Eve<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:28" href="/Genesis.1.28"><i>Gen</i>. 1:28</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the reason of Bar Qappara is the Fourth, evening of the Fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">A couple which marries on Wednesday will first sleep together in the following night. Since the Jewish day starts at nightfall, this already is Thursday; they immediately benefit of the blessing to be fruitful and multiply. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5a" href="/Ketubot.5a">Babli, 5a</a>, this is a <i>baraita</i> in Bar Qappara’s name.</i>, and the Fifth, evening of the Sixth<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5a" href="/Ketubot.5a">Babli, 5a</a>, the explanation of R. Yose is part of the <i>baraita</i> attributed to Bar Qappara.</i>. Is there not a blessing written also on Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 2:3" href="/Genesis.2.3"><i>Gen</i>. 2:3</a>.</i>? No blessing is written for creatures, only for the day.
Because no blessing is written for creatures? Could she have been married on the Sabbath if a blessing were written for creatures? But was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is stated in full in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.6.2-5"><i>Berakhot</i> 2:6</a> (5b 1. 7), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.10.1">Note 261</a>.</i>: “A man should not first have sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">With his virgin bride.</i> on the Sabbath, for he makes a wound.” It must follow “others”, for “others permit it.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This is part of the <i>baraita</i> text in <i>Berakhot</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 6b" href="/Ketubot.6b">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 6b</a>, the opinion of “others” is ascribed to “the Sages” and practice is decided following them.</i>” But “others” permit only when he is already married<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning the final marriage ceremony in which the bride enters her husband’s house, which consists of the recitation of the “Seven Benedictions” in the presence of at least ten witnesses (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.12">Note 76</a>) after which the couple is considered married in all respects by being alone together. This ceremony activates all monetary aspects of the marriage contract.</i>, for before he was married he had no right to what she finds, what she earns<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In addition, the woman acquires the right to all services the husband is obligated to deliver in return for his acquisition of her property rights.</i>, and to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Without needing her father’s consent; cf. <i>Nedarim</i> Chapter 11.</i>. After he married her, he has the right to receive what she finds or earns, and to dissolve her vows. If you say so, he is like someone who acquires on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Which is certainly forbidden by rabbinic standards, and, in the opinion of Isaiah, by biblical standards (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 58:13" href="/Isaiah.58.13"><i>Is</i>. 58:13</a>).</i>. Rebbi Mana said, this means that those who marry a widow<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Who make the big wedding meal Friday night, to save the expenses of a separate Sabbath meal.</i> must take her in<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">He must take her into his house before sunset to acquire his marital rights.<br>This sentence, which has no parallel in the Babli, is the source of an extensive rabbinic literature; cf. <i>Šulḥan ‘Arukh Even Ha‘ezer</i> 64:5. (In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Yoma 13b:3:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Yoma.13b.3.1">Tosafot, <i>Yoma</i> 13b, <i>s</i>. <i>v</i>. לחדא</a>, the statement is quoted in the name of R. Ḥanina.) The question is whether the clause “to take her in”, is different from “entering the <i>ḥuppah</i>” used to describe the final marriage ceremony of a virgin. From Medieval times, <i>ḥuppah</i> denotes the canopy, open on all sides, under which the pair stands for the recitation of the “Seven Benedictions”. But there is no reason to assume that חוּפָּה originally meant anything but the totally covered bridal bedroom (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 19:6" href="/Psalms.19.6"><i>Ps</i>. 19:6</a>), from חפה “to cover”. There is no indication here that the rules of transfer of property rights are different for marriages of virgins and widows.</i> when it is still daytime on Friday, that he should not be like someone who acquires on the Sabbath.
Rebbi Eleazar explains the reason given in the Mishnah, that if he has a complaint about virginity he can quickly go to court<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">His explanation is given later, by R. Hila. He insists that the Mishnah does not refer only to the fact that if he married a girl supposed to be a virgin and he found her lacking virginity that he can divorce her without paying but he can claim “erroneous acquisition” and ask the court to void the marriage without bill of divorce.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Eleazar: Since the time of danger<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta 1:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3b" href="/Ketubot.3b">Babli 3b</a>. As S. Lieberman points out (<i>Tosefta ki-Fshutah</i> vol. 6, p. 187), “danger” always refers to the persecutions after the war of Bar Kokhba, when Jewish observances were forbidden and, therefore, marrying on Wednesday would have been a capital crime. (The Babli explains otherwise.)</i> they used to marry on Tuesdays and the Sages did not object; about Monday one does not listen to him, but if it was because of a danger it is permitted. What is “because of a danger”? because of sorcery<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody is afraid that sorceresses will put a spell on him to make him impotent if he marries on a day known to be a day for marrying, one lets him marry on any other day.</i>. What is the difference between Monday and Tuesday? One who waits one day cannot be compared to one who waits two days. Why not let him wait two days? That his acquisition should not be sweet for him. Why should his acquisition not be sweet for him? One cannot tolerate it, since Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, if he found the door open, he is forbidden to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here סוֹטָה means “unfaithful, deviant” in a general sense, not in the technical sense discussed in Tractate <i>Soṭah</i>. R. Eleazar holds that the Mishnah does not only give the husband the right to complain about lack of virginity but obligates him to go to court to annul his marriage since nobody can stay married to an adulterous wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>) and he presumes his bride was deflowered after she was preliminarily married to him, up to a year earlier. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b-9a" href="/Ketubot.8b-9a">Babli, 8b/9a</a>, the same argument is quoted in his name.</i>. Could we not suspect that she was raped<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">If a married woman is raped, the husband does not have to divorce her unless he is a Cohen.</i>? A rape is public knowledge. And even if you suspect that she was raped, there is no other doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>editio princeps</i>: לֹא סָפֵק <b>אֶחָד</b> “is there not <i>only one</i> doubt?” It is a generally recognized principle in both Talmudim that a single doubt referring to biblical precepts has to be judged restrictively, a double doubt leniently. Cf <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:3:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.3.5"><i>Yebamot</i> 7:2, Note 73</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 3a" href="/Beitzah.3a">Babli <i>Beṣah</i>3a</a>.</i>. There is a doubt whether she was raped or whether she was [willingly] opened<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">If she was a willing partner to adultery. This only applies to a girl which has the status of adolescent since “the seduction of a minor is rape” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 33b" href="/Yevamot.33b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 33b</a>).</i>. From the words of the Torah one has to be stringent. Rebbi Yose said, if you suspect that she was raped, there are two doubts. There is a doubt whether she was raped or whether she was [willingly] opened; there is a doubt whether it happened after she was preliminarily married or before. From the words of the Torah, with two doubts one has to be lenient<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The husband who claims that his bride was not a virgin is not obligated to divorce his wife against his will; R. Eleazar’s interpretation of the Mishnah is rejected by R. Yose.</i>.
If he performed the preliminary marriage in the bridal chamber, these strictures do not apply. They said that Rebbi Mattaniah acted thus for his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">If the preliminary marriage (see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 6:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.6.2.6"><i>Peah</i> 6:2, Note 46</a>) precedes the final marriage ceremony only by a few moments, the bride could not possibly have committed adultery and R. Eleazar’s argument becomes pointless.<br>R. Mattaniah’s procedure was adopted by all Jewish groups (except that the bridal chamber was transformed into a canopy, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.3">Note 15</a>.) To separate the preliminary from the final marriage, one spends some time by publicly reading the marriage contract. However, it seems that the current procedure is not derived from any talmudic statement but is a consequence of the poverty of the remnants of the Jewish communities in Western Europe after the devastation of the First Crusade which did not allow most people to organize two festivities, one for the preliminary and a separate one for the definitive wedding; cf. I. Schepansky, התקנות בישׂראל, vol. 3, Jerusalem-NewYork 1992, pp. שע-שעא.</i>.<br>In the opinion of Rebbi Eleazar, could she be married any day at a place where courts are in session every day<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3a" href="/Ketubot.3a">Babli, 3a</a>, (and at the end also in the Yerushalmi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.10">Note 66</a>) this is accepted as a declarative sentence (subject to the condition that the groom spend three days to prepare the wedding feast.)</i>? And at a place where there are no courts (every day)<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">An erroneous corrector’s addition (reproduced in <i>editio princeps</i>).</i> could she never be married? One does not want to abolish the time of Wednesday<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody challenges the first statement in the Mishnah, even if they disagree with the meaning of the later part of that Mishnah.</i>. Why does one not want to abolish the time of Wednesday? Because he<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar accepts that the Wednesday/Thursday combination is preferable over Sunday/Monday, even though local courts always also sit on Monday.</i> also accepts what Bar Qappara stated. Bar Qappara said, because a blessing is written there. Could she not be married on Sunday, that he might quickly go to court on Monday? Some want to say, not to abolish the time of Wednesday; some want to say, because of what Bar Qappara stated, for Bar Qappara said, because a blessing is written there<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3b" href="/Ketubot.3b">Babli, 3b</a>, the reason of the rejection is that the groom has to spend three days to prepare the wedding feast.</i>.
One agrees that she should not be married either Friday or Saturday night. Not on Friday, for the honor of the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">That the wedding feast should not impinge on the observance of the Sabbath and the Sabbath meal. As noted above, the wedding of a widow, which proceeds without great fanfare, may be scheduled for Friday.</i>. Not Saturday night: The colleagues say, because of the exertion; Rebbi Yose says, for the honor of the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">That he should not prepare on the Sabbath for the feast scheduled directly after nightfall; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5a" href="/Ketubot.5a">Babli 5a</a>.</i>. A <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 2a" href="/Ketubot.2a">Babli 2a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3a" href="/Ketubot.3a">3a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5a" href="/Ketubot.5a">5a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 7a" href="/Ketubot.7a">7a</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta, 1:1</a>, this is given as an alternative to the reason explained in the Mishnah.</i> supports the colleagues: Why did they say, a virgin is married on Wednesday? That a man should prepare for his needs<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The wedding feast.</i> three consecutive days.
<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The parallels are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Beitzah 5:2:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Beitzah.5.2.2-16"><i>Beṣah</i> 5:2</a> (63, 1. 64) and <i>Ta‘aniot</i> 4:9 (69b, 1. 50).</i> Rebbi Abba bar Cohen said before Rebbi Yose: Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Jacob bar Idi: A man may not [preliminarily] marry on a Friday. That means, to make an engagement feast<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Since this would impinge on the Sabbath meal. It is in order to make the preliminary marriage on Friday and arrange the engagement feast as the Sabbath meal.</i>. This implies that the preliminary marriage itself is permitted. Samuel says, even on the Ninth of Ab<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The anniversary of both destructions of the Temple, the most severe day of mourning in the Jewish calendar, where any exhibition of joy is frowned upon.</i> a preliminary marriage is permitted, lest another forestall him. The argument of Samuel seems inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">A similar argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Moed Katan 18b" href="/Moed_Katan.18b">Babli, <i>Mo‘ed Qaṭan</i> 18b</a>.</i>, he says, “God puts singles in a house, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 68:7" href="/Psalms.68.7"><i>Ps</i>. 68:7</a>. The verse means that marriages are pre-ordained in Heaven. The verse is quoted in the name of R. Joḥanan in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 2a" href="/Sotah.2a">Babli, <i>Soṭa</i> 2a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 22a" href="/Sanhedrin.22a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 22a</a>, to show that selecting the right mate is as difficult as the liberation of Israel from Egypt, the topic of the second half of the verse.</i>,” “To rise on scales; they all are of vapor!<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 62:1" href="/Psalms.62.1"><i>Ps</i>. 62:1</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 29:5" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.29.5"><i>Lev</i>.<i>rabba</i> 29(5</a>), this verse is the topic of a sermon of R. Ḥiyya bar Abba in the name of R. Levi, that when the fetuses still are like vapor in their mothers’ wombs, they already are joined together on Heaven’s scales.</i>” And there, he says so<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">If marriages are pre-ordained, why should anybody be afraid that another man could snatch the bride preselected for him?</i>? That means, that he should not forestall him in prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Another man may by his prayer cause the Heavenly decree to be changed.</i>. Even so, it would not be permanent<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, Samuel tells a man that praying to change Heaven's decree leads to an early death of either groom or bride.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The same text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Beitzah 5:2:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Beitzah.5.2.2-16"><i>Beṣah</i> 5:2</a> (64 1. 59), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.5.2">Sanhedrin 4:6</a> (22b 1. 17).</i> Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Aḥa, said in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: It is forbidden to judge money matters on Friday. Does not a Mishnah object<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.5.1"><i>Sanhedrin</i>, Mishnah 4:6</a>: “In money matters, judgment can be rendered immediately. In criminal matters, the accused can be found innocent immediately, but he can be found guilty only the next day; therefore …” Since judgment may not be rendered on the Sabbath, the panel discussion cannot be held on Friday.</i>: “Therefore, one does not judge criminal matters on Friday or any day before a holiday”? Therefore, one judges money matters<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition is explicitly restricted to criminal matters.</i>! Also, Rebbi Ḥiyya stated thus: One judges money matters on Friday but not criminal matters. One is for practice, the other for Torah study<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In Sanhedrin: כָּאן לַהֲלָכָה כָּאן לְמַעֲשֶׂה “here for practice, there for action.” It is declared practice not to judge money matters on Friday but if a court held a session on Friday its decisions are valid. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 113a" href="/Bava_Kamma.113a">Babli (<i>Baba Qama</i> 113a</a>): One does not schedule court sessions on the eve of a Sabbath or holiday.</i>.
Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Crispus: An adult woman is like an open amphora<sup class="footnote-marker">47,</sup><i class="footnote">Once she is older than 1½ years, her body is so soft that the rupture of the hymen may not be noticed. The court will not hear such a case.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the quote in Tosaphot (9a, s. v. האומר): "an open wine amphora."</i>. That means, not to let her lose her <i>ketubah</i>. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">19,</sup><i class="footnote">Here סוֹטָה means “unfaithful, deviant” in a general sense, not in the technical sense discussed in Tractate <i>Soṭah</i>. R. Eleazar holds that the Mishnah does not only give the husband the right to complain about lack of virginity but obligates him to go to court to annul his marriage since nobody can stay married to an adulterous wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>) and he presumes his bride was deflowered after she was preliminarily married to him, up to a year earlier. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b-9a" href="/Ketubot.8b-9a">Babli, 8b/9a</a>, the same argument is quoted in his name.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel case in the Babli, 9a, the argument ascribed here to R. Yose (Notes 21-23) is used to restrict R. Eleazar's statement to the case of either a Cohen (who has to divorce his wife in case of rape) or a person who preliminarily married a girl aged less than 3 full years (who could not have had premarital sex). Note also the change of language: R. Hila in the name of R. Eleazar states that he <i>is forbidden to keep her</i>; here he <i>is not authorized</i> to keep her. As Rashi explains in the Babli, there one treats the case that the husband comes to court to report the case and is ready to be convinced if the proceedings clear his wife. In the Yerushalmi one treats the case that the husband comes to complain convinced that his bride was unfaithful after preliminary marriage. Then one follows the principle that if somebody is convinced that something is forbidden, one cannot permit it.<br>Since the husband is only subjectively forbidden to keep his wife who objectively may have been a virgin, he has to pay the full amount of her ketubah since obligations based on written contracts can be abolished only by a full proof of the guilt of the beneficiary.</i>. This also applies to what Rebbi Ḥanina said, since Rebbi Ḥanina said: It happened that a woman was found without virginity and the case came before Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10b" href="/Ketubot.10b">Babli, 10b</a>, a woman did not bleed when deflowered and Rabban Gamliel the elder accepted the fact that not to bleed was hereditary in her family and told the husband to enjoy his wife. In another case quoted there, Rebbi convinced the husband that he had not penetrated on his weddding night.</i>. He said to her, where is it? She said, the stairs in my father’s house were high and it was rubbed off. Rebbi believed her. That means, not to let her lose her <i>ketubah</i>. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful. This<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">That the woman wins her case in money matters does not imply that the court tells the husband to keep her.</i> also applies to what we stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup>: “The <i>ketubah</i> sum of a virgin who is a widow, or a divorcee, or one who had received <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, after a preliminary marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>. In all three cases the husband died before the <i>ḥuppah</i> ceremony and the women are presumed to be virgins.</i> is 200 [<i>zuz</i>], and they are subject to complaints about virginity.” That means, referring to a <i>ketubah</i> sum of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ketubah</i> sum of a non-virgin is 100 <i>zuz</i>, called מְנָה, a <i>mina</i> (1Μνᾶ = 100 Δράχμη, in contrast to the Babylonian מָנֶה <i>manēi</i> = 60 <i>šeqel</i>).</i>. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful. This<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">That the woman wins her case in money matters does not imply that the court tells the husband to keep her.</i> also applies to what we stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.5.1">Mishnah 1:5</a>.</i>: “One who eats unchaperoned at his father-in-law’s in Judea cannot go to court about virginity since he was alone with her.” That means, referring to a <i>ketubah</i> sum of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ketubah</i> sum of a non-virgin is 100 <i>zuz</i>, called מְנָה, a <i>mina</i> (1Μνᾶ = 100 Δράχμη, in contrast to the Babylonian מָנֶה <i>manēi</i> = 60 <i>šeqel</i>).</i>. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the court will not hear a claim to annul the marriage because of missing virginity since the groom was alone, unchaperoned, with his preliminarily married wife, if he asserts that he did not sleep with her before the <i>ḥuppah</i> one tells him that he cannot keep his wife.</i>. This<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">That the woman wins her case in money matters does not imply that the court tells the husband to keep her.</i> also applies to what we stated<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.6.1">Mishnah 1:6</a>.</i>: “If somebody married a woman and found her not to be a virgin. She says, I was raped after the preliminary marriage and your field was flooded<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">If a farmer buys a field and after the property rights were transferred to him the field is flooded and unusable for that year, he has no regress on the seller. While it is true that her <i>ketubah</i> is only a mina since the <i>ketubah</i> is executed at the time of the final marriage, his acquisition of marital rights was at the preliminary marriage and, therefore, he cannot claim to have been lured by false pretenses and cannot annul the marriage without paying anything.</i>, but he says, no, it was before the preliminary marriage and my acquisition was in error,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">It is a question who has the burden of proof. For Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer, the husband has the burden of proof and if he cannot prove his assertion he has to pay. For R. Joshua, the wife has the burden of proof and if she cannot prove her case the marriage is annulled and she gets nothing.</i>” that refers to a <i>ketubah</i> sum of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful. This<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">That the woman wins her case in money matters does not imply that the court tells the husband to keep her.</i> also applies to what we stated<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.7.1">Mishnah 1:7</a>. This case is completely parallel to the preceding one.</i>: “She says, I was injured by a piece of wood, but he says no, you were trampled on by a man,” that refers to a <i>ketubah</i> sum of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]. But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful. All these cases are based on what Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, if he found the door open, he is forbidden to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here סוֹטָה means “unfaithful, deviant” in a general sense, not in the technical sense discussed in Tractate <i>Soṭah</i>. R. Eleazar holds that the Mishnah does not only give the husband the right to complain about lack of virginity but obligates him to go to court to annul his marriage since nobody can stay married to an adulterous wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>) and he presumes his bride was deflowered after she was preliminarily married to him, up to a year earlier. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b-9a" href="/Ketubot.8b-9a">Babli, 8b/9a</a>, the same argument is quoted in his name.</i>.
When is an adult married following Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Since it was stated that no claim of missing virginity is possible for adult girls, there is no need to have the wedding on Wednesdays.</i>? When is a virgin after marriage married<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died immediately after the final marriage ceremony, the widow is still a virgin but in her next marriage she can claim only the widow’s mina for her <i>ketubah</i>, the same as a widow who is not a virgin. Therefore, for R. Eleazar there is no reason why she should marry on a Wednesday.</i>? When is a woman injured by a piece of wood married following Rebbi Meïr<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.3.1">Mishnah 1:3</a>. She can claim a virgin’s <i>ketubah</i> but is not subject to a claim of missing virginity.</i>? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.1.1">Mishnah 2:1</a>.</i>: “If there are witnesses that she went out in <i>hinuma</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A woman whose <i>ketubah</i> was lost who claims that she married as a virgin. If she can produce witnesses that ὑμέναια “wedding songs” were sung at her wedding, it is a proof that she married as a virgin (M. Sachs). Since wedding songs were prohibited after the wars of Bar Kokhba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 9:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.9.12.1"><i>Soṭah</i>9:13, Note 189</a>), the word <i>hinuma</i> changed its meaning. In Babylonia it became “a veil” (2:1, 26a 1. 71; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 17b" href="/Ketubot.17b">Babli 17b</a>), in Galilee φόρημα “a litter”.</i>” Wednesday was not mentioned. This means that Wednesday does not mean anything<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">A marriage on Wednesday is no proof of virginity and a marriage on another day is no proof of non-virginity.</i>.
“A widow [is married] on Thursday.” For if you would let him [marry] any other day of the year, he would go to work the next morning. Since you tell him, on a Thursday, he enjoys himself with her on Thursday, Friday, and Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument, somewhat enlarged, in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 5a" href="/Ketubot.5a">Babli, 5a</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta, 1:1</a>. From the Tosephta text it seems likely that one whould read בְּאֶחָד מִכָּליְמוֹת הַשַּׁבָּת “any other weekday”. Since the husband has to spend time on Friday and buy provisions for the Sabbath, it is not worthwhile for him to go to work.</i>.
Moses instituted seven days of a marriage feast<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The week-long wedding feast of Jacob and Leah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 29:27" href="/Genesis.29.27"><i>Gen</i>. 29:27</a>. But in the interpretation of Nahmanides, the Yerushalmi refers to an oral tradition going back to Moses, without reference to biblical verses. Sforno sees in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 29:21" href="/Genesis.29.21"><i>Gen</i>. 29:21</a> a biblical justification for R. Mattaniah’s procedure (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.5">Note 24</a>). In <i>Yalqut Šim’oni</i> II, 70, in a note attributed to <i>Pirqe R</i>.<i>Eliezer</i> (not in the surviving text): “The seven days of a wedding feast we learned from Jacob and Simson (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 14:12" href="/Judges.14.12"><i>Jud</i>. 14:12</a>).”</i> and seven days of mourning<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The week-long mourning for Jacob, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 50:10" href="/Genesis.50.10"><i>Gen</i>. 50:10</a>. Since this mourning was held before the burial, it cannot be the real paradigm for the rabbinic mourning period which starts after burial.</i>, but he instituted nothing for the widow. Even though you say that he instituted nothing for the widow, she needs a benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The “Seven Benedictions” without which the final marriage ceremony cannot be held. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 7a" href="/Ketubot.7a">Babli, 7a</a>, as an Amoraic statement.</i>. From Boaz, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:2" href="/Ruth.4.2"><i>Ruth</i> 4:2</a>.</i>: “And (Boaz)<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Not in the biblical text, implied by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:1" href="/Ruth.4.1">v. 4:1</a>; is also in <i>Ruth rabba</i> 4(7).</i> took ten men of the city Elders and said, sit here, and they sat down.” Rebbi Alexander said, <sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following statements are also in <i>Ruth rabba</i>4(7).</i> from here [one learns that] the lesser person is not permitted to sit down until the more important person<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since Boaz was of the family of the princes of Judah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:21" href="/Ruth.4.21"><i>Ruth</i> 4:21</a>; cf. the author’s Commentary to <i>Seder ‘Olam</i>(Northvale NJ 1998), pp. 124–125.</i> tells him to sit down. Rebbi Phineas said, from here [one learns that] this family<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The descendants of King David.</i> appoints Elders for their marriage feasts. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Yose said, from here [one learns that] the wedding blessing needs ten people [present]<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the preliminary marriage ceremony which requires only the presence of two witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazy said, not only a bachelor marrying a virgin, but also a widower marrying a widow, since Boaz was a widower and Ruth a widow, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 1:19" href="/Ruth.1.19"><i>Ruth</i> 1:19</a>. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 91a" href="/Bava_Batra.91a">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 91a</a>; <i>Ruth rabba</i> 3(6).</i> “The entire city was in an uproar because of them.” Is that possible that the entire town was in alarm because of the sorry state of Naomi? But Boaz’s wife had died that very day and when all the people went to the burial, Ruth and Naomi entered. It turned out that when one left, the other entered.
It was stated: The marriage benedictions are said all seven days<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 7b" href="/Ketubot.7b">Babli, 7b</a>: One recites the marriage benedictions in the presence of 10 persons all seven days. In <i>Megillah</i>: “Neither the marriage benedictions nor the mourning benedictions are said all seven days.” The following discussion shows that this cannot be the correct version.</i>. [Rebbi Jeremiah wanted to say that one re-enacts the marriage all seven days.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">How else could one recite the wedding benedictions?</i>] Rebbi Yose said to him, but did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state: The benedictions of mourners<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The special version of Grace for the mourner.</i> are said all seven days. Can you say that one buries the dead all seven days? How is that? Since here he consoles with him, so there he enjoys with him<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Anytime visitors to a house of mourners bring food and eat with the mourners, they recite the special version of Grace; anytime visitors of a newlywed couple who participate in a festive meal append the seven wedding benedictions to Grace recited after the meal.<br>In <i>Megillah</i>, the positions of  “consoles” and “enjoys” are switched.</i>; as here one remembers, so there one remembers<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The topic of conversation in a house of mourning is the deceased; the topic of conversation with the newlyweds is the marriage ceremony.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Slightly different version of this <i>baraita</i> are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 12a" href="/Ketubot.12a">Babli, 12a</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.4">Tosephta, 1:4</a>.</i> It was stated: Rebbi Jehudah said, in Judea in earlier times they appointed two best men, one for the bride and one for the groom, but<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This is a hidden polemic against the formulation of the Tosephta, that the best men were appointed three days before the wedding day and conducted a common investigation of the bridal chamber, so that there was no place where the groom possibly could make a blood-stained cloth disappear in order to accuse the bride falsely of not being a virgin and also that the bride could not hide beforehand a blood-stained cloth in order to fake a non-existing virginity.</i> they appointed them only for the wedding day. In contrast, this was not done in Galilee. In Judea in earlier times one let the fiancé be alone with the fiancée for an hour so that he became familiar with her; in contrast, this was not done in Galilee<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This practice is confirmed by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.5.1">Mishnah 1:5</a>. As noted there, it is obvious that at a place where one lets the pair be alone together there can be no claim of virginity and no best men were appointed.<br>In the Babli, and it seems also in the Yerushalmi’s discussion of R. Eleazar’s position (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.9">Note 54</a>), one assumes that at certain places in Judea one was very stringent and at others very lax. But it seems from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.5.2-3">Halakhah 1:5</a> that the radical change from appointing best men to letting the fiancé to be alone with the fiancée is not a matter of different localities but of different times (and the Yerushalmi’s practice certainly does not follow R. Eliezer).</i>. In Judea in earlier times the best men were investigating the places of groom and bride; in contrast, this was not done in Galilee<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph belongs together with the first; it explains the roles of the best men.</i>. In Judea in earlier times the best men were sleeping in the room with groom and bride<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">After bride and groom had finished their first sexual relations, the best men were invited for the remainder of the night to make sure no evidence was removed or introduced.</i>; in contrast, this was not done in Galilee. Anybody who did not follow these rules<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">In Jehudah, at a place where one did not let the pair be together unchaperoned.</i> could not present a claim of missing virginity.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 9:11, a statement of R. Jehudah.</i>: “Every vine gives wine; if there is no wine it is dried up<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τρυγητής, from τρύγη, ἡ, “crop, vintage; dryness”. It means that there are women who are congenitally unable to bleed. (In this and similar discussions it is always assumed that the causes of menstrual bleeding and bleeding when the hymen is torn are the same.)</i>.” Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Does that mean that Rebbi Jehudah does not admit claims of missing virginity<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Since he states that there are women who do not bleed when they are deflowered.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, in itself it means that Rebbi Jehudah admits claims of missing virginity, as it was stated: Rebbi Jehudah said, in Judea in earlier times they appointed two best men, one for the groom and one for the bride, but they appointed them only for the wedding day. In contrast, this was not done in Galilee … they were sleeping in the room with groom and bride; in contrast, this was not done in Galilee. How is this? She has to bring proof that she comes from a family of dryness<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The proven absence of bleeding is prima facie evidence of non-virginity, open to medical explanation which preserves the fact and denies the inference.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah was of the opinion to follow the standard of Judea in Galilee<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Since at the end of the Tosephta R. Jehudah states that anybody not following the procedure of Judea cannot claim absence of virginity, it seems that he denies to the people of Galilee the right to bring any such claim.</i>. Rebbi Yose said to him, is the standard of Judea in Galilee a testimony by biblical standards<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The assertion of R. Jeremiah is unreasonable since the procedure of certain places in Judea has no biblical basis.</i>? No, [one follows] the standard of Judea in Judea and the standard of Galilee in Galilee. If you say, it is not testimony by biblical standards, why appoint them<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">If the testimony of the best men is not needed, why are they there?</i>? That the daughters of Israel should not become wanton in immorality. If it is that the daughters of Israel should not become wanton in immorality, even if one appoints, they should not be trustworthy! Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila: A man would not go to all this expense in order to give his wife a bad reputation<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Since the groom bears all expenses of the wedding feast, he would not do that if his intention was from the start to claim non-virginity and go for an annulment of the match. There are much cheaper ways to get a woman for one night. (In a different context, the same argument is made in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10a" href="/Ketubot.10a">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 10a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107a" href="/Yevamot.107a"><i>Yebamot</i> 107a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 45b" href="/Kiddushin.45b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 45b</a>.)</i>. If it is that a man would not go to all this expense in order to give his wife a bad reputation, even if one does not appoint, he should be believed. Rebbi Hila said, because of one suspicion, because of one immoral person<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The entire set-up in certain regions in Judea is only because in a very few cases bad things do happen.</i>. Where do we hold? If he investigated and found, he found<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">He is bound by the testimony of the best men that his wife was a virgin.</i>! If he did not find but investigated, did he not investigate<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">He can go to court and ask for annulment of the marriage. {R. Nissim Gerondi (שיטה לר״ן, ed. A. L. Feldman, Jerusalem 1997, col. 28), copied from R. Crescas, reads: “If he did not check and found, or his side checked but not her side.”}</i>? But we deal with the case that he did not investigate and found<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">He claims that he could enter his (underage) wife without resistance and that, therefore, she could not have been a virgin. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10b" href="/Ketubot.10b">Babli, 10b</a>, dismisses such claims out of hand since (a) it might be possible to enter without rupturing the hymen and (b) any man making such a claim must have ample experience with women, virgins and non-virgins, so that he must be treated as an amoral person.</i>. She says, it is blood of virginity. He says no, it is a bird’s blood. His case is damaged since he did not follow the procedures. <sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">. In the parallel case in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 9a" href="/Ketubot.9a">Babli, 9a</a>, the argument acribed here to R. Yose (Notes 21–23) is used to restrict R. Eleazar’s statement to the case either a Cohen (who has to divorce his wife in case of rape) or a person who preliminarily married a girl aged less than 3 full years (who could not have had premarital sex). Note also the change of language: R. Hila in the name of R. Eleazar states that he <i>is forbidden</i> to keep her; here he <i>is not authorized</i> to keep her. As Rashi explains in the Babli, there one treats the case that the husband comes to court to report the case and is ready to be convinced if the proceedings clear his wife. In the Yerushalmi one treats the case that the husband comes to complain convinced that his bride was unfaithful after the preliminary marriage. Then one follows the principle that if somebody is convinced that something is forbidden, one cannot permit it.<br>Since the husband is only subjectively forbidden to keep his wife who objectively may have been a virgin, he has to pay the full amount of her <i>ketubah</i> since obligations based on written contracts can be abolished only by a full proof of the guilt of the beneficiary.</i> That means, not to let her lose her <i>ketubah.</i> But he is not permitted to keep her because she might have been unfaithful. It follows what we statedthere<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Note 53</a>.</i>: “A virgin and a widow, etc.” All these cases are based on what Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, if he found the door open, he is forbidden to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here סוֹטָה means “unfaithful, deviant” in a general sense, not in the technical sense discussed in Tractate <i>Soṭah</i>. R. Eleazar holds that the Mishnah does not only give the husband the right to complain about lack of virginity but obligates him to go to court to annul his marriage since nobody can stay married to an adulterous wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>) and he presumes his bride was deflowered after she was preliminarily married to him, up to a year earlier. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b-9a" href="/Ketubot.8b-9a">Babli, 8b/9a</a>, the same argument is quoted in his name.</i>.
It was stated: The claim of virginity is based on any amount (of blood). It happened that for a certain woman nothing was found except for [a stain the size of] a mustard seed. She came before Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose, who said to her, there should be many like you in Israel. Rebbi Zachariah the son-in-law of Rebbi Levi: He cursed her<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">As explained later, because she might not have children.</i>, like people who, when they see a blind man, call him “much light”. The colleagues said, he needled her, any woman with little blood has few children<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10b" href="/Ketubot.10b">Babli, 10b</a>, R. Meïr states the contrapositive: Any woman with much blood has many children.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, he praised her, any woman with little blood will not cause impurity to food prepared in purity<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10b" href="/Ketubot.10b">Babli, 10b</a>: She will not cause her husband any problems with the impurity of her period.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The minimum payable to the bride at the dissolution of the marriage either by divorce or by the husband’s death. This does not exclude that the <i>ketubah</i> document may stipulate higher amounts.</i> of a virgin is 200 and that of a widow one mina<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">100 <i>zuz.</i> The Mishnah remains noncommittal about the nature of the coin involved.</i>. The <i>ketubah</i> of virgins who after a preliminary marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>. In all three cases the husband died before the <i>ḥuppah</i> ceremony and the women are presumed to be virgins.</i> become widows, divorcees, or who received <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> is 200 and they are subject to a claim of non-virginity<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">To invalidate the document if they are found not to be virgins.</i>. The <i>ketubah</i> of a proselyte, a prisoner, and a slave who were redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that a female kidnap victim will be raped as a matter of course. But a girl raped at age less than 3 years still is a virgin.</i>, freed<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Since slaves can have guiltless sexual relations with Gentiles, it is assumed that they do have such relations.</i>, or converted<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">There is no presumed minimal age for sexual activity of Gentiles. Therefore, a proselyte aged more than 3 years at conversion is presumed not to be virginal.</i> at less than three years and one day of age, is 200 and they are subject to a claim of non-virginity<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">To invalidate the document if they are found not to be virgins.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The <i>ketubah</i> of a virgin is 200 and that of a widow one mina,” etc. Huna in the name of Samuel: In the Temple <i>šeqel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The Temple <i>šeqel</i> coins struck in Jerusalem during the first war with the Romans are silver coins weighing between 13.5 and 14.3 g. The corresponding Tyrian coinage is about 13.5 g. A Temple <i>šeqel</i> in Babylonian theory is twice the weight of a common <i>šeqel,</i> which is the name of the two-denar coin. This means that the Temple <i>šeqel</i> is equal, both in the Yerushalmi and in the Babli, to the Roman tetradrachma (סֶלַע), based on an unadulterated silver denar (drachma, זוּז) of 3.4 g. Tyre ceased to mint coins between the reigns of Augustus and Septimius Severus, meaning that Tyrian coins in the Mishnaic period were unadulterated silver. Samuel requires that the <i>ketubah</i> be adjusted for the inflation caused by the debasement of the currency in circulation. It may be that he holds that the basic <i>ketubah</i> amount is a biblical requirement (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:11:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.11.2-3">Halakhah 13:11</a>).</i><i>.</i> Rebbi Abba bar Bina said, circulating coin<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">The value of the <i>ketubah</i> has to be computed on the basis of the currency in circulation.</i>. A Mishnah supports Rebbi Abba bar Bina<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 8:7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.8.7">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 8:7</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 12:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).12.6">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 12:6</a>.</i>: “The five tetradrachmas of the firstborn<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The redemption of the firstborn, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 3:47" href="/Numbers.3.47"><i>Num.</i> 3:47</a>, identifying the biblical <i>šeqel</i> as tetradrachma.</i> are in Tyrian coinage, the 30 of the slave<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">30 <i>šeqel</i> weregilt for the killing of another person’s slave by one’s ox, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:32" href="/Exodus.21.32"><i>Ex.</i> 21:32</a>.</i>, the 50 of the rapist and the seducer<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">50 <i>šeqel</i> bride money paid by the rapist (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:29" href="/Deuteronomy.22.29"><i>Deut.</i> 22:29</a>) and, by inference, the seducer <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:15-16" href="/Exodus.22.15-16"><i>(Ex.</i> 22:15–16</a>) of a girl.</i>, the 100 of the slanderer<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">The fine imposed on a man wrongly accusing his wife of committing adultery during her preliminary marriage period, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.19"><i>Deut.</i> 22:19</a>.</i>, are all computed in Temple <i>šeqels</i> in Tyrian coinage.” A woman’s <i>ketubah</i> is not stated with them. Rebbi Abin said, did they not learn the <i>ketubah</i> of a woman from the rapist and the seducer<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Since the 50 tetradrachmas due from the rapist and the seducer are exactly 200 denarii; either these 200 denarii are the “bride money” described in the verse <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:16" href="/Exodus.22.16"><i>Ex.</i> 22:16</a> or at least they are the inspiration for the rabbis to fixate the minimum <i>ketubah</i> at 200 <i>zuz.</i></i>? Since the rapist and the seducer are mentioned, it is as if women’s <i>ketubah was</i> stated with them<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah from <i>Bekhorot</i> does not prove anything.</i>.
So far about a virgin. What about a widow? Rav Ḥinena said, it is enough for a widow that she take half of a virgin’s portion<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody agrees that the <i>ketubah</i> of a widow is a rabbinic institution.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada said, even if “a woman’s <i>ketubah</i>” was stated with them<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the Mishnah did state that the <i>ketubah</i> of the virgin is a biblical institution, practice could not follow that Mishnah since all amoraic authorities hold that the <i>ketubah</i> is a purely rabbinic institution. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10b" href="/Ketubot.10b">Babli <i>(Qiddu</i>š<i>in</i> 10b</a>) quotes <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 8:7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.8.7">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 8:7</a> with the addition that “all money due by rabbinic institutions is local coin”, following R. Abba bar Bun. A similar statement underlies the text here.</i>, do not all these rabbis disagree? Rebbi Ḥananiah and Rebbi Jonathan both say, circulating<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">This can be debased coin. However, if merchants refuse to accept debased silver coin but require to be paid in gold, it would not be possible to liquidate a <i>ketubah</i> debt in legal but not circulating coin.</i> coin. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, circulating coin. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Immi, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish in the name of Rebbi Jehudah Neśia: Current coin. Rebbi Joḥanan said<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The history of interpretation of this sentence is documented by D. Sperber, <i>Roman Palestine</i>200–400<i>, Money &amp; Prices,</i> Ramat Gan 1974, p. 223. I follow Sperber in identifying the coins referred to as those of Severus Alexander, whose Antiochene coins, following those of Elagabalus, earned the attribute of “good”, returning to earlier standards after the debasement of the gold minting by Caracalla.</i>, good Severan tetradrachmas, Jerusalem ones<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">This must refer to the full weight Jerusalem Temple <i>šeqels</i> of the war against the Romans, not the copper coins of Aelia Capitolina. R. Joḥanan here holds with Samuel that the <i>ketubah</i> goes by biblical standards.</i>. These are saying so, those are saying otherwise<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In general, R. Jonathan, R. Joshua ben Levi, and R. Joḥanan are the leading authorities; it is difficult to decide if they disagree.</i>! But he<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan changed his mind and agreed that the <i>ketubah</i> has to be satisfied by rabbinical standards.</i> also changed his mind and thought like them. Are not always these saying so, those are saying otherwise<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">The standing of the <i>ketubah</i> is no different from most other rabbinic institutions.</i>? Here, even he changed his mind and thought like them.
There came a case before Rebbi Ḥanina of a woman whose <i>ketubah</i> was less than 200 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbinic commentaries all explain that the <i>ketubah</i> was written for 200 (debased) silver denars, as R. Ḥanina lived in the first half of the third Century C.E., at the end of the Severan dynasty and the early military anarchy. It could also be that the document was written in terms of a foreign currency, Persian or other, which when translated into local currency turned out to be less than the statutory 200 <i>zuz.</i> In any case, it is clear that the <i>ketubah</i> did not amount to the value of 50 Temple <i>šeqel</i> when it became due.</i>, and he said, she should take what he had written for her. He said to Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">R. Mana I.</i>, sit down and sign. He answered, follow your argument and sign yourself, did not Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">This probably is a scribal error since R. Ḥiyya the Elder preceded Samuel and R. Ḥiyya bar Abba lived two generations later. One should read (Rav) Ḥuna, student of Samuel’s contemporary Rav (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.2">Note 112</a>).</i> say in the name of Samuel, by the Temple <i>šeqel</i>? Rebbi Eudaimon of Sepphoris in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna: Because of a renunciation<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Since the woman had agreed at the moment of marriage to be satisfied with the smaller amount. [In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a>, R. Meïr states that living with a woman without guaranteeing her the minimum support of the <i>ketubah</i> is immoral and cannot be tolerated. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57a" href="/Ketubot.57a">Babli, 57a</a>, decides that practice follows R. Meïr, against the opinion of R. Yose (usually the higher authority) that money matters between consenting adults are their private business. The Yerushalmi discusses R. Meïr’s opinion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.9.2">Halakhah 4:9</a> in a non-committal way; the discussion here shows that it accepts R. Yose’s opinion as determining practice.]</i>. Now, should a woman whose <i>ketubah</i> was for less than 200 [<i>zuz</i>] not hide her <i>ketubah</i> in order to collect by the Temple <i>šeqel</i>? They said in the name of Rebbi Ḥuna, at a place where one does not write a <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that there were places in Galilee where nobody could read or write. At such a place, the <i>ketubah</i> by default is 200 full weight silver denar. (A standard <i>ketubah,</i> as explained later, contains additions which exceed the legal minimum. Such additions are impossible if the <i>ketubah</i> is not written.)</i><i>.</i> But at a place where one writes a <i>ketubah,</i> what she presents she collects. Rebbi Joḥanan said, it was stated thus: If a deaf-mute man married a hearing wife, she has no claim for support nor <i>ketubah,</i> but if she died, he inherits from her, for she wanted to connect him with her property, but he could not want to connect her with his property<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">One must assume that the deaf-mute is also illitterate since, if he could communicate in writing, he would be able to conduct business. If he cannot write, he cannot transact business, cf. <i>Yebamot,</i> Chapter 14. The woman who marries him can accept all financial consequences of marriage, but her husband is incompetent to do so. (Naturally, the question could be asked, how can an incompetent person inherit? The question is asked for the next statement; it could have been asked here. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113a" href="/Yevamot.113a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 113a</a>, notes that if the husband is healed and becomes able to conduct business, the marriage ceremony has to be repeated.)</i>. If a hearing male married a deaf-mute woman, she has a claim to support and <i>ketubah,</i> but if she died, he does not inherit, for he wanted to connect her with his property, but she could not want to connect him with her property. But can a deaf-mute woman acquire and have <i>ketubah</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that the deaf-mute woman has a claim to support since she lives with her husband. The question is only, how can the deaf-mute woman acquire a claim to the <i>ketubah</i> that could be enforced against her husband’s legal heirs, whose claim to the inheritance is biblical?<br>In contrast, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113a" href="/Yevamot.113a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 113a</a>, holds that in this case of a deaf-mute bride her legal status is irrelevant; since the groom dedicated the <i>ketubah</i> money to her, the court will transfer it to her guardians. This must also be the theory of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.3">Tosephta, 1:3</a>, which prescribes 200 <i>zuz</i> for the virgin deaf-mute or insane bride.</i> Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, explain it that at the moment he married her, she was hearing. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, he married her when she was hearing but she turned deaf-mute<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">The two statements in the name of R. Eleazar are identical in meaning.</i>. In any case, did he not marry her when she was hearing<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation cannot work: if the woman was competent when she married, she acquired all the rights of a married woman and her later loss of hearing and speech cannot change that.</i>? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, explain it that she was deaf-mute and turned hearing; he married her when she was hearing and she turned deaf<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">She was deaf-mute before the marriage, she is deaf-mute now. But in between there was a period in which she could communicate with the outside world; she acquired all the rights of a married wife if the husband lived with her during her lucid period.</i>. That you should not say, because at the start she was deaf-mute she has [no] <i>ketubah,</i> therefore it is necessary to say that she (does not have) [has]<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The words in parentheses are those of the ms.; the words in brackets are those of the <i>editio princeps.</i> Only the latter make sense.</i>. Rebbi Yose does not say so, but since if one has sexual relations with a deaf-mute, is he not liable for a fine<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The fines of the rapist and the seducer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.2">Note 117</a>) of an underage girl. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 3:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).3.5">Tosephta (3:5</a>) states that the deaf-mute has no claim to a fine. The existing mss. and the <i>editio princeps</i> of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 36a" href="/Ketubot.36a">Babli (36a</a>) quote the Tosephta to the effect that she has a claim, but <i>Tosafot RID</i> quotes “she has no claim”. S. Lieberman concludes that the original version of the Babli (if there existed a uniform original version) cannot be reconstrued. He also accepts the emendation of M. Margalit: אִילּוּ מִי שֶׁבָּא עַל הַחֲרֶשֶׁת שֶׁמָּא <b>אִית</b> לָהּ קְנָס. וְכָל־שֶׁאֵין לָהּ קְנָס אֵין לָהּ כְּתוּבָּה. “If one has sexual relations with a deaf-mute, would he be not liable for a fine? Since there is no fine there is no <i>ketubah</i>.” Even though this changes only one letter in the text, one should hesitate to accept emendations of M. Margalit without very convincing reasons.</i>? Only if there were no fine would there be no <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Yudan said, does that depend on a fine? Look, the adult woman<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Who marries as a virgin.</i> collects no fine but her <i>ketubah</i> is 200, the virgin after marriage collects a fine<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">If she still has not reached 12 years and 6 months of age. The argument of R. Yose is shown to be wrong.</i> but her <i>ketubah</i> is a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died immediately after the final marriage ceremony, the widow is still a virgin but in her next marriage she can claim only the widow’s mina for her <i>ketubah</i>, the same as a widow who is not a virgin. Therefore, for R. Eleazar there is no reason why she should marry on a Wednesday.</i>!
<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.3">Tosefta 1:3</a>; a slightly different wording in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113a" href="/Yevamot.113a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 113a</a>.</i>”A deaf-mute or an insane male who were taken in<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Married.</i> by a hearing woman. Even if the deaf-mute became hearing, or the insane sane, she has no <i>ketubah.</i> If he wants to keep her, her <i>ketubah</i> is one mina<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Even if at the start she was a virgin, now, at the moment her husband is legally able to contract a marriage, she is no virgin.</i>.” Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Only if he slept with her after he became hearing or sane. If he did not sleep with her after he became hearing or sane, she does not even have a <i>ketubah</i> of a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Since there never was a legal marriage.</i>.
At less than three years and one day of age<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">This explains the statement of the Mishnah that girls violated less than three years of age are still virgins.</i>, Rebbi Yose in the name of [Rav] Ḥiyya bar Ashi, Rebbi Jonah, Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: What is this like? One makes a dimple in the flesh which straightens out by itself. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: Like one who muddies a source which becomes clear again. Rebbi Yose said, a Mishnah says so<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Niddah</i> 5:4</i>: Younger than that, it is as if one puts a finger on an eye. <sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 6:8:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.6.8.15"><i>Nedarim</i> 6:13, Notes 138-141</a>. Variant readings: ונמלכין ׀ נמלכו, אין הבתולין ׀ אינן, הבתולין ׀ בתולין.</i> Rebbi Abun said: “I am calling to Almighty God, to the God who decides with me.” If a girl is three years and one day old, if the Court decided to lengthen, her hymen repairs itself, otherwise her hymen does not repair itself.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If an adult male had sexual relations with an underage girl<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Too young to marry.</i>, or an underage boy<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Too young to marry.</i> with an adult female, or one injured by wood<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Her hymen was split by an accident.</i>, their <i>ketubot</i> are 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<i>,</i> the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, the <i>ketubah</i> of one injured by wood is a mina.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If an adult male had sexual relations with an underage girl,” etc. What is an underage boy and what is an underage girl? They said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Ḥagra, an underage boy is younger than nine years and one day<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The sex act of a boy of 9 years and one day has legal consequences; cf. <i>Yebamot,</i> Mishnaiot 10:15–18; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.10.2">Chapter 3, Note 143</a>. The sex act of a younger boy has no legal consequences.</i>, an underage girl is younger than three years and one day<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">This explains the statement of the Mishnah that girls violated less than three years of age are still virgins.</i>. One understands that if an adult male had sexual relations with an underage girl, her hymen repairs itself. If an underage boy has sexual relations with an underage female, her hymen repairs itself. But if an underage boy has sexual relations with an adult female, her hymen does not repair itself!<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">How can she marry as a virgin?</i> Rebbi Abin, explain it that he had relations with her without penetration<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">There was no penetration.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abin said, you can even say that he had normal relations with her. The relations of an underage boy are relations but he does not have the force to damage her hymen<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">This is a matter of dispute in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 11b" href="/Ketubot.11b">Babli, 11b</a>.</i>. It was stated thus: It happened that [an adult] became pregnant while her hymen was intact<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 14b-15a" href="/Chagigah.14b-15a">Babli, <i>Ḥagigah</i> 14b/15a</a>, holds that an intact virgin might become pregnant in a bathtub from semen floating there.</i>.
They objected to Rebbi Meïr: There is no hymen<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to the virgin whose hymen was ruptured in a mechanical accident.</i> and you say, her <i>ketubah</i> is 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<i>?</i> He answered them, is that dependent on the hymen? But the adult has no hymen<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Once she is older than 12½ years, her body is so soft that the rupture of the hymen may not be noticed. The court will not hear such a case.</i> and her <i>ketubah</i> is 200! the virgin widow has a hymen and her <i>ketubah</i> is a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>, about a girl whose husband dies in the <i>ḥuppah</i> after the recitation of the wedding benedictions.</i>! What is the reason? The adult still has all her grace<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The groom is willing to pay for a woman who never was with another male.</i>; the virgin widow has lost her grace. Where do they disagree? If she was injured by wood. Rebbi Meïr says, she did not lose her grace, but the rabbis say, she lost her grace.
Did they disagree that a virgin who had sexual relations with an underage boy<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">This is a problem only for R. Eleazar who holds (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.4"><i>Yebamot</i> 6:5, Note 108</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.1">7:5, Note 105</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.1.4">13:1, Note 14</a>) that sexual relations between unmarried partners are always harlotry which bars the female from marrying a priest. For all other authorities, there would only be a problem regarding the High Priest who may marry only a virgin.</i> or with someone who is not a man<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Sexual relations of a woman with an animal is a capital crime if initiated by the woman. But it has no influence on her marital status.</i> is enabled for the priesthood? Rebbi Ḥalaphta ben Shaul said, she is enabled even for the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59b" href="/Yevamot.59b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 59b</a>, this is an Amoraic statement by Samuel.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah and Rebbi Ammi asked<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The text is impossible as it stands. It must have been either “R. Jeremiah (fourth generation) said that R. Immi (second generation) asked” or “R. Yasa and R. Immi asked”. The sequel would support both versions.</i>: What is the difference between her<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">The woman whose hymen was impaired by a mechanical accident, who is declared eligible to marry a High Priest.</i> and one who had sex with a finger<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Either she or another person perforated her hymen with his finger in sexual activity without penetration by a penis.</i>? Is the one who had sex with a finger not disabled for priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">The high priesthood. Only the High Priest is required to marry a virgin.</i>? Rebbi Haggai said, explain it that there was no penetration<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">If the girl had sexual experience without any penetration, she will qualify for a virgin’s <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. Rebbi Haggai wanted to change his mind; Rebbi Abba said to him, do not change your mind. Why did Rebbi Haggai want to change his mind? Because of the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:13" href="/Leviticus.21.13"><i>Lev</i>. 21:13</a>, speaking of the high priest. The complicated expression אִשָּׁהבִבְתוּלֶיהָ “a woman in her virginities” instead of simpy בְּתוּלָה “a virgin” calls for an explanation.</i>: “But he shall marry a wife in her virginities,” only if she is a virgin in both respects<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">She must be a virgin without any sexual experience; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59a" href="/Yevamot.59a">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 59a</a>.</i>. Similarly, “a virgin and no man had known her.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 24:16" href="/Genesis.24.16"><i>Gen</i>. 24:16</a>; here again the double expression calls for an explanation. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 60:5" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.60.5"><i>Gen</i>.<i>rabba</i> 60(5</a>), the explanation is ascribed to R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>” A virgin, with respect to penetration. No man had known her, without penetration. Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar said, [no man] ever had wanted to touch her hand, for it was said<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 125:3" href="/Psalms.125.3"><i>Ps</i>. 125:3</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 60:5" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.60.5"><i>Gen</i>.<i>rabba</i> 60(5</a>), this explanation is ascribed to R. Joḥanan.</i>: “The staff of evil shall not rest on the just’s lot.” Why did Rebbi Haggai want to change his mind? He could explain it by “touching”. Why does (Rav Yosef) [Rebbi Yasa]<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Since the author here cannot be the fourth generation Babylonian Rav Joseph (bar Ḥiyya), most likely he is Rebbi Yasa (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:3:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.3.5">Note 163</a>).</i> not explain it by “touching”? Rebbi Mana said, because it presented a problem for him: Rebbi Yasa asked: What is the legal status of “touching”<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">The touching of the genitals of two persons, whether there was penetration or emission or not. “Touching” is the legal definition of the sex act both for marriage (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.3"><i>Yebamot</i>4:2, Note 59</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>) and for criminal law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 2:4" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.2.4">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 2:4</a>; cf. <i>Soṭah</i> 1:2, Notes 97,98). The same question is asked in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.2-33"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a> (59c 1. 14).</i> with a male? “Touching” with an animal?
