When Rebbi Jeremiah heard that of Rebbi Haggai, he said, that was not Rebbi Ammi’s problem<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">That solution is too obvious not to have occured to R. Ammi, and it does not address his question which asks for the difference between a hymen split by mechanical means or by the girl’s own finger. In both cases, no male was involved.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 2, Notes 108–111</a>.</i> For virgins who after a final marriage become widows, divorcees, or who received <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>, about a girl whose husband dies in the <i>ḥuppah</i> after the recitation of the wedding benedictions.</i>, their <i>ketubah</i> is a mina and they are not subject to a claim of non-virginity. For a proselyte, a prisoner, and a slave who were redeemed, converted, or freed at more than three years and one day of age, their <i>ketubah</i> is a mina and they are not subject to a claim of non-virginity.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A virgin, a widow, a divorcee after final marriage,” etc. Who is a virgin after marriage? Rebbi Joḥanan said, any who entered the bridal chamber but her witnesses testify that she had no sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">A different formulation of the same fact is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.4">Tosephta, 1:4</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 11b" href="/Ketubot.11b">Babli, 11b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, this implies that if a man married a woman under the presumption<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ḥazaqah</i> “holding fast” is the presumption that a known <i>status quo ante</i> remains unchanged until a change in status has been observed. In the case here, the groom had the right to assume that his bride was still the virgin she had been at birth. If before the marriage he required special assurances that the bride was a virgin, that is not a case of presumption, and if she was not virginal he can claim acquisition in error and annulment of marriage and forfait of <i>ketubah</i>.</i> that she was a virgin and she turned out not to be a virgin, that is not an erroneous acquisition to deprive her of the <i>ketubah</i> of a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of the Mishnah there was a presumption of virginity but only a <i>ketubah</i> of one mina; this shows that the presumption does not exclude that the bride was not a virgin. In the Babli, 11b (13a), a statement of Rav Sheshet; this might imply that “R. Yose” here is R. Yasa.</i>. If a man married a woman under the presumption that she never had illegitimate sex and she turned out that she had illegitimate sex, that is not an erroneous acquisition to deprive her of the <i>ketubah</i> of a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">This is essentially the previous case since, if there are witnesses that the husband had not slept with her, any defect could have come only from illegitimate sexual activity.</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar asked, what about a male who sleeps with a manumitted slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that this is a rhetorical question since the <i>ketubah</i> of the freedwoman is determined in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnaiot 1:2</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.4.1">4</a> and her right to the fine imposed on the rapist or the seducer in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:1:2-19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.1.2-19">3:1</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.2.2">2</a>. R. David Fraenckel emends מהו to מניין and reads the question as asking for the biblical source of the Mishnaiot mentioned.</i>? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:1:2-19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.1.2-19">Halakhah 3:1</a>.</i>: I could think that a male who sleeps with a Gentile slave has to pay<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The fine imposed on a person raping or seducing an underage girl, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.2">Note 117</a>.</i>; the verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:15" href="/Exodus.22.15"><i>Ex</i>. 22:15</a>.</i>: “He shall take her as wife by the bride price.” If he can marry her. This excludes the [gentile] slave (or any)<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Reading ארמית for מי או of the text.</i> whom he cannot marry. Only because he cannot marry her! Therefore, if he can marry her<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">If she is freed and can contract a marriage.</i>, she collects the fine, and any who collects the fine has a <i>ketubah</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.2-7">Halakhah 1:2</a>.</i> Rebbi Yudan said, does that depend on a fine? Look, the adult<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Who marries as a virgin.</i> collects no fine but her <i>ketubah</i> is 200, the virgin after marriage collects a fine<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">If she still has not reached 12 years and 6 months of age. The argument of R. Yose is shown to be wrong.</i> but her <i>ketubah</i> is a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died immediately after the final marriage ceremony, the widow is still a virgin but in her next marriage she can claim only the widow’s mina for her <i>ketubah</i>, the same as a widow who is not a virgin. Therefore, for R. Eleazar there is no reason why she should marry on a Wednesday.</i>! Rebbi Ze‘ira said before Rebbi Mana, explain it if she was converted or freed before she reached three years and one day. He said to him, any woman who was converted or manumitted before she reached three years and one day is like an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnaiot 1:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.3.1">3</a>:1 state clearly that in matters of marriage, girls becoming Jewish at a very young age are equal to those born Jewish [except for marriages with priests where practice follows <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 44:22" href="/Ezekiel.44.22"><i>Ez</i>. 44:22</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.2-3"><i>Bikkurim</i>1:5 (Notes 89–99</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 60b" href="/Yevamot.60b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 60b</a>.]</i>.
The blind woman and the she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">A woman without secondary female sex characteristics, presumed to be infertile; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:1, Note 65</a>.</i> are subject to claims of missing virginity. Symmachos said in the name of Rebbi Meïr that the blind woman is not subject to claims of missing virginity. What is Rebbi Meïr’s reason? I say, he found [her to be a virgin] and destroyed [the evidence]<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Since the blind woman cannot see what her husband does, she cannot see to it that the traces of her hymeneal blood are not destroyed, leaving her without defenses in court. R. Meïr assumes that she prefers to have an untouchable mina as <i>ketubah</i> over having 200 <i>zuz</i> with a chance of being deprived of it by a cheating husband.</i>. What is the rabbi’s reason? She can catch him. What does Rebbi Meïr with this argument? He can cleanse it with spittle<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 36a" href="/Ketubot.36a">Babli, 36a</a>, connects the disagreement between R. Meïr and the rabbis to that of Rabban Gamliel and R. Joshua (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.8.1">Mishnaiot 1:8</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.9.1">9</a>) whether her unsupported statement is credible or not. The rabbis follow Rabban Gamliel, R. Meïr follows R. Joshua. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 3:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).3.5">Tosephta, 3:5</a>, knows only of the rabbis’ position.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">This is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:14:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.14.2"><i>Yebamot</i> 13:15, Notes 123–130</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 111b" href="/Yevamot.111b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 111b</a>. The variant readings from <i>Yebamot</i> are indicated by י.</i> It was stated: A claim of non-virginity may be brought within thirty days, the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, immediately. Where do we hold? If he copulated, immediately. If he did not copulate, even after a longer delay. But we must deal with the case that it was not spelled out. Rebbi Meïr said, it is credible that a man may hold himself back for thirty days. But the Sages say, a man does not hold himself back even for one day. Rebbi Jeremiah asked: According to Rebbi Meïr, would a man be believed to assert that he held himself back for thirty days in order to make the child of unknown paternity? Let us hear from the following: “If the sister-in-law claims within thirty days that she was not copulated with, one forces him to perform <i>ḥalîṢah</i> with her. After thirty days, one asks him to perform <i>ḥalîṢah</i> with her.” And Rebbi Eleazar said, this is Rebbi Meïr’s. And Rebbi Eleazar said, that refers only to her, but not to her co-wife. As you say there, she is not believed to damage her co-wife, so here, he is not believed to damage his son.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody eats at his father-in-law’s in Judea without chaperones cannot claim missing virginity since he is alone with her<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah makes clear, he is supposed to sleep with his fiancיe.</i>. Both for an Israel widow as a Cohanim widow<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of a Cohen, even if married to an Israel.</i> the <i>ketubah</i> is a mina. The court of priests collected 400 <i>zuz</i> for a virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether this applies to marriages of daughters of Cohanim, or marriages of Cohanim, or both. Since this is generally accepted practice known to the groom at the time he contracted the marriage, it is legal and can be enforced even if the original <i>ketubah</i> was lost.</i>, to which the Sages did not object.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody eats at his father-in-law’s,” etc. In earlier times<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">The only time when the Roman government could be supposed to act officially in the manner described was during Hadrian’s persecution in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba.</i> they decided on a persecution in Judea because they had a tradition from their forefathers that Jehudah had killed Esaw<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">“Esaw” is a code name for Rome; e. g., <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 5:7" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.5.7"><i>Eccl</i>.<i>rabba</i> to 5:7</a>. The story that Jehudah killed Esaw when the latter wanted to kill Jacob at Isaac’s funeral is in <i>Midraš Soḥer ṭob</i> 18:32, mentioned in <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 348, quoted in <i>Yalquṭ Šim‘ony</i> 162. In the tradition of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 13a" href="/Sotah.13a">Babli, <i>Soṭa</i> 13a</a>, Esaw was killed by Ḥushim ben Dan at Jacob’s funeral.</i>, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 49:8" href="/Genesis.49.8"><i>Gen</i>. 49:8</a>.</i>: “Your hand is on your enemies’ neck.” They went and enslaved them<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">After the war of Bar Kokhba, most of the Jewish population of Judea were sold as slaves.</i> and raped their daughters; they decided that a soldier<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Greek στρατιώτης. In the considerably toned down version of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3b" href="/Ketubot.3b">Babli, 3b</a>, it was only the general, ἡγεμών, who would exercise a <i>ius primae noctis</i> over girls married on Wednesdays.</i> would have sex with her first. They decreed that her husband should come to her when still in her father’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">After the preliminary marriage.</i>; for when she knows that her husband’s fear is on her she is drawn after him<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The commentaries and S. Lieberman emend נִגְרֶרֶת to נִגְדֶּרֶת “she is fenced in.” This emendation has to be rejected since it is understandable that one should want the girl to be drawn to her husband and not to the soldier with whom she otherwise would have her first sexual experience.</i>. But is she not in the end being used for sex by a soldier? She is raped, and a rape victim is permitted to her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Num</i>. 7, based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:13" href="/Numbers.5.13"><i>Num</i>. 5:13</a>.</i>. What did Cohanot do? They were hiding them. Why did they not also hide the daughters of Israel? That becomes talk<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">If everybody does it, it cannot be kept secret.</i> and the government hears it; then these and those will be taken together. What kind of a sign did they have? The talk of a cook<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Greek μάγειρος, ὁ, “cook, butcher”.</i> in town: There is a wedding meal, there is a wedding meal<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">While in biblical Hebrew מִשְׁתֶּה is any festive meal, in rabbinic Hebrew the term is used exclusively for wedding festivities. Since one could not speak of weddings during the persecution, one spoke of the cook.</i>; there is light in Beror-Ḥayil<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beror-Ḥayil</i> was the residence of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai after the first war with the Romans; it must have been in the imperial domain of Jabneh, in the plain. Lights were lit to indicate an invitation to attend a forbidden circumcision, just as the presence of a professional cook indicated a wedding.</i>: a week for a son, a week for a son. When the persecution ended, the custom did not end. Rebbi Hoshaia’s<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">He taught in Galilee 100 years after the Hadrianic persecution. His family was from Judea, where his father still lived (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Niddah 3:3:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Niddah.3.3.2-6"><i>Niddah</i> 3:3</a>, 50 c 1. 71).</i> daughter-in-law was pregnant when she married definitively.
It was stated: “And for a widow 200.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">The court of Cohanim collected 200 <i>zuz</i> for a widow, against the explicit testimony of the Mishnah. In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 12" href="/Ketubot.12">Babli, 12a/b</a>, the priestly families tried to enforce this for their daughters but were forced to retract since nobody would take a widow for 200 <i>zuz</i> when he could get a virgin for the same price. The Babli also gives to non-priestly noble families the right to establish the higher tariff as default option for their daughters; the Yerushalmi considers this part of the Mishnah obsolete.</i>” It was stated: “This order applies both to a widow of an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of a Cohen, widow of an Israel.</i> and a widow of a Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of an Israel, widow of a Cohen.</i>”. Rebbi Yose said, it is reasonable that the daughter of a Cohen should collect, for her tribe collects. The daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen should not collect; is it not sufficient that she rose to the priesthood that you say, she should collect? Rebbi Mana said, it is reasonable the other way. The daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen should collect for she rose to the priesthood; the daughter of a Cohen should not collect for she stepped down from the priesthood. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, in both cases they demanded a fine so that everybody should cling to his tribe and family.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Somebody married a woman and found that she was no virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The fact is not in dispute.</i>. She says, I was raped after you had married me preliminarily, so your field was flooded<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.9">Note 58</a>.</i>. He says not so, but it happened before I married you preliminarily; therefore, my acquisition was made in error. Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer say, she is believed<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">If neither of them has any corroborating evidence, her claim that she <i>certainly</i> was raped later is stronger than his assertion that <i>maybe</i> she was raped or had consensual sex earlier. If the husband wants to deny her claim, he has to provide evidence.</i>. Rebbi Joshua said, we do not live off her mouth but there is a presumption that she had sexual relations before she was preliminarily married unless she provides proof of her statement<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Since she claims a <i>ketubah</i> and he does not want to pay at all, she claims money and a claimant in a civil suit carries the burden of proof.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Somebody married a woman and found that she was no virgin”, etc. Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Does this mean that a claim of missing virginity is impossible following Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">If the court automatically has to side with the woman, how could the husband hope to be heard?</i>, only following Rebbi Joshua? He turned around and said, a claim of missing virginity is possible following Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer, if she remains silent. And even if you say that she talks, if she said that he found her a virgin and destroyed the evidence. Why should she not be believed<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">If she claims to have been a virgin at the time of the final marriage ceremony.</i>? One cannot tolerate it, since Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, if he found the door open, he is forbidden to keep her because she might have been unfaithful<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here סוֹטָה means “unfaithful, deviant” in a general sense, not in the technical sense discussed in Tractate <i>Soṭah</i>. R. Eleazar holds that the Mishnah does not only give the husband the right to complain about lack of virginity but obligates him to go to court to annul his marriage since nobody can stay married to an adulterous wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>) and he presumes his bride was deflowered after she was preliminarily married to him, up to a year earlier. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 8b-9a" href="/Ketubot.8b-9a">Babli, 8b/9a</a>, the same argument is quoted in his name.</i>. Here you say, she is believed. There, you say that she is not believed. In this case, both agree that the door was open<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of the Mishnah here, the facts are not in dispute, only their explanation is. It is possible to prefer an explanation presented as certain over a presumed argument. But if she denies not being a virgin, he has to assume that she is forbidden to him and, because he <i>thinks</i> her to be guilty, has to divorce her irrespective of the real facts behind the case.</i>.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.1">Mishnah 7:8</a>. The groom says that he never would have agreed to the marriage had he known that the bride had a bodily defect; his preliminary marriage was arranged under false pretenses; he wants to withdraw without paying. The father asserts that at the time of the preliminary marriage the bride was without defects, and that “the groom’s field was flooded”. If the disagreement surfaces before the final marriage, the burden of proof is on the father; after that, the burden of proof is on the husband.</i>: “If she had bodily defects while still in her father’s house, the father has to bring proof.” Rebbi Eleazar asked Rebbi Joḥanan: Is this Mishnah from Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer? Not from Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Joshua puts the burden of proof on the wife in the Mishnah here; why is there no disagreement recorded there?</i>? He said to him, those are everybody’s words. There is a difference because bodily defects have a way to appear<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">For problems that have to be expected, the person in control of the place where they happened is responsible. In Halakhah 7:8, it is stated that in the matter of very frequent defects, the husband can complain if at the start he had stipulated that the bride be free from even the most minute impairment.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, formerly we saw rabbis who compared bodily defects to [defects of] virginity. These can be inferred from those and those can be inferred from these<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Claims for annulment of the marriage because of bodily defects of the bride and because of missing virginity follow identical rules.</i>. Bodily defects from claims of missing virginity: For if he slept with her in her father’s house, the father has to provide proof<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">It really is the other way around; in this case the rule about a complaint about virginity is derived from that about defects. If the final marriage ceremony is held at the father’s house, then in case of a blemish the burden of proof would have to be on the father; therefore, for the claim of missing virginity the father has to bring proof that his daughter either was a virgin at the moment of final marriage or lost her virginity in a manner which did not impair the validity of the marriage.</i>. Claims of missing virginity from bodily defects<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Again, this should be inverted: Rules for claims about blemishes derived from rules of complaints about virginity.</i>: For if she developed bodily defects and there is a doubt whether it happened after she entered his domain or before she entered his domain, the husband has to provide proof, from claims of missing virginity. But if she lost her virginity, was it not in her father’s house? Nevertheless, you say, the husband has to provide proof<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">This follows only Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer; it is the only indication that practice should follow Rabban Gamliel (and not R. Joshua against R. Eliezer); this is stated explicitly in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 12b" href="/Ketubot.12b">Babli (12b</a>). In the Mishnah here it is agreed that the loss of virginity occured in her father’s house. But since the argument developed after the final marriage in the husband’s house, the burden of proof is on the husband.</i>; so here also, the husband has to provide proof.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> She says<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah is a continuation of the previous one; there is no doubt but that the bride was not an intact virgin.</i>, I was injured by wood, but he says not so, you were trampled on by a man; Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer say, she is believed<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">If neither of them has any corroborating evidence, her claim that she <i>certainly</i> was raped later is stronger than his assertion that <i>maybe</i> she was raped or had consensual sex earlier. If the husband wants to deny her claim, he has to provide evidence.</i>. Rebbi Joshua said, we do not live off her mouth but there is a presumption that she was trampled on by a man unless she provides proof of her statement<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Since she claims a <i>ketubah</i> and he does not want to pay at all, she claims money and a claimant in a civil suit carries the burden of proof.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “She says, I was injured by wood,” etc. Rebbi Eleazar said, that follows Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr said the <i>ketubah</i> of one injured by wood is 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13a" href="/Ketubot.13a">Babli, 13a</a>, R. Eleazar is reported that she claims 100 <i>zuz</i> as <i>ketubah</i> but he does not want to give anything. This is the position articulated by R. Huna here. R. Joḥanan holds that she claims 200 but he wants to give only 100.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, we would think to say, when did Rebbi Meïr disagree with those rabbis? If he took her in assuming she was injured by wood. But if he took her in assuming she was a virgin and it turned out she was injured by wood, then even Rebbi Meïr agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband was not informed of the facts when he signed the <i>ketubah</i>, R. Meïr agrees that he can sue to annul the contract.</i>, since we have stated: “She says, I was injured by wood, but he says not so, you were trampled on by a man.” That means, there is a disagreement even if he took her in assuming she was injured by wood<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">There is agreement among all commentators that this should read: “if he took her in assuming she was a virgin.” But if that were true, R. Jeremiah would say the same as R. Yose. In addition, we know that there is a difference of opinion between R. Meïr and the rabbis about the <i>ketubah</i> of one who claims to have been injured by wood.</i> and she turned out to have been injured by wood. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira did not say so, but: She says, I was injured by wood and my <i>ketubah</i> is 200 [<i>zuz</i>]. He says, it is not so, but you were trampled on by a man and you have no claim on me. What are we talking about? If he married her as a virgin and she turns out to have been injured by wood, Rebbi Meïr will agree<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband was not informed of the facts when he signed the <i>ketubah</i>, R. Meïr agrees that he can sue to annul the contract.</i>. If he married her as one injured by wood and she turns out to have been injured by wood, is there a recognizable difference in the opening of the door between wood or man<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">In that case, the position of Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer is preferable since she holds the contract in her hands and the burden of proof is on the party contesting a written contract (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 9:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.9.6.2-5"><i>Baba batra</i> 9:8</a>, 17a 1.56).</i>? Rebbi Huna in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira did not say so, but: She says, I was injured by wood and so I stipulated with you, but he says, it is not so, but you were trampled on by a man and there was no stipulation between you and me<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13a" href="/Ketubot.13a">Babli, 13a</a>, R. Eleazar is reported that she claims 100 <i>zuz</i> as <i>ketubah</i> but he does not want to give anything. This is the position articulated by R. Huna here. R. Joḥanan holds that she claims 200 but he wants to give only 100.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she was seen speaking<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">An unmarried woman was seen having an affair with an unknown person.</i> to a man and one asked her, what kind of man is this? He is Mr. X, a Cohen; Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer say, she is believed<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">A single person engaging in sexual activity with a man whom she could marry is still permitted to marry a Cohen.</i>. Rebbi Joshua said, we do not live off her mouth but there is a presumption that she was lying with a Gibeonite and a bastard unless she provides proof of her statement<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Bastards (children of adultery or incest punishable by death by the court or Heaven) are forbidden to marry into the congregation by biblical decree (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.5"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:1, Note 29</a>) and Gibeonites by tradition (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4, Note 72</a>). Therefore, a woman sleeping with such a man is a זוָנָה and forbidden to marry a Cohen (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 6:5, Note 100</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she was seen speaking to a man,” etc. What is “speaking”? She had sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13a" href="/Ketubot.13a">Babli, 13a</a>, this is the opinion of Rav Assi. His (Babylonian) contemporary Ze‘iri explains that R. Joshua already disqualifies her from marrying into the priesthood if she had a rendez-vous with an unidentified person.</i>. Why did we state “speaking”? An expression for the knowing; Rebbi says, of purity.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joshia: Practice follows Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer since two form a majority against one<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Joshua is a higher authority than either Rabban Gamliel or R. Eliezer, the formulation of the Mishnah as a vote of 2 against 1 is to be read as endorsing the majority opinion.</i>. Rebbi Yose asked: If it is practice, why two? And if two, why practice<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">“Practice” usually means “prior practice”, going back for generations. In that case, the formulation of the Mishnah invites scrutiny whether it really supports a decision. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 14a" href="/Ketubot.14a">Babli, 14a</a>, the situation is resolved by the ruling that “practice follows Rabban Gamliel but one should act only if most people around that woman are qualified”, see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:8:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.8.3">Note 239</a>.</i>? Would that mean if Rebbi Joḥanan would hold with Rebbi Joshua that practice would not follow Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer but Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">If the decision in the Mishnah is problematic a leading Amora, whose opinion would count for nothing against an anonymous Mishnah, could lend his weight to the opposite opinion.</i>? What about it? It is a testimony for which a woman in empowered<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">In general, women can testify in court for matters of fact but not in law. But for the personal status of women, the testimony of women is accepted as it is from qualified men (<i>Yebamot</i> Chapter 15). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13b" href="/Ketubot.13b">Babli concurs, 13b</a>.</i>. They wanted to say, when does Rebbi Joshua disagree with these rabbis? At a place where most are disabling, but at a place where most are qualified, even Rebbi Joshua will agree<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">We have a principle that “it may be assumed <i>prima facie</i> that anybody who comes from a group belongs to the majority in that group” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli, 15a</a>). In a town where most inhabitants are Gentile, or otherwise disqualified from marrying Jewish women, one would assume that the unidentified man sleeping with that woman was disqualified (siding with R. Joshua), but in a town where she could legally marry most of the men, he would be qualified (siding with Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer).</i>. There came Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: There is disagreement even at a place where most are qualified. Does Rebbi Joshua think that immorality runs after the disabling<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">If only the disqualified engage in extramarital sex, the unidentified man does not come from the large group of city dwellers, most of whom are qualified, but from the small group of whorers, most of whom are disqualified. Then R. Joshua would be consistent and should be followed.</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, a <i>baraita</i> stated that even qualified people whore, as it was stated: Even the most pious man cannot be appointed guardian for illicit sex<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">The formulation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13b" href="/Ketubot.13b">Babli (13b</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.6">Tosephta (1:6</a>) is: “There does not exist a guardian against illicit sex.” In Babli and Tosephta this belongs to R. Joshua’s argument. For Greek ἐπίτροπος “guardian, administrator”, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.2-4"><i>Bikkurim</i> 1:5</a>, N. 82.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she was pregnant and one asked her, what kind of fetus is this? He is from Mr. X, a Cohen; Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer say, she is believed. Rebbi Joshua said, we do not live off her mouth but there is a presumption that she is pregnant from a Gibeonite or a bastard unless she provides proof of her statement.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she was pregnant,” etc. Rebbi Eleazar said, everybody agrees that the child is of unknown paternity<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 4:1</a>, the child of unknown paternity is barred from intermarrying with qualified Jews and is permitted only marriage with proselytes, freedmen, bastards, Gibeonites, those of unknown paternity, and foundlings.</i>. It was stated thus<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.6">Tosephta 1:6</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13b" href="/Ketubot.13b">Babli 13b</a>.</i>: “Where was this said<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">That the woman’s testimony is accepted without corroboration.</i>, for the testimony of the woman in her own behalf. But everybody agrees that the child is of unknown paternity.” Rebbi Joḥanan said to him, simply of unknown paternity<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Since the father is unknown, the child cannot inherit from him. The expression שְׁתוּקִי “silenced one” can be explained as “one silences him if he claims inheritance”.</i>! We find that a child of unknown paternity can be High Priest. How is this possible? A group of Cohanim was passing by, one of them came<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">He was not identified by name but certainly was a Cohen.</i> and had sexual relations; it turns out that the child of unknown paternity can be High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13b" href="/Ketubot.13b">Babli, 13b</a>, agrees that the child is qualified to marry in the congregation but denies that he is a Cohen, based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:13" href="/Numbers.25.13"><i>Num</i>. 25:13</a>: “A covenant of priesthood it shall be for him and his seed after him”, from which it is inferred that only a Cohen’s child which is recognized as his is a Cohen. In the case under discussion, the child “is silenced from claiming priesthood”.</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar said to him: Is not the dough widow<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">As a dough is a mixture of several ingredients, so the dough widow is a mixture; she is a woman qualified for priesthood who was married to a husband with a questionable family background (one whose females are permitted to marry Israels but not Cohanim). The problem is that there is the knowledge that something was wrong in the marriages of that family but the exact nature of the defect is not known.</i> qualified but her daughter is disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">She carries the possible disabilities of the father’s family.</i>? He said to him, whoever declares her to be qualified, declares her daughter to be qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">If the daughter might be disqualified then the mother might be desecrated, i. e., her husband might have been the offspring many generations back of a union forbidden to Cohanim.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, did he not say “whoever declares her to be qualified”? This implies that there is another who disqualifies! Who declares qualified? Rebbi Meïr. Who disqualifies? The rabbis. As we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kiddushin (Lieberman) 5:2" href="/Tosefta_Kiddushin_(Lieberman).5.2">Tosephta (<i>Qiddušin</i> 5:2</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 14a" href="/Ketubot.14a">Babli (14a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.4.2-3"><i>Qiddušin</i> 4:4</a>, 66a 1.29), there is no mention of the desecrated, but there is the added category of “king’s slaves”, who were used by the king to run the state and, by their influence and riches, were able to marry Jewish women even if not manumitted. In Jewish tradition (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Ketubot 14a" href="/Rashi_on_Ketubot.14a">Rashi 14a</a>), Herod was a slave of the Hasmoneans.<br>In the Babli tradition (cf. <i>Otzar haGeonim</i> 8, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 12" href="/Ketubot.12"><i>Ketubot</i>, הפירושים p. 12</a>), the dough widow was a woman who had married a man possibly descending from a desecrated woman. This definition is reproduced by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Ketubot 14a" href="/Rashi_on_Ketubot.14a">Rashi, 14a</a>. The difference between the Galilean and Babylonian traditions was already highlighted by Rabbenu Hananel (<i>Otzar ha-Geonim l</i>. c., לקוטי פירוש רבינו חננאל p. 12).</i>: What is qualified dough, anyone about whom there is [no suspicion of descent from] a desecrated, a bastard, or a Gibeonite. Rebbi Meïr says, the daughter of any woman not tainted with one of these is qualified for thepriesthood. But about a family in which a disability had disappeared<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">The nature of the disability was no longer known.</i>, Rebbi Meïr says he checks up to four mothers<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">These are really 8 mothers, spanning 3 to 4 generations, enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.4.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 4:4</a>.</i> and marries, but the Sages say, he checks forever<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Until he finds the source of the trouble.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira had a different version: Rebbi Eleazar asked Rebbi Joḥanan, what is the rule about a dough widow<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">As a dough is a mixture of several ingredients, so the dough widow is a mixture; she is a woman qualified for priesthood who was married to a husband with a questionable family background (one whose females are permitted to marry Israels but not Cohanim). The problem is that there is the knowledge that something was wrong in the marriages of that family but the exact nature of the defect is not known.</i>? He said to him, she is qualified. What about her daughter? He said to him, the one who declares her to be qualified, declares her daughter to be qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">If the daughter might be disqualified then the mother might be desecrated, i. e., her husband might have been the offspring many generations back of a union forbidden to Cohanim.</i>. They wanted to say, according to Rebbi Eleazar, a child of unknown paternity is disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 4:1</a>, the child of unknown paternity is barred from intermarrying with qualified Jews and is permitted only marriage with proselytes, freedmen, bastards, Gibeonites, those of unknown paternity, and foundlings.</i>; according to Rebbi Joḥanan, a child of unknown paternity is qualified. Rebbi Joḥanan also holds that in some cases a child of unknown paternity is disqualified; he answered [Rebbi Eleazar] following the latter’s reasoning: Since you reason that the child is simply of unknown paternity, we find that a child of unknown paternity can be High Priest! How is this possible? A group of Cohanim was passing by, one of them came<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">He was not identified by name but certainly was a Cohen.</i> and had sexual relations; it turns out that the child of unknown paternity can be High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 13b" href="/Ketubot.13b">Babli, 13b</a>, agrees that the child is qualified to marry in the congregation but denies that he is a Cohen, based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:13" href="/Numbers.25.13"><i>Num</i>. 25:13</a>: “A covenant of priesthood it shall be for him and his seed after him”, from which it is inferred that only a Cohen’s child which is recognized as his is a Cohen. In the case under discussion, the child “is silenced from claiming priesthood”.</i>.
The word of Rebbi Zera<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Babylonian spelling of Ze‘ira.</i> implies that a child of unknown paternity is qualified, for Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that R. Ze‘ira asked before his teacher R. Yasa, not before his student’s student R. Yose.</i>: Is it the same for families<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah, Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer declare than one believes the woman if she says that her child is a Cohen’s. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i>4:1</a> excludes a child of unknown paternity from marrying most Jews. What is the relation of the two Mishnaiot?</i>? He said to him, so says Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: There, for families<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody looks after the purity of his blood line, he should follow the Mishnah in <i>Qiddušin</i>.</i>, but here for sanctified food in the country<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">“Sanctified food in the country” is heave. The child is empowered to eat heave; this implies that he is qualified for certain aspects of the priesthood (on the model of the local priests in Josiah’s reform, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 23:9" href="/II_Kings.23.9"><i>2K</i>. 23:9</a>).</i>. The word of Rebbi Samuel ben [Rav] Isaac implies that a child of unknown paternity is disqualified, for Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac asked: Does this mean that a child of unknown paternity is does not exist following Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer, only following Rebbi Joshua? He turned around and said, a child of unknown paternity is possible following Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer, if she remains silent. And even if you say that she talks, if she said that she does not know<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">If the mother states that she does not know the identity of the child’s father, the child doubtless is of unknown paternity.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Yose said: It happened that, when a girl was raped while she went to draw water from the spring, Rebbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: If most people of the town can marry into the priesthood then she can marry into the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">He confirms the principle explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:8:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.8.3">Note 239</a>, that without proof to the contrary one may assume that an unidentified member of a group belongs to the majority in that group. Therefore, the girl was raped by a man whom she could have married without detriment to her status; the rape does not diminish her status.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Yose said: It happened,” etc. Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: That happened at the source<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κρήνη “well, source” (in the Hebrew transliteration, read י for ו.) The translator of the LXX books of Kings uses the word for בְּרֵיכָה “pond”.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 14b-15a" href="/Ketubot.14b-15a">Babli, 14b/15a</a>, the statement is used in an argument that R. Joshua will agree with R. Yose only in this case when the rape happened at a place where not only the inhabitants of the city but all travelers congregate and it was known that at that point in time only qualified people travelled there. One cannot read the Babli’s interpretation into the Yerushalmi text.</i> of Sepphoris.
Both Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Ḥama bar Uqba, say in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Rebbi Joshua agrees in the case of the rape victim<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli, 15a</a>, disagrees and holds that R. Yose speaks of a very special case, that the rape occured on a market day when many קְרָנוֹת, carriages, came to Sepphoris and it was ascertained that both the majority of inhabitants of Sepphoris and the majority of foreign traders there were acceptable to marry into the priesthood, implying that R. Joshua agrees that no special proof is needed only in case (a) there are two groups and the majority of both is acceptable and (2) the woman was a victim, not a willing partner.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Rebbi Joshua agrees in the case of the rape victim. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Yose who said in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Yasa: How does one act in a practical case? He said to him, following Rebbi Yose who spoke in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri.
Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Yannai: He cohabited with her inside of Sepphoris<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">The scene described by the Babli (Note 263) is rejected; it is purely the question of the people of the place.</i>. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Yannai: If he was seen coming out of Sepphoris and he cohabited, the presumption is that he disqualifies since he cohabited there<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">This is based on a statement attributed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli (15a</a>) to R. Ze‘ira: Everything fixed in its place is judged as 50/50. Since the population of the town has fixed residences, if a person was seen coming from one of the houses, he cannot be considered to be from the qualified majority but one considers it only a 50% chance that he be qualified. In this case, R. Joḥanan ben Nuri will agree that the rape victim cannot marry a Cohen.</i>. What about a thoroughfare<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πλατεῖα, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:1:21" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.1.21"><i>Berakhot</i> 5:1, Note 56</a>. The thoroughfare is government property even in the town.</i>? Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">This must be “Rav”. He is the early Amora Rav Jeremiah bar Abba, presenting a tradition of R. Yose the Tanna. He might be one of the editors of R. Yose’s <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i>; cf. the author’s Introduction (pp. x–xi) to hisedition of <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i> (Northvale 1998).</i> Jeremiah bar Abba, Rebbi Yose says: By a majority. The force of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">This must be “Rav”. He is the early Amora Rav Jeremiah bar Abba, presenting a tradition of R. Yose the Tanna. He might be one of the editors of R. Yose’s <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i>; cf. the author’s Introduction (pp. x–xi) to hisedition of <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i> (Northvale 1998).</i> Jeremiah comes from the following which Rebbi Ḥiyya had said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If a wall fell in a dead-end street populated by Gentiles, but where one Jew lived, one digs there<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">On the Sabbath, because for saving a life one violates all prohibitions of the Torah (except murder, incest and adultery, and idolatry).</i> because of the Jew; but in a thoroughfare one follows the majority<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">One searches for victims only if the majority of the users are Jewish or at least known not to be idolators.</i>. And what is the interpretation of what Rebbi Abba said in the name of Rebbi Yannai, if he was seen coming out of Sepphoris and he cohabited, the presumption is that he is disqualified since he cohabited there? In the opinion of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">This must be “Rav”. He is the early Amora Rav Jeremiah bar Abba, presenting a tradition of R. Yose the Tanna. He might be one of the editors of R. Yose’s <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i>; cf. the author’s Introduction (pp. x–xi) to hisedition of <i>Seder</i> ‘<i>Olam</i> (Northvale 1998).</i> Jeremiah, if one saw him coming out of a house<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">This is based on a statement attributed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli (15a</a>) to R. Ze‘ira: Everything fixed in its place is judged as 50/50. Since the population of the town has fixed residences, if a person was seen coming from one of the houses, he cannot be considered to be from the qualified majority but one considers it only a 50% chance that he be qualified. In this case, R. Joḥanan ben Nuri will agree that the rape victim cannot marry a Cohen.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Yose, even in a thoroughfare<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Since the thoroughfare is a Roman military road, it may be assumed that the majority of users are not qualified to marry Cohanim.</i>. If Sepphoris was locked<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">If the rape happened in the night, when the gates of Sepphoris are locked, by the argument of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:10:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.10.4">Note 265</a> there is no majority of qualified people and the rapist would have to be identified in order to permit his victim to marry into the priesthood.</i>. Rebbi Yose says, until there is proof. But here<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah.</i>, Rebbi Yose says, by a majority! The force of Rebbi Yose comes from the following, which Rebbi Ze‘ira had said: <sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">The following sentences are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 3:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.3.4.2"><i>Demay</i> 3:4, Notes 93–96</a>; the variant readings are noted <b>ד</b>. The problem is that a person who is careful about the laws of tithing brings his grain to a mill that also serves the ‘<i>am haäreṢ</i>, the person who can be presumed to have given heave but not tithes from his grain. If the miller switches batches, the observant is in trouble.</i> Rebbi [Ḥiyya] (Yose)<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">The words in brackets are from <i>Demay</i>, those in parentheses from <i>Ketubot</i>. The text from <i>Demay</i> seems preferable.</i> in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If his [box] (bread)<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">The words in brackets are from <i>Demay</i>, those in parentheses from <i>Ketubot</i>. The text from <i>Demay</i> seems preferable.</i> was exchanged at the miller’s, if it was established that an <i>am haäreẓ</i> gave [grain] to be milled there that day, he has to worry<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">He has to tithe a second time under the rules of <i>demay</i>.</i>; otherwise, he does not have to worry. Should he not worry? What is the difference between this and the Saracens? Was it not stated: “If a group of Saracens one day provisioned themselves from forbidden supplies<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">If the travelling Arabs buy once from unobservant Jews, one has to assume that they always do, and that the grain they sell is not exempt Gentile produce.</i>, then that day becomes a proof for all days.” It is impossible for Saracens not to supply themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Since they are itinerant sellers they have to buy provisions all the time. But the farmer mills once for his entire season.</i>. But here it was not established that the <i>am haäreẓ</i> was milling there that day.<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">End of the quote from <i>Demay</i>. The quote establishes that there is a presumption that things go wrong, in our case that the rapist was from a family disqualified for the priesthood.</i> And here, I am saying that the disqualified person went to draw water only that day, and one has to worry. And here, Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Yannai: He cohabited with her inside of Sepphoris. And here, Rebbi Abba said in the name of Rebbi Yannai: If he was seen coming out of Sepphoris and he cohabited, the presumption is that he is disqualified since he cohabited there<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">This conclusion differs from the position of the Babli (Note 263) but not by much: One can qualify the rape victim only if the gates of the city were not locked and the perpetrator was not seen coming from a fixed place; that the group from which he came was not composed of locals only (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:10:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.10.4">Note 265</a>).</i>.
“And everything found is judged by a majority.”<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence does not really belong here but is an intrusion from the Tosephta quoted in the sequel. It is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli, 15a</a>, in the same context. What is meant here is that a find is pure if most things in town are pure, otherwise it is impure. In principle, this can also be applied to permitted or prohibited things: If 9 stores in town sell kosher meat and 1 non-kosher, then any meat found on the street can be considered as kosher (Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel disagrees, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Tahorot 6:1" href="/Tosefta_Tahorot.6.1">Tosephta <i>Tahorot</i> 6:1</a>).</i> In difficult cases the rabbis compare this<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">The status of the rape victim.</i> to crawling things<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:29-30" href="/Leviticus.11.29-30"><i>Lev</i>. 11:29–30</a> contains a list of “crawling things”, mostly reptiles, whose cadaver is a source of impurity. The only cadavers that produce impurity are those of crawling things and mammals.</i>, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">A shorter version of this <i>baraita</i> is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 15a" href="/Ketubot.15a">Babli 15a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 18a" href="/Niddah.18a"><i>Niddah</i> 18a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Tahorot 6:2" href="/Tosefta_Tahorot.6.2">Tosephta <i>Tahorot</i> 6:2</a>.</i>: “Nine frogs and one crawling thing<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">They are all dead; the dead frogs do not carry impurity.</i> in a private domain<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Questions of doubt in matters of ritual impurity must be resolved by a presumption of impurity in private domains and a presumption of purity in public domains; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.2.5"><i>Soṭah</i> 1:2, Note 88</a>.</i>, if somebody touched one of them and it is not known which one he touched, in doubt he is impure. If he transferred to the public domain and touched, in doubt he is pure. If he returned to the private domain and touched, in doubt he is impure. And for what is found one follows the majority.” Rav Ḥisda said, no valiant person can find his hands<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">This is not rational, since the place where the object was found should be of importance.</i>. Rebbi Immi said, praise to Him Who chose them<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">The Sages. A similar expression in the heading of the <i>baraita</i> of <i>Abot</i>.</i> and their words; do not compare this<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">The case of the raped girl whose disqualification would be a case of impurity.</i> to a private domain but to the public domain! As it was stated: “Nine crawling things and one frog between them in the public domain, if somebody touched one of them and it is not known which one he touched, in doubt he is pure<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Even against all probabilities.</i>. If he transferred to a private domain and touched, in doubt he is impure. If he returned to the public domain and touched, in doubt he is pure. And for what is found one follows the majority.” Rav Ḥisda said, no valiant person can find his hands. Rebbi Immi said, praise to Him Who chose them and their words; is the spring of Sepphoris not public domain? Rebbi Yose said, since the two could be alone together it is treated as private domain<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">The difference between public and private domains is not in the ownership but in accessibility. A cave in the public domain has the status of private domain. Rav Ḥisda is justified; this kind of argument is not relevant to explain the relation of Mishnah 10 to Mishnaiot 8,9.</i>.
It happened that a baby girl was noticed who had been thrown on a garbage heap. The case came before Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose, who said, she should be adjoined to dough<sup class="footnote-marker">248,</sup><i class="footnote">As a dough is a mixture of several ingredients, so the dough widow is a mixture; she is a woman qualified for priesthood who was married to a husband with a questionable family background (one whose females are permitted to marry Israels but not Cohanim). The problem is that there is the knowledge that something was wrong in the marriages of that family but the exact nature of the defect is not known.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">She should be adopted by a family of questionable status.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah thought to say, to qualified dough, would Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose disagree with his father<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">He said that in a town of mostly qualified families, the children are automatically qualified.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, even if you say to disqualified dough, Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose would not disagree with his father. Why? While the qualified whore, only the disqualified throw away<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, that baby is from a group of mostly unqualified children.</i>.

Chapter 2



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman became widowed or divorced and she claims<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Either her <i>ketubah</i> is lost or, if she married at a place of illiterates, it never was written.</i> to have been married as a virgin, but he says not so, I married you as a widow, if there are witnesses that she went out in <i>hinuma</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.10">Chapter 1, Note 65</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.10.1">Chapter 2, Note 22</a>.</i> or with uncovered hair<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">A virgin will start covering her hair only at the wedding.</i>, her <i>ketubah</i> is 200 [<i>zuz</i>]. Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa says, the distribution of roasted kernels also is proof<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">At his place, this was a sign of the wedding of a virgin.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman became widowed,” etc. We understand if she was divorced. If she became widowed, who opposes? The heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Only the husband’s descendants, and in their absence the husband’s family, do inherit; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num</i>. 27:6–11</a>. The widow can claim only her <i>ketubah</i> (in the absence of a will).</i>.
Should one follow the majority, and most women are married as virgins. Say then that she was married as a virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Why does the Mishnah put the burden of proof on the woman when there should be a presumption in her favor to require the husband or the heirs to prove their case.</i>! This implies that in criminal cases and in money matters one does not apply a majority argument<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since the woman claims money, the burden of proof is on her; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.7.1">Chapter 1, Note 215</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 93a" href="/Bava_Batra.93a">Babli agrees, <i>Baba Batra</i> 93a</a>.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 5:1</a></i>, we have stated: “If an ox gored a cow and one finds her fetus beside her.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">If it cannot be ascertained whether the miscarriage was induced by the goring or preceded the goring, the ox’s owner pays (by biblical decree, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:35" href="/Exodus.21.35"><i>Ex</i>. 21:35</a>) half of the damage done to the cow but only a quarter of the value of the fetus. It is clear that the proven fact of the goring creates a presumption that the miscarriage was induced by it. This presumption is not sufficient to force the owner of the ox to pay; the value of the fetus, had it grown to be a calf, is “money in dispute”. Money in dispute for which there are no proofs either way is split evenly between the parties (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 2b" href="/Bava_Metzia.2b">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 2b</a>). A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 5:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.5.1.2"><i>Baba Qama</i> 5:1</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 46a" href="/Bava_Kamma.46a">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 46a</a>, denies the designation as “money in dispute” and puts the burden of proof on the claimant, the injured party.</i>” Do most cows have miscarriages? Say therefore that the goring induced the miscarriage. Rebbi Abbahu said, this implies that in criminal cases and in money matters one does not apply a majority argument. Rebbi Abun<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Baba Qama</i>, R. Yose.</i> said, in one case they applied a majority argument, as Rebbi Aḥa stated: If a camel was in heat among camels and one finds one of them dead, I am saying that the one in heat bit it<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 93a" href="/Bava_Batra.93a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 93a</a>: It is known that the one in heat killed it. The Babli holds that this is not a case of majority but one of <i>prima facie</i> evidence: Proof that the camel was in heat implies proof that it did attack other males. Therefore, the owner of the camel in heat would have to prove that the attack by the male in heat on the male not in heat was not lethal.</i>.
If somebody claimed a mina, the [defendant] denied it, and the [claimant] produced witnesses that the [defendant] owes him 50 [<i>zuz</i>]. The older Rebbi Ḥiyya said, [the defendant] has to swear about the remainder. Rebbi Joḥanan says, he does not have to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Following the principle that the defendant in a suit for money can by biblical law only be forced to swear if he admits that part of the claim is justified; based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:8" href="/Exodus.22.8"><i>Ex</i>. 22:8</a>, where the expression אֲשֶׁר יֹאמַר כִּי הוּא זֶה “if he agrees that this is so.” In <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i>(1:1, 7d 1. 24; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3a" href="/Ketubot.3a">Babli 3a</a>) the reason of the older R. Ḥiyya is “that what he admits himself should not have greater force than the testimony of witnesses.”</i>. The older Rebbi Ḥiyya learned it from two who are grabbing a toga, as we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:1</a>. If two people come to court, each grabs half of a toga and asserts ownership of the entire piece because he found it, each of them has to swear that he owns no less than half of it (so the court should not force obvious perjury) and takes half of the piece since “it is money in dispute”.</i>: “Two are grabbing a toga, one says, I found it, and the other says, I found it.” The one who grabs half of it is as if he brought witnesses that that half belongs to him. The other says, “it belongs to me entirely”, and the fact that he grabs half of it is as if he brought witnesses that this half belongs to him. The one who says, “it belongs to me entirely”, swears that not the entire [toga] is the other’s. But he did not hear that Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The student of the older R. Ḥiyya’s son Ḥizqiah.</i> that this oath is a rabbinic institution, that a man should not see another in the market and tell him, the toga which you are wearing is mine, come and split your toga with me!<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Baba Meṣ‘ia</i> 1:1, 7d 1. 33; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 3a" href="/Ketubot.3a">Babli 3a</a>; both in the name of R. Joḥanan. Rabbinic institutions do not imply anything for biblical law.</i> Rebbi Abin in the name of Rav: My uncle<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The older R. Ḥiyya, half-brother to both of Rav’s parents.</i> agrees in the case of a document. How is that? He claimed a mina, the [defendant] denied it, and the [claimant] produced a document that the [defendant] owed him 50 [<i>zuz</i>]. He has only fifty. And Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, we can understand it from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 10:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.10.2.1"><i>Mishnah Baba Batra</i> 10:2.</a> If the amount of indebtedness is illegible, the use of the plural proves that the amount was at least two.</i>: “‘The amount of … tetradrachmas’ and it was illegible, he owes no less than two. “If it is more, if the lender says five but the borrower says three, Ben Azzay says since he partially agreed to the claim, he has to swear, but the Sages say, what he agreed to is not of the kind which was claimed<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 10:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.10.2.2"><i>Baba Batra</i> 10:2</a> (by the editorial team of <i>Neziqin</i>, different from the editors of the rest of the Yerushalmi) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 4b" href="/Bava_Metzia.4b">Babli, <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i>4b</a>, the “Sages” are identified as R. Aqiba. In the Babli, Ben Azzai is replaced by R. Simeon ben Eleazar, 2 generations younger than Ben Azzai and R. Aqiba. In both sources, the reason of R. Aqiba is given that the borrower, in agreeing to pay more than he could be forced to by the existing document, is like a person returning what the other had lost, not directly answering the lender’s claim.</i>. Because it was not of the kind which was claimed! Therefore, if it were of the kind which was claimed, he would be obligated. And is it not here that the agreed sum was part of the claim<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In our Mishnah, why should the divorcing husband not be forced to swear that he does not have to pay 200 <i>zuz</i> even if there are no witnesses, since he agrees that he owes 100? {The heirs, not being able to swear, would have to pay.}</i>? Everybody agrees that he owes her a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Since this amount is not in dispute, the husband cannot be considered as agreeing to part of the claim; no oath is due.</i>. But she claimsanother mina from him, to which he does not agree. The burden of proof is on the claimant<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This is the standard formulation, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 46b" href="/Bava_Kamma.46b">Babli <i>Baba Qama</i> 46b</a>.</i>.
“In <i>hinuma</i>”. There, a veil. The rabbis here say, a <i>phorema</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.10">Chapter 1, Note 65</a>, originally a virgin was led to her husband’s house with ὑμέναιοι “wedding songs”. After the war of Bar Kokhba, when these songs were forbidden (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 9:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.9.12.1"><i>Soṭah</i> 9:13, Note 189</a>), the word <i>hinuma</i> changed its meaning. In Babylonia it became “a veil” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 17b" href="/Ketubot.17b">Babli 17b</a>), literally “a slumber cloth” from נום “to sleep”, in Galilee φόρημα “that which is carried”, i. e., “a litter”.</i>.
“She went out with uncovered head.” Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, like those who went out on the Day of Atonement<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The virgins of Jerusalem who went out to dance in the vineyards on the 15th of Ab and the Day of Atonement to find husbands (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.4.6.1"><i>Mishnah Ta‘anit</i> 4:8</a>).</i>. If she went out with uncovered head, the witnesses testify<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">To the fact that she had her head uncovered before the wedding.</i> that she had not been cohabitated with. Should one not worry that she was a virgin after final marriage? That means, a virgin after final marriage does not go out with uncovered head<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">As in German one says “under die Haube kommen” (“to get under the bonnet”) for “to be married”, the widow who is a virgin is a lady, always wearing a hat, no longer a girl.</i>. Should one not worry that she had been injured by wood? That must follow Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr says<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.3.1">Mishnah 1:3</a>.</i> the <i>ketubah</i> of one injured by wood is 200 [<i>zuz</i>]. Rebbi Joḥanan said, they did not worry about infrequent occurrences<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.1.1">Mishnah 2:1</a> does not contradict the position of the Sages in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.3.1">Mishnah 1:3</a>. The Babli agrees in a different context, 16a.</i>.
“Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa says, the distribution of roasted kernels also is proof.” Should one not worry that she was a virgin after final marriage? That means, for a virgin after final marriage one does not distribute roasted kernels. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 16b" href="/Ketubot.16b">Babli, 16b</a>, in an anonymous <i>baraita</i> it is stated that it was a sign of a virgin’s wedding if one brought before her a cup of good news or danced at her wedding.</i>: Abba Shaul says, also if one brought before her an amphora of good news<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the “cup of good news” is explained as a cup of heave wine, since heave is called “beginning” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:12" href="/Numbers.18.12"><i>Num</i>. 18:12</a>), the bride also represents a beginning. It probably is difficult to have a full amphora of heave wine; so one might think of the “good news amphora” as one of new wine which is opened for the first time at the wedding, just as the bride will be “opened” after the wedding.</i>. Should one not worry that she was a virgin after final marriage? That means, in front of a virgin after final marriage one does not bring an amphora of good news.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Joshua agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Even though he held in Chapter 1 that uncorroborated statements are not admissible in court, he agrees that if the question would not arise had a person not pointed it out, the same person is empowered to remove the difficulty he himself created. This is the principle behind the following Mishnaiot of this Chapter.</i> that if somebody says to another: “This field did belong to your father but I bought it from him,” that he is trustworthy since the mouth which forbade is the mouth which permits. But if there are witnesses that it did belong to [the second man’s] father and [the first] said, I bought it, he is not trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">If there are witnesses, even if they come to court after the first person explained the problem, the first person has to establish his claim following all rules of testimony.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Joshua agrees,” etc. Rebbi Joshua agrees, but he does not disagree<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">No disagreement is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>. Why should it be noted that R. Joshua agrees in another case? The reference is to all <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.1.1">Mishnaiot of Chapter 1</a> where he disagrees. The same explanation is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 16a" href="/Ketubot.16a">Babli, 16a</a>.</i>? In the former.
“He is not trustworthy” if he did not eat the years of legal claim<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">If a person can prove three years of undisturbed possession of real estate and claims legal acquisition (by sale, inheritance, or gift), the court has to confirm him in possession since documents have to be kept only for three years.</i> from it. But if he ate the years of legal claim from it, he is trustworthy if [the second person’s] father did not die in possession. But if [the second person’s] father died in possession, he is [not] trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The three years of undisturbed possession count only if the person from whom he acquired it was alive during these years since the heirs might not be knowledgeable enough of the details of the deceased’s property to exercise their duty to object to the squatter’s occupation.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Except for the last sentence, the following is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 3:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.3.4.2-3">Halakhah <i>Baba Batra</i> 3:4</a> in a different editing.</i> As the following: Reuben ate from a field<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Undisturbed for 3 years.</i> claiming that it was his. Simeon brought witnesses that his father died in possession. One removes [the field] from Reuben and hands the title to Simeon.
