Reuben came back and brought witnesses that [Simeon’s] father did not die in possession. Rebbi Naḥman ben Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">He should be called Rav Naḥman ben Jacob, in the Babli simply called Rav Naḥman, chief judge and highest authority in money matters in Babylonia.</i> said, I took it from Reuben, I am returning it to Reuben<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">If there are two against two witnesses and all four testimonies hold up under cross examination, there is no testimony and Simeon has no claim. The identical statement appears in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 31b" href="/Bava_Batra.31b">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 31b</a>.</i>. That is what the rabbis here think. The rabbis there say, from the time it was removed, by clear testimony it was removed<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Since (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>) “by the testimony of two or three witnesses the case shall be confirmed”, Reuben’s witnesses cannot be accepted unless they prove that Simeon’s witnesses were lying.<br>It is difficult to see who “the rabbis from there” are since Rab Naḥman was the authority in Babylonia and the Babli (<i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>.) decides explicitly that later claims are admissible in money matters.</i>. So the rabbis here say, from the time she married, by clear testimony she married<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">This really belongs to the next paragraph, about a woman whose husband has disappeared and she remarried on the testimony of two witnesses that her husband had died; when two witnesses come and say he is alive, they are not listened to.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the rabbis there agree that if during the first proceedings two [witnesses] say that his father died in possession and two say, he did not die in possession, Reuben’s claim is upheld<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">If during court proceedings there are contradictory statements, none of which can be shown to be false, there is no proof and the claim of legal possession cannot be denied.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.3.2-5"><i>Yebamot</i> 10:4</a>, explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:5:4-7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.5.4-7.1">Notes 99–114</a>. The variant readings are noted by <b>י</b>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, it was stated thus: “Two [witnesses] say he died, [later] two witnesses say, he did not die. She shall not remarry, but if she has remarried she should not leave. Two [witnesses] say she was divorced, [later] two witnesses say, she was not divorced. She shall not remarry; if she has remarried she must leave.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta <i>Yebamot</i> 14:1</a></i>” There, they say, it makes no difference; whether about death or divorce she should not leave. In the opinion of the rabbis there it is understandable, there is no difference between death and divorce. In the opinion of the rabbis here, what is the difference between death and divorce? Rebbi Ze‘ira said it without attribution, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It is reasonable to decide in the case of witnesses of death that if he returns he contradicts them. Rebbi Ḥizqiah said, the rabbis there stick to their opinion since the rabbis there say, when the [first] testimony was accepted, it was accepted as certain. So the rabbis here say, at the moment of her remarriage, she remarried based on certified testimony. Rebbi Yose said, it is reasonable that the rabbis there did not change their argument. Do the rabbis there not agree if two [witnesses] say, his father died while in possession, [and two say his father died while not in possession,] that the field is in Reuben’s possession? Therefore, if two say, she was divorced and remarried, and two say she was not divorced, rightly she should not leave. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “If two are saying, she was preliminarily married, and two are saying, she was not preliminarily married, she should not get married, but if she married she should not leave.” Rebbi Hoshaia said, Rebbi Joḥanan may explain it as follows: “If two are saying, she was divorced, and two are saying, she was not divorced, she should not get married, but if she married she should not leave.” What is the difference between this and the first case? There, she was considered a married woman in everybody’s opinion. Here, she is considered a married woman only for two people. If two others came and identified the man who was betrothed to her. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “If two are saying, she was kidnapped but is pure, and two are saying, she was kidnapped and is impure, she should not get married, but if she married she should not leave.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 2:2" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).2.2">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 2:2</a>. The kidnap victim who was raped cannot marry a Cohen.</i>” Rebbi Yose said, since these say, she is pure, and those say, she is impure, it is as if two said, she was kidnapped, and two said, she was not kidnapped, and we depend on what she says. If two are saying, she had been betrothed and two are saying she had not been betrothed. Rebbi Jonah compares that to fat. If two said, X ate fat, and two said, X did not eat fat, did he not have to bring a “hung” reparation sacrifice because of the doubt? Here, he should give a bill of divorce because of the doubt. Rebbi Yose said to him, do not compare this to fat, because even if he says my conscience bothers me, he brings a “hung” reparation sacrifice. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Yose: If two are saying she had been betrothed and two are saying she had not been betrothed, she should not get married. The end disagrees with Rebbi Jonah: If she married she must leave. Rebbi Mana said, Rebbi Yose did not say that she may marry, nor did Rebbi Jonah say if she married she must leave, he said only, do not compare this to fat, because even if he says my conscience bothers me, he brings a “hung” reparation sacrifice.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If witnesses said, this is our signature, but we were under duress, or underage, or disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">If at the time they witnessed the document they lived off illegal or immoral earnings (e. g., as gamblers having no other employment, who cannot make money if the game is honest).</i>, these are trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">They have witnessed a document of indebtedness or transfer of property which ended up in court. The court must first establish that the document is genuine by certifying the signatures of the witnesses. If the witnesses were unknown to the court, their testimony qualifies the document as genuine. But since theirs is the mouth which permits the introduction of the document, their mouth can prohibit its introduction by claiming that their signatures were obtained illegally.</i>. But if there are witnesses to identify their signatures, or their signatures are confirmed from another document<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">If the witnesses were unknown to the court but another document was presented carrying their signatures and certified by another court as genuine, then the court judging the present document is empowered to certify their signatures by comparing them to the certified ones. Their mouth is not the one which permits; therefore, their mouth cannot prohibit.</i>, they are not trustworthy.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If witnesses said, this is our signature,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">In slightly different wording in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 2:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).2.1">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 2:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:3:4-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.3.4-5"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 6:5</a>.</i>: And similarly, the witnesses who testified whether to declare impure or pure, or to remove or include, or to forbid or permit, or to obligate or absolve<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">These testimonies are all about personal status. To declare impure or pure is the same as to exclude (bastards from marrying Jewish partners or desecrated females from marrying Cohanim) or to include them in the pool of eligible marriage partners. Similarly, to forbid marriages (because the woman is still married) or to permit, to impose a purification sacrifice for sinful marriage or to absolve. The parallel Tosephta in <i>Sanhedrin</i> must be interpreted to deal with money matters, to impose payment or to absolve from payment.</i>, if they say we did invent this<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The text here is in doubt. The Erfurt ms. of the Tosephta reads מְבוּדִּין אָנוּin both places, “we were made to lie”; this is the reading of many German and Italian medieval authorities in the Yerushalmi. The text of the ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> is also the text of the Vienna ms. of the Tosephta and most African, Spanish, and French authorities; cf. <i>Tosefta ki-Fshutah</i>, part 6, p. 199–200.</i> before their testimony was investigated by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">This does not necessarily mean investigation by cross-examination but indicates that identification of their signatures was accepted by the court; cf. <i>Tosefta ki-Fshutah</i>, part 6, p. 200–202.</i>, they can be believed; after their testimony was investigated by the court, they are not trustworthy.” Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they considered witnesses who signed a document as if their testimony had been investigated by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Once the signatures have been accepted, the witnesses cannot change their stories since “no witness can testify twice in the same matter” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 18b" href="/Ketubot.18b">Babli 18b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 3:4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.3.4.5"><i>Bikkurim</i> 3:4, Note 72</a>). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 18b" href="/Ketubot.18b">Babli agrees, 18b</a>. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 10:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.10.3.3"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 10:5, Note 96</a>.</i>. If they say, these are our signatures, and others say, these are their signatures, Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: Their [testimony] does not add and does not detract<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Since their testimony is not needed, they do not have the power to modify the terms of the contract which they signed as witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, our Mishnah says so, “if there are witnesses to identify their signatures, or if their signatures are confirmed from another document<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">If the witnesses were unknown to the court but another document was presented carrying their signatures and certified by another court as genuine, then the court judging the present document is empowered to certify their signatures by comparing them to the certified ones. Their mouth is not the one which permits; therefore, their mouth cannot prohibit.</i>, they are not trustworthy.”
They say, these are our signatures, but others<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Witnesses before the court.</i> say, not their signatures. Rebbi Mana said, that becomes a document which has been put under acloud<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">A document signed by unidentified witnesses is worthless.</i>. Issi said, only if it had been put under a cloud but was confirmed by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement of the Mishnah, that witnesses are not needed if “their signatures are confirmed from another document.” He holds that signatures can be confirmed from other documents without asking the witnesses if there was a problem with the other document and it was confirmed by a court after due investigation. Since the signatures on a document whose validity is acknowledged by all parties do not have to be investigated, those signatures should not be used to validate documents in dispute. This opinion is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 19b" href="/Ketubot.19b">Babli, 19b</a>, as tannaїtic. Later, 20a, in the name of R. Assi (Issi), it is interpreted to mean that one may use a document in dispute to validate other documents only if the first document was confirmed by a court, implying that an undisputed document can be used even if no court ever had given its opinion on it. This cannot be the meaning in the Yerushalmi.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, if it was not confirmed by a court<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Any document accepted by a court, after investigation or without, is valid to compare signatures.</i>. Rebbi Ila said, the reason of Rebbi Eleazar is, that after the witnesses were confirmed as the signatories of the document, it is as if their testimony had been investigated by the court.
Rav Ḥana said, one learns from a corrected scroll, like those who say, Issi’s scribe<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">A document in the characteristic handwriting of a known scribe can be accepted, since that scribe would not be a party to a dishonest document.</i>. From letters it is problematic<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Letters cannot directly be used to identify handwriting since it is known, from Geniza documents and Sephardic documents through the 18th Century, that people develop very intricate signatures that cannot be compared directly to their fluent writing in letters.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, only from three documents in the hands of three people<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 20a" href="/Ketubot.20a">Babli, 20a</a>, accepts two documents in the hands of two people to verify signatures. It is explained that two documents in the hand of the same person are no help since just as he forged one document so he may have forged the other.</i>.
Rav Huna in the name of Rav: The witnesses can be trusted if they say, that is a document given in good faith<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A document of indebtedness while no debt exists, to be activated later if the debtor needs money, given in good faith that the lender will not use it unless there really will be a loan (naturally interest-free).<br>In a more general sense, a good faith document is a document covering eventualities which the parties expect never to happen. Such a document is not enforceable. Some rabbinic authorities hold that pre-nuptial agreements about eventual modalities of divorce are good faith documents since nobody marries with the idea of a divorce in mind.</i>, or a document in trust<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πίστις “trust, credit, credence” (in the <i>editio princeps</i> the spelling is פיסיטיס; Musaphia reads פסטיס). A document which does not correspond to reality and is not intended ever to correspond to reality, but to make the holder appear richer than he really is.</i>. But Rav said, it is forbidden to sign a document given in good faith, or a document in trust. Does this contradict what they say in the name of Rav, the witnesses can be trusted if they say, that is a document given in good faith, or a document in trust? One word of Rav contradicts a word of Rav! Rebbi Ḥaggai said, Rav did not say it is forbidden to sign but it is forbidden to keep<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli, in the name of Amoraim of the last generation, disagrees and holds that it is forbidden to sign inactive documents and that witnesses who claim the documents were not meant to be used declare themselves to be sinners and, therefore, unacceptable as witnesses. But if they say that the debtor stated before them that he agreed to the document only under duress, they are to be believed.</i>. As the following<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 11:14" href="/Job.11.14"><i>Job</i> 11:14</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 19b" href="/Ketubot.19b">Babli, 19b</a>, this is attributed to R. Joshua ben Levi.</i>, “if evil is in your hand, remove it,” that is a document given in good faith, or a document in trust, “do not let injustice dwell in your house,” that is a document of indebtedness which was paid<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">It should be torn up rather than invalidated by a separate receipt.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one says, this is my signature and that is my colleague’s signature, and the other says, this is my signature and that is my colleague’s signature, they are trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">There is a document before the court which should be certified and for that the court has to check whether the signatures of the two witnesses on the document are genuine. If each of the two witnesses testifies to the genuineness of both signatures, there are two witnesses for each signature and the document is validated. (While nobody can testify in his own behalf, here the witness testifies in behalf of the owner of the document.)</i>. If each of them says, that ismy signature, each of them needs another with him, the words of Rebbi, but the Sages say, everybody is trustworthy to confirm his own signature<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah explains, Rebbi requires that each signature on the document be certified by two witnesses but the Sages hold that only the contents of the document have to be certified by two witnesses.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If one says, this is my signature,” etc. Why was this necessary? For Rebbi. Even though Rebbi says, each of them needs another with him, here he agrees that they are trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">He accepts cross validations since there are two witnesses for every signature.</i>.
Rebbi Ze‘ira said: It was stated in Rav’s <i>Ketubot</i>: The words of Rebbi (Eleazar)<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">This is in the ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>, but does not fit the context. The correct text is in <i>Sefer Ha‘iṭṭur</i>(vol. 1, 14b, Note 74): אָמַר רִבִּי זְעִירָא. דִּבְרֵי רִבִּי <b>כְּמֵעִיד</b> עַל הַשְׁטָר וְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים <b>כְּ</b>מֵעִיד עַל הַמִּלְוֶה. This is the basis of the translation. However, since it leaves out the irrelevant information about Rav’s <i>Ketubot</i>, it probably is not an exact copy of the Yerushalmi text.</i> that he testifies about the document, the words of the Sages that he testifies about the loan<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah explains, Rebbi requires that each signature on the document be certified by two witnesses but the Sages hold that only the contents of the document have to be certified by two witnesses.</i>’<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli agrees (after some discussion), 20b/21a.</i>.
It was stated: A person may write down his testimony and testify about it even some years later<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 20a" href="/Ketubot.20a">Babli 20a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 2:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).2.1">Tosephta 2:1</a> (there, the wording is: even after 100 years.) The problem is that the verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>) requires that “anything be confirmed <i>by the mouth</i> of two or three witnesses.” The disagreement of Rav Huna and R. Joḥanan is confirmed by the Babli, but not its explanation.</i>. Rav Ḥuna said, only if he remembers his testimony. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even if he does not remember his testimony. It turns out that Rav Ḥuna follows Rebbi and Rebbi Joḥanan the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that nobody has to refresh his memory in order to identify his signature, so the difference must be about testifying to the substance of the document. R. Joḥanan follows the Sages since his testimony about his signature certifies the document and any additional information is ancillary but for Rav Huna the testimony about the signature says nothing about the contents of the document; any additional testimony must be <i>by the mouth</i> of the witnesses and not by his writing. (The explanation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 20a:9:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.20a.9.1"><i>Tosaphot</i>20a, <i>s</i>.<i>v</i>. ורבי יוחנן</a>, is difficult to accept.)</i>.
Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Ḥuna, in the name of Rav: One witness and someone from the market place cannot together certify the signature of the second witness<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">In the formulation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 21a" href="/Ketubot.21a">Babli, 21a</a>, one witness comes before the court but the other has died in the meantime. If the surviving witness were enabled to testify to his own signature and, with the help of an unrelated person, to that of the other witness, then 75% of the testimony would be from one witness (100% of his own half and 50% of the other half). But testimony of witnesses is acceptable only if both of them have equal validity.<br>The paragraph appears also in <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 2:1, 57d.</i>. How is that? If one identified his own signature<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Which he is enabled to do by the Mishnah following the Sages.</i> and that of his colleague, but that second witness’s signature was not known to anybody<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">In court.</i> except his colleague, may that colleague together with somebody from the market place<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., unconnected with the court and the parties before the court.</i> testify on that signature? That is what Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Ḥuna, said in the name of Rav: One witness and someone from the market cannot together certify the signature of the second witness. Another case where there are no two persons: The signature of one is known by everybody, but that second witness’s signature is not known to anybody except his colleague. Can that colleague testify on his signature as if he were someone from the market place? If you say so, the entire testimony is confirmed by one witness. Rebbi Yudan said, that is correct. If two people come from a town that is mostly Gentile, like Hippos<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">On the mountain ridge overlooking the Eastern Shore of Lake Genezareth.</i>. One is known by everybody as a Jew, but the other is not known by anybody except his companion. Can the latter be considered one from the market place to testify about him<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">To establish a Jewish identity, one witness is enough since it is a testimony about Torah prohibitions.</i>? If you say so, the entire testimony would be confirmed by one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">If the two testify about a document executed in the city of Hippos, the second witness testifies only because he was enabled by the first. Therefore, the second witness cannot be considered to be independent of the first.</i>! And in the prior case, the entire testimony would be confirmed by one witness.
Rebbi Ḥaggai said that Rebbi Ze‘ira asked: Can one witness testifying orally and one by a document be taken together? Is a single witness on a written document worth anything<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.10.2.1">Mishnah <i>Baba batra</i> 10:2</a>: A document signed by a single witness is invalid.</i>? Therefore, his question was, if there are two. They managed to confirm the first signature but not the second<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 165a" href="/Bava_Batra.165a">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 165a</a>, this is a question, if one signature was confirmed from another document and one by oral testimony. It is resolved that the document is valid.</i>. Rebbi Mana asked, is one witness on a written document enough to force anybody to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:9" href="/Exodus.22.9"><i>Ex</i>. 22:9</a> decrees that in all money matters in dispute, “if there is one who says, he is the one” who owes money, there should be an oath. This is interpreted to mean that the claimant can force the defendant to swear if he can support his claim by a single witness but does not have the two witnesses necessary to force the defendant to pay.</i>? Is a single witness on a written document worth anything? Therefore, his question was, if there are two. They managed to confirm the first signature but not the second. <sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1"><i>Soṭah</i> Chapter 1, Notes 46–71</a>. The text here is from the hand of the corrector; the scribe of the ms. only notes גרש בהילכתא קדמיתא דסוטה כולה עד וכה כל סימן וסימן צריך שני עדים “One reads all this in the first Halakhah of <i>Soṭah</i> up to ‘and here, every single hair needs two witnesses’.” There are several differences in the sequence of sentences in addition to systematic differences in spelling; it is clear that the corrector copied from a different ms. which now is lost.</i> Parallel to it: One does not accept testimony from witnesses unless they had seen together. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa says, even if they saw one after the other<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joshua ben Qorḥa will accept the written testimony of one witness (of two on a document) combined with the oral one of another; the Sages will reject it except in the three cases stated here. The same disagreement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 26b" href="/Ketubot.26b">Babli 26b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30b" href="/Sanhedrin.30b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 30b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac, in the name of Rav: The Sages agree with Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa for witnesses about primogeniture and rights of possession.
<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1"><i>Soṭah</i> Chapter 1, Notes 46–71</a>. The text here is from the hand of the corrector; the scribe of the ms. only notes גרש בהילכתא קדמיתא דסוטה כולה עד וכה כל סימן וסימן צריך שני עדים “One reads all this in the first Halakhah of <i>Soṭah</i> up to ‘and here, every single hair needs two witnesses’.” There are several differences in the sequence of sentences in addition to systematic differences in spelling; it is clear that the corrector copied from a different ms. which now is lost.</i> Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah. The same holds for testimony regarding signs. In that case, it is obvious if one says, I saw two hairs on his back and the other says, I saw two hairs on his back. If one says, I saw one hair on his back and the other says, I saw one hair on his belly, that is nothing; similarly on his back and on his back. If two say, we  saw one hair on his back and two others say, we saw one hair on his belly? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun and Rebbi Hoshaia ben Rebbi Shammai, one said, it is invalid, but the other said, it is valid. He who saysid it is invalid considers him as one who testifies to half a sign. He who said it is valid? Maybe they were rubbed off. One says, I saw two hairs on his back and one says, I saw two hairs on his belly. Rebbi Abba said, everybody agrees that this is valid [testimony]. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, everybody agrees that this is invalid. Rebbi Yose said, this is in disagreement. Rebbi Yose said to Rebbi Ḥaggai, does not Rebbi Yudan<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The statement of R. Yudan is in the text in <i>Soṭah</i>, missing here.</i> follow my opinion? He answered, I am disagreeing with his teacher, so much more with him. Rebbi Mana said, Rebbi Ḥaggai was correct. If a document was signed by four witnesses and it was disputed, if one person verified the signature of two [witnesses] and another that of the other two, is that worth anything? Does not every single signature need two witnesses? And here, every single hair needs two witnesses. Rebbi Ḥanania learns it from the years of possession. If one [witness] testified that he ate from the property the first, second, and third years and another [witness] testified that he ate from it the fourth, fifth, and sixth, is that worth anything<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah explains, Rebbi requires that each signature on the document be certified by two witnesses but the Sages hold that only the contents of the document have to be certified by two witnesses.</i>? Does not every single year need two witnesses? And here, ever single hair needs two witnesses.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman said, I was married but I am divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">She is new in the community and produces no divorce document.</i>, she is to be trusted, since the mouth which forbade is the mouth which permits. But if there are witnesses that she is married and she says, I am divorced, she is not trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">If the witnesses know of her marriage but do not know of her divorce, she has to prove her assertion; in the meantime she is treated as legally married and cannot remarry.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman said, I was married,” etc. It was stated: If the witnesses came after she remarried, she should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Her second marriage should not be dissolved.</i>. Rav Ḥuna and Rebbi Ḥanina both say, not only after she remarried but even after the court authorized her to remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 23a" href="/Ketubot.23a">Babli, 23a</a>, this is a statement of Samuel’s father, of the generation of transition between Tannaïm and Amoraïm.</i>. As the following: A woman came to Rebbi Joḥanan and said to him, I was married but I am divorced, and he permitted her. After she left, they said to him, are not her witnesses at Lod<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">She said that she had been married at Lod. Therefore, it would be possible to check her out by sending for witnesses from Lod.</i>? He said, so I am saying: Should she wait even if her witnesses are at קסוסנון<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>editio princeps</i>, the spelling is קסוסנין. {Perhaps cf. Greek κασαυρεῖον, τό, also κασώριον, “brothel”, with assimilation of σ from Greek ρ. The implication is that witnesses in any case would not be considered [E. G.].}</i>? Rebbi Yose bar Rebbi Abun said, there were two cases. In one case, they said to him, are not her witnesses at Lod? In the other case, they said to him, are not her witnesses at Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Caesarea Philippi, much closer to Tiberias than Lod in the South.</i>? And so it was!He said to them, so I am saying: Should she wait even if her witnesses are at קסוסנון?
Rebbi Yudan asked: “I had been married but I was divorced at place X”; if two [witnesses] come and say, no woman was divorced at place X, do they contradict her<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">No answer is given. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 23a" href="/Ketubot.23a">Babli (23a</a>) notes, “‘we did not see’ is no proof.” There are divorces done in privacy, and this kind of negative testimony is inadmissible. The reluctance of the Yerushalmi to decidehere is understandable; it may be that the correct spelling of the place in question had not been established and a divorce document is invalid if the names of the persons or of the place are incorrect. {For example, the Jewish community in Basel, Switzerland, was founded by Jews from Alsatia and until after 1918 all divorces were executed in old established Alsatian communities. When it was found necessary to perform divorces in Basel, the problem arose whether to write the name of the city as באזעל following the rules of Western Yiddish in which /a/ = א, /e/ = ע, or באזל since the /e/ is almost inaudible in local speech. The problem had to be settled by an outside expert in the writing of divorce documents.}</i>? Rebbi Yose asked, if she said, I had been married but I was divorced at place X at a certain date,” and two came and said, a woman was divorced at that place<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">But they have no direct knowledge of the specific case in question.</i>, but two [others] came and said, no woman was divorced at that place? That is a contradiction of the essence of the testimony; we live off her mouth.
One day, she said, I am married. The next day, she said, I am divorced. We asked her, yesterday you said this, today you say otherwise? She said to them, because of a group of amoral people who wanted to start up with me<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">She needed the protection given in society to married women.</i>. Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Ila: Since she provided an explanation for her words, she can be believed<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22a" href="/Ketubot.22a">Babli, 22a</a>, the case and its resolution is tannaïtic, attributed to the Sages of the court at Usha (probably under Antoninus Pius).</i>. A similar case: Samuel wanted to sleep with his wife, but she said to him, I am impure<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">And therefore forbidden for an additional 10 days.</i>. The next day, she said, I am pure. He said to her, yesterday, you said impure, today pure? She said to him, I did not feel well enough at that moment. He came and asked Rav, who told him, since she provided an explanation for her words, she can be believed<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22" href="/Ketubot.22">Babli, 22a/b</a>, Samuel accepted the ruling for everybody except himself; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 22b:1:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.22b.1.1">Tosaphot 22b, <i>s</i>.<i>v</i>. ואפילו</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> 6<i>:</i> If a woman said, I was kidnapped<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Even if a woman is held for ransom, it is assumed that her Gentile kidnapper raped her and that, therefore, she is forbidden to marry a Cohen.</i> but I am pure, she is to be trusted, since the mouth which forbade is the mouth which permits. But if there are witnesses that she was kidnapped and she says, I am pure, she is not trustworthy. If the witnesses came after she was married, she should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">If she is married to a Cohen, he does not have to divorce her.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman said, I was kidnapped,” etc. Rav Ḥuna said, not only after she remarried but even after the court authorized her to remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 23a" href="/Ketubot.23a">Babli, 23a</a>, this is a statement of Samuel’s father, of the generation of transition between Tannaïm and Amoraïm.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Halakhah is reproduced in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 23a" href="/Ketubot.23a">Babli, 23a</a>.</i> Women were kidnapped and brought there<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">To Nahardea in Babylonia.</i>. The case came before Abba bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel’s father.</i>, and Samuel. They ordered and gave them over to chaperones who were to return them to the Land of Israel. He<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel.</i> said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel’s father.</i>: What did we do for the earlier times when they were alone with them? Abba bar Abba said to him, would you say so if they were your daughters? Samuel’s daughters were kidnapped, “like an error which comes from the ruler”<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 10:5" href="/Ecclesiastes.10.5"><i>Eccl</i>. 10:5</a>. From the story of another daughter of Samuel, Rachel, who was kidnapped and raped during the destruction of Nahardea by a soldier of Odenathus who later converted and married her, it seems that one has to date this at 259 C.E., after Samuel’s death.</i>. When they were brought here, their kidnappers came with them. They came before Rebbi Ḥanina and left their kidnappers outside. They said to him, we were kidnapped but we are pure<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Speaking Hebrew, they made it clear that they were educated.</i>. He permitted them. After they left, their kidnappers sent after them<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">To collect the redemption money from the Jewish community of Sepphoris.</i>. He said, it is obvious that these are the daughters of a Sage. When they came to know who they were, they said to Simeon bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">A relative of Samuel and a Cohen.</i>, take care of your relatives. He married the first one, but she died. The second one and she died. Why? Because they lied? God forbid, they did not lie. But because of the sin of Ḥanania, Rebbi Joshua’s nephew, who intercalated the year outside the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">He was the founder of the Academy of Nahardea and the ancestor of its leaders, Abba bar Abba and Samuel. He validly intercalated years during the war of Bar Kokhba but tried to hold on to his prerogative after the patriarchate was re-established; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 6:8:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.6.8.13"><i>Nedarim</i> 6:13, Notes 118–129</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 63a" href="/Berakhot.63a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 63a</a>.<br>The last sentences of this paragraph have no parallel in the Babli.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two women who were kidnapped<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">This was known before the testimony.</i> and each one of them says I am pure, are not trustworthy. But if they testify one for the other they can be trusted<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In order to help kidnap victims, one admitted the testimony of a single witness. The Mishnah notes that this is true even if one would suspect that they do this in order to help one another.</i>.<br>Similarly, if of two men each one says that he is a Cohen, the cannot be trusted. But if they testify for one another, they can be trusted<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">This follows the opinion stated in the next Mishnah that the testimony of a single witness suffices to enable a person to receive heave and other gifts to the priesthood.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Similarly, if of two men,” etc. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The Mishnah is valid for countryside sanctified food<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Heave and <i>Ḥallah</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 24a" href="/Ketubot.24a">Babli, 24a</a>, that is a tannaïtic statement.</i>. But for family matters and the sanctified food of the altar<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.4.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 4:4</a> requires a check on the families of bride and groom for several generations to ascertain that no ancestor is a bastard or desecrated.</i> one needs two witnesses. But was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).2.3">Tosephta 2:3</a>. The Tosephta continues: But one demotes only on the testimony of two witnesses.</i>: One raises to priesthood, levitic status, or Israel, by the testimony of one witness. One understands priesthood and levitic status. But the status of an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">What privileges accrue only to an Israel?</i>? Is that not regarding family status<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">This would imply that the family status of a Cohen as entitled to serve in the Temple also could be proven by a single witness.</i>? To give him the tithe of the poor<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">But family status depends on two witnesses. This means that, even if the Temple is rebuilt, it cannot be staffed until either seamless documentary proof is found for some priestly families that their direct ancestors served in the Temple and none of them in the intervening time married an unsuitable woman, or that the immortal Prophet Elijah comes to indicate which Cohanim pass muster.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).3.1">Tosephta 3:1</a>; most of it also in <i>Peah</i> 4:6; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 25a" href="/Ketubot.25a">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 25a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 26a" href="/Ketubot.26a">26a</a>.</i>“In the Land of Israel there are two legal claims to priestly status, the priestly blessings<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody is admitted to recite the priestly blessings in the synagogue, it must be that the rabbinic authority at that place found him qualified.</i> and the distribution from the threshing floor<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Since a point can be made that heave and <i>ḥallah</i> in the Land of Israel are biblical obligations, the rabbinic authorities would not empower a man to receive heave unless they checked his credentials.</i>. In Syria<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The land ruled over by David outside the biblical borders of the Land; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 7:5:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.7.5.6"><i>Peah</i> 7:6, Note 119</a>.</i>, priestly blessings but not distribution from the threshing floor<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Since heave cannot be a biblical obligation in Syria, nobody checks eligibility there.</i>. Up to the place where the messengers for the New Moon arrive, up to Nimerin<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">A distance of 14 days’ walk from Jerusalem, cf. Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 1:3–4. {The place of Nimerin has not been determined, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 6:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.6.1.9"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 6:1, Note 50</a>; it could be biblical <i>Bet Nimra</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 13:27" href="/Joshua.13.27"><i>Jos</i>. 13:27</a>) in the territory of the tribe of Gad in Gilead.)</i>. Babylonia is like Syria. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, also in Alexandria in the time when regular courts are sitting there<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">As long as the Jews of Alexandria enjoyed a certain autonomy, before the revolt against Trajan.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel stated: Just as heave establishes a legal claim to priesthood, so First Tithe establishes a legal claim to priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: “for Levitic status.” The text of the Yerushalmi is also that of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 26a" href="/Ketubot.26a">Babli, 26a</a>. It is appropriate for the Babli, which reserves the First Tithe to priests, against the biblical rules. It is not appropriate for the Yerushalmi which assigns tithes to the Levites, but to priests only in their quality of Levites (cf. <i>Ma‘aśer Šeni</i> 5:5, Notes 88–89.) One has to assume a copyist’s error; in the absence of parallel sources this cannot be confirmed.</i>. If somebody gives his heave to the court to distribute he has no legal claim to priesthood;” I am saying that the heave came to him from his mother’s father, a Cohen.
Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose said, I never testified except once, when I raised a slave to priestly status<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">This disproves the Tosephta, that receiving heave is a sign of priestly status since all members of a Cohen’s household, including his slaves, are entitled to eat heave. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 28b" href="/Ketubot.28b">Babli, 28b</a>, the problem is connected with a dispute between R. Jehudah and R. Yose on whether a slave is entitled to receive heave from any person other than his master.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 28b" href="/Ketubot.28b">Babli, 28b</a>, the story is transferred to his brother, R. Eleazar ben R. Yose, and is explained away.</i>. Rebbi Isaac Ḥaqula and Rebbi Simeon ben Rebbi, one raised a brother on the testimony of his brother, the other a son on the testimony of his father; one to the priesthood, the other to levitic status<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">The problems raised here are explained at the end of the paragraph. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 25b" href="/Ketubot.25b">Babli, 25b</a>, the actors are Rebbi and the elder R. Ḥiyya.</i>. A person came before Rebbi Hila<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 25b" href="/Ketubot.25b">Babli, 25b</a>, the discussion is theoretical and put into the mouths of Rebbi and the elder R. Ḥiyya. Here, it is reported as an actual case. There is something wrong with the tradition of names here. If the case was before R. Hila, the opponent must be R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, his fellow-student before R. Joḥanan. If the opponent is the elder R. Ḥiyya, the case must be before Rebbi.</i>; he said to him, this is my son<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">From an extramarital relationship, otherwise he would not need confirmation as an heir by the court.</i> and he is a Cohen. He answered him, he is your son but he is no Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">He is accorded all rights of inheritance (and cannot marry his close relatives from his father’s side) but he cannot act as a priest.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya the elder said to him, if you believe him that he is his son, believe him that he is a Cohen. If you do not believe him that he is his son, do not believe him that he is a Cohen. He answered, he is his son but I say that he is the son of a divorcee or one who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Following R. Joshua in Chapter 1, the court is obligated to think the worst of an extramarital relationship unless proven wrong.</i>. Rebbi Abin said, so he said to him: If you believe him that he is his son, believe him that he is a Cohen. If you do not believe him that he is a Cohen, do not believe him that he is his son. In that case, he would be unrelated and trustworthy in his testimony!<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Since we said that one witness is enough to establish a title to priesthood, if the man is not his father, he could testify that the child is a Cohen (which by R. Ḥiyya’s argument would make the man his father and disqualified from testifying.)</i> He answered, he is his son but I say that he is the son of a divorcee or one who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Did they not say, Rebbi Isaac Ḥaqula and Rebbi Simeon ben Rebbi, one raised a brother on the testimony of his brother, the other a son on the testimony of his father<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">If the brother was a full brother, there is no problem. In the Babli, it was R. Ḥiyya who elevated a man to levitic status by the testimony of a (paternal half-)brother, since for Levites the status of the mother is irrelevant (as long as she is Jewish and not a bastard.)</i>? Let us say that Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that a name is missing here under the influence of the Babli.</i> elevated a brother on the testimony of his brother. You may even say, a son on the testimony of his father, to levitic status<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:7:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.7.3">Note 128</a>. In the Babli, the cases are switched.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Jehudah says, one does not elevate to the priesthood by the testimony of one witness. Rebbi Eleazar said, when is this? If there are protesters<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">They claim that the person’s mother was disqualified to marry into the priesthood.</i>; but if there are no protesters, one elevates to the priesthood by the testimony of one witness. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says in the name of Rebbi Simeon, the son of the second in command<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The executive officer of the Temple, who must have known the practice of the Temple Court which had to certify priests to be admitted to the service.</i>, that one elevates to the priesthood by the testimony of one witness.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Jehudah says, one does not elevate,” etc. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: A complaint needs at least two [plaintiffs]<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 26a" href="/Ketubot.26a">Babli, 26a</a>. The court will not listen to a claim that the person is the son of a disqualified mother unless confirmed by at least two independent witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked, how do we hold? If they elevated him on the testimony of one person, they should demote him on the testimony of one person. If they elevated him on the testimony of two persons, even if there are many [opposed] they should not demote him<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Since two witnesses confirm a fact by biblical standards, they are as weighty as any number of witnesses.</i>! Rebbi Ḥuna said, it follows the rabbis there<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.2.3">Note 41</a>; to cancel an action of the court, they require full testimony.</i>. But following the rabbis here and Rav Naḥman bar Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.2.3">Note 39</a>.</i>, just as one elevates him on the testimony of two persons, one demotes him on the testimony of two persons.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A woman who was jailed by Gentiles, if because of money matters, she is permitted to her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">She is permitted to her Cohen husband since certainly she was not raped; the Gentiles who hold her for the payment of a debt would be afraid to have to pay the diminution of her value following a rape.</i>; if because of criminal matters, she is prohibited to her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether this means that she is forbidden to her Cohen husband since she certainly would be raped, or even to her Israel husband since she would agree to sleep with one of her jailers who promised to save her.</i>. If a city was conquered after a siege<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Greek χαράκωμα “palisade”.</i>, all wives of priests in it are disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Disqualified from eating heave and from living with their husbands.</i>; but if they have witnesses, even a slave, even a slave girl, those are trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The singular shows that a single witness is acceptable, even though first “witnesses” are mentioned.</i>; but<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the examples that שֶׁ may mean וְ (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Beitzah 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Beitzah.1.3.1">Mishnah <i>Beṣah</i> 1:2</a>).</i> nobody is trustworthy about himself. Rebbi Zachariah, the son of the butcher<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">He was a Cohen.</i>, said, by the Temple! Her hand did not leave my hand from the moment the Gentiles entered Jerusalem until they left! They said to him, nobody testifies on his own behalf.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A woman who was jailed by Gentiles,” etc. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 8:2" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.8.2">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 8:2</a>; quoted <i>in extenso</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 26b-27a" href="/Ketubot.26b-27a">Babli, 26b/27a</a>. The argument is about the part of the Mishnah not quoted here, that the Sages forced the family to accept her as marriageable by a Cohen.</i>: “Rebbi Yose the Cohen and Rebbi Zachariah the son of the butcher testified about a girl who was given as a pledge in Ascalon<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">That she could be sold as a slave if her parents did not pay their debt.</i> and her family excluded her<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Declared her unfit to be married by a Cohen.</i>, but her witnesses testified that she never was in a secret place and was not impure.” Because the witnesses testified that she never was in a secret place and was not impure; therefore, not if no witnesses testified that she never was in a secret place and was not impure<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">She was held for money, and according to the Mishnah should need no witnesses.</i>! Rebbi Eleazar said, there is a difference about a pledge, because many treat her as permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">People assumed that ultimately she would be sold as a slave and, therefore, could be treated as such even beforehand. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27a" href="/Ketubot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>, this explanation is offered by Rava (cf. Introduction to Tractate <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 6" href="/Yevamot.6">Yebamot, p. 6</a>), but is rejected in that Talmud.</i>.
“If because of criminal matters she is prohibited.” Rebbi Yudan the son of Rav Ḥama<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rav” is certainly suspect. He might be identical with Rebbi Ḥiyya from Kefar Teḥumim.</i> from Kefar Teḥumim in the name of Ḥizqiah: Only if she was sentenced to death. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even if she was not sentenced to death<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Their disagreement is confirmed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27a" href="/Ketubot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>.</i>. They said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: A robber’s wife is like a robber<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Greek λῃστής.</i>’<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is Rav’s opinion.</i>.
What are palisades? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi: For examples if bells, chains, and ropes<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Interpretation of Musaphia. The parallel text in <i>Giṭṭin</i> reads וְאִיסְטְרָטִיּוֹת <i>soldiery</i>.</i>, and geese, and chickens and machinery<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Giṭṭin</i> כְּלָבִים “dogs”. The same in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27a" href="/Ketubot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>.</i> surround the town<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">The bells, geese, etc. shall make sure that nobody escapes.</i>. And Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Ḥama<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Here certainlyחמא  is a mistake for חייה, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:9:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.9.3">Note 159</a>.</i> bar Ashi said, it happened that a blind woman was able to flee from there<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">He questions the Mishnah. If a blind woman can escape a siege conducted so that nobody should escape, then everybody could escape and the fact that at the beginning of the siege the wife of a Cohen was in the town does not mean anything.</i>. If there was one breach<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">In the palisades surrounding the town.</i>, it saves all. If there were hiding places, it is questionable<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">It is undecided whether a woman can claim that she was in hiding and not a victim of the entering army.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Abba bar Zavda, Rebbi Isaac bar Ḥaqula, in the name of Rebbi Yudan the prince: Only if there were palisades of that government<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah speaks only of a revolt or a civil war, when the army is ordered to attack (and enslave) the civilian population. A conquering foreign army might plunder, but its soldiers are not under orders to rape all women. In the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 27a:9:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.27a.9.1">Tosaphot (<i>s. v</i>. כאן</a>), the same statement appears in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27a" href="/Ketubot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>, in the name of Ḥizqiah.</i>. But palisades from another government are like robbers.
And even a minor. Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Even a minor, even a relative. Even an underage relative? Let us hear from the following: Ḥananiah from Cartes<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27b" href="/Ketubot.27b">Babli, 27b</a>, the story is told by a R. Ḥanina from Carthage (or Carthagena).</i> was kidnapped, he, his son, and his wife. They came before Rebbi Ḥanina who did not receive them. They came before Rebbi Joshua ben Levi who received them<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">He let the husband, a Cohen, stay married to his wife on the testimony of his own underage son. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27b" href="/Ketubot.27b">Babli disagrees, 27b</a>, and admits the testimony of children and family slaves only if given spontaneously, without being asked; certainly not in the court of a rabbi.</i>. This implies, even an underage relative.
<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">He let the husband, a Cohen, stay married to his wife on the testimony of his own underage son. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 27b" href="/Ketubot.27b">Babli disagrees, 27b</a>, and admits the testimony of children and family slaves only if given spontaneously, without being asked; certainly not in the court of a rabbi.</i> Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef sent after his wife. He said, three students should accompany her, so that if one has to absent himself for his needs, she should still be with two of them. But did we not state: “And they give him two scholars to prevent him from sleeping with her on the trip”? Rebbi Abin said, with her husband that makes three. <sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">“He” is R. Zachariah, the son of the butcher, and “she” is his wife whom he refused to divorce but with whom he could not live.</i> Also he rented a house for her and looked after her upkeep but was never alone with her except in the presence of her children. He applied to himself the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 45:3" href="/Jeremiah.45.3"><i>Jer</i>. 45:3</a>.</i>: “I exercised myself in my worry but found no rest”.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In the following cases, one is trustworthy to testify as an adult about what one saw in one’s minority. A man is trustworthy to say, this is my father’s handwriting, my teacher’s handwriting, my brother’s handwriting<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Even though a minor is not admitted as a witness in money matters, since he testifies only to the genuineness of the document, not about its monetary implications, he can be admitted. A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 3:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).3.3">Tosephta 3:3</a>.</i>; I remember that this person went out in <i>hinuma</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.10">Chapter 1, Note 65</a>, originally a virgin was led to her husband’s house with ὑμέναιοι “wedding songs”. After the war of Bar Kokhba, when these songs were forbidden (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 9:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.9.12.1"><i>Soṭah</i> 9:13, Note 189</a>), the word <i>hinuma</i> changed its meaning. In Babylonia it became “a veil” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 17b" href="/Ketubot.17b">Babli 17b</a>), literally “a slumber cloth” from נום “to sleep”, in Galilee φόρημα “that which is carried”, i. e., “a litter”.</i> and uncovered hair<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The implication of the testimony is that the woman can collect a virgin’s <i>ketubah</i>; but this is not the direct text of the testimony.</i>, or that this man left school to immerse himself to eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">He is a Cohen and was taken by his father to learn how to eat heave in purity.</i>, or that he took his part with us on the threshing floor<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">One Cohen testifies for another that he is a Cohen.</i>, or that this place is <i>bet happeras</i><sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">A “field of pieces” is a lot of which it is known that there had been a grave but which was ploughed over and, therefore, there might be pieces of human bones anywhere and the passage through this lot is forbidden to Cohanim.</i>, or this far we went on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">To indicate the Sabbath boundary, 2000 cubits from the town. There may be implications for money matters, as noted in the Halakhah, if the town expanded or shrank in the meantime.</i>. But a person is not trustworthy to say that X had a right of way at this place<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">In that case, his testimony would directly transfer money’s worth from one person to another.</i>, or that X had a space for eulogies at this place.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Eulogies cannot be delivered in the graveyard; since the dead cannot deliver sermons, sermonizing there would be blasphemy since (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:5" href="/Proverbs.17.5"><i>Pr</i>. 17:5</a>) “he who mocks the poor insults his Maker”. There were public places on the road from the town to the graveyard where eulogies were held; some families had their own spots for eulogies of their deceased. The right to hold these eulogies has monetary value.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It was stated: Only these which they are used to<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">The adult is restricted to testifying about the handwriting of his father, teacher, and brother which he saw in his youth. He is not able to testify about other people’s handwriting even if he saw it frequently.</i>. It was stated: Only if they are supported by others<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The need for two witnesses is not waved.</i>.
Should one not worry that he might be a slave<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">May the child taken after school to be immersed to be purified for heave not be the slave of a Cohen who is entitled to eat it (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>)?</i>? This supports what Rebbi Ḥama bar Uqba said in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 28a" href="/Ketubot.28a">Babli, 28a</a>, in the name of R. Joshua ben Levi.</i>: It is forbidden for a man to teach Torah to his slave<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the Greek and Roman world, the literate person was supposed to be free, not a slave.</i>. But did not Rebbi Ze‘ira say in the name of Rav Jeremiah: A slave is counted as one of the seven readers<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">On the Sabbath, he can be one of the seven people called to read in the Torah. If he is illiterate, how could he possibly read? The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 28b" href="/Ketubot.28b">Babli, 28b</a>.</i>; <i>wayedabber</i> is counted as one of three verses<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">In any public Torah reading, three verses are the minimum. The short verse: “The Eternal spoke to Moses, saying” is a full verse and counted as one of the three; the rule also is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 21b" href="/Megillah.21b"><i>Megillah</i> 21b</a>.<br>This was the version written by the scribe. The corrector crossed out “3” and replaced it by “7”; followed in the <i>editio princeps</i>.</i>! Explain it, if he learned it by himself or his master taught him like Tebi<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel’s slave; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.8.1">Mishnah <i>Berakhot</i> 2:8</a>.</i>. Should one not worry that he might be a slave<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the testimony that the person was receiving heave on the threshing floor.</i>? This supports what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: Women<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Since a Cohen’s daughter loses her claim to heave upon marriage to a non-Cohen and the wife of a Cohen might lose it by divorce, they should not establish customary rights to receive heave directly from the farmer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 10a" href="/Yoma.10a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 10a</a>).</i> and slaves cannot share in the distribution on the threshing floor, but one gives them the gifts of priesthood and levitic status from the house<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Since they are entitled to eat. In all these cases, the Babli restricts the testimony to cases of rabbinic heave (other than heave of grain, wine, and olive oil in the Holy Land).</i>.
May one act in money matters on their testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">For example, on the testimony about the Sabbath boundary in earlier times.</i>? How is that? If everybody knew that the Sabbath boundary was at Reuben’s field; they came and said, this far we came on the Sabbath, and it turns out that this field is in Simeon’s hand. May one take it from Simeon and return it to Reuben<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">If Reuben claims ownership of the field but has no documents; Simeon also has no documents and does not claim to have bought it from Reuben. Neither this nor the following questions are answered.</i>?
Would they be trustworthy to say, we went out to collect unripe figs in the sabbatical year and heard X talking about his wife Y, or woman Z talking about her children<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah gives the adult permission to tell from his youth to confirm another man in the priesthood. Is he also permitted to tell things that would bar a man from the priesthood or even from marrying in the congregation, such as Mr. X telling about the unfaithfulness of his wife, or a woman about the fact that some or all of her children are not her husband’s?</i>?
Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Samuel asked: If they were proven to be false witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">By biblical decree (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:16-21" href="/Deuteronomy.19.16-21"><i>Deut</i>. 19:16–21</a>), the punishment of a false witness is that he suffers the punishment that would have been imposed on the defendant had the testimony stood up in court. Since the entire Mishnah is interpreted to speak about money matters, the punishment in this case would be monetary. (In rabbinic theory, a witness can be proven false only if it is shown that his testimony is impossible, i. e., that he was not at the place he testifies about at the time in question.)</i>, do they have to pay? <sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.1.9"><i>Soṭah</i> 1:1, Note 44</a>.</i> Or it might be, following what Rebbi Abba, Rav Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">If during court proceedings there are contradictory statements, none of which can be shown to be false, there is no proof and the claim of legal possession cannot be denied.</i>, said in the name of Samuel: One does not infer one thing from another in the matter of false witnesses. And here it is so.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 3:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).3.3">Tosephta 3:3</a>.</i>: “That we ate in X or Y’s clipping.” What is clipping? If a man sold his inherited field, his relatives filled amphoras with roasted kernels and nuts and broke them before children. The children were collecting them and saying, X was clipped from his inheritance. When he bought it back, they were doing the same and saying, X returned to his inheritance. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, <sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 38b" href="/Ketubot.38b">Babli 38b</a>. If a Cohen married a woman forbidden to him, his children would not be Cohanim and forbidden as marriage partners to the rest of the family. (Rabbinically, he himself would be barred from all priestly functions until he divorced the unsuitable wife.)</i> also if a man married an unsuitable woman, his realtives filled amphoras with roasted kernels and nuts and broke them before children. The children were collecting them and saying, X was clipped from his family. Whe he divorced her, they were doing the same and saying, X returned to his family.
“In the following cases, one is trustworthy to testify as an adult about what he saw in his minority,” etc. They are only trustworthy as adults<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise, the Mishnah simply could have stated: “In the following cases, one is trustworthy to testify about what he saw in his minority.”</i> about what they saw as minors; therefore, not as minors! There<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.10.2.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 10:2</a>, a statement of R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa.</i>, we have stated: “A woman or a minor are trustworthy when they said, from there a swarm of bees left. He then can enter another’s field and take his swarm.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">The beekeeper has permission to enter to retrieve his swarm but he has to pay for any damage he may cause.</i>” And here, you say so? Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥananiah in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa said this only about a swarm of bees because taking it is not robbery by biblical standards<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 10:2:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.10.2.2-3"><i>Baba Qama</i> 10:2</a>: “Because taking it is not robbery by stipulation.” There, the stipulation is attributed to Joshua at the time of the distribution of the Land. The moment the bees swarm, they really become ownerless. If the right of the beekeeper to the swarm which leaves his hive is by stipulation, then the testimony of a minor also can be accepted by stipulation; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.7.2">13:7, Note 110</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 114b" href="/Bava_Kamma.114b">Babli (<i>Baba Qama</i>114b</a>) agrees.</i>. Rav Oshaiah stated, only if it is swarming<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Some commentators want to refer “swarming” to the minor; that he can testify only as a “swarming minor” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 47b</a>), one for whom it is not clear whether he is a minor or an adult. That does not make sense, in particular because in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.2.2">Yerushalmi (<i>Berakhot</i> 7:2, Note 66</a>) he is simply called “doubtful”.</i>. But not if it clings to a branch<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Ha‘ittur</i> (part 2, p. 115a, Note 135) reads אֲבָל בְּשָׁכֵן לֹא “but not when it is resting.” The text of the ms. is preferable since (a) it is confirmed by the different editorship of <i>Baba Qama</i> and (b) the Mishnah continues with a dispute whether the beekeeper is entitled to cut off the tree branch on which the bees have settled (and then pay the tree’s owner.)</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Mana: Is that not reasonable only when it happens, but not after some time? He said to him, I agree. And we have stated: When is this said? When they testified to what they said<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Ha‘ittur</i>(<i>loc. cit</i>.) reads: בִּוְמַן שֶׁהָעֵדִים בְּמַעֲמָדָן “as long as the witnesses stand (before the court).” The text of the ms. is preferable since (a) by the general rules of procedure no witnesses can testify twice in the same matter (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.3.2">Note 56</a>) and (b) the reference is to the Mishnah here which is interpreted to mean that they are only trustworthy in matters that have pecuniary implications if their testimony is taken as soon as they indicate that they have knowledge of the matter, but not if in the meantime they were subject to outside influences. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 114b" href="/Bava_Kamma.114b">Babli (<i>Baba Qama</i> 114b</a>) admits the testimony of the minor about the swarm of bees “if he speaks without being prompted.”</i>. But if they left and came back, I am saying that they speak out of fear or were seduced.

Chapter 3



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following adolescent girls<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The biblical law prescribes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:28-29" href="/Deuteronomy.22.28-29"><i>Deut</i>. 22:28–29</a>) that the man raping נַעֲרָה בְתוּלָה “a virgin adolescent girl” has to pay her father 50 šeqel and must marry her. In the corresponding law about the seducer of a virgin (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:15" href="/Exodus.22.15"><i>Ex</i>. 22:15</a>) he has to pay if he does not marry the girl. In that paragraph, the adolescent is not mentioned; but since it is stated that the father has the right to withhold her from the seducer, it follows that the girl cannot be an adult; she must be underage or adolescent. An adolescent is a girl in the first 6 months after she grows two pubic hairs, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.10.2.1"><i>Nedarim</i> Chapter 10, Note 1</a>. The age at which the fine can be claimed is the topic of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:9:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.9.2-4">Halakhah 3:9</a>.</i> can claim a fine: From someone who has intercourse with a bastard girl<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, one who rapes or seduces an eligible Jewish girl has to pay. The Mishnah enumerates only those categories where there might be an argument that he should not be required to pay. Each category is discussed in the Halakhah. A bastard is excluded from contracting a valid marriage in the native congregation in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3"><i>Deut</i>. 23:3</a>.</i>, or a Gibeonite or a Samaritan girl, and one who comes to a female proselyte, a kidnap victim, or a slave girl who was redeemed, converted, or freed, at less than three years and one day of age<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>.</i>. Also from one who has intercourse with his sister, or his father’s sister, or his mother’s sister, or his wife’s sister, or his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">If she was divorced or became a widow before the final marriage. The preliminary marriage activates all incest prohibitions implied by marriage.</i>, or his paternal uncle’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">But for a capital crime he does not pay since there cannot be two punishments for one crime.
