Ismael Mišpaṭim</i> p. 285, <i>dR. Simeon bar Ioḥai</i> p. 182.</i>. He said to him, if following him who says “he shall pay the redemption of his person”, the one’s who caused the damage, everything is a fine<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">In that case there is no direct connection between the amount to be paid and the damage caused.</i>. Can one say to him, be also in the clear with Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Is there a moral obligation to pay when there is no legal way to force payment?</i>? Let us hear from the following: It happened that Rabban Gamliel knocked out his slave Tebi’s tooth<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">A slave has to be freed if his owner injures one of his limbs (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:26" href="/Exodus.21.26"><i>Ex</i>. 21:26</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:27" href="/Exodus.21.27">27</a>). On the other hand, there is an interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:46" href="/Leviticus.25.46"><i>Lev</i>. 25:46</a> which reads the statement about Gentile slaves, “for ever you shall have them work for you” that manumission of Gentile slaves without a good reason is forbidden. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.6.2">Yerushalmi (<i>Yebamot</i>11:6, Note 134</a>) this interpretation is ascribed to R. Yose the Galilean, in the Babli to Rav Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b"><i>Berakhot</i> 47b</a>) or R. Aqiba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 3b" href="/Sotah.3b"><i>Soṭah</i> 3b</a>). Another interpretation of the verse [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 47a" href="/Niddah.47a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 47a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Behar, Section 6 6" href="/Sifra,_Behar,_Section_6.6"><i>Sifra Behar Parašah</i> 6(6</a>)] insists that slaves can be used only for work, not sexual purposes.</i>. He came to Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 74b-75a" href="/Bava_Kamma.74b-75a">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 74b/75a</a>, reads the story as a ruling by R. Joshua that anybody who freed himself by confession from a fine cannot be fined even if later the fact is proven by two witnesses. It holds that Rabban Gamliel should have produced witnesses before talking informally to R. Joshua who even in a private setting could not forget about his position of president of the court.</i> and said to him, I found a reason to free my slave Tebi. He said to him, what do you have in your hand? Fines can be imposed only by witnesses! Could they not say to him, do your duty before Heaven? That means one does not tell him, do your duty before Heaven! Rebbi Gamliel ben Avina<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Elsewhere, the name is Ininia (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.12"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Note 61</a>).</i> asked before Rebbi Mana: Does Rabban Gamliel follow him who said, it is permitted to manumit? He said to him, the story in itself implies that it is forbidden to manumit since, otherwise, he could have freed him immediately!

Chapter 4



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Payments for shame, diminution of value, and fine of a seduced adolescent girl belong to her father, as are payments for suffering for the victim of an attack. If she appeared in court during her father’s lifetime, they are the father’s; after the father’s death they are the brothers’<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The claim to the payments is established with the first appearance of the claimants before the court (today one would say with the filing of court papers.) This might be different from the Babli, whose Mishnah requires that there were actual court proceedings during the father’s lifetime. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.7.2">Chapter 3, Note 109</a>. Once the claim is noted as the father’s, upon the father’s death it becomes part of the estate which is inherited by the male children. The inheritance of the brothers is subject to the claims of the daughters for sustenance and dowry. If there are only daughters, the daughters inherit.</i>. If she did not appear in court until after the father’s death, they belong to herself<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Following R. Aqiba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A seduced adolescent girl,” etc. Who stated “adolescent”? Rebbi Meïr. But following the rabbis, even an underage girl<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:9:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.9.2-4">Halakhah 3:9</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 40b" href="/Ketubot.40b">Babli 40b</a>.</i>.
“Payments for suffering for the victim of an attack.” The rape victim. This does not follow Rebbi Simeon since Rebbi Simeon frees the rapist from paying for suffering<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.5.2-4">Halakhah 3:5</a>.</i>.
So far payments that are consequences of sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since biblical law allows a father to marry off his daughter and to pocket the money given for her preliminary marriage, and explicitly states that the father receives the fine imposed on the rapist, it is natural that the father should receive all benefits accruing to him from the fact that she is his underage female child. But since the text nowhere gives monetary rights deriving from male children to the father, the question is who receives payments which do not depend on the sex of the child. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 87" href="/Bava_Kamma.87">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 87a/b</a>, states flatly that the father has no claims to sums due under laws which are independent of the sex of the injured party.</i>. If somebody injured her, blinded one of her eyes, cut off one of her hands, broke one of her legs<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 8:1</a> states that the person causing an injury is liable to pay for diminution of values (permament reduction of earning power), suffering, medical costs, lost earnings (earnings lost while disabled in treatment), and shame.</i>? To whom does he pay, to her or to her father? Rebbi Joḥanan said, he pays to her father; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, he pays to her. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish is of the opinion that her earnings belong to her even before she becomes an adult. Rebbi Joḥanan says, only after she comes of age. Rebbi Abin in the name of Rebbi Hila: They disagree before she comes of age, but after she is an adult everybody agrees that all belongs to her. A <i>baraita</i> supports either one of them. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: If somebody injures somebody else’s daughter or son, the payments for the son must be given immediately<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">As always, “son” or “daughter” means underage child. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 87b" href="/Bava_Kamma.87b">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 87b</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Kamma (Lieberman) 9:8" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Kamma_(Lieberman).9.8">Tosephta, <i>Baba Qama</i> 9:8</a>, the payment due the son is given in the form of a capital value which is transferred to the son on his reaching majority. Everybody agrees that the father has no claim to any sum due to his son.</i>; those for the daughter shall be held as property value<sup class="footnote-marker">8,</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>baraitot</i> of Babli and Tosephta: They belong to the father. This is then explained away as referring only to lost earnings since in the Babli everybody holds that all earnings of an underage daughter belong to the father.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In the opinion of R. David Fraenckel, the father collects the yield of the capital reserved for the daughter until she reaches adulthood and in this the <i>baraita</i> supports R. Johanan.</i>. Rebbi Yudan, the father of Rebbi Judah the father of Rebbi Mattaniah, said that some state it so that beginning and end support Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: If somebody injures his own underage daughter, diminution of value belong to her and he is free from paying for shame and diminution of value<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since he collects payments for shame and diminution of value from the rapist, he collects all payments of this kind due to his underage daughter. If he is the guilty party, he is free since he would have to pay to himself. In Babli and Tosephta, he is never required to pay anything to his own underage children of either sex.<br>It is clear that in the case of the father attacking his own daughter, “diminution of value” must refer to damage done to her physical appearance, not defloration. Since sexual relations with one’s daughter are a capital crime, no payment can be demanded (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.8">Note 111</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.1.7">Chapter 3:1 Note 30</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 7:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.7.1.2"><i>Terumot</i> 7:1 Note 5</a> ff.)</i>. If others injure her, diminution of values belong to her, the rest shall be transformed into property value<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Kamma (Lieberman) 9:9" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Kamma_(Lieberman).9.9">Tosephta <i>Baba Qama</i> 9:9</a> and the <i>baraita</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 87b" href="/Bava_Kamma.87b">Babli <i>Baba Qama</i> 87b</a> nothing is awarded to the father. This is then explained away as referring to children who no longer live at home. In the Yerushalmi, payments for shame and diminution of value belong to the father; of the others he collects the yield of the capital until the daughter reaches adulthood. The treatments in the two Talmudim have very few points in common even though they are based on almost identical tannaitic texts.</i>, but payments for shame and diminution of value belong to her father.
What did you see to say so<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the Mishnah, that if the case came to court after the father’s death the fine is not part of the inheritance but belongs to the girl even if she still is supported by the brothers and her earnings go to them.</i>? Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: “He shall give to the girl; he shall give to the girl’s father.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The following is the interpretation of R. David Fraenckel. In the case of the calumniator it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.19"><i>Deut</i>. 22:19</a>): “[The court] shall fine him 100 pieces of silver and give them to the girl’s father <i>because he calumniated, a virgin of Israel</i>”, stating first the fine and then the reason. But for the rapist it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:29" href="/Deuteronomy.22.29">v. 29</a>): “The man <i>who had lain with her</i> shall give 50 pieces of silver to the girl’s father.” Since the reason is stated immediately after the obligation to pay, it is inferred that the obligation to pay is independent of the availability of the father. Therefore, in the absence of a father, or if the girl is no longer in his <i>potestas</i>, one may disregard the mention of the father and read the verse as an obligation to pay the girl.</i>” How is this? If there were court proceedings<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">This quotes the language of the Babli Mishnah, cf. Note 1.</i> before her father died, you can say “he shall give to the girl’s father”; after the father died you can say “he shall give to her”. If there were court proceedings before she became an adult, you can say “he shall give to the girl’s father”; after she became an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.2.1">Mishnah 2</a>.</i> you can say “he shall give to her.”
From where comes this<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the Mishnah, that if the case came to court after the father’s death the fine is not part of the inheritance but belongs to the girl even if she still is supported by the brothers and her earnings go to them.</i>? Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: “You shall give <i>them</i> as inheritance to your sons to inherit property,” those to your sons and not your daughters to your sons; the verse speaks about the fine<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonian sources, this is a tannaitic statement: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 43a" href="/Ketubot.43a"><i>Ketubot</i> 43a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 16b" href="/Kiddushin.16b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 16b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Behar, Section 6 5" href="/Sifra,_Behar,_Section_6.5"><i>Sifra Behar Parašah</i>6(5</a>). The verse, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:46" href="/Leviticus.25.46"><i>Lev</i>. 25:46</a>, speaks of Gentile slaves. The main import of the verse is that slaves can be bought or inherited following the rules of real estate. As a side remark, it is stated that income due because of daughters does not become part of the estate.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: They<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The father’s heirs.</i> have no right to the fines of the daughter nor to payments for seduction or injuries. When does the fine become due? Rebbi Jonah said, from the first moment<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The act of rape creates the obligation to pay the fine.</i>; Rebbi Yose said, at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The judgment of the court creates the obligation to pay the fine.</i>. Rebbi Yose objected to Rebbi Jonah: Since you say, from the first moment, did we not state: “If there were court proceedings during her father’s lifetime, [the payments] are the father’s; after the father’s death they are the brothers’<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">If this is an argument of R. Yose against R. Jonah, the reference must be to the Mishnah in general and in particular to the last part, not quoted here, which gives the fine to the girl if court proceedings start after the father’s death. If the fine was due from the moment of rape, it should be part of the estate.</i>”? He said to him, that refers to what Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated, “He shall give to the girl; he shall give to the girl’s father.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.1.5">Note 13</a>. The exclusion of the fine from the estate is a biblical decree, independent of when the obligation starts.</i>” Rebbi Jonah objected to Rebbi Yose. In your opinion, since you say, at the end, did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">An enlarged version of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.2.1">Mishnah 2</a>.</i>: “If there were court proceedings before she became an adult, they are the father’s; after she became an adult they belong to herself.” Does an adult have a claim to a fine? He said to him, that refers to what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated, as Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: “Because he mistreated her,” that includes if she was an adolescent and became an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">It is not that an adult rape victim can claim a fine but the verse gives the adult the right to sue for what was done to her as an adolescent.</i>. Does it turn out that this disagreement parallels another disagreement, as we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 7:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.7.2.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 7:2</a>.</i>: “If he stole from his father, slaughtered or sold, and afterwards [his father] died, …, he pays fourfold or fivefold<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The fine for stealing is double restitution; the fine for selling or slaughtering stolen livestock is fourfold or fivefold restitution. The Mishnah requires the thief to pay fourfold or fivefold to the estate (unless he is the sole heir); but if the obligation does not start with the act of larceny then the fine should depend on the relative times of selling/slaughtering and the father’s death, as explained in the next sentence.</i>”? Rebbi Yose objected to Rebbi Ḥaggai<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">This should read: R. Ḥaggai objected to R. Yose (who holds that any obligation starts only with the court’s action.)</i>: In your opinion, since you say that it depends on the court proceedings, should one not state: If he stole from his father, slaughtered or sold during his father’s lifetime but did not appear in court until after his father’s death, he pays twofold<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">There is no doubt that he stole from the estate and has to make good. But since the injured party is no longer alive, according to R. Yose he should not have to pay the extra penalty for selling or slaughtering. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 71b" href="/Bava_Kamma.71b">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 71b</a>, agrees with this reasoning.</i>? But it says fourfold or fivefold! But here<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The verses, in R. Simeon’s interpretation, determine the obligation to pay a fine irrespective of the recipient of the fine. Therefore, the question of the start of the obligation is secondary.</i>, everybody agrees that they belong to herself. The only problem is whether he has to pay to her or to her father.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she did appear in court before she became an adult, [the payments] belong to her father, after the father’s death, they belong to the brothers. If she did not appear in court before she became an adult, they belong to herself. Rebbi Simeon says, if she did not collect before the father died, they belong to herself<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">R. Simeon holds that the father’s rights start only with the delivery of the money as explained in the Halakhah (and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 42b" href="/Ketubot.42b">Babli, 42b</a>). The anonymous majority hold that the payment ordered by the court can be enforced by foreclosure and therefore is ready money and part of the estate.</i>. Her earnings and what she finds, even if she had not collected [by the time] the father died, belong to the brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The earnings of an underage daughter belong to the father since even the money given for a preliminary marriage of an underage daughter is pocketed by her father (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.6.1">Mishnah 4:6</a>). After the death of the father only uncollected earlier earnings go to the estate, not her later earnings. The situation is slightly paradoxical since the brothers are obligated to support their unmarried sister but the father has only a religious, not a legal duty to support his daughters (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:8:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.8.2-15">Halakhah 4:8</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she did appear in court before she became an adult,” etc. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: “The man who had lain with her shall give 50 silver pieces to the girl’s father;” this teaches that the father acquires only by handing over<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 42b" href="/Ketubot.42b">Babli, 42b</a>, this is an Amoraic interpretation of R. Simeon’s position.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, the matter depends on the collection, but the rabbis say, the matter depends on the court procedure. Rebbi Simeon treats it as court decrees<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Money receivable because of a judicial decision is not counted as property to be part of the estate since in many cases the collection of such a judgment depends on the claimant swearing that his claim was not otherwise satisfied and the heirs cannot swear for their deceased father.</i> but the rabbis treat it as a loan<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Outstanding documented loans are property and part of the estate since the debtor would have to prove his case if he claims that the loan had been repaid.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon, he forecloses from the best land; in the opinion of the rabbis he forecloses from average land<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If the debtor is unable to pay cash and the creditor comes to foreclose real estate, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:1</a> states that debts for torts are foreclosed from the most valuable real estate, loans from average, and a <i>ketubah</i> from the least valuable (R. Meïr says, from average.) The value is determined by the going rate for a unit of surface area.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon, the Sabbatical year does not cancel the debt; in the opinion of the rabbis the Sabbatical year cancels the debt<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Only private debts are cancelled by the Sabbatical year, not those created by court order nor those handed over to a court for collection; Mishnah <i>Ševi‘it</i> 10:2. The details of the laws of the Sabbatical relating to this case are explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 10:1:17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.10.1.17"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 10:2, Note 69</a>.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon the firstborn takes a double portion; in the opinion of the rabbis the firstborn does not take a double portion<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The law of inheritance of the firstborn (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.17"><i>Deut</i>. 21:17</a>) states that the father has to give him a double portion (or <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub>, assuming there are only two sons) “of everything that is found with him”, meaning everything in actual possession at the time of death. Money due for an executable court order is money in possession; money due for an outstanding loan is not money in possession since it is subject to the uncertainties of a court proceeding if foreclosure is needed and the position of the firstborn is not privileged in regard to future income.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different version of the entire paragraph is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 43b" href="/Ketubot.43b">Babli, 43b</a>, where R. Ze‘ira points out that the brothers have to support their sisters but do not receive their incomes.</i> Rebbi Ze‘ira sent to Rav Naḥman bar Jacob and Rebbi Immi bar Pappai<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli Rav Abime bar Pappai; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:13:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.13.2">Note 262</a>.</i>: Who owns the earnings of the daughter? They said to him, the diligent said, herself. Who is the diligent? Samuel! Rebbi Mattanah said, it was said in the name of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: Rav.</i> as explanation of a verse: “You shall give <i>them</i> as inheritance to your sons to inherit property,” those to your sons and not your daughters to your sons; the verse speaks about the earnings of the daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonian sources, this is a tannaitic statement: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 43a" href="/Ketubot.43a"><i>Ketubot</i> 43a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 16b" href="/Kiddushin.16b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 16b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Behar, Section 6 5" href="/Sifra,_Behar,_Section_6.5"><i>Sifra Behar Parašah</i>6(5</a>). The verse, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:46" href="/Leviticus.25.46"><i>Lev</i>. 25:46</a>, speaks of Gentile slaves. The main import of the verse is that slaves can be bought or inherited following the rules of real estate. As a side remark, it is stated that income due because of daughters does not become part of the estate.</i>. Rebbi Yudan said, the Mishnah says so: “Her earnings and what she finds, even if she had not collected when the father died, belong to the brothers.” Anything she earned during her father’s lifetime. But what she earned after her father’s death according to everybody is hers<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">If the heirs retained the right to the earnings of the underage daughters, the Mishnah would not have to emphasize that they retain the right to income earned but not collected. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 43a" href="/Ketubot.43a">Babli, 43a</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody gives his daughter in preliminary marriage and she was divorced, in preliminary marriage and she was widowed, the <i>ketubah</i> belongs to him<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">As long as his daughter lives in his house, she is his property. The question whether a preliminarily married woman has a <i>ketubah</i> is treated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.1.2-6">Halakhah 5:1</a>.</i>. If he gave her in definitive marriage and she was divorced, in definitive marriage and she was widowed, the <i>ketubah</i> belongs to her. Rebbi Jehudah says, the first <i>ketubah</i> is his. They said to him, from the moment he gave her in definitive marriage, he no longer has any power over her<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Even an underage girl is emancipated in civil law by marriage.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody gives his daughter in preliminary marriage,” etc. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said, the reason of Rebbi Jehudah is to encourage a man to give an ample dowry to his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">This presupposes the earlier practice that the <i>ketubah</i> was written and the dowry given at the time of the preliminary marriage, in contrast to the later practice which postponed these transactions to the time of the definitive marriage. In that case, the dowry has to be returned at the dissolution of the preliminary marriage and it is clear that the father wants to have the dowry returned to him. {Many Jewish communities in the Middle Ages enacted rules which guaranteed the return of the dowry to the wife’s family if the marriage was of short duration and/or there were no children; the best known being the rules of the community of Ṭulaiṭula (Toledo), <i>Šulḥan ‘Arukh Even Ha‘Ezer §</i>118.)</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Isaac: Rebbi (Meïr)<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Meïr is not mentioned otherwise in this connection, it seems that this is a scribal mistake for R. Jehudah.</i> learned from the calumniator<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The calumniator accuses his definitively married wife, who is an adolescent, of infidelity while preliminarily married. If his accusation is false, he pays the fine to the father, not to his wife. This shows that the father retains an interest in the money coming to his adolescent daughter even if she is definitively married. In the opinion of Maimonides (<i>More Nebukhim</i>, part 3, Chapter 49) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.19">Nachmanides (Commentary to <i>Deut</i>. 22:19</a>), the fine of the calumniator is 400 <i>zuz</i> since he wanted to steal from her the <i>ketubah</i> sum of 200 <i>zuz</i> by his accusation; as a thief he has to pay double restitution to the injured party. This supports R. Jehudah’s contention that the father is the injured party. (Interpretation following R. Baruch Fränkel-Teomim.)</i>. Did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state: If she whored while in her father’s house and he calumniated her<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">He is called a calumniator by the biblical text because he has to accuse his wife of adultery in front of the court, and for that he is punished if his accusation is not sustained. For the court to act on his accusation he has to produce two witnesses to the adultery since as husband he is his wife’s relative and barred from acting as a witness for or against her.</i> after she became an adult, he is not flogged<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The expression “they shall punish him” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:17" href="/Deuteronomy.22.17"><i>Deut</i>. 22:17</a> is interpreted to mean “they have him flogged.”</i> nor does he pay 100 tetradrachmas<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:18" href="/Deuteronomy.22.18"><i>Deut</i>. 22:18</a> it is written: They shall fine him 100 silver pieces and give them to the adolescent’s father. If the girl is no longer an adolescent, the punishment does not apply.</i> but either she or the false witnesses are executed by stoning<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The standard punishment for adultery by a preliminarily married adolescent, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a>. If the witnesses for the husband are shown to be false (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.5">Note 86</a>), they are stoned since any false witness is punished by the sentence that would have been passed upon the accused if the testimony had been true.</i>? Rebbi Mana asked before Rebbi Yose: Think of it, if he calumniated her when she was an adolescent and now she is an adult? He said to him, we heard that he pays to her father<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">As long as the accusation is made when the girl is an adolescent, the verse gives the money to the father.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said before Rebbi Ze‘ira: I am wondering how could the rabbis compare a <i>ketubah</i> to a fine when they are not comparable! For the <i>ketubah</i> is an obligation from the first hour<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The groom has to accept all obligations of the <i>ketubah</i> before a definitive marriage is possible.</i> but the fine is only at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The fine is due only upon sentencing.</i>; and you say so? He said to him, who says that to you? Even the [obligation of the] fine is from the first moment<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that the act of rape creates the obligation to pay the fine rather than the court’s sentence.</i>. It turns out that Rebbi Mana is like Rebbi Jeremiah and (like Rebbi Yose ben Ze‘ira)<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This probably should read: וְרִבִּי יוֹסֵי כְּרִבִּי זְעִירָא. “and Rebbi Yose like Rebbi Ze‘ira,” that the obligation of the fine starts with the rape and, therefore, fine and <i>ketubah</i> are parallel institutions; the rules of the fine may inspire rules of <i>ketubah</i>.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a proselyte woman converted together with her daughter and the latter committed adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">As a preliminarily married adolescent.</i>, she is [executed] by strangling<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">As any adulteress. The special rules of the preliminarily married adolescent are addressed to “a virgin of Israel”. She may be a virgin, if she was converted before she reached the age of three years and a day, but she is not of Israel.</i>; she has neither a door of her father’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The adulterous preliminarily married adolescent is stoned there (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.21"><i>Deut</i>. 22:21</a>).</i> nor 100 tetradrachmas<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">If her husband had falsely accused her.</i>. If she was conceived not in holiness but born in holiness<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Her mother converted while pregnant.</i>, she is [executed] by stoning; she has neither a door to her father’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Since her mother s relationship with her father was a relationship of Gentiles at the moment of conception, it is non-existent for Jewish law.</i> nor 100 tetradrachmas. If she was conceived and born in holiness<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Her mother became pregnant after her conversion. Holiness is Judaism.</i>, she is a Jewish woman in all respects. If she<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This now refers to Jewish adolescents, rather than to proselytes. The sentence probably is the missing Mishnah 5.</i> has a father but no door to her father’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Her father owns no house.</i>, or a door to her father’s house but no father<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">If her father died.</i>, she is stoned since the door to her father’s house was mentioned only as a commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A biblical commandment only requires execution to the letter if it is characterized as either חוּקָּה or תּוֹרָה.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a proselyte woman converted,” etc. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.19"><i>Deut</i>. 22:19</a>.</i>: “For he calumniated a virgin of Israel”. That excludes this one<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The girl not born Jewish.</i> who is not from Israel. “For he calumniated a virgin,” to include the proselyte whose conception was not in holiness but her birth was in holiness, that she should be stoned. Why does one not add her for the fine<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The verse refers to the fine when she was falsely accused, not to her death when she was proven to be an adulteress.</i>? You cannot do that; as Ḥizqiah stated<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 44b" href="/Ketubot.44b">Babli, 44b</a>, that is a statement of R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>: We understand that it was said “they shall stone her<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.21"><i>Deut.</i>22:21</a>, speaking of the girl proven to be an adulteress: “her town’s people should stone her with stones that she dies.”</i>,” does that not imply that she dies? Why does the verse say, “and she shall die”? But there must be another one who is stoned but (she)<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text of ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> but one has to read וְהוּא פָטוּר for וְהִיא פְטוּרָה. As the Babli argues, there must be one case which is added only for this kind of death penalty.</i> [he] is free; who is that? That is the proselyte whose conception was not in holiness but who was born in holiness.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:13" href="/Deuteronomy.22.13"><i>Deut</i>. 22:13</a> ff.</i>: “If a man takes a wife, comes to her, and hates her.” He is not guilty unless he marries her definitively, has intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46a" href="/Ketubot.46a">Babli, 46a</a>, this interpretation is attributed to R. Eliezer ben Jacob, in <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 235, to R. Jehudah, as dissenting opinions.</i>, and accuses her not to be a virgin. “He puts a libel on her”; I could think even if she spoiled a dish<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Which according to the House of Hillel could be a cause for divorce, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:8:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.8.4">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:10</a>.</i>? It says here “a libel” and it says later “a libel”<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">V. 14 reads: “He attacks her by libel and calumniates her, <i>and</i> he says, I took this woman, came to her and did not find her to be a virgin.” One could read this as meaning that the libel and the claim of missing virginity are two different actions by the husband. But v. 17 makes it clear that there is only one action: “He attacks her by libel, saying, I did not find your daughter to be a virgin.” The same argument is in <i>Sifry Deut</i>.</i>. Since “a libel” later implies whoring, so also here it means whoring. Since “a libel” later implies from the place of virginity, so also here? From where if he came upon her otherwise<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">He sets himself up for punishment even if during the first intercourse he did not penetrate. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46" href="/Ketubot.46">Babli disagrees, 46a/b</a>; <i>Sifry Deut</i>. agrees.</i>? The verse says, “and he calumniates her”, in any way. “He said, I took this wife<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">לָקַחְתִּי can be translated as: “I bought”.</i> and came to her,” that excludes assignations<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">If a man buys somebody’s underage daughter as an indentured servant (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:7-11" href="/Exodus.21.7-11"><i>Ex</i>. 21:7–11</a>) he can later <i>assign</i> the price he paid for her as bride money either for himself or for his son and declare her preliminarily married without investing an additional penny in her. But since the money originally was given for her work as a servant, not for marriage, the husband cannot say “I bought her as a wife”.</i>; “I took”, to exclude the one waiting for her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The levir did not give any money, his deceased brother did.</i>; “I took”, to exclude the preliminarily married one<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, money was given but the marriage not consummated.</i>.
“I took”, that excludes assignations<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">If a man buys somebody’s underage daughter as an indentured servant (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:7-11" href="/Exodus.21.7-11"><i>Ex</i>. 21:7–11</a>) he can later <i>assign</i> the price he paid for her as bride money either for himself or for his son and declare her preliminarily married without investing an additional penny in her. But since the money originally was given for her work as a servant, not for marriage, the husband cannot say “I bought her as a wife”.</i>. Rebbi Jonah said, even following him who says that the money from the start was given for assignation<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2</a> (59b 1. 40), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 19a" href="/Ketubot.19a">Babli 19a</a>, the only other places where the question is raised, only R. Yose ben R. Jehudah holds that the original money was not given with the idea that eventually it would be used as brides-money. But everybody agrees that the verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:8-9" href="/Exodus.21.8-9"><i>Ex</i>. 21:8–9</a> require a separate action of assignment which is distinct from the original acquisition; therefore, the marriage of the indentured servant is not a “buy”.</i>. “I took”, to exclude the one waiting for her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The levir did not give any money, his deceased brother did.</i>; not only for the earlier teachings that the obligation of the levirate precedes that of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, but even according to the later teachings that the obligation of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> precedes the obligation of levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:6:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.6.8"><i>Yebamot</i> 12:7, Note 140</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 1:7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.1.7"><i>Bekhorot</i> Mishnah 1:7</a>.</i>. “I took”, to exclude the preliminarily married one<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, money was given but the marriage not consummated.</i>.
“I came to her and did not find her a virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:14" href="/Deuteronomy.22.14"><i>Deut</i>. 22:14</a>.</i>.” Should we not worry that he found and made disappear<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">It is difficult to accept that the court should take the case simply on the husband’s statement, in particular because the husband cannot be cross-examined as a witness since he is related to his wife and relatives are barred from being witnesses.</i>? The husband brought witnesses that she committed adultery while in her father’s house. “This is proof of my daughters virginity.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:17" href="/Deuteronomy.22.17"><i>Deut</i>. 22:17</a>. The father also is barred from being a witness in a case involving his daughter.</i>” Should we not worry that this is bird’s blood? The father brought witnesses to prove perjury by the husband’s witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The case is a regular criminal case to be adjudicated following all rules of criminal procedure; the only new feature is the punishment inflicted on the husband if his case is not sustained in court.<br>In talmudic law, there are unreliable witnesses and there are perjurers. If the story of the witnesses does not hold up under cross-examination, or if the witnesses’s story is contradicted by equally trustworthy witnesses, the witnesses are unreliable and their testimony is not accepted as basis of a judgment. Perjury with its attendant penalties (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:18-20" href="/Deuteronomy.19.18-20"><i>Deut</i>. 19:18–20</a>) only is impossible testimony, i. e., that the opposing party produces witnesses to testify that the other witnesses could not possibly have seen what they testify to since they were at another place at the time they pretend to have seen certain things.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, in this paragraph there are witnesses, witnesses of perjury, and witnesses of perjury of the witnesses of perjury: The husband says, these are witnesses that she whored in her father’s house. The father brought witnesses to prove perjury of the husband’s witnesses. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said: The father brought witnesses to prove perjury of the husband’s witnesses. And the husband brought witnesses to prove perjury of the father’s witnesses. Some Tannaïm state: “If this was true,” that the father found witnesses to prove perjury of the husband’s witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The penalties mentioned in this paragraph can only be imposed if the case is one of proven formal perjury.</i>.
“And they spread out the cloth.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:17" href="/Deuteronomy.22.17"><i>Deut</i>. 22:17</a>. It was proven that this sentence cannot mean what it says.</i>” That is all simile. Rebbi Ismael stated: That is one of three verses in the Torah which have been written as simile<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Deut</i>. 237; in Finkelstein’s opinion not of the original <i>Sifry</i> text. A slightly enlarged version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:8:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.8.2-3"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 8:8</a>, 26c 1. 6.</i>. “If he gets up and walks outside on his support, the one who hit him is not prosecuted.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:19" href="/Exodus.21.19"><i>Ex</i>. 21:19</a>, speaking of a person who deliberatly injures another. <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Mišpaṭim</i> 6; <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> p. 174.</i>” Could anybody think that one walks in the market and the other is executed because of him? But what is “on his support”, in his health<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">If the injured person regains his health but then has a relapse and dies, the person who injured him cannot be prosecuted for murder.</i>. “If the sun shone on him, he has blood.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:2" href="/Exodus.22.2"><i>Ex</i>. 22:2</a>, speaking of a thief digging a tunnel under a house, who can be killed with impunity if found out since in the tunnel “he has no blood”.</i>” Does the sun shine only on him? But just as the sun is particular that it brings peace to the entire world, so also this one, if one knows that [the other] is at peace with him and he kills him, he is guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 72" href="/Sanhedrin.72">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 72a/b</a>, this can only be asserted of a father coming to steal from his son. In the opinion of the Yerushalmi (Note 89) it cannot be asserted of anybody. Cf. <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Mišpaṭim</i> 13; differently in <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> p. 192.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46a" href="/Ketubot.46a">Babli 46a</a>, <i>Sifry Deut</i>. §237. In the interpretation of the Babli, R. Eliezer ben Jacob requires that the court hear testimony about virginal blood.</i>: Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob says, the words should be said as they are written. What means “the words should be said as they are written”? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, he is not guilty unless he marries her definitively, has intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46a" href="/Ketubot.46a">Babli, 46a</a>, this interpretation is attributed to R. Eliezer ben Jacob, in <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 235, to R. Jehudah, as dissenting opinions.</i>, and accuses her not to be a virgin. “They spread the cloth<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:17" href="/Deuteronomy.22.17"><i>Deut</i>. 22:17</a>. It was proven that this sentence cannot mean what it says.</i>”. Not that “they spread the cloth” but until the things become clear like a cloth<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, new cloth was simply bleached, not dyed. חִװֵר really means “pale”; only in a derivative sense it means “logically consistent”.</i>. Assi said, “they spread the cloth”, the witnesses are not stoned, nor is the husband flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas, until they say: you were with us at a certain place<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This is necessary to prove the witnesses guilty of perjury, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.5">Note 86</a>.</i>, and the husband hired them to testify falsely<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">This is necessary to impose penalties on the husband.</i>. If they said, you were with us at a certain place, but they did not say, the husband hired them to testify falsely? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">This attribution seems most unlikely. Since the argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46a" href="/Ketubot.46a">Babli, 46a</a>, as a tannaitic statement attributed to R. Jehudah, it is more likely that the original text was: In the name of R. Simeon ben Ioḥai.</i>: It is said here “putting”, it is said there “putting”. Since “putting” there means money, also “putting” here must mean money<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is a little more explicit in the Babli. It is written here, “he puts a libel on her”. It is written in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:24" href="/Exodus.22.24"><i>Ex</i>. 22:24</a>: “you shall not charge interest to [the recipient of a loan].” From the principle that a word has only one meaning, one infers that the husband “puts” a libel on his wife by paying for it; then according to this opinion he cannot be punished unless he actually pays for the false testimony.</i>. But did we not state: He did not say to the witnesses, come and testify in my case, but they came on their own, he is not flogged nor does he pay 100 tetradrachmas but either she or the false witnesses would be stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The standard punishment for adultery by a preliminarily married adolescent, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a>. If the witnesses for the husband are shown to be false (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.5">Note 86</a>), they are stoned since any false witness is punished by the sentence that would have been passed upon the accused if the testimony had been true.</i>’<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 46a" href="/Ketubot.46a">Babli agrees, 46a</a>.</i>? Because he did not say. But if he said, even if he did not hire them it is as if he hired them<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">This disagrees with the opinion given before. The husband must actively be involved in bringing the witnesses before the court but he does not have to pay them in order to become criminally liable. In general, a person who hires another to commit a crime (or simply induces him to commit a crime) cannot in general be prosecuted since “there is no agent for sin” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 42b" href="/Kiddushin.42b">Babli <i>Qiddušin</i> 42b</a>); exeptions to that rule must have a biblical basis.</i>. If the father brought two groups of witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Who then are proven to have perjured themselves. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 9b" href="/Sanhedrin.9b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 9b</a>, discusses only the simple case that the same witnesses testify both about the other witnesses and the husband’s involvment.)</i>. One side say, you were with us at a certain place. The other side say, the husband hired them to testify falsely. It is obvious that those who said, you were with us at a certain place, are stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since, if their testimony had been true, the husband’s witnesses would have been stoned.</i>, and those who said, the husband hired them to testify falsely, are flogged and pay 100 tetradrachmas<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Since they testify to the involvement of the husband in the prosecution of his wife.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, neither by these not by those are they flogged and pay 100 tetradrachmas<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Since they testify to the involvement of the husband in the prosecution of his wife.</i>, but they are flogged because of “you shall not testify as a false witness against your fellow man.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:17" href="/Exodus.20.17"><i>Ex</i>. 20:17</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 2b" href="/Makkot.2b">Babli disagrees, <i>Makkot</i> 2b</a>, since “a prohibition violated without an action is not prosecutable” (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.1.1.1"><i>Nedarim</i> 1:1, Note 2</a>).</i>”
Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: If the father brought witnesses to prove the perjury of the husband’s witnesses; but the father’s witnesses were proven perjurers, is he flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas by the judgment of three and the witnesses are stoned by the judgment of 23<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Money matters are adjudicated in a court of 3 judges (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:1-3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.1-3.3">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:1</a>), capital cases by a court of 23 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.4.1">Mishnah 1:4</a>). The anonymous majority hold that potential cases of flogging are adjudicated by a court of 3 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>). Therefore, flogging and payment of a fine can be imposed by the same court.</i>? He said to him, if the father’s witnesses are not proven perjurers, is not the husband flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas by the judgment of three and the witnesses are stoned by the judgment of 23<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">It is not necessary to discuss the case that the witnesses to perjury are found to be themselves perjurers; the same result can be obtained assuming the husband’s witnesses are perjurers. Then also the husband’s case is one of flogging and fine, in the competence of a small court, but that of the witnesses is a capital case which requires the large court.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 8b" href="/Sanhedrin.8b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 8b</a>, this is reported as the opinion of R. Ḥiyya bar Abin and the Babylonian Rava.</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira is of the opinion that there are two different proceedings. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: There is only one proceeding<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Since the husband can only be flogged and fined if the witnesses are stoned, the husband’s case is an appendix to that of the witnesses.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Abbahu: “To the town’s Elders”, that is a court of three members; “to the gate”, that is a court of 23<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> is not found in other sources. The reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:15" href="/Deuteronomy.22.15"><i>Deut</i>. 22:15</a>, where the girl’s father is instructed to go “to the town’s Elders, to the gate.” The double determination is read as instruction to appear before two different courts.</i>. He explains it following Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr says that he is flogged and pays<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.1.7">Chapter 3:1, Note 30</a>. He will agree that the two punishments of the husband are in the competence of one court. The Sages, who hold that in general the culprit who is flogged does not pay, must agree that the husband can only be flogged by the court which sentences the witnesses for perjury.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:1-3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.1-3.3">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:1</a>.</i>, we have stated: “The seducer, the rapist, and the calumniator [are judged] by three [judges], the words of Rebbi Meïr; but the Sages say, the calumniator by 23 since it is a potential capital case.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Since the wife has to be stoned if found to have committed adultery as a preliminarily married adolescent.</i>” Rebbi Mana said, they disagree about the preliminarily married adolescent. Rebbi Meïr says, she loses her <i>ketubah</i> in a court of three and is stoned by a court of 23; but the Sages say, at the same place which sentences her to be stoned she loses her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Since the husband can be freed from his obligations under the <i>ketubah</i> only if the wife is found guilty, a set-up in which two courts could come to contradictory conclusions is impossible.</i>. But in the case of the calumniator, everybody agrees that by the court in which the witnesses are stoned, the husband is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to him, would they differ where it was not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:1-3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.1-3.3">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:1</a> states clearly that there is a disagreement in the case of the calumniator. If there were a disagreement in the case of the preliminarily married adolescent, it would have to be stated in the Mishnah.</i>? But they differ about the calumniator! Rebbi Meïr says, he is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas by the judgment of three and the witnesses are stoned by the judgment of 23; but the rabbis say, by the court in which the witnesses are stoned, the husband is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas. But by the case of the preliminarily married adolescent, everybody agrees that at the same place which sentences her to be stoned she loses her <i>ketubah</i>. [It turns out that Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun follows Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Mana [follows] Rebbi Abbahu]<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Text of the Constantinople edition. Text of the ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>: וְאַתְיָא דְרִבִּי מָנָא כְרִבִּי זְעִירָא וּדְרִבִּי יוֹסֵי בֵּירִבִּי בּוּן כְּרִבִּי אַבָּהוּ “Rebbi Mana follows R. Ze‘ira and R. Yose bar Abun follows R. Abbahu.” It is possible to explain that version, in that R. Yose bar Abun was forced to invent the case that the witnesses for perjury were perjurers since in the case of the husband he follows R. Abbahu and that R. Mana, who in the main rule disagrees with R. Ze‘ira, accepts his explanation that the <i>baraita</i> is R. Meïr’s.</i>.
The husband is never flogged, nor does he pay 100 tetradrachmas, unless the witnesses are stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Since only in this case is the husband’s guilt established.</i>. When is he obligated for the fine? Rebbi Jonah said, at the end. Rebbi Yose said, from the first hour<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">They switch their positions from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.1.2-6">Halakhah 1</a>, in the case of the fine imposed on the rapist. “At the end” means after sentence is imposed, “the first hour” is the moment he falsely accuses his wife of adultery.</i>. Rebbi Yose objected to Rebbi Jonah: In your opinion, since you say at the end, can he be flogged and made to pay 100 tetradrachmas by a court of three and the witnesses stoned by a court of 23<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">If the obligation of the fine is a consequence of the conviction of the witnesses, flogging and the fine should be mentioned after the sentence imposed on the witnesses and not before.</i>? Rebbi Mana said, even according to Rebbi Yose one could ask the question following him who holds that perjured witnesses need to be warned. If they did not warn them, is he flogged and made to pay 100 tetradrachmas by a court of three; are the witnesses stoned by a court of 23<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">If the witnesses are shown to be perjurers but they cannot be punished because they were not warned of the consequences of perjury, the fact that they cannot be convicted frees the husband and, therefore, his obligation could not be from the first moment.</i>? Rebbi Abbamari said, who is that who says so<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody holds that witnesses need special warnings since they must be informed by the court about the importance of their testimony. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 33a" href="/Ketubot.33a">Babli agrees, 33a</a>.</i>?
Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina: One who rapes or seduces an orphan is free<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">He does not have to pay the criminal fine, but the payments enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.5.1">Mishnah 3:5</a> in civil law are still due.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, this is in dispute; following Rebbi Yose the Galilean. But following Rebbi Aqiba a fine is due, and the fine belongs to herself<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.4.2-4">Halakhah 3:4</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">This now refers to Mishnah 5.</i> says so: “She has neither a door to her father’s house nor 100 tetradrachmas;” is she not like an orphan<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah refers to the girl whose mother converted while pregnant with her, who legally has no father since by conversion her mother became a new person, unrelated to her prior existence.</i>? Rebbi Immi and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi both say, one who calumniates an underage girl is free<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">He does not have to pay the criminal fine, but the payments enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.5.1">Mishnah 3:5</a> in civil law are still due.</i>. Rebbi Hoshaiah said, that is correct. If she were an adult who was not warned, would there be any case<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Even the adolescent, who is an adult in criminal law, cannot be executed for adultery if at the moment of her adultery she was not duly warned in front of two witnesses that she would risk the death penalty if she went ahead with her adultery. It was stated before that the husband pays only if his witnesses are stoned. But his witnesses can be stoned only if the woman would be stoned had their testimony been true. If there are no witnesses to the warning, the witnesses to the adultery cannot cause her to be executed. Therefore, if these witnesses are found perjured, they cannot be stoned. Therefore, the husband cannot be flogged and fined.</i>? And an underage girl who was warned is like an adult who was not warned<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">A minor cannot be criminally liable. Since the underage wife could under no circumstances be stoned, the husband cannot possibly be flogged and fined. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 44b" href="/Ketubot.44b">Babli, 44b</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Hamnuna in the name of Rav Ada bar Aḥawa: She cannot be executed unless she is an adolescent at the time of the execution. What is the reason? “They shall execute the adolescent at her father’s door<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:18-21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.18-21"><i>Deut</i>. 22:18–21</a>.</i>.” But did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state<sup class="footnote-marker">128a</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Notes 46–49.</i>: If she whored in her father’s house and [the husband] calumniated her after she became an adult, he is not flogged nor does he pay 100 tetradrachmas but either she or the witnesses are executed by stoning. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav Ada bar Aḥawa: “If he escaped after being sentenced and then his pubic hair grew fully.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.6.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 8:6</a>, speaking of the unruly son, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18-21" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18-21"><i>Deut</i>. 21:18–21</a>, who can be judged only if he is an adolescent, in the 6 months after he grew two pubic hairs before the pubic hair is fully grown. If he was sentenced as an adolescent, he can be executed as an adult.</i>” There, you can say “they shall execute the adolescent” who whored; can you say here “they shall execute him”, the son<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.21"><i>Deut</i>. 22:21</a> says only “they shall stone him”, without indicating age.</i>?
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 45b" href="/Ketubot.45b">Babli 45b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 10:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.10.4">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 10:10</a>.</i>: One stones a preliminarily married adolescent girl who whored at her father’s door. If she does not have a father’s house’s door one stones her where she whored. If it was a Gentile town one stones her at the court’s door. Also, a person who practiced idolatry one stones at the place where he worshipped. If it was a Gentile town one stones him at the court’s door. But did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state: “Take the blasphemer out from the encampment,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:14" href="/Leviticus.24.14"><i>Lev</i>. 24:14</a>. The same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45b" href="/Sanhedrin.45b">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 45b</a>.</i>” this teaches that the court sits inside and the place of stoning is outside. Rebbi Yose said, there is a difference: The place where he went astray is the place where he was found, is the place where he was judged, is the place where he was stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 45b" href="/Ketubot.45b">Babli, 45b</a>, this is a tannaitic statement about <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>, that the idolator has to be stoned “at your gates.” In <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 148: “The gate where he was found, not the gate where he was judged.”</i>. “For she did a foul deed in Israel.” This one befouled all of Israel, for she came to whore in her father’s house. The bad growth they grew shall come and foul up them and their growth.

Halakhah 5



Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The father has the benefit to give his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">As long as she is not an adult.</i> in preliminary marriage by money<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">He can pocket the money.</i>, contract<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">He can make himself be paid for signing the marriage contract.</i>, or intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a> states that a woman can be preliminarily married either by money (given by the groom to his bride or her father) or by a contract (by which the groom signs his intention to marry his bride) or by intercourse (which has to be performed in front of two witnesses to be legally valid); the latter way is frowned upon in practice.</i>; he has the right to what she finds and to her earnings, to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Nedarim</i> Chapters 10–11.</i>, and to receive her bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">As long as she is not definitively married.</i>, but cannot eat usufruct in her lifetime<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">If her mother is dead and she inherits from her maternal grandfather, all yield from that property is hers and has to be kept in trust for her. But if she dies unmarried, the father inherits from her.</i>. If she is definitively married, the husband in addition<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to what she finds and earns, and to dissolve her vows.</i> eats usufruct in her lifetime<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Of all property she brings into the marriage; cf. Chapter 8.</i> but is required to pay for her upkeep, her ransom<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">If she is kidnapped.</i>, and her burial. Rebbi Jehudah says, even the poorest in Israel should not provide for her less than two flutes and one wailing woman.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The father has the benefit to give his daughter,” etc. One understands that the father has a benefit from money or contract. By intercourse? Explain it that [the groom] said to [the father]: When your daughter becomes mine by intercourse, this money shall be your property.
“He has the right to what she finds.” Rebbi Zakkai from Alexandria asked: How do you treat what she found on [her] field<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">A field which she inherited from her mother’s side and to whose yield the father has no claim.</i>, as a find or as her usufruct? If you treat it as usufruct it is hers.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">While R. Zakkai’s question is not answered, the fact that only one interpretation is analyzed further seems to indicate that anything she finds on her field belongs to her.</i>.
“If she is definitively married, the husband in addition eats usufruct in her lifetime,” as a regulation they instituted that he should oversee his wife’s property and eat from it. Is it also thus for the father? Without incentives the father overseas the daughter’s property; should he eat? “He is required to pay for her upkeep and her ransom.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">This is an unnecessary quote from the Mishnah; the text continues to refer to the wife’s property.</i>” It was stated: If the husband said, it is impossible for me to eat and to oversee, one does not listen to him<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is a generally valid regulation, the court cannot relieve the husband from caring for his wife’s property. (But the husband can cede the administration of the property to his wife by a private contract as long as no court is involved.)</i>; but if the father said, I shall oversee if I can eat, one listens to him<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The court may allow the father a reasonable fee for administering his underage daughter’s property if this is to her advantage.</i>.
“And her burial.” It was stated: If the husband refused to bury her, the father buries her and recovers his expenses in court. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, they said only, the father. Therefore, a third party cannot recover. Rebbi Yose says, both the father and also a third party can recover. There is a parallel disagreement, as we have stated there: “He is required to pay for her upkeep, her ransom, and her burial.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The reference here really should be to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.2.1">Mishnah 13:2</a>; the parallel to this paragraph, formulated in a slightly different way, is at the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:2:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.2.2-7">Halakhah 13:2</a>. The essence of that Mishnah is that if the husband is absent without providing for his wife and a third party supports the wife without either having the wife sign a document that she recognizes the money for support as a loan, or being appointed her guardian by the court, he has no regress on the husband upon his return.</i>” Rebbi Ḥaggai said, they said only, a third party. Therefore, the father can recover. Rebbi Yose says, neither the father nor a third party can recover. In the opinion of Rebbi Ḥaggai, both for burial and for upkeep the father can recover, a third party cannot recover. In the opinion of Rebbi Yose, for burial both the father and also a third party can recover because it is unthinkable that his wife should be thrown to the dogs<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">If the community buries her, they can recover the costs from the husband. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 47a" href="/Ketubot.47a">Babli, 47a</a>, refers this to the husband: If somebody tells his heirs not to bury him, the community buries him and recovers the cost from the estate since one will not allow a man to have himself buried with taxpayers’ money in order to increase his estate.</i>. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:2" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.2">Tosephta 4:2</a>, <i>Śemaḥot</i> 14:7. The fee of the preacher who eulogizes the deceased can be recovered from the husband.</i>: At a place where it is customary to eulogize, one eulogizes.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> She always remains in the father’s power<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">For all the rights and duties enumerated in the preceding Mishnah.</i> until she enters the husband’s power for definitive marriage. If the father entrusted her to the husband’s emissaries she is in the husband’s power. If the father went with the husband’s emissaries, or the father’s emissaries went with the husband’s emissaries, she is in the father’s power. If the father’s emissaries entrusted her to the husband’s emissaries<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Even though they will accompany the bride to the place of the nuptials and participate in them.</i>, she is in the husband’s power.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “She always remains in the father’s power,” etc. Not only to the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the original Yerushalmi Mishnah did not read “until she enters the husband’s power for definitive marriage” but “until she enters the bridal chamber” with most Mishnah mss. and the Munich ms. of the Babli. S. Lieberman emphasizes on several occasions that it seems that the scribe of the Leiden ms. obtained the Mishnah text not from the Yerushalmi text he was copying but from a separate Mishnah ms.</i> but to a house where the bridal chamber is. In which way? A banquet hall<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τρικλίνιον, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:5:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.5.10"><i>Berakhot</i>3:5, Note 229</a>.</i> and a bedroom<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοιτών.</i>, the bridal chamber being the bedroom, and she entered the banquest hall. In which respect? Rebbi Eleazar said, to inherit from her<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 48b" href="/Ketubot.48b">Babli, 48b</a>, this is Samuel’s opinion, that after the signing of the <i>ketubah</i> document, the husband’s rights and obligations are activated not by the formal “seven benedictions” of the definitive marriage but by the bride entering the husband’s power.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 48b" href="/Ketubot.48b">Babli, 48b</a>, he is reported to hold that after this moment, if she is divorced or widowed before entering the bridal chamber, she legally becomes a divorcee or widow after definitive marriage. This parallels R. Ze‘ira’s interpretation here, that the husband acquires all rights even if he cannot exercise them yet.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, even though Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, to dissolve her vows, he agrees that he does not actually dissolve them until she enters the bridal chamber. Rebbi Huna said, a <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49a" href="/Ketubot.49a">Babli, 49a</a>.</i> supports Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “To whore in her father’s house,” that excludes the case that the father’s emissaries entrusted her to the husband’s emissaries, after which she<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">If now she should commit adultery before two witnesses after being duly warned that it would be a capital crime, she is treated as a definitively married woman, not as a preliminarily married adolescent.</i> should not be stoned but strangled.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The father is not obligated to support his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ketubah</i> contract with his wife does not force a father to feed his underage or adolescent daughter even though he has the right to receive her earnings.</i>. This inference did Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah explain in the vineyard of Jabneh<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">The seat of the central rabbinic authority in the time between the two wars with the Romans.</i>: “The sons shall inherit and the daughters be supported.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The original Hebrew text of the <i>ketubah</i> stipulation quoted in Aramaic in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.1">Mishnah 12</a>.</i>” Since the sons do not inherit before their father’s death, neither are the daughters supported before their father’s death.
