<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The father is not obligated to support his daughter,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:8" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.8">Tosephta 4:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49a" href="/Ketubot.49a">Babli 49a</a>. In these sources, and in the <i>editio princeps</i> corrected following the Babli, “R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa said, it is <i>obligatory</i> to feed one’s daughters.</i> It is meritorious to feed one’s daughters, unnecessary to say this of sons. Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa said, it is meritorious to feed one’s daughters. Some Tannaim state, the sons are most important<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49a" href="/Ketubot.49a">Babli, 49a</a>, identifies this Tanna as R. Meïr, the one who gives preference to the daughters as R. Jehudah, with the same reasoning as given here. In the Tosephta only the first opinion is given, anonymously.</i>. Some Tannaim state, the daughters are most important. He who says the sons are most important, for the study of Torah. He who says the daughters are most important, that they should not go outside for bad behavior<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">That they should not be forced into prostitution.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Ḥananiah<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49b" href="/Ketubot.49b">Babli, 49b</a>, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.12"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Note 59</a>, and eventually in the next paragraph, he is called R. Jehudah bar Ḥanina.</i>: They voted at Usha<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The temporary meeting place of the supreme religious authority in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kohkba; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.12"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Note 60</a>.</i> that a man has to feed his underage children. Rebbi Joḥanan said, we know who participated in that vote<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">They were important enough to accept their vote as judicial practice. (In today’s practice of the Israeli Rabbinate, support is required to the end of the child’s schooling.)</i>. Uqba came before Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">He was sued for child support by either his wife or the local overseer of charity who did not want to spend public funds on Uqba’s children.</i> who said to him: Uqba, feed your children. He answered, Master, why<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">There is no biblical authority to force me to feed them.</i>? He said to him: Evil Uqba, feed your children. Rebbi Ulla<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Probably R. Hila (Ilaï), the tradent of R. Simeon ben Laqish’s statements in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49b" href="/Ketubot.49b">Babli, 49b</a>.</i> said, a Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.11.1">Mishnah 5:13</a>. The Mishnah shows that the husband has less revenue and more expenses because of the feeding of his baby.</i> confirms that a man has to feed his underage children, since we have stated there: “If she is nursing, she has to work less and one adds to her food.”
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Ḥananiah: They voted in Usha that if one writes all his property over to his sons, he and his wife are supported by them<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the property be given unconditionally and immediately, it is a law promulgated at Usha that the sons have to care for their parents (Rashi, on Babli 49b).</i>. What is the situation of underage children? Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah, but some say it in the name of Rebbi Judah ben Ḥanina: He, his wife and his underage children are supported by them.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">The adult sons who inherited from their living parents.</i> What about his widow<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">She cannot collect her <i>ketubah</i> since her husband died without leaving an estate. Therefore, if the sons supported her during their father’s lifetime, they must support his widow indefinitely.</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, this was asked but not resolved. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, it was asked and resolved, Rebbi Abba said, it seems reasonable that if she ate during her husband’s lifetime then she eats; otherwise, she does not eat. It says only “if one writes”; that excludes the seller. If he wrote to his sons<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">The sons received only part of the estate; the remainder was sold to outsiders and the proceeds used up.</i> and sold to others, what is here reasonable? Rebbi Ḥanina said, I would not give him anything. Rebbi Mana: Is it not reasonable that they hire him a servant and marry a wife to him so she should serve him<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">As a matter of honoring father and mother, not as a monetary obligation deriving from their partial inheritance.</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph, transmitted here in rudimentary form, is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:4:2-5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.4.2-5.4"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:4</a>. The variant readings are indicated by <b>גי.</b> In this text, “here” means the text in <i>Giṭṭin</i>, “there” is a different setting in <i>Yebamot</i> 6:6 (Notes 115,116). The topic of the Mishnah in <i>Giṭṭin</i> is the enforcement of the <i>ketubah</i> contract for the support of a wife and her daughters; the question is whether the <i>ketubah</i> also covers granddaughters. Similarly, here the question is whether the rules of Usha require a man to feed his underage grandchildren (if they have no father or the father is incapacitated.) In <i>Yebamot</i>, the question is whether grandchildren count as much as children in the obligation “to be fruitful and multiply.” The answer there is a qualified yes, while here and in <i>Giṭṭin</i> it is no.</i> What is the situation of grandchildren? Rebbi Mana said, [grandchildren are like children. Rebbi Yose said, grandchildren are not like children.] Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Mattaniah were sitting together. They wanted to say, the same situation applies to grandchildren here as there. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina said to him, inheritance by biblical law jumped on grandchildren<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">In biblical obligations, grandchildren can be counted as children. But in rabbinic institutions involving monetary obligations, only what is specified counts.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish in the name of Rebbi Jehudah bar Ḥaninah: They voted in Usha that one who insults an Elder or hits him has to indemnify him fully for his shame. It happened, that somebody who insulted an Elder and hit him had to indemnify him fully for his shame. They said, it happened to Rebbi Jehudah ben Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.5.2"><i>Baba Qama</i> 8:6</a> (6c) that the “full payment for shame” is one Roman <i>libra</i> of gold.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is essentially from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:12-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.12-13"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Notes 58–64</a>, as noted by the scribe when he stopped copying the entire paragraph. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 50a" href="/Ketubot.50a">Babli, 50a</a>.</i> Rebbi Simeon bar Laqish said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Ḥanina: They voted at Usha that a person may donate a fifth of his property for good deeds. How far down? Rebbi Jeremiah and Rebbi Abba bar Cahana; one said corresponding to <i>terumah</i> and the <i>terumah</i> of the tithe, the other said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 3:9" href="/Proverbs.3.9"><i>Prov.</i> 3:9</a>): “Honor the Eternal with your property” … “corresponding to the first of all your yield”<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Peah</i> it is clear that the inference is from the part of the verse which is not quoted here.</i>. Rebbi Gamliel bar Ininia asked before Rebbi Mana: Does it mean one fifth every year? {One studies this in the first Halakhah of Peah.}<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is essentially from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:12-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.12-13"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Notes 58–64</a>, as noted by the scribe when he stopped copying the entire paragraph. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 50a" href="/Ketubot.50a">Babli, 50a</a>.</i> Will he not die<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">If every year he gives away one fifth of his property, soon he will have nothing. This part is formulated differently in <i>Peah</i>: A person is permitted to give to charity one fifth of his property once; from thereon in he is restricted to one fifth of his income lest he die of hunger in the future.</i>? But lest he die in the future.
<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah the text essentially is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:3:3-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.3.3-9"><i>Yebamot</i> 15:3, Notes 34–79</a> (whose readings are denoted by <b>י</b>); its Tannaïtic parts are paralleled in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:9-13" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.9-13">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:9–13</a>.</i> Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah insisted on interpreting the <i>ketubah</i>: Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah explained: ‘The sons shall inherit and the daughters shall be supported.’ Since the sons can only inherit after their father’s death, so the daughters can claim support only after their father’s death.
The House of Hillel insist on interpretation of the <i>ketubah.</i> Hillel the Elder explained it, using the vernacular. In Alexandria they were writing that a man there became betrothed to a woman. Another man abducted her from a public place. When this came before the Sages, they intended to declare [the children] as bastards. Hillel the Elder told them, bring your mothers’ <i>ketubah.</i> They brough their mothers’ <i>ketubah.</i> They found written there: “When you enter my house you shall be my wife according to the laws of Moses and the Jews.”
The House of Shammai insist on interpretation of the <i>ketubah.</i> As the House of Shammai explain, the text of her <i>ketubah</i> document teaches, for he writes: “If you would be married to another man you shall take the amount I wrote for you.” The House of Hillel reversed themselves and taught following the House of Shammai.
Rebbi Meïr insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Meïr explained, if somebody accepts a field as a contractor, at the moment [he] accepts, one estimates how much it is expected to yield and he gives to [the owner]. Because the standard contract reads: “If I let it lie fallow and do not work on it, I shall pay as if from the best.”
Rebbi Jehudah insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Jehudah explained: A man brings for his wife any sacrifice she is obligated for, even if she ate suet or desecrated the Sabbath. Also, Rebbi Jehudah says, once he divorces her, he is no longer obligated for her, for she writes to him “any other obligations that may come to you from me from earlier times.”
Rebbi Yose insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Yose explained: In a place where one treats the <i>ketubah</i> as a loan, she collects the entire amount. Where one doubles, she collects only half the amount. Rebbi Eleazar the caper grower insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Eleazar the caper grower explained: nobody is permitted to buy domesticated or wild animals or birds unless he has food prepared for them. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa explained: a person lending money to another person should not take pledges except in court; he should not enter [the debtor’s] house to take the pledge, for he writes to him: “It will be paid by the property that came to my hand that I shall acquire corresponding to this [sum].”<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">In the text of <i>Yebamot</i>: “a person lending money to another person should not take pledges from him for more than the value of the loan since he writes for him: It will be paid …” That text should be considered the correct one since (a) it refers to the text of the contract and (b) the statement here is a biblical commandment (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:10-11" href="/Deuteronomy.24.10-11"><i>Deut.</i> 24:10–11</a>).</i>
Rav Huna insists on interpreting the contract text. Rav Huna explained: “The sons shall inherit but the daughters must be fed.” Since the sons inherit movables, the daughters also are fed from movables. Samuel said, the daughters are not fed from movables. A Mishnah supports Samuel: “The female children you shall have from me shall dwell in my house and be supported from my property.” It was stated on this: From real estate but not from movables. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda said: Rav Huna follows Rebbi and Samuel follows Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar, as it was stated: “One uses both guaranteed property and non-guaranteed property for the support of the wife and the daughters, the words of Rebbi. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, guaranteed property may be taken by sons from sons, by daughters from daughters, by sons from daughters, and by daughters from sons. But non-guaranteed property may be taken by sons from daughters but not by daughters from sons.” They said, Rav Huna reversed himself. They said, that was well done, <i>ketubah</i> is a biblical commandment but support of the daughters is from their words. May their words uproot a biblical commandment? It must be that they differ about the money contained in their mother’s <i>ketubah.</i> [Even if you say, they differ about the money contained in their mother’s <i>ketubah.</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Inserted here by the corrector who prepared the <i>editio princeps</i>; missing in <i>Yebamot</i>.</i> But is the money stipulated in their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> not also real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.19"><i>Deut</i>. 22:19</a>.</i>?
“If somebody who works his wife’s property has the intention of divorcing her and goes and takes from the ground, he is quick and is rewarded. If somebody who works the property of prisoners heard that they prepare to return, goes and takes from the ground, he is quick and is rewarded. These are properties of prisoners: In any case where his father, brother, or any person from whom he might inherit, went overseas; it was heard that they died, and he went to work the inheritance. But property of abandoning persons one takes out of their hands. These are properties of abandoning persons: In any case where his father or any person from whom he might inherit went overseas, he did not hear that they died, but he went to work the inheritance. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, I heard that there is no difference between prisoners and abandoning persons. But property of broken persons one takes out of their hands. These are properties of broken persons: In any case where his father, brother, or any person from whom he might inherit, went overseas, and his whereabouts are not known. Samuel says, the prisoner is one who left involuntarily. If he had left voluntarily he would have given him instructions. The abandoning person is one who left voluntarily. You should know that he had the intention of keeping [the relative] off his property since he left voluntarily and did not give him instructions. Rebbi Abba, Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel: Movables do not fall under the rules of broken people. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Yebamot,</i> “Rav Jehudah”. It is impossible to determine the original reading since R. Jacob bar Aḥa, a student of R. Joḥanan, was a great collector of the sayings of earlier authorities.</i>: <sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">There are two sentences from <i>Yebamot</i> missing here which are needed to make sense of the statement. “Standing grain ready to be harvested and grapes ready to be harvested are movables [for the rules of broken people]. Rav Sheshet asked”.</i> Those date palms of Babylonia which do not need grafting, is it not reasonable that we should treat them like standing grain ready to be harvested and grapes ready to be harvested?

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he did not write her a <i>ketubah,</i> a virgin collects 200 [<i>zuz</i>] and a widow 100, for this is a stipulation enforced by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that there is a marriage creates the financial obligations of the husband even in the absence of a contract. This stipulation bars any <i>mut‘a</i> marriage (temporary marriage for sexual pleasure only). A similar institution, ἄγραφος γάμος, “marriage without written contract,” which nevertheless implied all monetary obligations of the husband towards his wife, was known in contemporary Egyptian native law; cf. R. Taubenschlag, <i>The Law of Greco-Roman Egypt in the Light of the Papyri,</i> New York 1944, Chapter IIB3.</i>. If he substituted something<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah of the Babli: “A field.” Since the lien of the <i>ketubah</i> is a mortgage (primarily or exclusively) on all the husband’s property, it is reasonable to assume that in the Yerushalmi version likewise it is understood that a piece of real estate was offered to satisfy the <i>ketubah</i> claims.</i> valued at a mina for the 200 <i>zuz</i> and did not write “that all my property is guaranty for your <i>ketubah,</i>” he still is obligated by it, for this is a stipulation enforced by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, all the stipulations mentioned in this and the following Mishnaiot are not written in <i>ketubah</i> contracts following the Babylonian style; the fact that a document is designated as <i>ketubah</i> makes these stipulations enforceable.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he did not write her a <i>ketubah</i>,” etc. The Mishnah is Rebbi Meïr’s, since Rebbi Meïr said<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, all the stipulations mentioned in this and the following Mishnaiot are not written in <i>ketubah</i> contracts following the Babylonian style; the fact that a document is designated as <i>ketubah</i> makes these stipulations enforceable.</i>: “Anybody who writes for a virgin less that 200 [<i>zuz</i>] or a mina for a widow engages in immoral intercourse.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Meïr, the existence of a marriage is proof of a responsibility of the husband or his estate for at least 200 or 100 <i>zuz</i>; that amount can therefore be foreclosed. A similar argument is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51a" href="/Ketubot.51a">Babli, 51a</a>, where, however, the position is taken that R. Jehudah agrees that in the absence of evidence to the contrary the obligation of the husband’s estate is 200 or 100 <i>zuz</i> but that by <i>written</i> agreement of the wife this obligation can be reduced.</i>” Who needs it<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">The position of R. Meïr in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a> does not yet explain why a document of indebtedness does not have to be produced in court.</i>? Rebbi Meïr! Even though Rebbi Meïr says that any contract which does not contain an alienation clause<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">R. Meïr holds that a loan document which is not a mortgage, i. e., does not contain a clause which states that in the case of nonpayment some of the debtor’s property will be alienated to the creditor, cannot be enforced in court. In that he is opposed by R. Jehudah who holds that the absence of such a clause is a scribal error (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51" href="/Ketubot.51">Babli 51a/b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.6.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:6</a>).</i> cannot be foreclosed, here he agrees that it can be foreclosed<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51b" href="/Ketubot.51b">Babli, 51b</a>, qualifies this statement that R. Meïr permits foreclosure only from real estate not otherwise pledged while the Yerushalmi will permit foreclosure from real estate pledged after the marriage was contracted (because the wife’s lien cannot be removed.)</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he did not write her “if you are kidnapped I shall ransom you and bring you back as my wife,” or for Cohens’ wives “I shall return you to your country<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is forbidden to him as a probably rape victim, he has to divorce her and pay her <i>ketubah</i> in addition to the ransom he paid for her.</i>,” he is obligated,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the ransom will exceed the value of her <i>ketubah.</i></i> for this is a stipulation enforced by the court.<br>If she was kidnapped he is obligated to ransom her. If he said, here is her divorce document and her <i>ketubah,</i> let her redeem herself; he is not allowed to do that<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">He is not allowed (a) to cap possible ransom by the value of the <i>ketubah</i> and (b) to deduct the amount of the ransom from her <i>ketubah.</i></i>. If she was smitten<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">If she became sick.</i>, he is obligated to heal her. If he said, here is her divorce document and her <i>ketubah,</i> let her redeem<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">This probably is a scribal error. In all other mss. (Babli and independent Mishnah mss.): תְּרַפֶּה “let her heal herself.”</i> herself; he is allowed to do that<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation given for the rule is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta 4:5</a>, that ongoing medical expenses are part of the upkeep promised in the <i>ketubah.</i> This means, as explained in the Halakhah, that medical costs which can be determined beforehand are not part of the husband’s obligation but ongoing costs for chronic conditions are to be paid by the husband just like ongoing costs for food are his responsibility.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he did not write her “if you are kidnapped I shall ransom you,” etc. “If she was kidnapped he is obligated to ransom her,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta 4:5</a>.</i>: If a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">The widow of childless man who waits to be married in levirate. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 52a" href="/Ketubot.52a">Babli, 52a</a>, reports the same rule for any widow.</i> was kidnapped, the heirs do not have to ransom her. Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">This should be “Rav”.</i> Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: Not only if she was kidnapped when her husband was still alive but even if she was kidnapped after the husband’s death, the heirs do not have to ransom her. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">This name does not appear otherwise in the Talmudim. In the Babli, Rav reports his argument in the name of his uncle, the elder Rabbi Ḥiyya (bar Abba bar Aḥa Karsala).</i>: The Mishnah supports Rav: “And bring you back as wife;” there is no “wife”.
“For Cohens’ wives ‘I shall return you to your country.’” Does this mean, exactly to her country? To a civilized place.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">To a Jewish community where he pays her the <i>ketubah</i> and where she can find a new husband.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph refers to the statement about medical costs.</i> Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel stated<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta 4:5</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 52b" href="/Ketubot.52b">Babli, 52b</a>.</i>: For any hurt which has a fixed medical fee, she is healed from her <i>ketubah</i>. If it does not have a fixed medical fee, she is healed from the estate<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">If she is a widow who preferred to be sustained by the estate instead of collecting her <i>ketrubah</i> in cash.</i>. As the following: A woman came to Rebbi Joḥanan. He asked her: Did your doctor give a fixed price? She said, no<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">He told her to insist the doctor be paid for each visit, not to give the treatment on an all-inclusive fixed price. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 9:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.9.4.2-3"><i>Baba Batra</i> 9:6</a>, 17a 1. 20, the woman is identified as a relative of R. Simeon ben Abba. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 52b" href="/Ketubot.52b">Babli, 52b</a>, R. Joḥanan is reported to have sided with the heirs, telling them to get an all-inclusive price from the doctor.</i>. Did not Rebbi Ḥaggai say in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: “Do not turn yourself into an pleader<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Abot</i> 1:8. It is unethical for a judge to dispense legal advice.</i>,” that one shall not disclose the judgment to a party? He knew her to be honest<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">She would not change her behavior based on the information received from him.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he did not write her “the male children you will have from me shall inherit the amount of your <i>ketubah</i> in addition to their part with their brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife should die before the husband and the husband inherits from her then, if the husband dies, the sons of his several wives can first claim their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> (the ≥200 <i>zuz</i> from the husband and all the dowry noted in the document) from the estate; only the remainder is divided between the sons (with an eventual first-born son taking two parts.)</i>”; he is obligated, for this is a stipulation enforced by the court.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he did not write her “the male children,” etc. That is what Rebbi Immi said, that a man should be disposed to give generously to his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">If he knows that the dowry will remain the possession of his grandchildren, he will be more inclined to provide his daughter with a dowry. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 52b" href="/Ketubot.52b">Babli, 52b</a>, the explanation is ascribed to R. Joḥanan and the recommended amount is 10% of the father’s property.<br>The same statememt is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:2:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.2.2-4">Halakhah 10:2</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">A similar, but more tersely and clearly formulated text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba Batra</i> 8:6</a>.</i> There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Batra</i> 8:6</a>. The biblical law of inheritance (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:8-11" href="/Numbers.27.8-11"><i>Num.</i> 27:8–11</a>) states that inheritances should be distributed to the next of kin; it is implied that all persons of the same degree of relationship shall be treated equally (except for the rule of the firstborn. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:15-17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.15-17"><i>Deut.</i> 21:15–17</a>). In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.5.1">Mishnah 8:5</a>, the anonymous majority states that a person may make a will in which he distributes his property unevenly. The will will be valid if formulated in the language of gifts, invalid in the language of inheritance. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.6.1">Mishnah 8:6</a>, R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa states that even the language of gifts is acceptable if and only if the recipient is a legal heir directly in line; e. g., one son among many, but not a daughter in the presence of sons since daughters inherit only if there are no sons. If there are no sons, R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa will accept unequal distribution of the estate among the daughters. The Mishnah here is formulated following Ben Beroqa since it accepts unequal distribution of the estate even without writing (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 131a" href="/Bava_Batra.131a">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i> 131a</a>).</i>: “Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa says, if he speaks about somebody who is a legal heir, his statements are valid, but about somebody who is not a legal heir, his statements are invalid.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, Ben Beroqa spoke only about a son among sons or a (daughter)<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">This was the first (correct) word written by the scribe who then (incorrectly) crossed it out and replaced it by “son” to produce a meaningless sentence.</i> son among daughters, not about a daughter and brother or a brother among daughters. Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: There was a case and Rebbi decided following Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Rebbi asked Nathan the Babylonian, why did they say that practice follows Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa? Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: What is the reason? He asked Nathan the Babylonian, why did the Sages say that practice follows Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah in <i>Ketubot</i> is anonymous, it represents practice and it follows R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 131a" href="/Bava_Batra.131a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 131a</a>, presents the question in slightly different form and ends up by denying its validity. The Babli holds (seemingly against the Yerushalmi) that property rights based on a <i>ketubah</i> stipulation are strictly weaker than those mentioned in the <i>ketubah</i> contract in that they cannot be asserted against third parties.</i>? Are you not the one who stated “shall inherit”? (He said to him, you stated “shall take”; he came to him)<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">The fragments of sentences in this parenthesis make no sense; they belong to nearby texts and the scribe seems to have been unsure about the order of the sentences. It is best to leave the parenthesis unexplained.</i>. He said to him, there is no “shall inherit” but “shall take”<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">It is not quite clear whether this is Rebbi’s or R. Nathan the Babylonian’s statement. It changes the language of the Mishnah, that the woman’s sons “shall take her <i>ketubah</i>”, making the transaction one of a gift valid from the time of the marriage. Therefore, the rules of inheritance are irrelevant and there is no relation between the Mishnah here and Ben Beroqa’s statement about wills. (Everybody agrees that by a gift “valid now but executed only after my death”, a person can freely dispose of his assets without regard to biblical laws of inheritance.)</i>. When he came to his father, he said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">When Rebbi came to Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel, the latter affirmed the text of the Mishnah as the correct one.</i>: you disadvantaged Nathan the Bablylonian; there is no “shall take” but “shall inherit”. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, this is what he told him: I made an error in what I taught you; there is no “shall take” but “shall inherit”. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, this is one of the leniencies of the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations. In general, a person can transfer rights only by a document; here even verbally. In general, a person cannot transfer rights to somebody not yet existing; here to the non-existing<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">At the date of the marriage, no sons are yet born. For everybody except R. Meïr, the unborn cannot be the recipient of a gift (other than through a guardian); the same argument is in the Babli, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said before Rebbi Ze‘ira: I am wondering how the rabbis can compare <i>ketubah</i> to inheritance, for inheritance is a biblical law but <i>ketubah</i> is from their words<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketubah</i> is purely a rabbinic institution (or better, a generally followed practice in post-exilic Judaism, inspired by but not derived from the biblical “bridal gift”.) This is the opinion of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel, cf. the last paragraph of this tractate.<br>Since the Mishnah text is Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s, the question is relevant.</i>; how can one argue this? Even if you say that <i>ketubah</i> is a biblical law, do they not agree that the stipulations of the <i>ketubah</i> are from their words<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, there is no connection between the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations and the laws of inheritance.</i>?

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> “The female children you will have by me shall live in my house and be supported by my estate until they are married to men”; he is obligated, for this is a stipulation enforced by the court.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> ““The female children you will have by me,” etc. Rav Ḥisda said, if they became adults, they lost the support<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Since support for daughters is stipulated only until marriage, the support ends once the usual age for marriage, adolescence, has passed.</i>. If they married, they lost their dowries<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">If after the father’s death she did not claim her dowry at the moment of marriage, she is presumed to have renounced her right to a dowry which on average is 10% of the estate (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.2-4">Halakhah 6:6</a>). In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:17" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.17">Tosephta, 4:17</a>, this is the opinion of R. Simeon ben Eleazar.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:17" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.17">Tosephta 4:17</a>, opinion of the anonymous majority.</i>: “If they became adults without being married or were married without being adults, they lost their support but not their dowries.” Rebbi Abin in the name of Hila: They all agree on the following: If a widow sues the heirs, she says I did not receive my <i>ketubah</i>, but the heirs say you received your <i>ketubah</i>. Before she remarried, the burden of proof is on the heirs that she received her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">There is a parallel text in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96" href="/Ketubot.96">Babli, 96a/b</a>, but it deals with the case that the widow comes at the end of a year and claims not to have received support for the past year. There is no mention of <i>ketubah</i> in the Babli since it requires either that the widow present the <i>ketubah</i>, which will be torn up upon payment, or bring witnesses that she married at a place where routinely no <i>ketubah</i> is written; then she has to deliver a receipt.</i>. After she remarried, the burden of proof is on her that she had not received her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Since all support by the estate stops upon remarriage of the widow, it would be a most unusual circumstance if the <i>ketubah</i> was not liquidated at that time.</i>. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.1">Mishnah 6:6</a>.</i>: “If an orphan was married off by her mother or her brother and they wrote her [a dowry of] 150 <i>zuz</i>, after she grows up she can extract from them.” The reason, because she was underage. Therefore, a grown up gave up her claim<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">She is supposed to have renounced her claim if she did not request her dowry at the time of the marriage; the underage girl may wait until she becomes an adult able to act in legal matters.</i>. Explain it that she had received partial payment<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">If the quarrel is not about the entire amount of the <i>ketubah</i>, there can be no argument that the widow renounced her claim.</i>. Did not Rebbi Avina say in the name of Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">This must be Rav Assi, quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 136a" href="/Bava_Batra.136a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 136a</a>.</i> Assi: If a firstborn took as a simple [brother]<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The ms. formבְּפָשׁוּט , in his quality of “simple” brother (i. e., taking only one portion in contrast to the firstborn’s double share), is good rabbinic Hebrew style and does not have to be changed into כְּפָשׁוּט.</i>, this is <i>prima facie</i> evidence that he gave up his claim. Still, if she had received part payment. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, this one did not take anything from his primogeniture<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, the case of the firstborn is different from that of widow or orphan girl. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 136a" href="/Bava_Batra.136a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 136a</a>, this is very much in dispute since a dissenting opinion holds that the firstborn only lost his right to re-open past distributions but that he is not restrained from asserting his double claim in the future.</i>. There came a case before Rebbi Mana, who wanted to act following Rav Ḥisda. Rebbi Ḥananiah said to him, did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state, “if they became adults without being married or were married without being adults, they lost their support but not their dowries”? He said to him: I quoted a tradition, you quoted a <i>Baraita</i>. Let the tradition be disregarded before the <i>Baraita</i>.
““And you shall dwell in my house”. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: If he slept with her when she still was in her father’s house, did he then activate all <i>ketubah</i> stipulations or is that only by definitive marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">The question is not answered. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 53a" href="/Ketubot.53a">Babli, 53a</a>, it is stated that <i>ketubah</i> stipulations do not apply to the preliminarily married woman. This is obviously implied by the question raised here.</i>? Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: If she renounced her <i>ketubah</i>, what is the situation? She renounced her rights but not those of her children<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">One could read this sentence as a question: She renounced her own rights (which she can do following R. Jehudah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a>), but was she able to renounce those of her children? In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 53a" href="/Ketubot.53a">Babli, 53a</a>, the question is answered in the positive: she renounced all rights. Under the influence of the Babli, the commentators chose the interpretation as a question.</i>.

Halakhah 13

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> “And you shall dwell in my house and be supported by my property during all of your widowhood”; he is obligated, for this is a stipulation enforced by the court.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">This text is difficult in several places. There exists a version quoted and explained by <i>Rosh</i> (R. Asher ben Ieḥiel) which in itself is not without problems, see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:13:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.13.2">Note 267</a>. As the reader will easily verify, the Aramaic portions of the text have been adapted to Babylonian spelling. Therefore, the text cannot serve as witness to the details of the text: <br>רִבִּי זְעִירָא שָׁלַח שָׁאִיל לְרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יַעֲקֹב וּלְרַב אֲבִימֵי בַּר <i>פָּפָּא</i>. לֹא הָיָה שָׁם בַּיִת <i>מַאי</i>. אָֽמְרוּ לֵיהּ. הַיּוֹרְשִׁין שׂוֹכְרִין לָהּ בַּיִת. מִיכָּן <i>וָאֵילַךְ</i> הִיא אוֹמֶרֶת קַרְקַע <i>וְהֵם אוֹמְרִים</i> מָעוֹת. הַדִּין עִם הַיְּתוֹמִים. כְּהָדָא. חָדָא <i>אִיתְּתָא</i> הֲוָה פֶורנָהּ עֶשְׂרִין דֵּינָרִים. וַחֲוָה תַמָּן חַד בַּיִת <i>טָב</i> עֲשָׂרָה דֵינָרִין. אָתָא עוֹבְדָא קוֹמֵי רִבִּי חֲנִינָה. אָמַר. אוֹ <i>יְהָבוֹן</i> לָהּ בַּיְתָא אוֹ <i>יְהָבוֹן</i> לָהּ עֶשְׂרִים דֵּינָרִין. אָמַר <i>לֵיהּ</i> רִבִּי מָנָא. מִכֵּיוָן דְּלֵית בֵּיתָא אֶלָּא <i>בָעֲשָׂרָה דֵּינָרִין</i> כְּמָאן דְּלֵית לָהּ פֶורְנֵה אֶלָּא <i>בָעֲשָׂרָה דֵּינָרִין</i>. מִיכָּן וָהֵילַךְ הִיא אוֹמֶרֶת קַרְקַע וְהֵן אוֹמְרִין מָעוֹת. הַדִּין עִם הַיְּתוֹמִים. <br>Rebbi Ze‘ira <i>sent to ask</i> Rav Naḥman bar Jacob and (Rebbi)<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">This title is in error; it might be “Rav”. In the Babli, he has no title.</i> Abime bar Pappai: What if there was no house? They said to him, the heirs rent a house for her. One concludes<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation of מכאן ואילך as a technical term follows <i>Qorban Nathanael</i> (the standard commentary to <i>Rosh</i>),<i>ad loc</i>.</i> that if she says real estate and they say money, the law sides with the heirs. As the following: A woman’s <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Greek φερνή “nuptual gift” used as synonym with <i>ketubah,</i> representing both the sum the husband gave from his side and the dowry which has to be returned at the dissolution of the marriage.</i> was twenty denars<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Gold denars, at the usual rate of 25 silver <i>zuzim</i> for one gold denar a total of 500 <i>zuz</i>.</i>, and there was a house worth at most ten denars. The case came before Rebbi Ḥanina who said, either they give her the house or they give her twenty<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">In the version of the ms., supported by the quote in <i>RAN</i> (R. Nissim Gerondi, in his commentary on Alfasi, 20b in the Wilna ed.), R. Ḥanina tells the heirs either to give the widow (who probably is not their mother) the house to dwell in or to pay the <i>ketubah</i> in full, where R. Mana disagrees and holds, in accordance with the practice of the Babli, that the <i>ketubah</i> cannot be worth more than the real estate which guarantees it. In <i>Rosh’s</i> version, the entire discussion is only about the right of the widow to an apartment.</i> denars. Rebbi Mana said, since the house is not worth more than 10 it is as if her <i>ketubah</i> was only 10<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence certainly is correct in <i>Rosh</i> and incorrect in the ms.</i>. One concludes that if she says real estate and they say money, the law sides with the heirs. <br>The following is Rosh’s explanation (Chapter 4, #29): “This is the explanation: What are the rules if there was no house there appropriate as a dwelling for the widow and the orphans together? They said to him, the orphans rent a house for her and if she says, real estate, i. e., ‘I want to dwell in my husband’s house’, but they say money, ‘we rent you an apartment but we want to dwell [in the house]’, the law sides with the heirs since she has no property rights in the real estate, only an easement. Therefore, they can rent an apartment for her and they can dwell in that house. {And what we say that she has the right to continue living in her husband’s dwelling (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.3.1">Mishnah 12:3</a>), that is if the house is large enough for all but they want to move her to a lesser apartment.} In the case of that woman, whose <i>ketubah</i> was 20 denars and the only apartment in the estate was a house worth 10 denars (Note of <i>Qorban Nathanael</i>: insufficient to pay the <i>ketubah</i>), R. Ḥanina ruled that either they give her the house or they pay her 20 denars. On that, R. Mana(I) said that she should not take the real estate but that they could give her 10 denars since she has no property rights in the real estate, only an easement. Therefore also in general, since she has no property rights to the apartment, only a claim to be given one, they can move her out of the apartment and rent a different one for her.</i> Rebbi Ze‘ira asked Rav Naḥman bar Jacob and (Rebbi) Abime bar Pappai: What if there was no house? They said to him, the heirs rent a house for her. One concludes that if she says real estate and they say money, the law sides with the heirs. As the following: A woman’s <i>ketubah</i> was twenty denars, and there was a house worth at most ten denars. The case came before Rebbi Ḥanina who said, either they give her a house or they give her twenty denars. Rebbi Mana said, since the house is not worth more than 20 it is as if her <i>ketubah</i> was only twenty. One concludes that if she says real estate and they say money, the law sides with the heirs.

Halakhah 14

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> This<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">The stipulation of Mishnah 14.</i> is what the people of Jerusalem wrote. The people of Galilee wrote like the people of Jerusalem. The people of Judea wrote: “Until the heirs will want to pay her the <i>ketubah</i>.” Therefore, if the heirs wish they can pay her the <i>ketubah</i> and send her away<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Whereas in Jerusalem it was the widow’s choice whether to claim housing and support or payment of the <i>ketubah.</i></i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “This is what the people of Jerusalem wrote,” etc. The people of Galilee cared for their honor more than for their money<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow can claim her <i>ketubah</i> unless she was supported by the estate for 25 years (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.4.1">Mishnah 12:4</a>), it is clear that the heirs save money by immediately paying the <i>ketubah</i> in full. But certainly it is not honorable to evict the widow from her husband’s home.</i>; the people of Judea cared for their money more than for their honor. Rebbi Ḥananiah the son of Rebbi Abbahu, and some say it in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Caesarea Philippi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:1:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.1.13"><i>Berakhot</i>2:1, Note 40</a>.</i> follows Judea and all other countries Jerusalem<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">The stipulation of Mishnah 14 is enforced everywhere except in R. Abbahu’s town.</i>.
A man said when he was dying: “This man’s wife should be paid her <i>ketubah.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">He told his heirs to immediately pay the <i>ketubah</i> and not provide dwelling and sustenance for his widow.</i>” The case came before Rebbi Mana, who said, let the words of the deceased be confirmed<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">It is a general principle that legal death-bed dispositions must be followed.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina said to him: Can a person do away verbally with a <i>ketubah</i> stipulation<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations are part of the marriage contract, they cannot be abrogated except by mutual consent, by a rider attached to the <i>ketubah</i> contract. There can be no unilateral abrogation of contractual obligations.</i>? He answered, since you are saying that, what is your reason? He said to him, are we not living in Galilee? And we are taught to say that the people of Galilee prefer their honor over their money<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Since the wife at the time of marriage could expect that all <i>ketubah</i> stipulations were part of the contract; the dying husband’s wish was illegal and could not be enforced.</i>.

Chapter 5



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Even though they said that a virgin collects 200 [<i>zuz</i>] and a widow a mina, if he wants to add even 100 minas, he may add<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ketubah</i> document is formulated to indicate that the husband obligates himself for 200/100 <i>zuz</i> by law; the additional sum he takes on himself must be spelled out separately.</i>. If she became widowed or divorced, whether preliminarily or definitively married, she collects everything. Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah says, definitively married, she collects everything; preliminarily married a virgin collects 200 [<i>zuz</i>] and a widow a mina since he added only with the idea to bring her in<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Since the document was signed and witnessed beforehand and it is stated that the addition is invalid before the definitive wedding, the question arises when and how the addition becomes enforceable by law.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Even though they said that a virgin collects 200,” etc. How does he become indebted to her? Do not Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, if somebody writes a debenture for another person under the assumption that he owes him and it turns out that he does not owe, [he does not have]<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">From the parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:1:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.1.2-4">Halakhah 12:1</a>, required by the context. If the addition is not valid for the woman who becomes a widow before her definitive wedding, why is the additional gift ever enforceable in court? Can the heirs not argue that the deceased never was obligated to pay the addition and, therefore, his estate is not required to pay?</i> to give to him! He wants to give much to be called X’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The addition is payment for value received; this makes it an enforceable obligation.</i>. That is, if he decided this<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">To add to the obligatory amount of the <i>ketubah</i>.</i> at the time of the preliminary marriage. What if he decided this<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">To add to the obligatory amount of the <i>ketubah</i>.</i> at the time of the definitive marriage? He wants to give much for sexual relations with her, which are sweet<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Old German law knew of a similar gift, called <i>Morgengabe,</i> “gift on the morning (after the nuptials)”; Latin <i>dotalicium.</i> This is the only reason accepted by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56a" href="/Ketubot.56a">Babli, 56a</a>.</i>. That is if he slept with her. If he did not sleep with her? He wants to give much for the acquisition<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The marriage which is called “acquisition”.</i> he made. If he had decided at the preliminary marriage, at the definitive marriage, he already is called X’s son-in-law, sexual relations are nothing new, there is no new acquisition; from thereon<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., if the husband should add to the <i>ketubah</i> sum while married, what makes that addition enforceable?</i> he wants to give much that she should not change her mind<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">But stay married to him.</i>. But can she? Was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 14:2:1-3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.14.2.1-3.2">Mishnah <i>Yebamot</i> 14:2</a>. In strict talmudic law, divorce is a unilateral act by the husband though in cases of spousal abuse the court can force a divorce by punishing the husband “until he says, I want [to divorce]”. Otherwise, the wife cannot force a divorce.</i> that “a man divorces only by his own will”? Rebbi Abin said, she makes his life miserable and he frees her<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody says that she needs a court to get a divorce.</i>.
It was stated: Just as the husband decides<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">He may decide to give to his wife more than the legal minimum.</i>, so the father decides<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">He decides to give his daughter a dowry. The daughters have a legal right to a dowry from the estate but not from the living father.</i>; only that the husband transfers rights in writing but the father only by speech, restricted to those things that can be acquired by speech<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Dowries of daughters and endowments of sons are the only things that can be finalized by speech only; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 102a" href="/Ketubot.102a">Babli 102a</a>.</i>. What is that? Gidul in the name of Rav: How much are you giving to your son? Such and such. And how much are you giving to your daughter? Such and such. When he preliminarily married her<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 102a" href="/Ketubot.102a">Babli, 102a</a>: If the groom preliminarily married the bride immediately after the young couple was promised the money by their respective parents. The Yerushalmi has to be understood in this sense also.</i>, the daughter acquired among the daughters. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Joseph said, Gidul found something large and said something small<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">By restricting the right of informal acquisition to the daughter.</i>! But it is as follows: How much are you giving to your son? Such and such. How much are you giving to your daughter? Such and such. When he preliminarily married her, the daughter acquired among the daughters and the son among the sons<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Babli’s formulation of Rav Gidul’s statement. “Among the daughters” means that if the father should die before the dowry was paid, its amount does not form part of the estate; the same holds for the son and the capital promised him.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, is that something small? Does he not acquire a wife on top of movables with one <i>peruṭa</i>’s worth<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The minimum amount a man has to give a woman for the preliminary marriage is one <i>peruṭah</i> (in the tradition of the House of Hillel; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a>). The <i>peruṭah</i> is the smallest coin, about 2 g bronze, valued at 1/144 or 1/192 of a silver <i>denar</i> (1/6 or 1/8 of the smallest Roman coin, the <i>as</i>). That coin disappeared with the Hasmonean kingdom; it remained as the smallest unit of value in legal theory. In rabbinic practice, <i>Šulḥan ‘Arukh Even Ha‘ezer</i> 27:10, the value of a <i>peruṭah</i> is half a grain of sterling silver (0.0324 g).<br>If the marriage of the couple is contracted by the respective parents, the groom acquires not only a wife but all that is promised him from both sides by giving one <i>peruṭah.</i> Since the <i>peruṭah</i> is the smallest unit of computation, the fact that one may acquire more than one thing with one <i>peruṭah</i> is not trivial and needs to be spelled out.</i>? But nobody can acquire two wives with one <i>peruṭa</i>’s worth<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.2.5.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 2:6</a>. It is possible for a man to simultaneously preliminarily marry any number of women by giving something of value to one of them if she is empowered by the other women to receive the value on their behalf and if there is at least one <i>peruṭah</i> for each of them.</i>! But cannot a person acquire real estate and several movables with one <i>peruṭa</i>’s worth<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate can be acquired by money and everything can be acquired with real estate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i>1:5</a>); therefore, any number of things can be acquired by giving one <i>peruṭah</i> for real estate (cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 3:7:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.3.7.6"><i>Peah,</i> Chapter 3, Notes 135</a> ff.).</i>? For a person can acquire two pieces of real estate with one <i>peruṭa</i>’s worth, but nobody can acquire two wives with one <i>peruṭa</i>’s worth.
Rebbi Abba bar Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: “How much are you giving to your son? Such and such. How much are you giving to your daughter? Such and such. When he preliminarily married her, the daughter acquired among the daughters and the son among the sons,” but only if it is a first marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The waiver of the rules of acquisition explained in the previous paragraph applies only if it is the first marriage for both parties.</i>. This follows what Rebbi Ḥanania said: If somebody definitively married off his son in a house, the latter acquired the house, but only if it is a first marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 144a" href="/Bava_Batra.144a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 144a</a>, only if (1) the son was an adult, (2) marrying a virgin, (3) as his first wife, and (4) is the first of his children to be married. Since “house” usually means “one-room house”, the father gives the house to be used by the pair as bridal chamber, with them staying there alone after all wedding guests have left.</i>. Rebbi Hoshaia said, she<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Probably this sentence has to be formulated in the masculine.</i> acquired movables but did not acquire the house. Do they disagree? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Explain it that his father used it for storage<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">While the newlyweds were living there alone, if the place was used as storage for produce, that is indication enough that it was intended only as a temporary dwelling place and R. Hanania will agree that the son did not acquire the house with the wife.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: It is needed in case what was stored was borrowed from the market. Rebbi Abbahu said, if he said it is loaned<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">If the father tells his son that the house is a loan, not a gift, it is not a gift.</i>, he did not acquire it. There came a case before Rebbi Jacob ben Rebbi Abun and he instructed following Rebbi Abbahu. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, essentialy this has no basis<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Greek θεμελίωσις “basis”. The acquisition of valuables by speech has no basis in the rabbinic legal system; nevertheless, it is subject to detailed rules. In the Babli, <i>loc.</i> <i>cit</i>., this is called “practice lacking a reason”.</i> but the rabbis build and add to it!
You say that the father decides for his daughter; even if she is an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Is the promised dowry for an adult daughter due on a verbal promise if the daughter is already an adult, no longer in the father’s power. Since the Babli (Note 23) requires the bride to be a virgin, it must deny the power of verbal acquisition to the adult daughter.</i>? Let us hear from the following: The father decides for his daughter, but the mother does not decide for her daughter, nor the brother for his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Reading of Alfassi (12:1,#384): “Neither the brother for his sister nor the mother for her daughter, even if she is underage.” Mother and brother can give only in the legal forms, by money, document, or handing over.</i>. Is there a difference about his sister whether she is an adolescent or an adult? So here, there is no difference whether she is an adolescent or an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>baraita</i> formulates no age criterion, there is none.</i>. Rebbi Abba from Carthage asked, even a third party? They said, even if she be an adult? A third party, let us hear from the following: The father decides for his daughter, but the mother does not decide for her daughter, nor the brother for his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">If mother and brother are disqualified from informal giving, so are third parties.</i>. So much more for the adult. Also in money matters it is so: Give your daughter to X and I shall give you so-and-so much. Buy this field and I shall give you so-and-so much<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">If close relatives other than the father are excluded, then third parties in general are excluded.</i>.
So is the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This is a parapharase of the Mishnah, given also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56a" href="/Ketubot.56a">Babli, 56a</a>. The problem of the Babli, whether the contract becomes valid by intercourse or by the possibility of intercourse, attributed there to the Galilean R. Abin, seems to have been decided in Galilee without great discussion. Cf. J. N. Epstein, מבוא לנוסח המשנה<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>, p. 494, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:2:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.2.2-3">Halakhah 2</a>.</i>: “Because he did only add for the love of the first night, when he had intercourse with her.” If he slept with her, divorced her, and took her back<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">He took her back on the terms of the prior <i>ketubah</i> before he paid her for the divorce; he remains obligated for the entire sum.</i>, the love of the first night is still there. If he slept with her, died, and she became available to the levir, the love of the first night is still there<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Her claim to the entire sum is intact.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Alexis in the name of Ḥizqiah: Practice follows Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah who said, if they were divorced or widowed after a preliminary marriage she collects 200, after the definitive marriage she collects everything. Rebbi Ḥanania said, practice follows Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. Rebbi Abbai<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">This name is unknown otherwise. The quote below and the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56a" href="/Ketubot.56a">Babli (56a</a>) show that one must read: R. Yannai.</i> said, they said to Rebbi Ḥanania, get outside to recite<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: Get out and recite your verse outside; a standard expression of disapproval.</i>. Rebbi Jonah, Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Jonathan said, practice follows Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. Rebbi Yosa, Rebbi Ze‘ira<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora quoted here cannot be R. Yose, the colleague of R. Jonah, who proves below that practice follows R. Eleazar ben Azariah. Therefore, the name quoted later, R. Yose bar Ze‘ira (no relative of R. Ze‘ira) seems to be the correct one, characterizing his statement as that of a very minor figure.</i> in the name of Rebbi Jonathan said, practice does not follow Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah. Rebbi Yose said, we had a rule that Ḥizqiah and Rebbi Jonathan said the same thing. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:14" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.14">Tosephta 4:14</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 132a" href="/Bava_Batra.132a">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i>132a</a>.</i>: If somebody’s son went overseas and one heard that he died, [the father] went and wrote his property to somebody else, and after that, the son returned. The gift remains valid; Rebbi Simeon ben Menasia says that the gift is invalid since he would not have written the deed if he had known that his son was alive<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The deed is a will, executed now to become effective after the testator’s death, and duly signed by two witnesses.</i>. And Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, practice follows Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah, and the reason of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah is the reason of Rebbi Simeon ben Menasia<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>loc. cit</i>., Rav Naḥman, the great authority in matters of money and contracts, agrees.</i>; and Rebbi Yannai said, they said to Rebbi Ḥanania, get outside to recite. And Rebbi Yose bar Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Jonathan said, practice does not follow Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">His opinion is not counted against that of R. Jonah, head of the Academy.</i>. An actual case was judged according to Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli agrees to the practice after an inconclusive debate, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56a" href="/Ketubot.56a"><i>Ketubot</i>56a</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Jehudah says, if he wants he writes for a virgin a contract of 200 [<i>zuz</i>] and she writes “I received 100 from you”, or for a widow a mina and she writes “I received 50 from you.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously the woman must agree to the smaller sum.</i>” Rebbi Meïr says, anyone who diminishes [the <i>ketubah</i>] of a virgin below 200 or that of a widow below 100 is engaging in whoring copulation<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">For him, the sums of 100/200 <i>zuz</i> are the absolute minimum. He admits that there are places where one does not write a <i>ketubah</i> document; this fact does not diminish the amount of <i>ketubah</i> due.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Jehudah says, if he wants he writes,” etc. Does Rebbi Jehudah think that the minimum for a virgin is a mina and for a widow 50 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Since those are the amounts he settles for.</i>? Should he not write so from the start? But it must be a diminution afterwards<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah cannot alter the established practice that at the time of the wedding the amounts must be 200/100 <i>zuz.</i> The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57a" href="/Ketubot.57a">Babli disagrees (57a</a>) in the name of Bar Qappara.</i>. Why can he not write that “I received from you such and such”? It was found that <i>bar Kappara</i> stated: “I received from you such and such<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Any amount is possible if the wife agrees.</i>”. Rebbi Joḥanan said: Rebbi Jehudah formulated this only for the end; but at the start, even Rebbi Jehudah agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah cannot alter the established practice that at the time of the wedding the amounts must be 200/100 <i>zuz.</i> The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57a" href="/Ketubot.57a">Babli disagrees (57a</a>) in the name of Bar Qappara.</i>. What is the beginning and what is the end? The colleagues in the name of R. Joḥanan: Before he had intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This is the definition of beginning.</i>, and after he had intercourse. Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of R. Joḥanan: Before he took her in, and after he took her in<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">“Taking in” is the ceremony of the definitive marriage; in this second version the wife can write a partial receipt even before they sleep together.<br>In a different setting, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57a" href="/Ketubot.57a">Babli (57a</a>) quotes these two possibilities and in addition “beginning” as before the definitive marriage and “end” as after sexual relations. This is theoretical since the Babli decides that practice follows R. Meïr.</i>. If he did not have intercourse with her, divorced her, and took her in again; that is before and after<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Since a woman divorced after the definitive marriage but before sexual relations can claim only a <i>ketubah</i> of a mina, it is at the end. But since she still is a virgin, it is the beginning. The definition of R. Ze‘ira leads to the construction of a self-contradictory case; it should be rejected.</i>.
What is a wife and what is a concubine<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Since the institution of <i>pilegeš</i> does not exist in rabbinic practice, the question is of purely theoretical character, an inquiry into the essence of the biblical institution of legal concubine.</i>? Rebbi Meïr says, a wife has a <i>ketubah,</i> a concubine has no <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Meïr in the Mishnah forbids any marriage without a full <i>ketubah</i>, he must hold that a concubine is not married. This is the position of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 21a</a>, articulated by Rav. (For rabbinic practice in Medieval Spain, cf. Menaḥem ben Aaron ben Zeraḥ, צדה לדרך Part 3, Chapter 2.)</i><i>.</i> Rebbi Jehudah says, both have a <i>ketubah.</i> A wife has a <i>ketubah</i> and the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations; a concubine has a <i>ketubah</i> but no <i>ketubah</i> stipulations<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Since he permits any modification of the financial aspects of marriage by written mutual consent, he also admits a situation in which a female of lower social rank signs away her rights.</i>. Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The context requires this translation.</i> Jehudah in the name of Rav: These are the opinions of Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Jehudah. But the words of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.7">Tosephta 4:7</a>.</i>: “A man may marry a woman and stipulate with her not to feed her and not to provide for her<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This Tosephta has two aspects. It implies that the institution of concubines has no place in rabbinic law but that the parties are free to decide on the material aspects of their marriage (while retaining the formal requirement of a <i>ketubah</i> of 200/100 <i>zuz</i>)<i>.</i> It also recognizes that a woman of higher social standing can buy herself a husband on her terms. Cf. <i>Tosefta ki-Fshutah,</i> part 6, p. 244.</i>. Not only that, but that she should feed and provide for him and teach him Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">This may mean that she pays for him so he can go and study full time. However, R. Petaḥya of Regensburg reports that a daughter of the Gaon of Baghdad was a lecturer in his Academy, and the Yerushalmi looks approvingly on women’s Torah study; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.3.2"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:3, Note 137</a>.</i>. It happened that Rebbi Joshua, son of Rebbi Aqiba, married a woman and stipulated with her not to feed her and not to provide for her. Not only that, but that she should feed and provide for him and teach him Torah. But when years of famine came and they distributed the properties among themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what this means; it could be that her family’s property was distributed among the heirs and her part was no longer sufficient.</i>, she started complaining about him to the Sages of Israel. He<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">R. Aqiba’s son said to the Sages.</i> said to them, for me she is trustworthy more than anybody. She told them, it is true that thus I stipulated with him. [They said to her]<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Inserted from the Tosephta, not in the Yerushalmi text.</i>, nothing comes after acquisition<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Since there are contracts written for the future, such as the <i>ketubah,</i> the execution of the contract alone does not make it valid or irrevocable. For this it needs an act of acquisition, exemplified by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:7" href="/Ruth.4.7"><i>Ruth</i> 4:7</a>, where the acquirer (Boaz) takes his sandal and lets the seller (the redeemer) move it in front of witnesses. {In the Tosephta, the expression is קיצה “contract”.} After acquisition, a contract can only be modified by a written rider agreed to by the parties.</i>.”

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One gives a virgin twelve months from when the husband requested to marry her to provide for herself<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">To make her trousseau.</i>. Just as one gives to the woman so one gives to the man to provide for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">To look for a house and otherwise prepare for a family. The girl’s family cannot force the husband into a definitive marriage before 12 months after the date of the preliminary marriage.</i>. And to a widow thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Since she already has a trousseau.</i>. If the time has come and they are not definitively married, they eat from his [property] and may eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">If the prospective husband is a Cohen, the preliminary marriage is the act of acquisition. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>, speaking about heave, reads: “If a Cohen buy a person with his money, that person may eat it.” Since the preliminary marriage is formally an acquisition by money, the bride can eat heave as soon as the groom is required to feed her. Therefore, if the delay of the wedding is his fault, the girl’s family can require that he feed her after the statutory 12 months delay, and he can fulfill his obligation by providing her with heave (for which he did not pay) and which she must eat in levitic purity in her father’s house.</i>. Rebbi Ṭarphon says, one gives her everything in heave. Rebbi Aqiba said, half profane and half heave<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah explains, a woman regularly has periods of impurity. R. Aqiba requires the groom to provide her with profane food for her periods of impurity; R. Tarphon, in the interpretation of the Babli, thinks that she can sell the heave and buy profane food for the money. This is a very problematic proposition since heave, for which the only possible buyers are other Cohanim, cannot fetch a price commensurate with that of profane food.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One gives a virgin twelve months.” It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57b" href="/Ketubot.57b">Babli 57b</a>. It is difficult to know what “in its time” means. The Tosephta reads: “Adulthood is equivalent to a request [for marriage], twelve months.” This means the same as the explanation in the Babli: “If a girl became preliminarily married after she was an adult for 12 months, one gives her 30 days as for a widow,” since she had ample time to sew her trousseau. One can read the Yerushalmi in the same sense, that the time of reaching adulthood is as good as an engagement.</i>: Adulthood in its time is twelve months. Rebbi Hila said, state: One gives an adult twelve months and one gives her a preliminary wedding, and thirty days to a widow. We have stated: “One gives a virgin twelve months,” and you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">How can the time given between definitive and preliminary marriages be 30 days when it is 12 months?</i>? Rebbi Abin in the name of Rebbi Hila<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">This is the explanation in the Babli (cf. Note 68) where also the tannaitic text is close to unintelligible.</i>: After she was an adult for twelve months one gives her the preliminary marriage and afterwards thirty days. If she spent twelve months for the first<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">And for some reason, she was not married but divorced or widowed.</i> and then the second one came. If he says to her, did you not wait already?
