She can say to him, I love you better than the young one<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">She has everything prepared but never used her trousseau. Her new fiancé wants to marry immediately and notes that she already has everything. She can say that her trousseau was good enough for the first, to whom she never was definitively married, but for him it will not be good enough and she needs more time to prepare more things. She cannot be forced be marry immediately.</i>. He is a widower, she is a virgin, and he wants to definitively marry. She can say, I love you better than a bachelor<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The same kind of argument as in the preceding case. In each case, neither party can be sued for breach of contract before the time allotted in the Mishnah has expired.</i>. If he is a bachelor and she a widow, and she wants to be definitively married. He can say, I love you better than a virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The same kind of argument as in the preceding case. In each case, neither party can be sued for breach of contract before the time allotted in the Mishnah has expired.</i>. If she is underage and wants to grow up one listens to her<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">While the underage girl can be preliminarily married to a man by her father without her being asked, she cannot be definitively married against her will while underage. The formulation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57b" href="/Ketubot.57b">Babli (57b</a>) is: One does not contract for an underage girl to be definitively married while underage but one may contract for an underage girl to be definitively married when reaching adulthood. That formulation does not require the underage girl to ask for the delay.</i>.
When the time came and they were not definitively married, they eat from his property and [do not] eat heave. If the husbands died, they eat from his property and eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The word in parenthesis is a correction by the scribe himself, in the wrong gender and probably at the wrong place. The sentence is quoted by <i>Tosafot,</i> 58a, <i>s. v</i>. ואפילו; there it reads: הִגִּיעַ זְמָן וְלֹא נִישְּׂאוּ אוֹ שֶׁמֵּתוּ בַעֲלֵיהֶן אוֹכְלוֹת מִשֶּׁלּוֹ וְאוֹכְלוֹת בִּתְרוּמָה. “When the time came and they were not definitively married or their husbands died, they eat from his property and eat heave.” The next Mishnah will state that all this and the connected difficulties are removed by later practice, that no woman married to a Cohen can eat from her husband’s heave unless she is definitively married to him. The practice of the returnees from Babylonia probably should read: “When the time has come and they were not definitively married, they eat from his property and eat heave. If the husband died, they eat from his property and [do not] eat heave.” The levir who is a Cohen cannot cause his prospective wife to eat heave since in contrast to his brother he has no preliminary marriage that could count as acquisition. A Cohen’s widow can eat heave only if she remains a member of the priestly clan, i. e., if any descendants of her husband by her survive her husband’s death. Vice versa, a Cohen’s daughter married to an Israel can eat heave after her husband’s death only if no descendants of her husband by her survive her husband’s death.</i>. Samuel, the brother of Rebbi Berekhiah, said: Only if the time was up on a Wednesday<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">“12 months after she was asked to marry” means that the virgin can request to be definitively married on the first Wednesday following the end of the twelfth month (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>). Therefore, she cannot ask to be sustained by her husband before that Wednesday.</i>. What if the time was up on Tuesday or Thursday? Rebbi Ḥama bar Uqba in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina and Levi: Both say that he is as if the Sages had jailed him. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, if the delay is his fault, she is fed from his property<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The court will uphold her claim to be paid back the money she spent on her own food only if the delay is the groom’s fault.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 58a" href="/Ketubot.58a">Babli 58a</a>, speaking of a Cohen’s wife. It is to be noted that the complete rules of purity were fully observed for almost 200 years after the destruction of the Temple; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.1"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:1, Note 3</a>. If heave cannot be eaten, it has to be given in minute amounts (“1 kernel of grain frees an entire silo”) and be destroyed; no wife can be fed with it.</i>: “Rebbi Ṭarphon says, one gives all heave to her, for heave is found everywhere. Rebbi Aqiba says, half profane [food] and half heave, for women frequently are impure for holy things.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is not yet definitively married she can be presumed not to be pregnant; then she is impure every month during her menstrual period.</i>” It was stated: “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, any place, where heave is mentioned, one gives her twice the corresponding amount of profane [food]<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">He agrees with R. Ṭarphon that she can be given all her food as heave but he holds that for her period of impurity she has to be given enough of the heave that she could sell a certain amount to Cohanim and buy profane food. Since there are few buyers, heave can be sold only at a large discount. Babylonian sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 58a" href="/Ketubot.58a">Babli 58a</a> and Tosephta) record a fourth opinion, by R. Jehudah ben Bathyra of Nisibis, that she is given ⅔ of heave and ⅓ in profane food, which should be enough for her total sustenance.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The levir does not cause her to eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Since he cannot acquire his sister-in-law otherwise than by sexual relations, after which she will be his wife in all respects, a woman engaged to be married by the levir is not part of his clan.</i>. If she spent six months for her husband and six months for the levir, or even all the time for the husband except for one day for the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The moment a levir enters the picture, the earlier acquisition by the husband is suspended.</i>, or all the time for the levir except for one day for the husband, she cannot eat heave. That is the earlier Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Both <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.3.1">Mishnaiot 3</a> and 4.</i>. The court in later times said that no woman eats heave unless she had been entering the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The definitive marriage. For the original husband, no sexual act is required.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The levir does not cause her to eat heave,” etc. Rebbi Jeremiah said, we stated there: The sister-in-law is fed from her husband’s estate all of the three months<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The widow of the childless man cannot remarry or be freed by her levir to remarry until three months have passed since her husband’s death and it has been ascertained that she is not pregnant, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.1">Mishnah <i>Yebamot</i> 4:11</a>. Therefore she can claim her sustenance from her husband’s estate like any other widow. The same statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 107b" href="/Ketubot.107b">Babli 107b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 41b" href="/Yevamot.41b"><i>Yebamot</i> 41b</a>.</i>. If her levir had come before the court<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">And he had agreed to marry his brother’s widow in levirate, or to free her by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after the end of the three months’ waiting period.</i> and fled, she is fed from his property<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Since he had taken responsibility for his sister-in-law, he cannot avoid his financial responsibility by his absence.</i>. If he became sick it is as if he had fled<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 107b:3:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.107b.3.1">Tosaphot, 107b, <i>s. v</i>. עמד</a>, this rule does not apply if the levir is sick at the end of the three months and is unable to marry his sister-in-law at the first possible moment.</i>. If he went overseas it is as if he had fled. If the widow said, I am bound in my widowhood to my husband’s house, one listens to her<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">If she says that she has no desire to remarry, neither in levirate to her levir nor to any other man by <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> the heirs have to pay indefinitely for her upkeep in her husband’s house.</i>. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila: The one who says, I shall not give<i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">He says that he wants to marry his sister-in-law; therefore, he becomes responsible for her upkeep immediately at the end of the three months’ waiting period.</i><i>,</i> is like the one who says, I shall not divorce. Rav Zabda said, Rebbi Isaac intructed that the one who says., I shall not give <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> is like the one who says, I shall not divorce.
“If she spent six months for her husband and six months for the levir, she cannot eat heave. Not only six months for the levir but even all the time for the levir except for one day, she cannot eat heave.” The Mishna follows neither the earliest not the last Mishnah, but the intermediate development. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">A similar statement is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>, where, however, the intermediate Mishnah is not mentioned. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.8.1.2"><i>Terumot</i> 8:1, Note 9</a>.</i>: First, they were saying that a preliminarily married woman, daughter of an Israel, could eat heave, for they were explaining: “If a Cohen acquires a person, acquistion by money<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11">Lev. 22:11</a>. The verse ends: “He shall eat [the Cohen’s sacred food]”. A parallel statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57b" href="/Ketubot.57b">Babli, 57b</a>.</i>;” for what would be the difference between one who acquires a wife and one who acquires a slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The slave girl, by becoming the property of a Jew, is presumed to become Jewish by immersion in a <i>miqweh.</i> Then she has to follow all Jewish laws valid for women (only that, being unable to marry, she is permitted guiltless unmarried sex with everybody except Jewish men). By manumission she would become a full Jewish woman. While a Gentile cannot become impure by biblical standards, the immersion in the ritual bath makes her subject to all rules of purity. If her owner is a Cohen, she may eat his sacred food if in the appropriate state of ritual purity.<br>A wife is usually acquired in preliminary marriage, as far as criminal law is concerned, by a gift of money or its equivalent. The argument is shaky since one should mention that if the wife is acquired by a matrimonial contract or by sexual relations without a gift of money (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a>), there would be no reason to permit heave to the Israel woman preliminarily married to a Cohen. Nowhere do we find that the way the preliminary marriage is effected makes any difference.</i>? They changed, to say: after twelve months, when he becomes responsible for her upkeep. The court of the later ones said: A woman never eats heave before she enters the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>. However, the same Tosephta (and the Yerushalmi. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:12:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.12.5"><i>Yebamot</i> 4:12, Note 197</a>) mentions that in a famine, R. Tarphon (a Cohen) preliminarily married 300 women to give them access to sanctified food. This means that the “later Mishnah” has to be dated some time after the destruction of the Temple when, probably, the importance of heave for the income of Cohanim was rapidly diminishing.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>.</i>”Already Rebbi Joḥanan ben Bagbag sent to Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The leader of Babylonian Jewry in the first half of the 2<sup class="footnote-marker">nd</sup> Century C.E.</i> at Nisibis: They say in your name that the preliminarily married daughter of an Israel eats heave. He sent back the following: I had been convinced that you are knowledgeable in the secrets of the Torah, but you do not even know the rules <i>de minore ad majus</i>! Since money can acquire a Gentile slave girl to permit her to eat heave, but she cannot be acquired by sexual relations<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Being Gentile, she could be married to a Gentile by sexual relations. But sexual relations with her are forbidden to a Jew and, therefore, she cannot be acquired by a Jew through sexual relations either as a slave or a wife.</i> to permit her to eat heave, whereas a wife can be acquired by sexual relations to permit her to eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">If preliminary and definitive marriage are enacted together in the bridal chamber without any gift of money, the woman is a wife and entitled to eat her husband’s food by biblical standards.</i>, it is only logical that money can acquire a wife to permit her to eat heave! But what can I do? They said that no woman eats heave before she enters the bridal chamber,” and they supported it by the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:11" href="/Numbers.18.11"><i>Num.</i> 18:11</a>. The wife is part of the household only after the definitive marriage. The argument is rejected in <i>Sifry Num.</i> 117, since in. v. 13 a similar restriction is noted, “every pure person in your household shall eat it,” and it is a generally accepted hermeneutical principle that “two consecutive restrictions mean a relaxation”, in this case, that the wife may eat heave from the moment of the preliminary marriage. Therefore, the restriction to definitively married wives is purely rabbinical.</i>: “Every pure person in your household shall eat it.” Rebbi Yudan said, that is an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> that can be reversed! Because he could say to him, since a Gentile slave girl can be acquired by active possession<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The word חֲזָקָה “grasping” can have two very different meanings. In legal arguments, it denotes a general assumption which generates <i>prima facie</i> evidence. In the law of real estate and slaves, it denotes the exercise of possession. For example, if an intestate person dies without heirs (e. g., a proselyte who failed to start a Jewish family), his property becomes ownerless and is up for grabs. Therefore, if somebody goes to the ownerless real estate and acts as proprietor, fencing in or harvesting a field or painting a house, he has acquired the piece of real estate by his action. Similarly, if somebody takes an ownerless slave from the estate and tells him to work on his orders, the work of the slave makes him the property of the person giving the orders. The work can be quite symbolical, such as carrying a stone for a short stretch, to qualify as חֲזָקָה and if the acquirer is a Cohen, the slave is qualified to eat heave. Therefore, the means of acquisition of slave girls and wives are only partially comparable; the ways of acquisition of a slave are not subordinated to those for a wife.</i> to permit her to eat heave, what can you say about a wife who cannot be acquired by active possession? If an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> can be reversed, the argument is invalid.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody dedicates his wife’s earnings<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">He makes a vow that any benefit that will accrue to him from his wife’s earnings shall be dedicated to some religious institution.</i>, she can work and sustain herself<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.6.1">Mishnah 6</a> how much a wife must work for her husband to be entitled to support. If the husband does not support her, she certainly is entitled to work and use her work for her own support. The husband cannot dedicate anything to which he has no right of possession.</i>. The excess, Rebbi Meïr says, is dedicated, Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian says, it is profane<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that nobody can dedicate anything before it exists; therefore the husband cannot dedicate his wife’s future earnings: the vow is void.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody dedicates his wife’s earnings,” etc. Rebbi Meïr says, it is sanctified as his property<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Meïr holds that a man means what he says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 2:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.2.1.2-6"><i>Nazir</i> 2:1</a>, 51d 1. 16; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 5a" href="/Arakhin.5a">Babli <i>Arakhin</i> 5a</a>). Since he must agree with R. Joḥanan the Alexandrian and everybody else that nobody can dedicate anything that is not under his control, he will interpret the husband’s vow not that he dedicates the future earnings of his wife but he dedicates her hands for what they will produce in the future. Since the hands do exist and the wife is required to work for him, the vow is valid.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian says, it is profane as his property<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody can dedicate anything that is not under his control; the husband can appropriate his wife’s work for himself as profane property.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The following text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 11:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.11.4.2"><i>Nedarim</i> 11:4, Notes 50–53</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 57b" href="/Ketubot.57b">Babli, 57b</a>, different but similarly sounding explanations are given in the names of the Babylonians Rav and Samuel.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they disagree about the excess over five tetradrachmas. He explains it in the case of one who supports his wife with food but does not give her an obolus for her needs<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Since a woman divorced after the definitive marriage but before sexual relations can claim only a <i>ketubah</i> of a mina, it is at the end. But since she still is a virgin, it is the beginning. The definition of R. Ze‘ira leads to the construction of a self-contradictory case; it should be rejected.</i>, as we stated: “If he does not give her an obolus for her needs, what she earns is hers”. Rebbi Joḥanan said, they disagree about the excess left after [the husband’s] death; for he explains it if he does not support her with food. But if he supports her with food, everybody agrees that it became dedicated.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">End of the parallel in <i>Nedarim.</i></i> Rebbi Ze‘ira said, what one states there<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. The <i>baraita</i> is not in the Babli.</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: “When was this said? If he does not feed her. But if he feeds her, everybody agrees that it was sanctified.” But is not everything a wife has subject to the husband’s claim to its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of a written contract to the contrary, the husband is the administrator of the wife’s property; he is paid for his efforts by the cash yield of the property (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>). Therefore, while he has no property rights to his wife’s excess earnings, by the <i>ketubah</i> he has a contractual interest in the increase of property generated by these earnings since such an increase could increase the cash yield which will be his. Therefore, he should be an interested party and his vow should be recognized by both R. Meïr and R. Joḥanan the Alexandrian without restrictions. This argument is too far-fetched to merit an answer.</i>?
Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, [the status] of her earnings is between them. Rebbi Meïr says, the earnings are susceptible to be dedicated from the first moment; Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian says, the earnings are not susceptible to be dedicated from the first moment<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">They cannot be dedicated before they exist.</i>. “What I shall inherit from my father (today) is sold to you, what I shall catch today in my trap is sold to you; his words are valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Nedarim (Lieberman) 6:7" href="/Tosefta_Nedarim_(Lieberman).6.7">Tosephta <i>Nedarim</i> 6:7</a>, Babli <i>Baba Meṣï‘a</i> 16a, <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon bar Ioḥai</i> p. 212. In the last source, the text is a commentary on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:24" href="/Exodus.22.24"><i>Ex</i>. 22:24</a>, which is read as: “If you extend a loan <i>of what you have with you</i> to a poor person,” meaning that transactions cannot validly be made about nonexisting things (explanation by J. N. Epstein).</i>” Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If he takes out a loan for his father’s burial shrouds, if his father was sick or in mortal danger<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The transaction should be invalid as long as his father is still alive. The Babli, <i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>., concurs that this is a rabbinic exemption from the rules if necessary for his father’s honor.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Only if the trap was set<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The selling of the expected catch is accepted as regular trading practice once the trap is set because the probability that there will be a catch is high. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 16" href="/Bava_Metzia.16">Babli, <i>Baba</i> <i>Meṣi‘a</i> 16a/b</a>, the transaction is validated only on an emergency basis, if otherwise the catcher would have nothing to eat. It seems that the Tosephta follows the Yerushalmi.</i>. And Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: But as a dedication it would not be sanctified. Why? Because of the disagreement of Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">This fixes practice following R. Joḥanan the Alexandrian, that futures contracts in general cannot be enforced.. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 59a" href="/Ketubot.59a">Babli, 59a</a>, this is an explicit statement.</i>. One could say, there is a difference about the dedication, because the trap is not usually successful<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Even R. Meïr will agree that a contract of which both parties assume that it will not be realized is invalid. The technical term for such a contract is אַסְמַכְתָּא. (Since few people used to marry with the idea that the marriage would end in divorce, some rabbinic authorities hold that pre-nuptial agreements about the consequences of a divorce are <i>asmakhta</i>; but cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.8.5">Note 226</a>.)</i>. Rebbi Yose said to Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa: Do you remember that both you and Rebbi Jeremiah were saying in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Who stated about the dedication, because the trap is not usually successful? The disagreement of Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian! Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish has many a thought<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation that a dedication of future earnings is invalid as <i>asmakhta</i> contradicts R. Simeon ben Laqish’s explanation of the Mishnah, which describes a setting in which the husband has lost his rights to his wife’s earnings. Why did he not explain the Mishnah simply because one cannot dedicate future earnings, the explanation accepted in the Babli? The answer is that he would agree to the Babli’s explanation, except that he has another one in addition. Since the Mishnah can be explained in several ways consistent with his legal doctrines, he may choose different (parallel, not contradictory) doctrines in different situations.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: If somebody dedicated his slave’s earnings and the latter was a hunter, what are the rules<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">If the owner expects the slave to feed himself from his catch.</i>? Let us hear from the following: If somebody dedicates his slave, that one is dedicated but his earnings are profane<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The slave becomes Temple property, but he can use anything he catches or earns for himself without stealing dedicated property.</i>. His [slave’s] earnings, he is profane and his earnings are dedicated<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In this version, the slave cannot eat anything he catches because that immediately becomes Temple property, any profane use of which is larceny. The Tanna of this <i>baraita</i> seems to hold that an owner is not obligated to feed his slave.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is out of place and belongs to the discussion below.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, if somebody cuts off the hands of another person’s slave, that one’s owner collects the payments for his injuries, his pain, his shame, and impairment but he shall go out and subsist on alms. Did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta ‘<i>Arakhin</i> 3:8.</i>: If somebody dedicates his slave, that one takes out his provisions but the remainder is dedicated<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the slave is not dedicated, since the owner is obligated to feed his slave one automatically interprets his dedication to mean that only the excess earnings over the slave’s minimal needs are dedicated.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, nobody thinks that he should die<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">It remains open whether there is an obligation on the part of the owner to feed his slave but in any case, nobody thinks that the slave should suffer king Midas’s fate that he could not eat anything that he made or earned.</i>. [ ] more than for slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The text is defective. The original text must have been similar to the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.4.2"><i>Baba Qama</i> 8:4</a> from a different editorial team: אָמַר רִבִּי אָחָא. מְצוּוִּים יִשְׂרָאֵל לְפַרְנֵס בְּנֵי חוֹרִין יוֹתֵר מֵעֲבָדִים. “Rebbi Aḥa said, Jews are more obligated to provide for free persons than for slaves.”</i>. Did not Rebbi Joḥanan say, if somebody cuts off the hands of another person’s slave, that one’s owner collects the payments for his damages, his pain, his shame, and impairment<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.4.2"><i>Baba Qama</i> 8:4</a> one adds: His medical costs. This means that the owner presents the bill for medical costs to the person causing the injury.</i> but he shall go out and subsist on alms. The rabbis of Caesarea in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: Jews are obligated to care for amputees, even slaves.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Baba Qama</i>: “R. Aḥa said, Jews are more obligated to provide for amputated slaves than for whole ones.” On that statement then comes the objection that R. Joḥanan shares his meat and wine with his slave.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan gave to his slave from everything he himself ate<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">His deeds do not follow his words that the owner has the right to let his slave be fed from charity. In <i>Baba Qama</i>, the answer is given that his rule is legal, his behavior moral.</i> and quoted for this<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 31:15" href="/Job.31.15"><i>Job</i> 31:15</a>, speaking of Job’s slaves.</i>: “Did not his Maker make me in the belly and formed me likewise in a womb?”

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> These are the kinds of work a woman does for her husband: She grinds flour, bakes, launders, nurses her baby, makes his bed, and spins wool<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The amount is determined in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.11.1">Mishnah 13</a>.</i>. If she brought a slave girl with her<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">As her dowry.</i>, she does not have to grind flour, bake, and launder. Two, she does not have to nurse her baby. Three, she does not have to make his bed or spin wool. Four, she sits in a chair<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Greek καθέδρα “chair”. “Sitting in a καθέδρα” means “sitting idle”.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer says, even if she brought him a hundred slave girls, he forces her to spin wool because indolence causes immorality.<br>Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, also a man who by a vow forbids his wife to work must divorce her and pay her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Since the divorce is his fault.</i> since idleness induces mental illness.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “These are the kinds of work a woman does for her husband,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:4" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.4">Tosephta 5:4</a>.</i>: Seven main labors did they enumerate; the rest the Sages did not need to specify<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61a" href="/Ketubot.61a">Babli (61a</a>) notes that the additional services, such as mixing the wine, a wife does even if otherwise she is “sitting in a chair”.</i>.
“She nurses her baby.” Rebbi Ḥaggai said, is says only “her baby,” therefore not twins<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">The singular implies that the husband has to hire a wet-nurse for the second child. Aliassi (§274) quotes this rule in the name of R. Ḥanina.</i>. Why does it say “<i>her baby</i>”? As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.5">Tosephta 5:5</a>, in a different order; a partial quote in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 59b" href="/Ketubot.59b">Babli, 59b</a>.</i>: “A man cannot force his wife to nurse another man’s child, nor can a woman force her husband to let her nurse another woman’s child<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">To earn money.</i>. If she made a vow not to nurse her baby, the House of Shammai say that one removes the breast nipple from his mouth<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The reason of the House of Shammai is not stated. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 59b" href="/Ketubot.59b">Babli, 59b</a>, conjectures that the vow is one “between her and him” and, therefore, it would be in the husband’s power to annul the vow (cf. <i>Nedarim</i> Chapter 10). If he does not annul his wife’s vow, he has to pay the wet-nurse.</i>, but the House of Hillel say, one forces her<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">They always hold that nobody can get rid of his obligations by a vow. The vow does not have to be annulled.</i>. If she was divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation to nurse her baby ends with the divorce.</i>, one cannot force her if [the baby] is not used to her, but if he is used to her one forces her<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.2.3">Tosephta <i>Niddah</i> 2:5</a>, the formulation is: If the baby recognizes his mother one may not give him to a wet-nurse since that would be a danger to his life.</i> and pays her wages to nurse her baby.” How old is the baby if he can be presumed to know her? Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is attributed to Rav Jeremiah bar Abba, of Rav’s Academy. Probably something is missing from the text since R. Jeremiah cannot really have addressed his teacher R. Ze‘ira as “you”.</i> in the name of Rav: Three months. But Rebbi Ze‘ira was staring at him<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">“Staring at somebody” is always a sign of disapproval.</i>. He asked him, why are you staring at me? Should I say to you following Samuel, since Samuel said, three days<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 60a" href="/Ketubot.60a">Babli, 60a</a>, Samuel is quoted as refusing to set a time limit but to put the mother in a line-up with other women and see whether the baby recognizes her.</i>? Samuel follows his opinion, since Samuel said, I recognized<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">As a newborn.</i> the midwives who delivered me. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, I recognized the circumciser who circumcised me. Rebbi Joḥanan said, I recognized the women who kept my mother company.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 2:2" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.2.2">Tosephta <i>Niddah</i> 2:3</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 60a" href="/Ketubot.60a">Babli 60a</a>. In both these texts, one reads: If he stopped <i>after</i>24<i>months,</i> one does not return him. A parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Niddah 1:4:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Niddah.1.4.2-7">Yerushalmi <i>Niddah</i> 1:5</a>, with a different tradition of names.</i>: A baby suckles continuously until 24 months; after that he is as if an unclean creature would suckle, the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But Rebbi Joshua says, he suckles continuously even four or five years. If he stopped, one does not return him. How long? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This reading is impossible since R. Jacob bar Aḥa is one generation before R. Jeremiah. One must read “Rav Jeremiah”, the colleague and student of Rav.</i> in the name of Rav: From hour to hour<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">From a certain hour one day to the same hour the next day, i. e., 24 hours.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Three days from hour to hour<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 60a" href="/Ketubot.60a">Babli, 60a</a>, this is attributed to the school of Samuel.</i>. It was stated: From hour to hour. Rebbi Hizqiyah, Rav: When has this been said? If he stopped while being healthy. But if he stopped because of sickness, one does return him. When there was no danger. But if it was because of danger, one returns him even after a number of days<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">This argument is not mentioned in the Babli which, therefore, can be<br>assumed to agree.</i>.
“If she brought”. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, not only if she brought but even if she could have brought<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">If her dowry is large enough to pay for a slave girl. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61a" href="/Ketubot.61a">Babli, 61a</a>, this is a statement of R. Samuel ben Naḥmani.</i>. As it was stated: His wife ascends with him but does not descend with him<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">This clause is also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 48a" href="/Ketubot.48a">Babli (48a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61a" href="/Ketubot.61a">61a</a>). It means that if the material circumstances of the husband improve, he has to provide for his wife according to his social standing; but if he loses money, he cannot reduce her standard of living below the level he provided for her at the time of the wedding.</i>; a widow and her children descend but do not ascend<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">They are supported from the estate and only have a claim to the lesser amount of the yield of the estate at the time of the husband’s death or now. If the heirs improve the yield of the estate, the improvement is theirs (assuming zero inflation). Similarly, the claim of the daughters to a dowry is limited to 10% of the estate at the time of the father’s death.</i>; workers ascend but do not descend<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The standard contract for journeymen stipulates that the employer must feed the workers (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.7.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba</i> <i>Meṣi‘a</i> 7:1</a>); he cannot reduce his contribution below the standard accepted at the beginning of the contract.</i>. The daughter neither ascends nor descends. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Jehudah said, because one cares for the slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">That she should not be overworked. It is difficult to see why the slave girl should be overworked with three types of work but the wife not with seven. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61a" href="/Ketubot.61a">Babli, 61a</a>, this question is asked and the answer is that the slave girl also has to care for guests.</i>. Rebbi Abun said, Because these labors are degrading, they are referred to as the slave girl’s. Rebbi Judah ben Rebbi Abun said, because usually a woman does not sit aimlessly in her house<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The other things, except grinding flour, baking, and washing, the wife does anyhow.</i>. Rav Huna said, even if she brought him 100 slave girls, he can force her to serve him with particular attention<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">A similar statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61a" href="/Ketubot.61a">Babli, 61a</a>.</i>. What are services with particular attention? She rubs his body, washes his feet, and mixes him the cup<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, “she mixes his cup, makes his bed, and washes his face and feet.”</i>. Why? Because she is obligated to do that, or because it is not appropriate to use a slave girl for these<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">These are intimate services; if a slave girl would perform those, the husband would start to sleep with her.</i>? If you say because it is not appropriate to use a slave girl for these, here she brought him slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah does not mention that she could have brought a male slave as dowry who could serve as the husband’s valet, to free the wife from personal services.</i>! It must be because she is obligated to do that. Rebbi Eudaimon in Sepphoris asked before Rebbi Mana: Is it not reasonable because she is obligated to do that? He said to him, that is what I am always thinking.
It was stated so: He forces her to work<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Following R. Eliezer.</i> with wool, but not with flax since that causes bad breath and broadens the lips<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:5:2-6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.5.2-6.2"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:5</a>, it is stated in more general terms: He can force her to work with wool but not anything else (unless stipulated otherwise in the marriage contract) since the terms of a contractual relationship cannot be changed unilaterally. For the damage that spinning flax does to the lips, cf. the Brothers Grimm’s fairy tale, <i>die drei Spinnerinnen</i>.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody by a vow bars his wife from sexual intercourse, the House of Shammai say two weeks, the House of Hillel say one week<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">If he does not have his vow dissolved by that time, the wife can go to court and force a divorce with full payment of the <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. Students can go to study Torah for thirty days without permission<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Without asking his wife’s permission if she married him knowing he was a student.</i>; journeymen one week<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">They can hire themselves out to work at another place where they cannot return to their homes every night.</i>. The period mentioned in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:10" href="/Exodus.21.10"><i>Ex.</i> 21:10</a>, where it is spelled out that a man can take a second wife only if he does not reduce the amount of sexual activity with his first wife.</i>: People who do not have to work every day<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">If a man marries a woman telling her that he is rich enough not to have to work, he is obligated to sleep with her every night and cannot later reduce this amount without the wife’s consent. Similarly, a donkey driver engaged in local traffic, who is home every week, cannot change his profession to camel driver engaged in long distance caravan traffic without his wife’s consent.</i>, journeymen twice a week, donkey drivers once a week, camel drivers once in thirty days, sailors once in three months, the words of Rebbi Eliezer.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody by a vow bars his wife from sexual intercourse,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.6">Tosephta 5:6</a>.</i> The House of Shammai say, two weeks as after the birth of a girl<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">After the birth of a girl, the mother is forbidden intercourse for two weeks, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:5" href="/Leviticus.12.5"><i>Lev.</i> 12:5</a>. Since this is a normal occurrence in a marriage, the wife can be assumed to be able to live for two weeks without intercourse.</i>. But the House of Hillel say one<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The masculine אֶחָד refers to שָׁבוּעַ “week”, the intended meaning of שַׁבָּת in this context.</i> week, as after the birth of a boy<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:2" href="/Leviticus.12.2"><i>Lev.</i> 12:2</a>.</i> or the days of her menstruation<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:2" href="/Leviticus.12.2"><i>Lev.</i> 12:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:19" href="/Leviticus.15.19">15:19</a>. Since a forced abstinence of seven days is routine in the marriage, it is reasonable to ask the wife to wait for 7 days before giving her the right to sue in court (the Babli’s interpretation of the House of Hillel, 61b).</i>.
“Students can go to study Torah for thirty days without <i>their wives</i>’<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Addition to the Mishnah text.</i> permission.” Therefore, with permission even longer<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 61b-62a" href="/Ketubot.61b-62a">Babli agrees, 61b/62a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: “He sent them to the Libanon, ten thousand per month.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 5:28" href="/I_Kings.5.28"><i>1K.</i> 5:28</a>.</i>” Rebbi Abin said, the Holy One, praise to Him, preferred being fruitful and multiplying over the Temple. What is the reason? “One month they would be in Libanon, two months each in his house.”<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 62a" href="/Ketubot.62a">Babli, 62a</a>, is explicit that R. Joḥanan requires a student who leaves his house for study to make up for it and spend double the time with his wife.</i> Rav said, “the one entering and the one leaving, month for month for all months of the year.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 27:1" href="/I_Chronicles.27.1"><i>1Chr.</i> 27:1</a>, speaking of all watches in the service of the king. The interpretation is that each watch served for six months each year, one month at a time. Rav will require a student to spend only one month with his wife for every month away. In the Babli, R. Joḥanan rejects this argument since the king’s servants were well paid and absences for money-making purposes follow different rules.</i>”
Here you say, one week. But there, you say, twice a week<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah permits journeymen to absent themselves for one week but requires them to sleep with their wives twice a week. How can the two statements be reconciled?</i>. Bar Qappara stated: “Journeymen can hire themselves out without their wives’ permission for one week.”<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">The agreement of the wife is taken for granted since she also lives off her husband’s earnings. But if he is at home, she has the right to expect that he sleep with her twice a week.</i>
”The period mentioned in the Torah.” <sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Mekhilta dR</i>.<i>Ismael</i> (ed. Horovitz-Rabin p. 259), the first opinion is attributed to Rebbi, the second to R. Joshia; the explanation attributed here to R. Eliezer ben Jacob is there in the name of R. Jonathan. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 47b" href="/Ketubot.47b">Babli, 47b</a>, the first opinion is attributed to R. Eleazar or R. Eliezer, the second is anonymous; the <i>midrash</i> of R. Eliezer ben Jacob is given in his name, 48a. <i>Mekhilta dR</i>.<i>Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> follows the attributions of the Yerushalmi (pp. 167–168).</i> Some Tannaïm state<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The problem is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:9" href="/Exodus.21.9"><i>Ex.</i> 21:9</a> which states that a man who takes an additional wife may not diminish שְׁאֵר, כְּסוּת, and עֹנָה of his first wife. The meaning of כְּסוּת “garment, covering” is clear but the meaning of the other two words is a matter of controversy. שְׁאֵר means “flesh” but, as the verses quoted in support of different meanings show, it means both “meat” and “relative, one’s flesh and blood.” Note also in Accadic <i>šērum</i> “flesh”, <i>š’r</i> (of a different etymology) “to go towards; to have sexual relations”. The root שאר II has no connection with the usual שאר “to remain, be a remainder” (Arabic سار.).<br>The problem with עֹנָה is that the verb ענה “to humiliate, inflict pain” in sexual context always means “to rape, to have forced intercourse” but in the verse here it has a positive meaning, the intercourse to which the wife is entitled. [Note that in Arabic, عنا means both “produce plants” (said of the earth) and “to be humiliated, captive” (from this العَوَانِي “Moslem women”).] From the positive meaning of עֹנָה in the verse comes the rabbinic-modern Hebrew עוֹנָה “season”, used in the <i>midrash</i> of R. Eliezer ben Jacob.</i>: שְׁאֵר that is intercourse; עוֹנָה that is food. Some Tannaïm state: עוֹנָה that is intercourse; שְׁאֵר that is food. He who said שְׁאֵר is intercourse: “No person to the שְׁאֵר of his flesh;<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:6" href="/Leviticus.18.6"><i>Lev.</i> 18:6</a>: “No person to the שְׁאֵר of his flesh should come close, to uncover nakedness.”</i>” עוֹנָה is food: “He fed you and made you hunger<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 8:3" href="/Deuteronomy.8.3"><i>Deut.</i> 8:3</a>, usually translated as: “He <i>chastised you</i> and made you hunger before He fed you with the manna that neither you nor your fathers knew.”</i>”. He who said שְׁאֵר is food: “He let rain on them שְׁאֵר like dust<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 78:27" href="/Psalms.78.27"><i>Ps.</i> 78:27</a>.</i>”; עוֹנָה that is intercourse, “that you should not deprive my daughters,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 31:50" href="/Genesis.31.50"><i>Gen</i>. 31:50</a>. “That you should not deprive my daughters nor take wives in addition to my daughters.” In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 74:12" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.74.12"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 74(12</a>), this verse is explained that (a) Bilha and Silpa also were Laban’s daughters from slave women and (b) that Laban made Jacob swear that he would not deprive his daughters of intercourse during their lifetime nor take additional wives after their deaths.</i>” that refers to intercourse. Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob explains the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">He denies that there is a biblical command which fixes minimal amounts of sexual attention due wives. He explains <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:9" href="/Exodus.21.9"><i>Ex.</i> 21:9</a> as exhortation rather than prescription, reading “her flesh, her garment, and her season he should not diminish”.</i>, “her flesh her garment”, that her garment should fit her flesh, that he should not give a young woman clothes of an old woman nor an old woman clothes of a young one. “Her garment her season”, that he should not give summer clothing for the rainy season nor that for the rainy season in summer. From where does he get food<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">How can he establish an obligation of the husband to feed his wife?</i>? Since he is not permitted to withhold from her things that are not necessities of life<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">A new garment at least twice a year.</i>, not so much more things that are necessities of life! From where does he get the obligation of periodic intercourse? Since he may not withhold from her things which do not constitute the main reason for marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">A new garment at least twice a year.</i>, so certainly he may not withhold the things which constitute the main reason for marriage!
Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">His list of prescribed minimal frequencies of intercourse is based on the occupation of the male. The same argument is given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 76:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.76.6"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 76(6</a>); it is reproduced in Rashi’s Commentary to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 32:15-16" href="/Genesis.32.15-16"><i>Gen</i>. 32:15–16</a>.</i> inferred from the gift which Jacob had sent to his brother Esaw, for he sent him according to copulations. “200 she-goats and 20 he-goats,” one for ten; “200 ewes and 20 rams,” one for ten<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">One male can satisfy 10 females since it has nothing to do except grazing and copulating.</i>. “Nursing camels and their sons 30.” Rebbi Berekhiah said, because it is decent in his sexual behavior did the verse not publicize<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 76:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.76.6"><i>Gen</i>.<i>rabba</i> 76(6</a>), R. Berekhiah in the name of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel implies that 30 males (בנאים “builders”) accompanied the 30 females.</i>. “40 cows and ten bulls,” one for four since they are tired<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Cattle was used extensively for ploughing and drawing agricultural implements.</i>; “20 she-donkeys and ten he-donkeys,” one for two since they are tired.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Is it reasonable to consider scholars like those who do not work? Rebbi Mana said, would it not be more reasonable to compare them to sailors<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Who have to sleep with their wives only once every six months.</i> since they exert themselves harder? Rav said, “she eats with him every Friday night”<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.11.1">Mishnah 5:13</a>. A man who does not live with his wife but supports her financially through an intermediary nevertheless has to sleep with her every Friday night (unless he actually is away as in the cases enumerated in the Mishnah). Therefore, the scholar has to sleep with his wife at least every Friday night.</i>, in clean language<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">“Eating” is a common metaphor for sexual relations; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 39:6" href="/Genesis.39.6"><i>Gen</i>. 39:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 30:20" href="/Proverbs.30.20"><i>Prov.</i>30:20</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman revolts<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">While one could read the Mishnah as speaking of a woman refusing any of the work enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.6.1">Mishnah 6</a>, from the Halakhah it seems that one speaks only of a woman refusing sexual relations with her husband. (This remains a matter of dispute in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 63" href="/Ketubot.63">Babli, 63a/b</a>.)</i> against her husband, one<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">The court, following the husband’s complaint.</i> reduces her <i>ketubah</i> by seven denars a week; Rebbi Jehudah says, by seven <i>tropaïkes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Late classical Greek τροπαϊκόν, τό, “a half denarius” defined in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 64a" href="/Ketubot.64a">Babli (64a</a>) as στατήρ (name introduced by Alexander the Great for a gold coin but used in later antiquity for silver didrachmas of varying standards, i. e„ half a <i>sela</i>.) The name τροπαϊκόν was given to coins depicting a trophy (τροπαίον); in the Roman Empire it was identified with the <i>victoriatus</i>(<i>nummus</i>)<i>,</i> a small silver coin stamped with the image of Victoria, goddess of victory; declared by Varro to be equal to the <i>quinarius argenteus</i>, one-half of a <i>denarius argenteus</i>. This is the meaning used here.</i>.<br>For how long does one reduce? Up to the amount of her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Then the court will force the husband to divorce his wife without payment of a <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. Rebbi Yose says, he continues to reduce<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">The husband cannot be forced to divorce his wife.</i>, for maybe an inheritance will come to her from outside and he would be able to collect from it. Similarly, if the husband revolts against his wife, one adds to her <i>ketubah</i> three denars a week; Rebbi Jehudah says three <i>tropaїkes</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “For how long does one reduce? Up to the amount of her <i>ketubah</i>”<i>,</i> etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">A shortened version of the paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 52:13" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.52.13"><i>Gen</i>.<i>rabba</i> 52(13</a>), with most of the attribution of names omitted.</i> Here you say seven, and there you say three? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina said, since she is obligated for seven<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">The 7 types of work enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.6.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i>, he deducts seven; he, since he is obligated for three<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">The obligations enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:9" href="/Exodus.21.9"><i>Ex.</i> 21:9</a>, whatever they mean.</i>, has to add three. Think of it, if she brought him slaves, she is not obligated for anything! Think of it, if he stipulated [that he is not obligated for] either <i>šĕ‘ēr</i>, or dress, or <i>‘onāh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">While in general we hold (following R. Jehudah) that in money matters biblical rules are only default options which can be changed or eliminated by contract, in non-monetary matters one usually holds that biblical rules are prescriptive and cannot be abolished. The Yerushalmi here considers sexual intercourse a money matter since the Mishnah gives monetary value to the refusal of intercourse. This argument, which is against all principles of the Babli in the usual rabbinic interpretation, will be important for the last statement of the Halakhah.<br>In any case, the arguments given here show that the explanation cannot be the correct one (even though it is quoted by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 63a:4:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.63a.4.1">Tosaphot, 63a <i>s. v.</i> פוחתין</a>, as <i>the</i> opinion of the Yerushalmi. Tosaphot do not attribute the statement to R. Yose ben R. Ḥanina, even though the latter is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 63a" href="/Ketubot.63a">Babli, 63a</a>, representing the opinion that “revolting” refers to any of the mutual obligations in marriage). One must agree that the Mishnah speaks only of the case that one partner refuses sexual activity with the other. The Babli leaves the question open as to which interpretation is the correct one.</i>, he is not obligated for anything! What is it? Following Rebbi Joḥanan, that the suffering of the male<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">If deprived of sexual fulfillment.</i> is greater than that of the female. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Judges 16:16" href="/Judges.16.16"><i>Jud.</i> 16:16</a>, speaking of Delilah and Simson.</i>: “It was when she had nagged him day after day and pressured him.” What means “and pressured him”? Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 9b" href="/Sotah.9b">Babli, <i>Soṭah</i> 9b</a>, in a slightly more graphic description, “R.Isaac in the name of Rebbi Ammi” or something similar.</i> said, that she slipped away from under him. “He felt badly, to die”. <i>He</i> felt badly, ready to die, but she did not feel badly, to die. But some say that she fulfilled her needs with others. So much more she should have wanted<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rather weak argument, that Delilah could not have slept with other men since then she would also have wanted to sleep more with Simson, in view of the enormous sum of money promised her by the Philistine princes. The argument of R. Naḥman in the name of a different R. Naḥman is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 107a" href="/Sanhedrin.107a">Babli (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 107a</a>) in the name of R. Jehudah.</i>, since Rebbi Naḥman said in the name of Rebbi Naḥman: This human limb, if you starved it you satisfied it, if you satisfied it you starved it.
Following Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">who in the Mishnah held the wife of a sailor to one sex act every six months. If she refuses sex with her husband, does she lose 7 denars every week or every six months?</i>, how far can he deduct? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">In a somewhat different formulation, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.7">Tosephta 5:7</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 63a" href="/Ketubot.63a">Babli 63a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 64a" href="/Ketubot.64a">64a</a>.</i>: Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: One writes a bill of rebellion for the husband<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">The expression על בעלה is uncommon. Although it can be explained as “for her husband’s benefit”, probably it is a copyist’s error for על כתובתה mentioned in the quote of the Tosephta later in this paragraph.</i> of a preliminarily married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Who now is forbidden to sleep with her husband but who made it clear that she will refuse sex with him when definitely married. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 63a" href="/Ketubot.63a">Babli, 63a</a>, explains that she is inflicting pain on the husband since “one cannot compare one who has bread in his basket to one who has no bread in his basket”, i. e., one who is assured of a sexual partner after time. The same argument is to be assumed for the woman being temporarily disabled by her period.</i>, or a sick one, a menstruating woman or one who is waiting for her levir. Where do we hold? If she rebelled against him when she was having her period, the Torah made her rebel against him<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Since sexual relations with her are forbidden, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:19" href="/Leviticus.18.19"><i>Lev.</i> 18:19</a>.</i>! But we must hold that she rebelled against him before she had her period and now she has it. At that moment she would not be able to rebel but you say one writes, therefore one also deducts<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, the sailor’s wife loses money every week, not every three months.</i>. From where does one deduct? From the additions to her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τά παράφερνα, “additions to the dowry which the bride brings”. This corresponds to תּוֹסֶפֶת כְּתוּבָּה, the amounts the husband promises his wife for her dowry over and above the legal minimum of 200/100 <i>zuz</i> (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.3.1">Mishnah 6:3</a>). In this opinion, one forces the husband to divorce his wife after the additions to the dowry were written down.</i><i>.</i> Let us hear from the following: “Rebbi Yose says, he continues to reduce, for maybe an inheritance will come to her from outside and he would be able to collect from it.” He mentioned only inheritance, which is infrequent. That means he deducts from the additions to he <i>ketubah.</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">From here on, a parallel but different text is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 64a" href="/Ketubot.64a">Babli, 64a</a>.</i> Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Samuel: One writes a bill of rebellion for a preliminarily married woman, but one does not write a bill of rebellion for one who is waiting for her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Since she always can receive <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and leave the family.</i>. But did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state that one writes a bill of rebellion on the <i>ketubah</i> of a menstruating woman or a sick one, a preliminarily married woman or one who is waiting for her levir? There, according to the first Mishnah, here according to the later Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 1:7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.1.7">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 1:7</a>, that in earlier times levirate marriage was preferred over <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> so that the woman refusing her levir was inflicting pain on him, but today <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is preferred and in refusing her levir the woman is acting correctly. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:6:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.6.8"><i>Yebamot</i>12:7, Note 140</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, even if you say according to the later Mishnah, <sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Different formulations in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.6">Tosephta 5:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 63b" href="/Ketubot.63b">Babli 63b</a>.</i>”the later Court [instituted that] one warns her for four weeks, then she writes a receipt for her <i>ketubah</i> and leaves<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">I e., she confirms in writing that her former husband does not owe her any money; then she can claim a bill of divorce from him.</i>.”
Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose: A wife who leaves because of a bad reputation<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">A woman whom her husband divorces without paying the <i>ketubah</i> since he can produce evidence of unfaithfulness of his wife even though it does not add up to formal legal proof (which could be produced only by the testimony of two eye witnesses to the illicit copulation.)</i> has no rags<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">If the value of the garments she brought into the marriage was determined and written into the <i>ketubah</i> document as monetary obligation of the husband. If the divorce is for cause, the husband does not have to pay. It is stated here that in this case, even if the garments still exist at the time of the divorce, the divorcee cannot take them; they remain the husband’s property. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 101b" href="/Ketubot.101b">Babli, 101b</a>, emphatically disagrees.</i>; the rebellious one has rags. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: The rebellious one and the one who leaves because of a bad reputation can claim neither sustenance nor rags.
<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence has been discussed in great detail by M. A. Friedman, <i>Jewish Marriage in Palestine, A Cairo Geniza Study,</i> Tel-Aviv and New York 1980, vol. 1, Chapter V,A: The Wife’s Right to Demand Termination of the Marriage, pp. 312–346.<br>The stipulation referred to is quoted in part in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:6:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.6.7">Halakhah 7:7, Note 96</a>. The full text has been recovered by Friedman (<i>loc. cit.,</i> pp. 328–329) from Geniza <i>ketubot</i>: “If X, the groom, hates this Y, does not desire her, and wants to separate from her, he shall pay all that is written and specified in this marriage contract, completely. And if this Y hates this X, her husband, and desires to leave his home, she shall lose her <i>ketubah</i> money, and she shall not take anything but only that which she brought from her father’s house and she shall go out by the mouth of the court (עַל פֻּם בֵּית דִּינָה) and with the consent of our masters, the Sages.”<br>The sentence about the husband hating his wife does not bring anything new. The sentence about the wife hating the husband states first that the husband does not have to pay the promised <i>ketubah</i> sum, then that she takes the rags with her (following R. Ismael ben R. Yose in the preceding paragraph), and, finally, that she is to be divorced “by the mouth of the court,” i. e., that the court will direct the husband to divorce his wife. Even though biblical law, as interpreted by all Jewish sects, does grant the husband the exclusive power to divorce, to the exclusion of any right of the wife to force a divorce, R. Yose (the Amora) holds that if the divorce is forced as consequence of a monetary settlement, the stipulation regards monetary, not religious, obligations and is enforceable in court.<br>The essence of this prenuptial agreement, which allows a woman to buy her freedom from an intolerable marriage, was adopted in Babylonia by the Saboraim Rav Rabba and Mar Rav Huna as a <i>taqqanah,</i> a rabbinic ordinance, which instructed the husband to divorce his rebellious wife while granting him the monetary advantages of the Yerushalmi agreement. This ordinance was in fact disestablished by R. Asher ben Ieḥiel, <i>Rosh,</i> in the 14th Century, when he interpreted the rule as a recommendation, not obligatory on the husband. Cf. I. Szczepansky, The <i>Takkanot</i> of Israel, Jerusalem-New York; Vol. 3, Chapter 13 (1992) (Hebrew). The dependency of the Saboraïm on the Yerushalmi is studied by Dr. Eliahu Raḥamim Ziani, רבנן סבוראי וכללי ההלכה, Haifa 1992.</i> Rebbi Yose said: Those who write: “If he hates, if she hates”, that is a monetary condition and these conditions are valid<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is asserted as R. Jehudah’s opinion: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 19b" href="/Kiddushin.19b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 19b</a>. In the Yerushalmi it is a generally accepted principle transmitted anonymously: Below 9:1 (32d 1. 51); <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 7:10 (11c 1. 11), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba batra</i>8:6</a> (16b 1. 28), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.8.2">8:8</a> (16c 1. 37).</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody provides for his wife through a third party, he cannot give her less that two <i>qab</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">One sixth of a <i>seah,</i> about 2.17 liters. One speaks here of grain, delivered per week.</i> of wheat or four <i>qab</i> of barley. Rebbi Yose said, only Rebbi Ismael assigned her barley, becaused he lived in proximity of Idumea<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 64b" href="/Ketubot.64b">Babli, 64b</a>, reads this sentence as meaning that only R. Ismael requires that the quantity of barley be double that of wheat. There is no reason to assume this interpretation for the Yerushalmi; it seems that R. Yose forbids a husband to give his wife barley except in regions in which wheat is not cultivated.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody provides for his wife through a third party,” etc. What is “in proximity of Idumea”? In the South<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">It is known that R. Ismael, the student of R. Joshua, lived in the South but it is not known what the definition of “South” is, whether in the mountains South of Hebron or in the Southern plain near Ascalon. He probably did not live in <i>Kefar Aziz,</i> cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 6:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.6.3.1"><i>Kilaim,</i> Chapter 6, Note 42</a>. Idumea in Second Temple times was the Negev.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One gives her half a <i>qab</i> of legumes<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Peas or beans.</i> and half a <i>qab</i> of oil<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Olive oil.</i>, a <i>qab</i> of dried figs or a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>mina</i> as a weight is 60 <i>šeqel.</i></i> of fig cake; if there are none available one finds her fruit from other places. Also one gives her a bed and a mat; if he has no bed, a mat and a rug<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">To sleep on it.</i>. Also, one gives her a cap for her head<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Since a married woman may not be seen in public without a bonnet on her head. Bed, mat, cap, and belt are once-a-lifetime gifts.</i> and a belt for her loins, and shoes every holiday, and garments worth 50 tetradrachmas every year. One does not give her new ones in the summer or worn ones in the winter, but one gives her garments worth 50 tetradrachmas in the winter and she covers herself with the worn garments<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Which in the meantime became summer weights by constant use.</i> in the summer; and the rags are hers<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">The husband has no right to require her to hand over last year’s used garments before giving her the new ones.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One gives her half a <i>qab</i> of legumes and half a <i>qab</i> of oil,” etc. Rebbi Mana said, a mina, i. e. four <i>riṭl</i><sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">It is not known what these <i>riṭl</i> are. It is the consensus of the linguists that Syriac <i>raṭl,</i> Arabic <i>roṭi,</i> with the derived verb <i>rṭl</i> “to weigh by hand” is simply Greek λίτρα, a Roman pound of 12 oz. This also is Musaphia’s explanation of <i>riṭl’,</i> but a mina of 60 <i>seqalim</i> is about 2 <i>librae.</i> (In modern times, the weight of a <i>roṭi</i> varied from .45 kg in Egypt to 3.2 kg in Syria.) R. Mana states that the mina used here is 4 Roman 1bs., 1.38 kg, or 100 “holy” <i>šeqel.</i> The translation follows S. Lieberman [<i>Tarbiz</i> 4 (1933), p. 377–378] who identifies וּ as shorthand for הוּא “this is”.</i>. He gives her a pillow, a light<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">A small clay vessel to be filled with oil.</i> and wick, and an amphora, and a pot. Rebbi Yose said, she has no right to a pillow since the wives of poor men do not sleep on a pillow<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rules given here have to be generally valid, only the minimum amounts can be prescribed; the remainder is a matter of private contract between husband and wife. The rule is a matter of dispute in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65a" href="/Ketubot.65a">Babli, 65a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If she left over from her food, it is hers, if she left over rags they are his - if she left over rags they are hers<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">The text is unclear here between the scribe and the first corrector. The next sentence shows that both possibilities are valid; it was a matter of dispute between schools which alternative was chosen. The Babli disagrees with all the rules spelled out here, 65b.</i>. That is, of a married woman. But for a widow, both her leftover food and her leftover rags are hers<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Anything given by the heirs to the widow becomes the latter’s unconditional property.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One gives her a silver obolus for her needs and she eats with him Friday nights<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">“Eating” is a common metaphor for sexual relations; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 39:6" href="/Genesis.39.6"><i>Gen</i>. 39:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 30:20" href="/Proverbs.30.20"><i>Prov.</i>30:20</a>.</i>. If he does not give her a silver obolus for her needs, she works for herself. And what does she work for him? In Judea, a weight of five tetradrachmas warp<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">She spins. The warp, being fixed under tension in the weaving frame, has to be spun much tighter than the woof.</i>, which is ten tetradrachmas in Galilee, or in Judea the weight of ten tetradrachmas woof which are twenty tetradrachmas in Galilee. If she was nursing, one reduces the amount of her work and increases her food. When has this been said<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">For whom are the amounts mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.11.1">Mishnaiot 11–13</a> binding?</i>? For the poorest man in Israel. But for the most honored one, everything commensurable with his honor<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">The wife would have standing in court if she complains about being treated shabbily.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One gives her a silver obolus for her needs and she eats with him every Friday night,” etc. The matters are formulated in clean language<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opinion of Rav at the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8">Halakhah 8, Note 198</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65b" href="/Ketubot.65b">Babli, 65b</a>, it is attributed to Rav Assi, the colleague of Rav (in many mss. and the <i>editto princeps</i> erroneously: Rav Ashi).</i>. Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Really eating<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this opinion is attributed to Rav Naḥman, Samuel’s student.</i>. In the opinion of Rav, she eats at his expense<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Since “eating” is meant as an euphemism for sexual intercourse, it implies in the context that she does not eat Friday nights from the food allotted her during the week.</i>; in the opinion of Rebbi Joḥanan she eats at her own expense.
