She has no claim to wine since poor Jewish women do not drink wine<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">And the rules are written only for the poor; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:8" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.8">Tosephta 5:8</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 64b" href="/Ketubot.64b">Babli 64b</a>.</i>. Do rich women drink? Did we not state: It happened that the Sages assigned to Martha bat Boethos<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">The paradigm of a rich widow; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 6:4, Note 75</a>.</i> two <i>se‘ah</i> of wine every day. How can the court assign wine<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Let a woman drink wine in the absence of a husband. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65a" href="/Ketubot.65a">Babli, 65a</a>, approves of not more than one cup of wine per meal.</i>? Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada said, because of “Whoring, wine, and cider will destroy the mind.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 4:11" href="/Hosea.4.11"><i>Hosea</i> 4:11</a>. It is inferred that drinking wine induces sexual desires.</i>” But did we not state: ”If she was nursing, one reduces the amount of her work and increases her food”? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said wine, for it increases the milk<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65b" href="/Ketubot.65b">Babli, 65b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Also<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">The original scribe wrote אין which by the first corrector was changed into אף. One has to assume that the scribe intended אִין, Babylonian Aramaic “yes”; in a Yerushalmi text this is a corruption.</i> they assigned it for cooking<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">If her food was cooked with wine there was no problem since cooking eliminates the alcohol.</i>. Nevertheless, she cursed them and said to them, so you should give to your daughters. Rebbi Aḥa said, and we answered her, Amen<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">As confirmation.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Ẓadoq said, I should not see consolation<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Being part of an oath formula, the positive has a negative implication and vice versa. The implication is that the speaker would give up his share of paradise if what he says is not true.</i> if I did not see her collecting barley grains between horses’ hooves at Acco. I quoted about her the verse: “The dainty one among you and the pampered, …<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 28:56" href="/Deuteronomy.28.56"><i>Deut.</i> 28:56</a>, the chapter of curses.</i>” “If you have no experience, most beautiful of women, go following the flock …<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 1:8" href="/Song_of_Songs.1.8"><i>Cant.</i> 1:8</a>. This verse has a positive interpretation in all Midrash sources.</i>”. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">The reliability of the tradition about Martha bat Boethos is questioned since a parallel tradition is reported about another woman. But it seems that both traditions are one and that Martha (“the lady”) bat (“of the family of”) Boethos is Miryam bat Simeon ben Boethos, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 6:4, Note 75</a>; Josephus <i>Antiquities</i> xv. 320 ff. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65a" href="/Ketubot.65a">Babli, 65a</a> and 66b/67a (for the second story, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 5:9-10" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).5.9-10">Tosephta 5:9–10</a>), both stories refer to one person, the widowed daughter-in-law of one Nikodaimon ben Gorion waiting for her levir; in the second story (in an intended contrast to the Yerushalmi) it is emphasized that nobody said “amen”, (because the unhappiness of a childless widow cannot be compensated with money.)</i>: It happened that the Sages assigned to Miryam, the daughter of Simeon ben Gorion, a daily supply of perfume for 500 denar, when she was only waiting for her levir. Nevertheless, she cursed them and said to them, so you should give to your daughters. Rebbi Aḥa said, and we answered her, Amen. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Ẓadoq said, I should not see consolation if I did not see her bound with her hair to a horse’s tail at Acco. I quoted about her the verse: “The dainty one among you and the pampered, …”.

Chapter 6



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> What a woman finds or makes with her hands belongs to her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.6.1">Mishnah 4:6</a>.</i>. Of what she inherits he eats the yield during her lifetime<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">He is obligated to administer her property so it retains its value. For this, he is paid with the yield of the property. All these rules can be modified by prenuptial agreements.</i>. [Payments she receives for] settlements for shame and diminution of value belong to her<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">If she is injured by a third party, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 8:1</a> states that the attacker has to pay for injury, pain, medical costs, lost earnings, and mental anguish. The expression “diminution of value” used here covers both injury (permanent impairment) and pain; “shame” is mental anguish. Since the husband has a claim to her handiwork, he also has a claim for payment for the time his wife is unable to work.</i>; Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra says, in case it is covered<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The wife’s injury is covered by her clothing; then the husband’s shame that he was unable to defend his wife is not so great. If the wife’s injury is visible, the husband’s loss of face is serious.</i>, she receives two thirds and he one third; in case it is visible, he receives two thirds and she one third. His part shall be given immediately; her part shall be invested in real estate and he eats its yield.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “What a woman finds or makes with her hands belongs to her husband,” etc. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Immi: Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagree: One said, this is everybody’s opinion, the other said it is in dispute<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Between R. Meïr and R. Joḥanan the Alexandrian who disagree in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.5.1">Mishnah 5:5</a> whether a man can dedicate his wife’s work to Heaven.</i>. We do not know who said what. It is reasonable that Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish should be the one who said it is in dispute since he explained that [the husband] provides her with food but does not give her a silver obolus as pocket money<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.5.2-4">Halakhah 5:5</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 11:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.11.4.2"><i>Nedarim</i> 11:4, Notes 51–55</a>. R. Meïr holds that the obligatory work the wife does for her husband is for her silver obolus and what she does in addition is for her food. Therefore, if he does not provide her with pocket money, he has no right to her work and, similarly, to what she finds. For R. Joḥanan the Alexandrian, the work is for her food and the excess for the pocket money. (This is where R. Joḥanan disagrees.) Therefore, the husband has the right to what she makes and finds.</i>, and we did state: “If he does not give her a silver obolus as pocket money, what she makes with her hands is hers.” The work of her hands is parallel to what she finds. Rebbi Jacob bar Immi came in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: It is everybody’s opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">What she finds belongs to her husband according to everybody, as explained in the next paragraph.</i>. That means that Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish varies in his opinions<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that he taught different approaches to different students.</i>.
For whom is it needed<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The clause in the Mishnah that the husband has only the usufruct of any inheritance coming to his wife during the marriage.</i>? For Rebbi Meïr! Even though for Rebbi Meïr the hand of the slave is his master’s hand<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Similarly, R. Meïr holds that a wife cannot act legally except as her husband’s representative. It would seem reasonable that a wife can retain separate property by prenuptial agreement (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 7:1, Note 1</a>), but for R. Meïr one would expect that a wife can only acquire an inheritance as representative for her husband. Therefore, it is essential that the Mishnah state that an inheritance becomes the wife’s sole property for which the husband has to act as administrator. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 11:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.11.9.1"><i>Nedarim</i> 11:8, Note 70</a>; <i>Ma‘aser Šeni</i> 4:4, Note 95; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 88b" href="/Nedarim.88b">Babli <i>Nedarim</i> 88b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 23b" href="/Kiddushin.23b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 23b</a>.</i> and if the wife acquired title the husband should have acquired it; he agrees that his rights over it<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The inheritance.</i> are restricted to the use of the yield. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:5</a>.</i>: “The finds of his underage son and daughter or of his Canaanite slave<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">It is not required that the slave be Phoenician. Any non-Jewish slave who became semi-Jewish by circumcision (for a male) and immersion in a <i>miqweh</i> is called “Canaanite slave”. In the theory of the Babli, the Canaanite slave’s body is the property of his master; therefore, if the slave lifts a find to acquire it, it is legally his master whose hand took it.</i> or slave-girl as well as his wife’s find belong to him,” for he can direct them to do other work. Why do we say: “The finds of his adult son and daughter or of his Hebrew slave<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">While the rules for the treatment of Hebrew slaves (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:1-11" href="/Exodus.21.1-11"><i>Ex.</i> 21:1–11</a>) are a frequent topic in the Talmudim, the subject is purely theoretical since the institution of Hebrew slavery disappeared with the end of the First Commonwealth. It is asserted that only the working capability of the slave is the master’s, not his body. Therefore, if he lifts a find to acquire it, it is not the master’s hand which lifts the find.</i> or slave-girl belong to them,” because he cannot direct them to do other work<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, the master can direct the Hebrew slave to perform any task he asks of him; but he cannot direct him not to use his hands for anything else.</i>. But his wife he cannot direct to do other work<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In Chapter 5, an exhaustive list was given of work the husband can demand from his wife. The wife’s body certainly is not her husband’s property. Therefore, one does not understand why her find should be her husband’s.</i> and you say that her find belongs to him! Rebbi Joḥanan said, there is another reason for his wife. What is the other reason for his wife? Rebbi Ḥaggai says, because of quarrel<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">One has such a poor opinion of Jewish husbands that one is afraid he would be offended if the wife would not share her find with him [mentioned also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:5:2-6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.5.2-6.2"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:5</a> (8a 1. 15)]. This is the only explanation offered in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96a" href="/Ketubot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>; it is called “because of jealousy”.</i>. Rebbi Yose does not say so, but that she should not smuggle away<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning: stealing.</i> any of her husband’s property and say, I found it. Think of it, if another person gave it to her as a gift<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The gift can be given on condition that the husband have no right to it. Should the wife not be believed if she says she received a gift?</i>! A gift is public knowledge, a find is not public knowledge. Think of it, if she found it in the presence of witnesses! This because of that<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose will agree that in the case of a find in the presence of other people his reason is invalid. He holds that, nevertheless, the rabbinic decree giving the find to the husband stands because ịt would be impractical to admit exceptions.</i>. Rebbi Yoḥanan said, if they<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the adult children to whom the Mishnah in <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> assigns their finds. This is qualified; the Mishnah applies only if the children are financially independent. In the Babli, this is formulated that “they are not dependent on their father’s table.” Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 4:6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.4.6.3"><i>Peah</i> 4:6, Note 107</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 1:5:2-6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.1.5.2-6.2"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 1:5</a> (8a 1.3); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 12b" href="/Bava_Metzia.12b">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 12b</a>.</i> are not dependent on their father. But if they are dependent on their father, their finds belong to him.
Rebbi Isaac instructed about one who had sent away his wife but not liquidated her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Greek φερνή “dowry”. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:6:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.6.2-7">Halakhah 7:7</a>, the word is used in the meaning of <i>ketubah</i>, the document in which the value of the dowry was recorded. Therefore, it seems reasonable to read the text that R. Isaac obligated the former husband to support his former wife until he had paid the last penny of everything he was obligated to by the <i>ketubah</i> document, not only until he had returned all her dowry.</i>, that he has to feed her until the time he liquidated it.
Rebbi Redipha, Rebbi Aḥa, in the name of Rebbi Abun bar Cahana: Because he does not make her lose anything<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the rules of R. Yehudah ben Bathyra who gives the husband part of the payment for shame and diminution of value. Why should the husband get part of the payment for shame? Since the payment is pure revenue for the recipient, not restitution, she still ends up having more than she did before her injury.</i>. In secret<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">If the scars of her injury are not visible in public. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 66a" href="/Ketubot.66a">Babli, 66a</a>, formulates: His wife is his body.</i>, why does he take? Because of the pain he suffers with her.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody decided<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">He promised a fixed amount of dowry payable at the moment of the final marriage ceremony.</i> on money for his son-in-law and the son-in-law died<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Between the preliminary and the final marriage ceremony.</i>, the Sages said that he can say<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">To the levir who is scheduled to marry his daughter. This is intended to induce the levir to prefer <i>ḥălîṣah</i> to the levirate marriage.</i>, I was ready to give to your brother, but it is impossible for me to give to you.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody decided on money for his son-in-law and the son-in-law died,” etc. Are these not the things that are acquired by speech<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.1.3">Halakhah 5:1, Notes 16</a> ff., that promises made at the moment of the preliminary marriage are enforceable in court. Why can the levir not sue for his brother’s property?</i>? Bar Qappara stated: He promised the dowry on condition there be a marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">A promise of dowry becomes enforceable only after the definitive marriage ceremony.</i>. And it is so<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.5.2-3">Halakhah 13:5</a>: If somebody promised a sum to his son-in-law at the moment of the preliminary wedding but went bankrupt before the final wedding, and the groom is not willing to proceed with the definitive marriage without the dowry being paid, the question is whether the girl can insist on either to be married or to be freed to marry somebody else. In Tosephta 13:4, it is stated: If somebody decided on money for his underage daughter but then went bankrupt, one forces him to give because one can give a minor benefit but not obligation. A similar text is in the Babli, 109 a. In all these texts, it is stated “one forces him”, without an explanation whom one forces.</i>: If somebody decided on money for his underage daughter, one forces him to give. But not for the adult one<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Is a promise of dowry for an adult daughter not enforceable?</i>? Rebbi Abun said, one forces [the groom] to give a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If the daughter was a minor at the time of the preliminary marriage and then the father went bankrupt, the court will force the groom either to marry the girl without money or to free her by a bill of divorce since acts of third parties to the detriment of minors are invalid and not enforceable in court. The same explanation is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 109a" href="/Ketubot.109a">Babli, 109a</a>, by Rava, a frequent discussion partner of Ravin (= R. Abun.)</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she decided to bring him 1’000 denars, he decides as equivalent fifteen minas<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If the dowry is in cash which the groom will use in his business, he has to obligate himself in the <i>ketubah</i> to return 150% of the capital at the dissolution of the marriage to account for his earnings from that capital.</i>. Corresponding to estimates he decides one-fifth less<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">As a matter of principle, any part of the dowry given in goods has to be capitalized at 80% of its estimated value at the time of marriage. Some commentators of the Babli explain that the 20% represent the depreciation of things in use; others explain that estimators have a tendency to inflate the values to make the bride appear richer than she is. Cf. Note 42.</i>. If it was appraised for a mina and it is worth a mina, he has only a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">If the rule of the preceding paragraph is not followed and the groom agrees to accept in the <i>ketubah</i> the full written value as value received, he cannot later complain and have the <i>ketubah</i> sum reduced.</i>. For the estimate of a mina she gives him 31 [tetradrachmas and one]<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">In ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>, and in a few other mss., two words are missing. The corrected text reads:<br>שְׁלֹשִׁים וְאַחַת סֶלַע וְאֶחָד דֵּינָר. This text was translated. Cf. The Babylonian Talmud with Variant Readings, Tractate Kethubot vol. 2, ed. M. Herschler, Jerusalem 1977, p. קי-קיא, Notes 54–55.</i> denar<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">·31·4 + 1 = 125; 0.8·125 = 100.<br>For a value of 100 denars written in the <i>ketubah</i>, she has to deliver goods estimated at 125 denars.</i>. For 400 she gives 500, for what the groom decides, he decides one-fifth less.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she decided to bring him 1’000 denars,” etc. Why did they say for money, one and one half times, and for estimations less one fifth? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, one estimates the will of the woman that she wants to use her vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">כלי includes both garments and household vessels. Tosaphot (66a, <i>s. v.</i> פוחת) quotes the statement in the name of Samuel but in Alfasi the text is quoted as in the ms.</i> and depreciates them by a fifth. One estimates the will of the man to use it<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The cash received.</i> in trade and to make them one and one half<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">He expects to earn more than 50% from the dowry.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, this implies<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The cash received.</i> that nobody has the right to sell his wife’s vessels. Example: Rebbi Ḥiyya, Rebbi Yasa, and Rebbi Immi went to appraise for Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina’s daughter. They said to [the groom]: Deduct a fifth and double<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">First he is told to deduct 20% to arrive at the real value of the dowry and then to double, to inflate the apparent value. This was a widespread practice in Babylonia and was proposed by the three Babylonian-born rabbis acting as appraisers. The device was rejected by the Palestinian groom. The subject is dealt with by M. A. Friedman (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.8.5">Chapter 5, Note 226</a>), vol. 1, pp. 296–298, where references to the large literature about the subject are given. Friedman notes that none of the Palestinian <i>ketubot</i> edited by him exhibit artificial inflation of the value of the dowry.</i>. He said to them, he<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning himself.</i> deducts a fifth and does not double.
Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If she brought him gold, at full value<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Gold jewellery does not depreciate when worn. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 67a" href="/Ketubot.67a">Babli, 67a</a>, points out that under a government which depreciates its currency, gold coins have the status of jewellery, not of coin.</i>. This was also stated<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah states that certain things in the dowry are accepted at full value.</i>. Jewellery to be turned into denars<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This becomes the husband’s working capital.</i>, at the rate of one and one half. Denars to be turned into jewellery, at their full value. Rebbi Aḥa bar Pappos asked before Rebbi Immi: If she brought him an animal<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Either cattle for agricultural work or goats for milk.</i>? He said to him, at full value. If she brought him real estate: He said to him, at full value. But does he not gain from it<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Why is real estate not evaluated at 150%?</i>? But she collects the real estate, he has only the usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate, whether mortmain or paraphernalia, remains the wife’s property of which the husband has the usufruct. Since at the dissolution of marriage the real estate returns to the wife, there is no need to increase its value in the <i>ketubah</i>. (Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 7:1, Note 1</a>.)</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she decided to bring him money, each tetradrachma is turned into six denars<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This is 150%, as stated in the preceding Mishnah.</i> and the groom engages himself for ten denars for the perfume box for each mina<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">He will provide her with perfumes and accessories worth one tenth of the cash dowry.</i>; Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, all follows local custom.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she decided to bring him money,” etc. “If she decided to bring him 500 denars by appraisal, he makes it 400. If he did not do that but made it 1’000; if she made an agreement<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">This meaning is conjectural, based on the meaning of קצצא in Syriac (cf. <i>Tosefta ki-Fshutah Ketubot</i> p. 245). In the commentary on the Tosephta which is parallel to the text here (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:2-7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.2-7.4">6:6–7</a>), S. Lieberman reads in the text נקִיצּוּתָהּ “what she had decided”, based on the Tosephta text (6:6), and explains that the woman takes all if she actually delivered what she had promised. But in the ms. it is clear that in the Yerushalmi the word ends in the definite article תא, and Lieberman’s identification of Tosephta and Yerushalmi texts (pp. 278–279) cannot be accepted (or the ending תה in the Tosephta should be interpreted as תא.). In the Babli, קִיצוּתָא is “a fixed date”, קִיצְוְתָא “a fixed price.” The explanation given here is close to that proffered by R. Moses Margalit.<br>Since the groom doubled the original appraisal and deviated from the norm, acceptance of this deviation is valid only if explicitly endorsed either in the <i>ketubah</i> or in an accompanying document. In the <i>ketubot</i> published by A. M. Friedman, the sums are regularly acknowledged by the bride’s representatives. It is to be assumed that in every case where one speaks of an agreement made “by the bride,” it means an agreement signed by her father or in his absence another duly authorized member of her family.</i>, she collects everything; if not, he deducts five denars for each tetradrachma, but he cannot touch the addition<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This follows the Mishnah, for each 5 denars of appraised value, the husband (or his estate) is obligated only for 4 denars, one <i>sela</i>. But what he added over and above the appraised value is his irrevocable gift since in Galilee one did not routinely double the appraisals (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.3.2">Note 41</a>.) The widow collects from the estate 400 denars for the appraisal and 500 additional, for a total of 900.</i>. If she decided to bring him 500 denars in coin, he makes it 750<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">As prescribed by the Mishnah.</i>. If he did not do that but made them 1’000; if she made an agreement, she collects everything; if not, he deducts six denars for each tetradrachma<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">If the amount actually given as dowry cannot be ascertained, the husband’s estate is entitled to deduct 6 denars for every 4 in dispute. But the additional 250 denars have to be paid in full.</i>, but he cannot touch the addition. If she decided to bring him 1’000 <i>zuz</i>, he must turn them into fifteen minas. If he did not do that but wrote over to her a field worth 12 minas in place of the 1’000 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">He offers only 1200 in place of the 1500 for which he was obligated by the rules. If the wife accepts this in writing, because she prefers 1200 in real estate to 1500 in silver coin whose silver content depends on the policies of the government, she takes everything that is written in the <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. If she made an agreement, she collects everything; if not<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">And the amount of her claim is in dispute.</i>, one does not decrease for a virgin to less than 200 and for a widow to less than a mina.” Here, you say, he deducts. But there, you say, he does not deduct<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In all cases except the last, definitive rules are given as to how to compute the claim on the estate. Only in the last case can the entire dowry be lost.</i>. Here, if she invalidated part of it, there if she did not invalidate part of it<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Following the reading בבטלה conjectured by S. Lieberman (<i>loc. cit</i>. p. 279) instead of בְּבִטְּלָה ,בנטלה “she invalidated” instead of בְּנָֽטְלָה “she took”.</i>. Here, you say, he touches the addition but there, you say, he does not touch the addition<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In all cases except the last one, the estate has to pay the full amount of the addition over and above the value of the dowry. Only in the last case, there is no clause that protects the addition. By taking real estate for 1’200 <i>zuz</i> she renounced 300 <i>zuz</i> that would have come to her, putting the entire <i>ketubah</i> in question.</i>. Here, he added but did not subtract; there, he subtracted but did not add. It was stated: Both for appraisal and for coin<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">They follow the same rules.</i>. Why for appraisal? Corresponding to what he subtracts, corresponding to what what he adds, corresponding to what she brings<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">All this needs confirmation by the parties in writing.</i>.
So is the Mishnah: “And a perfume box for every mina<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The corrected text is not that of the Mishnah (and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.6">Tosephta, 6:6</a>), “ten denars <i>for</i> the perfume box for each mina” but “ten denars <i>and a</i> perfume box for each mina.” Cf. J. N. Epstein, <sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>מבוא לנוסח המשנה p. 494; תלמוד בבלי עם שינויי נוסחאות כתובות, vol. 2, p. קיב, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.2.1">Note 25</a>; תוספתא כפשוטה כתובות p. 277.<br>One has to interpret הַכֹּל מְנָה as לְכָל־מְנָה. It is not necessary to change the text; cf. the author’s <i>The Scholar’s</i> <i>Haggadah</i>, Northvale 1995, p. 322.</i>.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, they made usufruct of perfumes like usufruct of money<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what is referred to. From the next sentence, it seems that the paragraph refers to the statement of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel that in the absence of explicit written agreement, all monetary aspects are judged based on local customs. Spices and perfumes given as articles of trade have the status of money (are better than money in an inflationary environment, and still are equal to money after Diocletian’s stabilization of the Roman currency.) In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 67a" href="/Ketubot.67a">Babli, 67a</a>, this is restricted to Antiochene spices and perfumes (which, probably, were of guaranteed quality.)</i>. Rebbi Avin said, they made usufruct of procreation like usufruct of money<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The groom can be generous in the conditions of the <i>ketubah</i> since he or his children will inherit the money. It is left to local custom (in the Middle Ages mostly: local regulations) to deal with the disposition of the dowry if the couple remain childless; a clause which denies the husband the inheritance of his childless deceased wife is authorized by R. Yose and the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:1:2-8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.1.2-8.5">Halakhah 9:1</a>; cf. M. A. Friedman, <i>Jewish Marriage in Palestine</i>, vol. 1, VE, pp. 391–418.</i>. As the following: The students of Rebbi Yose went to Qaddišin; they found them childless. They said to them: Did you stipulate between you? If you stipulated, it is fine<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The rule that the husband inherits from his wife, being a money matter, can be set aside by stipulation. The biblical root of the rule is not explicit; cf. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 134.</i>; otherwise everything follows the local custom.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody marries off his daughter without mentioning particulars he should not give her less than 50 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">As dowry. A person having a capital of 50 <i>zuz</i> (silver denars) as working capital is barred from taking welfare payments (Mishnah <i>Peah</i> 9:9).</i> If he had decided to take her in naked<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.2-4">Halakhah 6</a>, some people have to come up with a large dowry to marry off their daughter but some can take money for giving away their daughter.</i> the husband should not say, if she comes to my house I shall clothe her in my garment, but he covers her when she still is in her father’s house. Similarly, those who marry off an orphan girl<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The overseers of charity can use public money and even impose a tax on the public to provide a minimal dowry for a fatherless girl. (It is really the mother and/or the brothers who <i>marry</i> <i>off</i> the girl but the overseers of charity <i>provide</i> the money.)</i> should not give her less that 50 <i>zuz</i>, and if money is available one provides for her according to her social standing<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The overseers of charity cannot collect money to provide the girl with a dowry that would approximate what her father would have given had he lived, but if there already is money in the charity account they have the right to vote her more than 50 <i>zuz</i>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody marries off his daughter,” etc. Rebbi Abba Mari, Rebbi Yose’s brother, asked: Did we not state: From where that even if he said, I shall go naked but clothe her, one does not tell him to be naked and to clothe her but he clothes her according to her social standing<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The intended text is probably close to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.7">Tosephta 6:7</a>: If somebody marries off his daughter and contracted with his son-in-law that the latter should stand naked if only he provided her with clothes , one does not tell him to stand naked in public but that he has to clothe her according to her standing. In the Tosephta, “standing naked” is a figure of speech; why should it be taken literally in the Mishnah?</i>? There, it is the way of people to say, it is better for me to stand naked if only I cover my wife; but here it was a prior condition.
So is the Mishnah: And so those who provide for the orphan girl<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.5.1">Note 68</a>, parenthesis.</i>. Rebbi Ḥinena said, this means that one says to the overseers to take out a loan<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The overseers of charity can use public money and even impose a tax on the public to provide a minimal dowry for a fatherless girl. (It is really the mother and/or the brothers who <i>marry</i> <i>off</i> the girl but the overseers of charity <i>provide</i> the money.)</i>. For he explains it, if nothing is in the wallet one takes out a loan up to fifty. But if there is money in the wallet, one may add. Rebbi Yose said, this means that one does not say to the overseers to take out a loan. For he explains if there is money in the wallet<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that he does not accept the last sentence in his Mishnah text.</i>. But if there is no money one diminishes. As the following, about a girl in the days of Rebbi Immi. He said, let it be held over for the holiday<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">R. Immi did not want to give public funds for the dowry of an orphan girl because he needed the money to distribute to the poor for their holiday needs.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said to him, you are causing a loss<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The orphan girl will not be able to marry.</i>, but give everything, for the Lord of the holiday exists<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Give her a dowry of what is available in the charity account and God will see to it that money will be donated to charity for the holiday.</i>. It turns out that Rebbi Ḥanina holds with Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Yose with Rebbi Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">If R. Immi thought that the overseers of charity can take out loans, he would not have to worry about the holiday.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If an orphan girl was married off by her mother or her brothers and they wrote her 100 or 50 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Less than what she could have expected, given her father’s wealth.</i>, after she becomes an adult she can claim from them what is appropriate to be given to her. Rebbi Jehudah says, if he married off his first daughter, the second should be given in the way the first had been given<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">If the father died before the second daughter was married, the second should get the percentage of the estate that the first got from the property.</i>. But the Sages say, sometimes it happens that a person was poor and became rich, or was rich and became poor. But one appraises the property and gives to her<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The standard 10%. They will interpret “rich” and “poor” as feeling rich or poor, and giving his daughter more or less than the standard 10%.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If an orphan girl was married off by her mother or her brothers,” etc. So is the Mishnah: If they married off the first one there should be given<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of a number of Mishnah mss., among them both the Cambridge and the Kaufmann mss. A number of mss., among them the Parma ms., read השׂיאה “she (the mother) married off” (<i>Babli with variant readings</i>, p. קלג). In this version, what the father did is not a precedent for his heirs but the heirs have to be consistent in the treatment of the daughters. (The text of the Mishnah here, in the Babli, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta 6:3</a> which refers to the father, is found in the Munich ms. of the Babli and the Mishnah mss. of the Maimonides tradition.) The arguments of J. N. Epstein (<i>loc. cit</i>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.4.2">Note 62</a>) who wants to disregard the change in number, cannot be sustained in view of the many Mishnah mss. confirming the Yerushalmi reading.</i>. The words of the Sages: <sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta 6:3</a>.</i>”Sometimes a man marries off his daughter and spends money on her, and sometimes a man marries off his daughter and collects money for her.”
Rebbi Ze‘ira asked Rav Naḥman bar Jacob and Rav Ammi bar Pappai, who is the Tanna of “a tenth of the estate”? Rebbi Ze‘ura<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">He probably is the Amora called Ze‘iri in the Babli.</i> said to him in the name of Rav Jeremiah: A tenth of the estate following Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This is an explicit <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta, 6:3</a>: Rebbi says, each [daughter] takes a tenth of the estate. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 68a" href="/Ketubot.68a">Babli 68a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 52b" href="/Ketubot.52b">52b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 39b" href="/Nedarim.39b"><i>Nedarim</i> 39b</a>.)</i>. They asked before Rebbi: If there were ten daughters. Then if the first one took a tenth of the estate, the second took a tenth of the estate, the third, the fourth, the fifth, and so on up to the tenth, there is nothing left for the son! He said to them: The first one takes a tenth of the estate and leaves<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The first one takes her part, the younger sisters get less than she did. This is also accepted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 68" href="/Ketubot.68">Babli, 68a/b</a>.</i>; the second takes a tenth of the remainder, the third from what then is left, the fourth of what then is left, up to the tenth from what then is left. It turns out that the daughters take two thirds less a little, and the son takes one third plus a little<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Let us assume that each daughter takes a part <i>p</i> from the estate. Let <i>E</i><sub>o</sub> be the original estate, <i>E</i><sub>n</sub> the amount left after the <i>n</i>-th daughter took her part. Then<br><i>E</i><sub>n</sub> = (1 - <i>p</i>)<i>E</i><sub>n-1</sub> = (1-<i>p</i>)<sup>n</sup><i>E</i><sub>o</sub>.<br>In our case, <i>p</i> = .1, <i>n</i> = 10, we have .9<sup>10</sup> = .3487 = .3333 + .0154. The last term is the “little bit” which the son takes above <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> and the daughters combined take less than <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub>. On the word פָּרָא “less than” and its possible derivations cf. E. and H. Guggenheimer, Notes on the Talmudic Vocabulary, <i>Lešōnēnū</i> 39(1975) pp. 59–62.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel arguments are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 69a" href="/Ketubot.69a">Babli 69a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 51a" href="/Gittin.51a"><i>Giṭṭin</i>. 51a</a>.</i> If there were two daughters and one son; the first one took a tenth of the estate, but the son died before the second could take her tenth<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The son died childless; then the two daughters inherit the estate.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina was of the opinion that the second takes a tenth of the estate and the rest they divide equally among themselves. Rebbi Joḥanan told him that in this case there was nothing else to provide for her, but here she may sell from the remainder and provide for herself<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, R. Joḥanan holds that the second daughter gave up her claim for the extra 10% and takes 50% of the estate. According to R. Ḥanina, 45% go to the first daughter and 55% to the second.</i>! Rebbi Tebi in the name of Rebbi Joshia: The reason of Rebbi Ḥanina: If she can collect from encumbered real estate, from what lies before her not so much more<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that providing a dowry for the daughters is a <i>ketubah</i> obligation and as such has the status of a mortgage. Therefore, in talmudic law (abolished by the Geonim in Babylonia after the Arab conquest and apparently never followed in the European provinces of the Roman empire) the claim for a dowry must be satisfied by real estate. If the father sold a piece of real estate and there is none left to satisfy the demand for dowry, the daughter can go to court to repossess the land and let the buyer be indemnified by the estate.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan sticks to his opinion, since Rebbi Ze‘ira said that Rebbi Joḥanan does not collect<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">He refuses to grant repossession for claims to dowry.</i>. Who collects? Rebbi Ḥanina [and Rebbi Hila] collect. Rebbi Yasa was appointed custodian of orphans’ property<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Valuables, not real estate.</i>. There were orphan [girls] who asked to be provided for. He brought the case before Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon bar Yaqim. Rebbi Simeon bar Yaqim said, is it not better to provide for them from their father’s estate rather than from charity<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The underlying hypothesis here is that dowries from estates are given only from real estate. R. Simeon ben Yaqim holds that an estate rich in money but without real estate should provide for the daughters in money and not force them to apply to public charity for their dowry.</i>? Rebbi Eleazar said to him: If such a case came before our teachers, our teachers would not touch it<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The Patriarch’s court in his days could not decide whether dowries should be paid from real estate or movables; why should a lower court deal with the matter?</i>; would we act? Rebbi Yose said, I shall give to them, and if some orphans get up and complain, I would give it to them<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">In a similar situation, he provided for the daughters from movables. But since he had no precedent, if the male orphans were to appeal the judgment, he would rescind it. Since there was no appeal, a precedent was created that dowries be given from movables. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 69b" href="/Ketubot.69b">Babli strongly disagrees, 69b</a>.</i>. Even so, they saw and did not complain. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Yose: How do you decide in practical cases? He said to him, following Rebbi Ḥanina. And so an actual case was decided following Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">To split the inheritance 55% / 45%, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.4">Note 89</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Hila: One considers the estate as if it were dry<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The daughters cannot claim part of the yield of the estate for their dowry.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody gives money in trust<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">To buy some real estate for his daughter, after the giver’s death.</i> for his daughter and she says, I am trusting my husband<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">She wants the money to be given to her husband that he could buy the piece of real estate for her.</i>, the trustee should execute what he was entrusted with<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">And not hand over the money to the husband.</i>, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Yose says, is it not only about a field? If she wants to sell it, can she not sell it now<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Could she not legally sell today the field that in the future will be bought for her by the trustee, to be the buyer’s after the trustee will have delivered the field to her. Therefore, the trustee should follow the daughter’s instructions.</i>? When has this been said? If she is an adult. But about a minor, no legal act of a minor is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose agrees that the instructions of an underage daughter should not be followed.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody gives money in trust for his daughter and she says, I am trusting my husband,” etc. The Mishnah speaks of the case that he gave at the time of the preliminary marriage. But if he gave at the definitive marriage even Rebbi Meïr agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Since the husband gets the income from the real estate after the definitive marriage, there is no reason why he should not be entrusted with buying the real estate. A similar argument is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 69b" href="/Ketubot.69b">Babli, 69b</a>, and an explicit text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:9" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.9">Tosephta 6:9</a>.</i> If he established the trust after the definitive marriage, that is the disagreement<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">If the father by his action shows that he does not trust his son-in-law, the trustee should not hand over the money. R. Yose holds that even in this case the daughter can sell her rights to that land any day of that year.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 6:10" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).6.10">Tosephta 6:10</a>; the first part also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 69b" href="/Ketubot.69b">Babli, 69b</a>.</i>”If somebody says<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In his will to the executors of his estate after his death.</i>, give my sons one <i>šeqel</i> per week and they need a tetradrachma, one gives them a tetradrachma<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">If prices rise, since 2 <i>šeqalim</i>, 1 tetradrachma, comprise at least one <i>šeqel</i>.</i>. Do not give them more than one <i>šeqel</i> per week, one gives them a <i>šeqel.</i> But for the support of the wife and the daughters, whether he says give or do not give, one gives them a <i>šeqel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">All sources of the Tosephta read: “A tetradrachma.” This reading is required since the widow and her daughters are fed by the <i>ketubah</i> contract and a will cannot modify a contractual obligation.</i>. It was stated: Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, Meïr used to say, if somebody says, give my sons one <i>šeqel</i> per week and they need a tetradrachma, one gives them a <i>šeqel</i>, and for the remainder they should be provided for by charity<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The executors are not empowered to deviate from the testator’s instructions even if it means that the children have to apply to public welfare.</i>. But the Sages say, one takes continuously until the property is used up<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody should be forced to apply for welfare if there is a possibility to avoid it.</i> and after that they should be provided by charity.” Rebbi Yose said, that gives a simple example for Ḥilfai’s question. He said, I shall sit on the river bank and if I cannot extract the teachings of the elder Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">The Tosephta. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 69b" href="/Ketubot.69b">Babli, 69b</a>, he is called Ilfa and it is explained that he objected to the use of <i>baraitot</i> and <i>tosephtot</i> in the study of Jewish law and was ready to jump into the sea if somebody could produce a <i>baraita</i> whose teachings he could not derive from the Mishnah. In the Babli, R. Yose’s observation is Ḥilfai’s own.</i> from the Mishnah, throw me into the river. What could he say<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Where does he find justification for the position of R. Meïr that the executors of the will cannot deviate from their instructions even in case of necessity.</i>? “The trustee should execute what he was entrusted with.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Even if it seems reasonable to follow the daughter’s wishes.</i>”
<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to a sentence in the Tosephta quoted in the preceding paragraph: “If he said, if they should die, others should inherit, then one gives them only a <i>šeqel,</i> whether he said to give, or not to give more.” The fact that others have to be mentioned in the will proves that these are not the legal heirs to whom the inheritance would have been given had the testator died intestate.</i>”If they died, others should inherit.” Did not Rebbi Abbahu say in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: A person can transfer property rights in any language except with an expression of inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Since inheritance is defined in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num</i>. 27:6–11</a> and transfer of property by inheritance is restricted to the paternal family. The last sentence in this paragraph will make clear that one supposes that the beneficiaries of the will are one or more sons-in-law whose wives are excluded by biblical law from the inheritance if there is a son at the time of the father’s death, even if that only son should then die childless.<br>In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.4.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Batra</i> 8:5</a>, R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa holds that a testamentary gift may be formulated in the language of inheritance if the recipient is a relative on the father’s side who might be an heir if the other prospective heirs would die before him.</i>? One does not have here “they shall inherit” but “they shall take”<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">It is suggested that the (Hebrew) text of the Tosephta be explained (in Aramaic) to remove the objection.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Mana: Do they not differ here in matters of a gift? If somebody signed over<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">In one document.</i> all his property to two persons at the same time; to one he wrote in the language of gift but to the other in the language of inheritance. Rebbi Eleazar said, since the one acquired in the language of gift, the other one acquired in the language of inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that a document is either valid or invalid. Since the bequest by gift is valid, the entire document is valid. The same argument is in the Babli in greater detail, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 129a" href="/Bava_Batra.129a"><i>Baba Batra</i> 129a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, it seems that one did acquire in the language of gift but the other did not acquire in the language of inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The document is valid but the bequest of inheritance to a non-heir is not enforceable in court.</i> Rebbi Phineas said, there came a case before Rebbi Jeremiah: Practice follows Rebbi Eleazar since Rebbi Eleazar stated a docrine but Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar gives a straight decision, implying that he learned this principle from his teachers. R. Joḥanan’s statement seems to be tentative.</i> said only “it seems”. Rebbi Samuel said, but did not Rebbi Meïr say that and it does not seem reasonable; is that nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan gives a definitive statement: R. Meïr’s opinions in the Tosephta are rejected. Therefore, R. Jeremiah’s argument is without base.</i>? <sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The next three sentences are from <i>‘Orlah</i> 3:2, Notes 88–94.</i> Did not Rebbi Joḥanan say in the name of Rebbi Assi<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">This must be read with the text in <i>‘Orlah</i>: Rebbi Assi (Yasa) in the name of R. Joḥanan; the latter is the teacher and the former the student.</i>: Carded firstling wool becomes insignificant in a plurality<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">A firstling sheep may not be shorn (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 15:19" href="/Deuteronomy.15.19"><i>Deut</i>. 15:19</a>). The wool is forbidden for usufruct but, in contrast to fruits from a tree less than three years old, the wool according to R. Joḥanan does not make everything forbidden if it is mixed with permitted fibers.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya the Sepphorean brought before Rebbi Ammi a pound in eight<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">One pound of firstling wool mixed with eight pounds of wool from other sheep, and thoroughly mixed so that one cannot recognize the fibers coming from the firstling.</i> but the latter refused to rule since had not Rebbi Assi said, is that not a Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">It is Mishnah <i>‘Orlah</i> 3:3 but <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.2.1">Mishnah 3:2</a> shows that it represents R. Meïr’s minority opinion; therefore, it is not practice.</i>? “If somebody weaves the length of a <i>sîṭ</i> of firstling’s wool in a cloth, the cloth must be burned, of hair of a <i>nazir</i> or firstling donkey in sackcloth, the sackcloth must be burned”? The following Mishnah disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “If he wrote any expression of gift either at the start, or in the middle, or at the end, his instructions are valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.4.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Batra</i> 8:5</a>. If somebody wrote a will in which either he gave some property to a non-heir or he distributes his estate in unequal portions between the heirs, if he wrote either “<i>as a gift</i> this property is given to X” or “this property <i>as a gift</i> is given to X” or “this property is given to X <i>as a gift</i>”, the gift is valid and can be collected by court order. This is the Babli’s interpretation in <i>Baba Batra.</i> The Yerushalmi in <i>Baba Batra</i> does not discuss the meaning of the sentence. R. Eleazar could read the Mishnah as stating that a will is valid if it gives property to three people if to one of them at least it is given as gift (position of Rav Sheshet in the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i> Note 118).<br>The Mishnah clearly implies that any of these instructions makes the entire will valid.</i>” There, to one person in an expression of gift and to one an expression of inheritance. But here to each one both in the language of gift and the language of inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan would agree that a document, in which some property is given as a gift and other property as inheritance to one and the same person, is valid. But if the recipients are two different people, the validity for one does not imply the validity for the other.</i> Rebbi Ḥaggai asked before Rebbi Yose: But does he not prejudice the rights of others<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">By naming his daughters and their husbands as heirs after his sons, does he not deprive his brothers of their biblical right of inheritance?</i>? He said to him, if there are no brothers. But does he not prejudice the rights of his paternal uncles? Rebbi Ḥanania the son of Rebbi Hillel: A person prefers the good of his house over his relatives<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">In order to execute the will of the deceased, the court has to enforce a will giving property to daughters and their husbands even against the testator’s brothers.</i>.

Chapter 7



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody makes a vow that his wife should not have any usufruct from him<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Then he cannot fulfill his obligation to feed, clothe, and house his wife.</i>, up to thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">This can be read to mean that the wife cannot sue for divorce if the husband limits his vow to thirty days. But if his vow is unlimited, the wife can demand an immediate divorce. It might also mean that in no case can the wife sue unless the husband did not provide for her for at least 30 days.</i> he shall appoint a provider<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Who provides for her from his own money and only later is repaid by the husband.</i>, more than that he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Jehudah says, if he is an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Who can remarry his divorcee if he found an Elder who dissolves his vow.</i>, for one month he should keep her, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>; in the case of the wife of a Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">He is given more time to find a way to dissolve his vow since he never could remarry his divorcee, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev.</i> 21:7</a>.</i> for two months he should keep her, for three he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody makes a vow that his wife should not have any usufruct from him,” etc. There<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.7.1">Mishnah 5:8</a>. There, the House of Hillel already force the husband to divorce his wife after one week.</i>, we have stated: “If somebody by a vow bars his wife from sexual intercourse,” and here you say so? There, he makes a vow to separate her from his body<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">A vow not to sleep with his wife is essentially a vow to terminate the marriage; a vow concerning money matters is not.</i>, but here he makes a vow to separate her from his property. But can anybody make a vow not to pay his debt<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Why should the vow be valid if it infringes contractual rights of third parties? (Cf. <i>Introduction to Tractate Nedarim.</i>)</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, since in the future he will divorce her, pay her the <i>ketubah,</i> and stop her food supply, it is as if there was no debt<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 70a" href="/Ketubot.70a">Babli, 70a</a>, notes that the partners in a marriage have the right to separate their incomes: The husband can renounce any benefit from his wife’s work and not pay any of her expenses or the wife can renounce any support from her husband and keep all her earnings. But any of these possibilities presuppose mutual consent.</i>. Why could she not sit there and wait; if he divorced her everything would be in order, otherwise let him provide her with food<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:7:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.7.2-7">Halakhah 5:8</a> the obligation of the husband to feed his wife was given a biblical basis, why should the husband’s vow not simply be declared invalid and he be forced to feed his wife by a court order?</i>? It follows him who said that the wife’s food is not from words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">This and the next argument are explained in <i>Ma‘serot</i> 3:1, Notes 11–13. Cf. also the argument of R. Eliezer ben Jacob in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:7:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.7.2-7">Halakhah 5:8</a> and the last sentence of Chapter 13.</i>, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sheviit (Lieberman) 5:22" href="/Tosefta_Sheviit_(Lieberman).5.22">Tosephta <i>Ševi‘it</i> 5:22</a>.</i>: The court will not determine food for the wife from Sabbatical money, but she may be given Sabbatical produce to eat at her husband’s<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband is away on a trip and the wife needs money to survive, she can sell some of the husband’s property under the supervision of the court. She cannot sell Sabbatical produce since nobody may use such produce to pay his debts (and the wife’s claim is a debt based on the <i>ketubah</i> document.) But if the husband is present, she may eat from his Sabbatical fruit since this fulfills the rabbinic ordinance to support the wife and is not counted as paying a debt.</i>. Then should she not be considered as a worker not worth a <i>peruṭah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Which is not a defect for a male, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.5">Note 137</a>.</i>? This proves that she is not considered as a worker not worth a <i>peruṭah.</i>
He could appoint a provider<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah requires the husband to look for a provider but in fact he cannot appoint one since his vow prohibits him to provide for his wife through an agent. The only way the husband can fulfill his obligation is indicated by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Nedarim 4:8" href="/Mishnah_Nedarim.4.8">Mishnah <i>Nedarim</i> 4:8 (Notes 101</a>,102) quoted here, in that he indicates to a third person that he is ready to repay that person after he has provided for his wife, in a way that the provider could not have recourse to the courts if the husband would not pay.</i>, as the following: “X is forbidden any profit from me by a vow and I do not know what to do.” Let him appoint a provider<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Why can the wife force a divorce if she is provided for?</i>! A woman has the right to say, it is impossible for me to be provided for by anybody other than my husband. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.9.1">Mishnah 5:11</a>. That Mishnah and the following give detailed instructions how a wife is provided for by an agent, giving the impression that this refers to a permanent arrangement. Why is this only accepted as very temporary in the Mishnah here?</i>: “If somebody provides for his wife through a third party.” There, if she accepted it; here, if she did not accept it. If she did not accept it<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This clause is an insert by the first corrector. The text is suspect since אִי is Babylonian, for Galilean אִין “if”.</i> then he should not appoint even for one day! She continues with him for one month, perhaps he will find an opening for his vow<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">One requires a cooling-down period of one month to give the husband time to regret his vow and seek dissolution of the vow by an Elder.</i>. Samuel says, if he vowed for thirty days. But if he vowed forever, he shall divorce immediately and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Avina in the name of Rav: Even if he vowed forever, she continues with him for one month, perhaps he will find an opening for his vow<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71a" href="/Ketubot.71a">Babli, 71a</a>, the positions attributed to Samuel and Rav are switched.</i>.
Some Tannaïm state: thirty days. Some Tannaïm state: up to thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">All ms. sources (Mishnah, Tosephta 7:1, quotes in Yerushalmi and Babli) support the second version.</i>. He who says thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This is the minimum delay before the wife can go to court; therefore the husband certainly has to provide for 30 days.</i> supports Rav; he who says up to thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The divorce proceedings should be finished by then and the full <i>ketubah</i> paid.</i> supports Samuel.
Rebbi Yose said, they<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah and R. Meïr, the author of the anonymous Mishnah. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.1">Tosephta 7:1</a> it is stated: “He should appoint a provider for up to 30 days, and for a Cohen’s wife three months, the words of R. Meïr.” At first glance, this seems to indicate that R. Jehudah permits the court to force the husband to divorce his wife immediately after the end of the second month but R. Meïr only after the end of the third.</i> differ about wives of Cohanim. “Beyond that he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the end of the second [month]<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Scheduling one month for the court proceedings.</i>. “Rebbi Jehudah says, if he is an Israel, for one month he should keep her, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the end of the second [month]. “In the case of the wife of a Cohen for two months he should keep her, for three he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the beginning of the third. And a disagreement was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta.</i>, at the end of three [months], the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Mana said to him, where no disagreement was stated, you introduce a disagreement. But they disagree if he is an Israel. “Beyond that he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the beginning of the second [month]. “Rebbi Jehudah says, if he is an Israel, for one month he should keep her<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">In a short month only 29 days, in opposition to R. Meïr who requires 30 days in every case (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71a" href="/Ketubot.71a">Babli 71a</a>).</i>, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the beginning of the second. “In the case of the wife of a Cohen for two months he should keep her, for three he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>,” at the end of three [months]. It was stated thus: At the end of three by everybody’s opinion.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody causes<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah will explain how a husband can cause a wife’s vow.</i> a vow of his wife that she should not taste any kind of fruits has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Jehudah says, if he is an Israel, for one month<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Most mss. of the Babli and the Mishnah read “day” instead of “month”. The reading “month” is found in a number of early medieval authors discussing the Babli.</i> he should keep her, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah</i>; in the case of the wife of a Cohen for two [months] he should keep her, for three he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody causes a vow of his wife,” etc. Can anybody cause somebody else’s vow during his lifetime? It must be that the wife made a vow, the husband heard it, and said to her: If you will eat from such and such, my property will be forbidden to you. If she ate from such and such, why should his property not be forbidden to her<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is the cause.</i>? Is that not the case from the beginning of the chapter<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">He forbade his property to her. Why does the anonymous Tanna require a stay of 30 days in the first Mishnah but none in the second?</i>? But if his wife made a vow, her husband was informed, and did not dissolve it, following him who says that he put his finger between her teeth<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The question whether the husband is responsible for the consequences if he does not dissolve his wife’s vows is in the last paragraph of <i>Nedarim</i>, 11:13, Notes 98–103. The image is that if he puts his finger between her teeth, he has only himself to blame if she bites. R. Meïr and R. Jehudah hold that he put his finger between her teeth; cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71a" href="/Ketubot.71a">Babli 71a</a>.</i>, he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Ḥuna said, even he who said that she put his finger between her teeth, and should be divorced without <i>ketubah,</i> will agree<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">That he has to pay.</i> in case he provoked her to make the vow.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not adorn herself with one of the kinds<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Kinds of perfume. In modern Hebrew, only jewellery would be קישוּט.</i> has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Yose says, among the poor if he did not give a time limit, among the rich for thirty days.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not adorn herself,” etc. Rav Huna said, so is the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">J. N. Epstein, <sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>מבוא לנוסח המשנה, p. 474–475 conjectures that originally the Mishnah read: “if he set a time limit, he may keep her,” and only Rav Huna changed the text to adapt it to the other Mishnaiot of this series. In any case, all mss. of Mishnah and Babli follow Rav Huna’s reading.</i>: “Among the poor if he did not give a time limit.” Ulla bar Ismael said, among the poor if he did not give a time limit; but if he gave a time limit even if it were for ten years<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71b" href="/Ketubot.71b">Babli, 71b</a>, this is R. Joḥanan’s opinion.</i> it is permitted, for no fox dies if he gets dusty from his lair<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">This popular saying also occurs in a slightly different version in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71b" href="/Ketubot.71b">Babli, 71b</a>. If the husband himself smells badly, he will not be bothered by his wife’s smells.</i>. Nathan bar Hoshaiah said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Except holidays<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71b" href="/Ketubot.71b">Babli, 71b</a>, this is ascribed to Rav Ḥisda.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not go to her father’s house, if they live in the same city she does, for one month he should keep her, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> If they live in another city, for one holiday he should keep her, for two he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not go to her father’s house,” etc. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, they stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia.</i>: If he made her make a vow that she should not wash in the bathhouse<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The public thermal bath.</i>, in walled cities one week, in villages two weeks. That she should not wear shoes<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Only sandals.</i>, in villages three months<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides (<i>Hilkhot Iššut</i> 13:9) reads: Three days.</i>, in walled cities 24 hours.
Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 71b" href="/Ketubot.71b">Babli, 71b</a>, this is said in the name of Rabba bar Ulla with the concurrence of R. Joḥanan.</i> said, they taught that about the pursueds’ holiday. What is the pursueds’ holiday? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Bun said, that is the first holiday<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">After her final marriage.</i> when her father drives her to her husband’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">When it is customary for the newlywed to visit her family and the father sends her back to her husband’s house.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Mishnah is explained in the Halakhah.</i> If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not pay condolence visits or go to weddings has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i> But if he argues because of another reason, he is in his rights. If he said to her you should tell X what I said to you<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text in the Yerushalmi and one Babli mss. In all other Talmud or Mishnah mss.: “What you said to me or what I said to you” (text in the Halakhah) or “what I said to you or you said to me”.</i> or that she should fill [vessels] and pour them out on garbage heaps, he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody causes a vow of his wife that she should not pay condolence visits,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:4" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.4">Tosephta 7:4</a>: “fine and coarse sieves and portable ovens.”</i>”If he made her vow not to lend out fine and coarse sieves, he shall divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah,</i> since he gives her a bad reputation among her [female] neighbors. And so if she made a vow not to lend out fine and coarse sieves, she should leave without <i>ketubah</i> since she gives him a bad reputation among his [male] neighbors.” <sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>, In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:5" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.5">Tosephta 7:5</a>: She will die and nobody will care.</i>”If he made her vow not to pay condolence visits or go to weddings, he shall divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah,</i> since tomorrow a relative of hers will die and nobody will take notice of her.
