And so if she made a vow not to pay condolence visits or go to weddings, she should leave without <i>ketubah</i> since tomorrow a relative of his will die and nobody will take notice of him.” <sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Similar but slightly different texts in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.6">Tosephta 7:6</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 7:6" href="/Ecclesiastes.7.6"><i>Eccl.</i> 7:6</a>).</i>”Rebbi Meïr is saying in the name of his teacher Rebbi Aqiba: ‘It is better to pay condolence visits than to go to a wedding since the former is the end of every human, and the living should take notice.’ Why does the verse say, ‘and the living should take notice’? But do so they shall: eulogize so they should eulogize, bury so they should bury, accompany<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Accompany the coffin to the cemetery.</i> so they should accompany.”
“If he argues because of another reason, he is in his rights,” because of bad reputation<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">If he objects only to certain visits where his wife is likely to meet persons of bad reputation who might seduce her.</i>.
“If he said to her I require that you tell Mr. X what you said to me,” alone, “or I said to you”, alone<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Private matters at the time of sex play; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:6" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.6">Tosephta 7:6</a>. The formulation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli 72a</a>, “shameful matters” is ambiguous.</i>, “or that she should fill [vessels] and pour them out on garbage heaps, he has to divorce her and pay the <i>ketubah.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: Because he does not treat her following the laws of Moses and Israel. The formula for the preliminary marriage is that the woman shall be married to the man “following the laws of Moses and Israel.”</i>” There<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli 72a</a> in the name of Samuel.</i>, they say, like Er’s action<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Which in Jewish tradition was identical to Onan’s sin. He requires her to take contraceptive action; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 38:7" href="/Genesis.38.7"><i>Gen.</i>38:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 38:9" href="/Genesis.38.9">9</a>. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 85:5" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.85.5"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 85(5</a>) where the expression is: He ploughed in the gardens and poured out on the garbage heaps.</i>, but the rabbis here say, senseless things<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">In the words of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>, if she pours water out on the garbage heap “her neighbors would consider her insane.”</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following leave without <i>ketubah</i>: Any one violating the laws of Moses or Jews. What is the law of Moses? She feeds him what is not tithed, or makes him sleep with her when she is menstruating, or does not cut <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">In all these cases, she causes him to commit a sin punishable by extirpation. One recommends to the husband to divorce her since “nobody should live with a snake in the same basket” [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli 72a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 2:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.2.2.6">Yerushalmi <i>Demai</i>2:2 (Note 129</a>; 22d l. 59)].</i>, or makes vows which she does not keep. And what is the law of Jews: She leaves home with her hair in disorder<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In both Talmudim, this is interpreted that she leaves home with her hair uncovered.</i>, or spins in public<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that it was a common sign of a free woman engaged in prostitution to appear as if spinning in public (in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli, 72b</a>, if she is spinning with a rose on her ear), in contrast to slave girls used as prostitutes who were exhibited naked in front of brothels.</i>, or speaks with everybody<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">This also could be interpreted as a way of soliciting.</i>. Abba Saul says, also one who curses his parents in his presence. Rebbi Tarphon says, also the big-voiced.<br>What is the big-voiced? Any who speaks inside her house and her neighbors hear her voice.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following leave without <i>ketubah</i>,” etc. “What is the big-voiced,” etc. And all with witnesses. “X tithed<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>.</i>, X saw the stains<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">She said to her husband that she showed her stained underwear to a rabbi who decided that it was not menstrual blood. In the first Century C. E. it was a common usage of Jewish sects to accuse the adherents of other sects of sleeping with menstruating women. Pharisees accused Sadducees and Samaritans because they considered all genital discharges as menstrual (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Niddah 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Niddah.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 4:1</a>) and Sadducees accused Pharisees because they do not consider all genital discharges as menstrual (Damascus Document A 5:7). Later practice eliminated the problem by observing both Pharisaic and Sadducee prohibitions. Pharisaic distinctions between pure and impure blood required women to consult rabbis about their discharges. It is not likely that this ever was widespread practice except for wives of Cohanim in whose household impurity had to be reduced to an absolute minimum. The disappearance of priestly purity in the second century C.E. probably put an end to that practice even though the fourth Century Babylonian Rava still claimed full knowledge of all relevant rules.</i>, X cut her <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The heave to be taken from bread dough. It was common practice to have a professional baker prepare bread dough for private households and to take <i>ḥallah</i> from it; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Challah 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Challah.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Ḥallah</i> 1:7</a>.</i>, X permitted her vow.” They checked and found it was not so.
“She feeds him what is not tithed, or makes him sleep with her when she is menstruating, or does not cut <i>ḥallah,</i> or makes vows which she does not keep.” We understand all these because he is involved<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In the first three cases, she leads him into sin.</i>. “She makes vows which she does not keep,” what is his interest in this? He can say, I cannot live with a vowing wife because she buries her children. It was stated in the name of Rebbi Yudan<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 4:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.4.3.2-4"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 4:3</a> (45c 1. 63), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 5b" href="/Shabbat.5b"><i>Šabbat</i> 5b 1. 8</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli 72a</a> in the name of Rav Naḥman. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 32b" href="/Shabbat.32b"><i>Šabbat</i> 32b</a> in the name of Rav Naḥman bar Isaac (also thus in one Geniza ms. of <i>Ketubot</i>); in <i>Yalquṭ Šim‘oni Jer.</i> #266 a different verse in the name of R. Nathan (anonymous in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72a" href="/Ketubot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>).</i>: Children die for the sin of vows, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 2:30" href="/Jeremiah.2.30"><i>Jer.</i> 2:30</a>.</i>: “For vain [vows] I smote your children.
“With her hair in disorder.” They said that for the courtyard<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">It is supposed that no house has a direct exit to the street but that a number of houses share a common courtyard from which one leaves to a passageway or a street.</i>; so much more for the passageway<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">A side street which is not a thoroughfare. It may be a dead-end street or not; it is public domain but mainly used by the dwellers of courtyards opening to that side street.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If one goes out in her wig<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The word was identified by Musaphia as Latin <i>capillitium.</i> But the meaning of that word as given in the dictionaries is not “wig” as asserted by Musaphia but “the hair” (collective). The meaning “false hair, wig” is found in Latin <i>capillamentum.</i> Cf. also the Latin adjective <i>capillatus, -a, -um</i>“having hair, with fine head of hair”.<br>The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli, 72b</a>, has קלתה which Rashi explains as a makeshift head cover formed by an inverted basket, which is declared as forbidden.</i>, she does not go out with her hair in disorder. That is, to the courtyard; if she does it in the passageway, she goes out with her hair in disorder. There exists a courtyard which is like a passageway and a passageway which is like a courtyard. A courtyard through which outsiders have broken<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">It has become a shortcut for outsiders.</i> is like a passageway and a passageway through which no outsiders are breaking<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">A dead-end street used only by the inhabitants of its houses.</i> is like a courtyard.
Abba Saul says, also one who curses their child in his parents’ presence<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli, 72b</a>, as Amoraic statement: One who curses his parents before his children.</i>. Rebbi Tarphon says, also the big-voiced. What is the big-voiced? Samuel says, any who speaks and her women neighbors hear her voice<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, all his marital disagreements are immediately public knowledge.</i>. Rav says, any one whose voice is heard by other people from bed to bed during intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement is also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli, 72b</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">This text seems to be in rather bad shape and the secondary sources are contradictory, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:6:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.6.6">Note 79</a>.</i> Rebbi Ḥanin stated in the name of Rebbi Samuel: Both for women about whom they said that they have <i>ketubah</i> as also those about whom they said they leave without <i>ketubah</i>, as the minor, the secondarily prohibited<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously one has to read in the first clause: have no <i>ketubah.</i> Somehow the text should accommodate several kinds of divorces.<br>The minor who is mentioned in this connection is an underage girl married off by her mother or brothers after her father’s death whose marriage has no biblical validity and who can walk out of it without formality (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:2, Note 118</a>). Her repudiation of her husband annuls her marriage and with it her <i>ketubah</i> but it does not touch her property rights; both mortmain (<i>dos aestimata</i>) as also paraphernalia (<i>dos non aestimata</i>) must be returned to her (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 7:1, Note 1</a>).<br>Secondary prohibitions are rabbinically prohibited unions extending biblical prohibitions, usually for one additional generation (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4, Note 67</a>). The rabbinate will force the husband to divorce his wife and, in order to scare away women from such marriages, will not enforce any payment of <i>ketubah.</i> But her property rights for mortmain and paraphernalia are not touched (and her children are legitimate.)<br>The she-ram (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:1, Note 65</a>) is a woman exhibiting secondary male sex characterstics. She is presumed to be congenitally infertile; her marriage is considered invalid by biblical standards, and she will have difficulty collecting the <i>ketubah</i> but not recovering her property.<br>The statement as it stands now does not cover women who are divorced following <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.6.1">Mishnah 6</a>, who may not be able to recover their property.</i>, and the she-ram, did they speak about a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]? But even if the <i>ketubah</i> was a thousand denars<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Promised by the husband; this does not touch repayment of the dowry.</i>, she loses<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">R. Nissim Gerondi (Commentary to Aliasi, 59b in the Wilna edition) reads: נָשִׁים שֶׁאָֽמְרוּ חֲכָמִים אֵין לָהֶן כְּתוּבָּה. כְּגוֹן הַיְתוֹמָה וְהַשְּׁנִייָה וְהָאַייְלוֹנִית. לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא מְנָא מָאתַיִים. אֲבָל כְּתוּבָּה שֶׁלְּאֶלֶף דֵּינָר נוֹטֶלֶת “Women about whom they said that they leave without <i>ketubah,</i> as the underage orphan, the secondarily prohibited, and the she-ram, they spoke only about a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>] But if the <i>ketubah</i> was a thousand denars, she takes it.” As the commentators of the Babli explain, the obligatory <i>ketubah</i> must be lost since she leaves without <i>ketubah</i>; but any additional sums are voluntary gifts from the husband. The claim to such a voluntary gift can be lost only by criminal behavior of the wife, not by an inherent defect of the marriage which was known to the husband at the time he made the promise.<br>Naḥmanides (<i>Sefer Hazzekhut,</i> in Alfasi, <i>loc. cit.</i>) reads: תַּנֵּי רִבִּי חָנִין בְּרִבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל. נָשִׁים שֶׁאָֽמְרוּ אֵין לָהֶן כְּתוּבָּה יֵשׁ לָהֶן תּוֹסֶפֶת. וּשֶׁאָֽמְרוּ יוֹצְאוֹת שֶׁלֹּא בִכְתוּבָּה אֵין לָהֶן אֲפִילוּ תוֹסֶפֶת. “Rebbi Ḥanin ben Rebbi Samuel stated: Women about whom they said they have no <i>ketubah,</i> receive the additions; but those about whom they said that they leave without <i>ketubah</i> do not even get the additions.” Women who have no <i>ketubah</i> are those whose marriage was invalid from the start, e. g., the underage orphan, the secondarily prohibited, and the she-ram. They receive the voluntary additions as explained above. Women who leave without <i>ketubah</i> are those who are divorced because of their crimes; they lose also the husband’s voluntary gift since they force the husband to divorce them.<br>Probably one should read in the text: “Rav Ḥanin (known as Rav’s student) in the name of Samuel.” This is consistent with the quote later in the paragraph.</i>, but she takes her existing rags<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Her used clothing; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:8:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.8.4">Chapter 5, Notes 224–225</a>.</i>. But the one who leaves because of a bad reputation loses everything<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Including mortmain, the dowry given to the husband as the latter’s property subject to his obligation to return their value in the fixed amount stated in the <i>ketubah</i> document. Nothing is said about paraphernalia, the wife’s separate property which is administered by her husband. The parallel statement of Samuel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 101a" href="/Ketubot.101a">Babli, 101a</a>, agrees that she loses the husband’s additions above the minimal <i>ketubah</i> but is silent about mortmain.</i>. Can she take her paraphernalia<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This means her dowry as addition to the <i>ketubah,</i> including mortmain and paraphernalia in the literal sense.</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, she takes. Rebbi Hila said, she does not take. Rebbi Hila, Rebbi Yasa, Rebbi Abba bar Cohen mention it in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel: Both women about whom they said that they leave without <i>ketubah</i>, did they speak about the <i>ketubah</i> of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]? But even if the <i>ketubah</i> was a thousand denars, she loses<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">This text does not make too much sense. Probably one should read something similar to the text of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.7">Tosephta 7:7</a>: כָּל־אֵילּוּ שֶׁאָֽמְרוּ. יוֹצְאוֹת שֶׁלֹּא בִכְתוּבָּה. לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא מְנָא מָאתַיִים אָלָּא אֲפִילוּ הָֽיְתָה כְּתוּבָּתָהּ שֶׁלְּאֶלֶף דֵּינָר מְאַבֶּדֶת אֶת־הַכֹּל וְנוֹטֶלֶת בְּלָאיוֹת שֶׁמּוֹצָא לְפָנֶיהָ. “[Women] about whom they said that they leave without <i>ketubah,</i> they spoke not only about a mina or 200 <i>[zuz],</i> but even if the <i>ketubah</i> was a thousand denars, she loses everything, but she takes her used clothing..” The Tosephta can be quoted in support of R. Hila that she takes anything that clearly is her property at that moment (her personal effects and the paraphernalia proper) but the husband is not required to return her mortmain which has become his property; her claim to it is voided.</i>. Rebbi Simon said, Rebbi Joḥanan: All the Mishnaiot<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">All Mishnaiot on the topic why a women should be divorced.</i> are connected to this <i>baraita.</i> Rebbi Mana said before Rebbi Yasa: About which <i>baraita</i>? Of Rebbi Ḥanin from Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is clearly formulated as Amoraic opinion of a single person, it cannot be the central topic of a whole series of Mishnaiot.</i>? He said to him, it is everybody’s opinion. And Rebbi Ḥiyya formulated so<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.7">Tosephta 7:7</a>.</i>: “Women who infringe upon the law lose everything.
Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">In the opinion of S. Abramson, the name should be Ze‘ira ben Ḥanina, an Amora contemporary with rabbis Yose and Mana mentioned later in the text. Cf. בירורם ,שרגא אברמסון, Sinai 89 (1981) pp. 118–121.</i>: If they saw her putting on her underpants<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:2:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.2.7"><i>Soṭah</i> 1:2, Note 115</a>.</i> and the pedlar leaves her house, the thing is ugly, she should leave<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 24b-25a" href="/Yevamot.24b-25a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 24b–25a</a>, this and the following statements are by R. Ḥiyya (the elder) quoting the authority of Rebbi. In all these cases, where adultery is not proven by two witnesses to the act, one implies that the woman can be divorced without payment of the <i>ketubah</i> since the acts describe a high probability of adultery, which is admissible proof in money matters and does not need prior warning.</i>. There is slime on her bed, the thing is ugly, she should leave. There is slime on his<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The other man’s.</i> bed, the thing is ugly, she should leave. His sandal is in front of her bed, the thing is ugly, she should leave. Her sandal is in front of his<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The other man’s.</i> bed, the thing is ugly, she should leave. Both leave the same dark place, the thing is ugly, she should leave. They lift one another from the cistern, the thing is ugly, she should leave. Both of them clap on her thighs in the bathhouse<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Where everybody is naked. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.1">Mishnah 9</a> implies that the use of public thermal baths was separate by sex; then the reference would be to lesbian relationships which, while not forbidden (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:6:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.6.4"><i>Yebamot</i> 8:6, Note 240</a>) are generally classified as undesirable.</i>, the thing is ugly, she should leave. Ḥanina bar Iqa in the name of Rebbi Jehudah, in all these cases, if she brings an explanation for her behavior she is believed. Rav Ada bar Aḥawa in the name of Rav: A case came before Rebbi and he said, what of it<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">It seems to mean that Rebbi did not want to see the courts involved as long as the testimony did not amount to a legal proof. Some commentators of the Babli read the sentence as referring to the woman’s explanation, that Rebbi would not accept any explanation except a legal disproof (cf. R. Yosef Ḥabiba, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 6a" href="/Yevamot.6a"><i>Nimmuqe Yosef,</i> on Alfassi <i>Yebamot,</i>6a</a> in the Wilna edition.)</i>? They asked before him<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">This seems to refer to the person mentioned at the head of this paragraph Note 87.</i>: Even if they saw him putting his mouth on her mouth? He said, this did happen, that they saw a man<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">A man other than the husband.</i> putting his mouth on her mouth. The case came befote Rebbi Yose, who said that she should leave without <i>ketubah.</i> Her relatives appealed the case and said, if she is deviant<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A proven adulteress. Since there is no legal proof, she should take the entire <i>ketubah</i> amount if the husband divorces her.<br>A document in which כתובה and פרנה are used interchangeably was published by S, Asaph, <i>Tarbiz</i> 9(1938), #1, p. 25.</i>, she should leave without <i>ketubah.</i> If she is not deviant, she should take the entire <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Mana said to them, bring the <i>ketubah</i> that we may read it. They brought the <i>ketubah</i> and found written in it<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">About this <i>ketubah</i> text which gives the wife the right to force a divorce in exchange for a predetermined financial reward for the husband, see the details in Note 226, Chapter 5.</i>: If this X marries this Y as her husband and should no longer desire his company, she shall take half the <i>ketubah</i> sum. Rebbi Abun said, since she agreed that he<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">A man other than the husband.</i> should put his mouth on her mouth it is as if she hated him; she has only half the <i>ketubah.</i> She lies in his bosom<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">For Aramaic חוּבָּה = Hebrew חיק, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 4:6" href="/Exodus.4.6"><i>Targum Yerušalmi Ex.</i> 4:6</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 4:7" href="/Exodus.4.7">7</a>. A less likely explanation would be “hideout”, derived from the Hebrew root חבא “to hide”. In the cases mentioned here, there are witnesses but the parties are fully clothed.</i> or he lies in her bosom, she is deviant<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">And may be divorced without claim to the <i>ketubah.</i></i>. If they embrace, she is deviant. If they kiss, she is deviant. If the door is locked, she is deviant. If it is blocked<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Not locked, but some obstacle would have to be removed before a third party could enter the room.</i>, that is a problem<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The wife has not lost her right to sue for the <i>ketubah</i> amount but the outcome of the suit cannot be guaranteed.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody performed the preliminary marriage with a woman on condition that she had no obligation of vows on her and it turned out that she had vows to fulfill, she is not preliminarily married<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">No conditional contract is valid if the condition is not fulfilled at the moment the contract is activated.</i>. If he married her definitively without inquiry<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Vows were not mentioned at all in the preparations for the preliminary marriage.</i> and she had vows to fulfill<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Of the kind she could expect that the husband would object to.</i>, she should leave without <i>ketubah</i>. If somebody performed the preliminary marriage with a woman on condition that she had no bodily defects and it turned out that she had bodily defects, she is not preliminarily married. If he married her definitively without inquiry and she had bodily defects, she should leave without <i>ketubah</i>; and<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the cases where שֶׁ and וְ have the same meaning.</i> all defects which disqualify a priest<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">From Temple service; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:16-24" href="/Leviticus.21.16-24"><i>Lev.</i>21:16–24</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.7">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 7</a>.</i> disqualify a woman.<br>If she had bodily defects<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The preliminarily married groom divorces her because of the defects and refuses to pay the <i>ketubah.</i> Is the burden of proof on the claimant (in this case the bride and her father) or on the person who wants to break the contract (the groom)? Since in money matters the burden of proof is both on the claimant and on the person who disputes the validity of a document, a way has to be found to reconcile the two conflicting rules. This Mishnah presupposes that the <i>ketubah</i> was written at the time of the preliminary marriage.</i>, as long as she is in her father’s house, the father has to prove that the defects developed after she was preliminarily married and his field was swamped<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">This agricultural simile is used generally to describe that an accident happened in the buyer’s domain. If somebody buys a field and then finds out that is was recently flooded and became unusable for the current season, it is of the essence that the date of the flood be determined exactly to find out whether it was his bad luck or that he had been sold the field fraudulently. In the latter case he can recover the price paid in court.</i>; once she entered her husband’s domain, the husband has to prove that she had the defects before the preliminary wedding so that his acquisition was in error<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The underlying principle is: There is a <i>prima facie</i> assumption that a defect happened where it was discovered.</i>, the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, when was this said? For hidden defects, but he has no claim about visible defects<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is not supposed to marry a woman he had not seen before the marriage.</i>, and if there is a public bathhouse in his town he has no claim for hidden defects since he checks her out through his female relatives.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody performed the preliminary marriage with a woman on condition that she had no obligation of vows on her,” etc. “If she had bodily defects, as long as she is in her father’s house,” etc. We have stated defects. Which vows<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah stated a criterion for defects which are serious enough for annulment of the marriage. Does there exist a similar criterion for vows? “Vows” without a qualifier are always “vows or oaths of prohibition for the purposes of mortification”; cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Nedarim.</i><br>The entire Halakhah from here on is also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.5.2-4">Halakhah <i>Qiddus̄in</i>2:5</a><i>.</i> The variant readings are noted <b>ק</b>.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Yoṣadaq: If she vowed not to eat, or not to drink wine, or not to wear dyed garments<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli 72b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:8" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.8">Tosephta 7:8</a>. These vows either interfere with her ability to cook for her husband or they detract from his standing in the community if his wife appears in undyed woolen or linen garments used only by the poor.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, the fine linen garments which come from Bet She‘an have the status of dyed garments<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">These are bleached white; he asserts that bleaching is the equivalent of dying.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the Mishnah deals with the case that he said to her, “on condition that you have no obligation of vows on you.” But if he said, “on condition that you have no obligation of <i>any</i> vow on you,” then even if she made a vow not to eat carob fruit<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">In which case nobody should care. A similar argument is ascribed to Rav Pappa in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b" href="/Ketubot.72b">Babli, 72b</a>.</i> it is a vow.
<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 7:8; quoted in Babli 74b; also in Yerushalmi Qiddušin 2:5 (62c l. 66).</i>“If she went to an Elder and her dissolved her vow, she is preliminarily married. To a doctor and he healed her, she is not preliminarily married.” <sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (previous Note) this is quoted as a tannai'tic text.</i> What is the difference between the Elder and the doctor? The elder uproots the vow from its start; the doctor heals only for the future. <sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The following text has a parallel with different emphasis in the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Some Tannaïm state: Even if she went to an Elder and her dissolved her vow, she is not preliminarily married. The <i>baraita</i> follows Rebbi Eleazar, as we have stated there: “Rebbi Eleazar said, they forbade this only because of the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.4.7.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 4:7</a> where it is stated that a man who divorces his wife because of her vows is never permitted to take her back. This is a rabbinic rule. R. Meïr holds that no remarriage is permitted in case of any vow that needs to be annulled by an Elder (cf. <i>Nedarim</i> Chapter 9). The reason is that one has to avoid a situation in which the divorcee marries another man and for him goes to an Elder to have him annul the vow. If the ex-husband says, “if I had known that her vow will be annulled, I would not have divorced her,” he retroactively would annul the bill of divorce, make his ex-wife a bigamist and bastards of her children from the second husband. Therefore, one has to make clear to him that the divorce is final and irreversible, to prevent him from having second thoughts. But if the cause of the divorce is an invalid vow, the divorce is not caused by the vow and the husband may remarry his divorcee (as long as she did not marry another man). R. Eleazar says that remarriage was forbidden in the second case because of the first one since it is obvious that the husband must be an ignoramus if he divorces his wife because of a vow which every competent scholar will immediately declare as invalid if asked about it (“a vow which does not have to be investigated by a Sage” because the Sage will declare it invalid at first sight.)</i>” What is the reason of Rebbi Eleazar? It would have been logical about a vow which has to be investigated by a Sage … because a vow which does not have to be investigated by a Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">This text is clearly elliptic. There does not seem to be a lacuna, but rather the text is a reference to an extensive argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 4:7:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.4.7.2-3"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 4:7</a> (and a related text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 2:4:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.2.4.2-5"><i>Qiddušin</i> 2:5</a>):אָמַר רִבִּי לָֽעְזָר. לֹא אָֽסְרוּ זֶה אֶלָּא מִפְּנֵי זֶה. בְּדִין הָיָה שֶׁאֲפִילוּ נֵדֶר שֶׁהוּא צָרִיךְ חֲקִירַת חָכָם יַחֲזִיר. שֶׁהַזָּקֵן עוֹקֵר אֶת הַנֵּדֶר מֵעִיקָּרוֹ מִפְּנֵי מָה אָֽסְרוּ נֵדֶר שֶׁאֵין צָרִיךְ חֲקִירַת חָכָם. מִפְּנֵי נֵדֶר שֶׁהוּא צָרִיךְ חֲקִירַת חָכָם. “Rebbi Eleazar said, they forbade this only because of the other. It would have been logical that even in the case of a vow which has to be investigated by a Sage he could take her back. For the Elder uproots the vow from the start. Why did they forbid a vow which does not have to be investigated by a Sage? Because of a vow which has to be investigated by a Sage.”</i>. Some Tannaïm state: She is allowed to marry<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The woman whose preliminary marriage has been declared invalid because of her vows may marry any other man without a divorce from the first.</i> without a bill of divorce. Some Tannaïm state: She is forbidden to marry without a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">This is also quoted in the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i></i>. They wanted to say that he who says, she is allowed to marry without a bill of divorce, is Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Who holds that all these prohibitions are only extreme precautions.</i>, and he who says, she is forbidden to marry without a bill of divorce, are the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">This position, rejected here, is the one adopted in the Babli. It seems that the Babli would reject the argument given for the permission to remarry as unreasonable (cf. R. Nissim Gerondi, <i>ad</i> Aliassi 35a.)</i>. Everything follows the rabbis. He who says, she is allowed to marry without a bill of divorce: Since she knows that if she went to an Elder, he would dissolve her vow, since she does not go therefore she can be married without a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">If she does not go to stay married to the first husband, one does not expect her to try to dissolve her vow for any other man.</i>. But he who says, she is forbidden to marry without a bill of divorce, that she should not go to an Elder<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Having used the vows to escape a marriage chosen for her when adolescent by her father, she might be expected to have the vow annulled as an adult for a man of her choice.</i> who would dissolve her vow, then the preliminary marriage would become retroactively valid for her and it would turn out that her children become bastards. Therefore she is forbidden to marry without a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">From her first husband, who in executing the divorce has to forswear any hope ever again to be married to her.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, the Mishnah deals with the case that he married her preliminarily conditionally but definitively silently<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah does not spell out what the connections are between preliminary and definitive marriage ceremonies. R. Simeon ben Laqish reads the Mishnah as one statement: If he stipulated for the preliminary marriage that the woman should be without vows or blemishes, if his condition is not met he can walk out of his commitment without further obligation. If he goes ahead with the definitive marriage, the marriage is valid and can be dissolved only by a bill of divorce, but his original condition has not been withdrawn and, therefore, he does not have to pay.</i>. But if he married her preliminarily silently and definitively silently, she can claim her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">This case has not been dealt with in the Mishnah; therefore the groom has no legal basis for refusing to pay the <i>ketubah</i> even if one agrees that he can divorce his wife for cause since he cannot be expected to live with a vowing or invalid wife. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:9" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.9">Tosephta, 7:9</a>, supports R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even if he married her preliminarily silently and definitively silently, she has no <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that the two cases in the Mishnah, referring to preliminary and definitive marriages, are independent of one another. Therefore, anybody who finds his wife encumbered by vows or having bodily defects can divorce her without <i>ketubah,</i> even if the subject was never mentioned at the preliminary marriage.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: But she needs a bill of divorce from him even if he married her preliminarily conditionally but definitively silently<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Since the stipulation was not repeated at the definitive marriage, the fact of the definitive marriage retroactively validates the preliminary marriage that would have been invalid if the condition of the bride had been investigated by the groom. Therefore, the stipulation can refer only to money matters, not to the validity of the marriage and the marriage cannot simply be declared nonexistent.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 72b-73a" href="/Ketubot.72b-73a">Babli, 72b/73a</a>, this is the position of Rav, disputed by Samuel. The Babli explains that Rav holds that if a man sleeps with a woman he shows that in his mind he is legally married (and the preliminary marriage is validated retroactively); Samuel does not attribute such pious thoughts to men.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Mana: In case he married her preliminarily silently and divorced her after the preliminary marriage, what does Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish say<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>ketubah</i> was written for the preliminary marriage, does R. Simeon ben Laqish equate the signing of the <i>ketubah</i> document to a definitive marriage as far as money matters go?</i>? Let us hear from the following: “If she had bodily defects, as long as she is in her father’s house, the father has to prove.” This implies that if the father proved his case, she can claim her <i>ketubah.</i> What do you see to say, if he married her preliminarily silently and divorced her after the preliminary marriage! Where do we hold<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">This proves that the Mishnah must assume the preliminary marriage to have been unconditional.</i>? Since afterwards [it is stated]: “When was this said? For hidden defects, but he has no claim about visible defects.” If he [made it conditional]<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">From the parallel in <i>Qiddušin,</i> missing here in ms. and <i>editio princeps.</i></i>, could he not also claim for visible ones? But did not the colleagues say before Rebbi Yose: Should we say that the following statement disagrees with Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish? “Once she entered her husband’s domain, the husband has to prove.” This implies that if the husband proved his case<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to an unconditional preliminary marriage.</i>, she has no claim to <i>ketubah.</i> But by the statement of Rebbi Simeon ban Laqish, she has a claim to <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Cohen in the name of the rabbis of Caesarea: The Mishnah deals with the case that he definitively married her but did not sleep with her; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish speaks about the case that he definitively married her and slept with her; I am saying that she was acceptable to him since he took her to bed<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">He must have been aware of her bodily defect. The Mishnah treats the cases of vows and defects as completely parallel; one must therefore restrict the statement of R. Simeon ben Laqish to the case that the husband was aware of his wife’s vows when he slept with her for the first time.</i>.
“And all defects which disqualify a priest disqualify a woman. They added to them for women mouth odor, sweat odor, and a hairless mole.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:9" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.9">Tosephta 7:9</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 75a" href="/Ketubot.75a">Babli 75a</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 6" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.6">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> Chapter 6</a> enumerates the defects which make an animal unfit for the altar. Chapter 7 states that any defect making an animal unfit will disqualify a Cohen from Temple service. In addition, a misshapen head will disqualify a priest, also a bald pate not bordered in the front by a line of hair from ear to ear.</i>” Rebbi Ammi bar Uqba in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: They taught this<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The mole.</i> about the skin of the face. But did we not state: “When was this said? For hidden defects, but he has no claim about visible defects,” and this is of the visible defects! Explain it if she hid it under her headgear. It was stated: “A mole with hairs is a defect, whether it be large or small, whether it be on the body or on the face. Without a hair it is a defect on the face but not on the body. When has this been said? If it is small. But if it is large, it is a defect whether it be on the body or on the face. How big is large? Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, up to an Italic <i>as</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">A rather large copper coin, abount an inch in diameter.<br>The <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 75a" href="/Ketubot.75a">Babli, 75a</a>; the following amoraic comment (and reduction in size) has no parallel there.</i>.” Rebbi Eleazar bar Ḥanina said, for example such a Gordianic denar<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Minted by Gordianus III. Really a double denar, an <i>Antoninianus,</i> but whose weight was only ⅓ larger than the simple denars minted by Gordianus I and II. Cf. D. Sperber, <i>Roman Palestine,</i>200–400,<i>Money and Prices,</i> Ramat Gan 1974, pp. 39,226. Since the text here is confirmed by its parallel in <i>Qiddušin,</i> the different readings in הילכות טרפות לבני ארץ ישראל, תלפיות ח 1963, pp. 324–5, do not refer to the text here.</i> his measure is half an ubiquitous gold piece<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This R. Eleazar bar Ḥanina is not mentioned again in the Talmudim. In <i>Qiddušin,</i> the quote is “R. Eleazar in the name of R. Ḥanina”; the latter lived under the last Severan emperors and the early military anarchy. The gold coin is an <i>aureus</i> of Septimius Severus or his successors.</i>. Rebbi Radifa, Rebbi Jonah: Rebbi Jeremiah asked: A bald woman with a row of hair going from one ear to the other<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Which is not a defect for a male, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.5">Note 137</a>.</i>? They wanted to understand it from the following: “They added to them for women mouth odor, sweat odor, and a hairless mole.” They did not mention baldness. They wanted to conclude that it is not a defect. There came Rebbi Samuel the son of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun: Rebbi Nasa said, it is a defect. It is listed only if it is ugly for both sexes. But something which is beautiful in one sex but ugly in the other, like a bald pate, even though it is a defect it was not listed. You should know that this is so because a beard is beautiful for a man and a defect for a woman, and we did not state: In addition, for a woman a beard. There are breasts which are beautyiful for a woman and a defect for men, and we did not state: In addtion, for a man women’s breasts<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">No list is complete. In the Babli, oversized woman’s breasts are listed as defect.<br>In <i>Qiddušin,</i> this is the end of the Halakhah.</i>.
The Mishnah deals with defects which do not spontaneously appear<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Defects that do not appear during the natural aging process. Without prior stipulation the husband cannot complain if his wife is not permanently youthful looking.<br>There is a possibility that this paragraph refers to a statement similar to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:10" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.10">Tosephta 7:10</a>: The Sages agree with R. Meïr (in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 7:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.7.7.1">Mishnah 8</a>) that for defects which usually develop (in Nachmanides’s opinion, birth defects or defects that develop in early childhood) the father has to bring proof even if she is in her husband’s house (even if these are visible defects). In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 77a" href="/Ketubot.77a">Babli, 77a</a>, epilepsy is a hidden defect if the onset of an attack is preceded by signs which give the girl time to hide herself; it is a public defect if attacks come without warning.</i>. But about defects which spontaneously appear, the husband has to bring proof and say that he stipulated about them.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a man developed defects, one does not force him to divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife claims that she cannot live with such a man.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, when has this been said? For minor defects. But for major defects one forces him to divorce.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a man developed defects,” etc. Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: So is the Mishnah, “if he had.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, 77a, Rav Jehudah reads that the defect “developed (after the marriage)” and Rav’s son Ḥiyya reads “was (in existence at the time of marriage)”.</i>” But if they developed newly, one forces him to divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rav Jehudah’s conclusion.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Cahana in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is a statement of R. Abba bar Jacob in the name of R. Joḥanan, it is rejected by the Babylonian Amoraïm.</i>. There came a case before Rebbi Jeremiah about a <i>kopeaḥ</i><sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">This is mentioned in Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 7:6 as כיפח (in the Maimonides tradition of the Mishnah and oriental mss. of the Babli collected by R. Beṣalel Ashkenazi) or קיפח. According to Rashi <i>(Bekhorot</i> 45b), he is overly tall but has soft bones so that he cannot walk straight. R. Beṣalel Ashkenazi (<i>Bekhorot</i> 45b, Note י) quotes one opinion that he is an epileptic.</i>, and he forced him<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">To divorce his wife upon her demand.</i>. It turns out that following Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., in Rav’s interpretation of the anonymous Tanna in the Mishnah.</i> if he did not become so, following Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel if he became so. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel follows Rebbi Meïr. Which [statement of] Rebbi Meïr? The former or the later<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The former statement is in Mishnah 9, that one assumes that the defect occured at the place it was detected. The later statement is that of Mishnah 11: a woman may claim that she married because she thought she could stand to live with a man having such a defect but she recognizes now that this is impossible for her.</i>? If the former, until she made a condition<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">If the reference were to Mishnah 9, one would require the woman to stipulate before the marriage that the man be free of defects. In that case, everybody agrees that she can force a divorce.</i>. If the later, even if he made a condition it is nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">If he divulged his defect to his fiancee before the marriage, R. Meïr still will not force the woman to stay married if she finds the experience intolerable.</i>. But this Mishnah turns out following Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Mishnah 10 is Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s. (One usually reads Mishnaiot containing a statement “when has this been said” to be the text of the person who explains). Since he makes a distinction between small and large defects, he must speak of newly developed defects.</i>; does “the following one forces to divorce” [follows] the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Does Mishnah 11 follow the rabbis in Rav’s interpretation, dealing with pre-existing conditons?</i>? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 7:9, Babli 77a; the language of the Tosephta is closer to the Yerushalmi.</i>: “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, if it was a major defect, e. g., blind in one eye, amputated of one of his hands, lame in one of his legs, immediately he shall divorce and pay the <i>ketubah.</i>” This Mishnah turns out following Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Mishnah 10 is Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s. (One usually reads Mishnaiot containing a statement “when has this been said” to be the text of the person who explains). Since he makes a distinction between small and large defects, he must speak of newly developed defects.</i>; “the following one forces to divorce” [follows] the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Since the defects mentioned in the Mishnah are not on Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s list.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following one forces to divorce: Those smitten with boils, the one afflicted with a polyp<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πολύπους “many-footed”, a cancerous growth in the nose (according to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 77a" href="/Ketubot.77a">Babli, 77a</a>, an evil smelling growth.)</i>, the dung collector<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">He collects animal dung to sell to tanners; he smells badly.</i>, the brass refiner, and the tanner<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">All these have professions that impregnate them with bad smells which even with a bath cannot be removed.</i>, whether they were in this before they married or they came to it after they married. For all of these says Rebbi Meïr that, even if he contracted with her<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">He informed her of his impediment before the marriage.</i>, she can say “I thought that I could stand it, now I cannot stand it.” But the Sages say, she is forced to stand it except for the one smitten with boils because she causes him consumption<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">In talmudic medical theory there are kinds of boils for which sexual activity is very detrimental.</i>. It happened in Sidon that a tanner died<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">He died childless; his widow can force her levir not to take her in levirate marriage and free her by <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i> who had a brother tanner; there the Sages said, she can say: “I could stand that in your brother, I cannot stand it in you.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following one forces to divorce: Those smitten with boils,” etc. “The <i>meqammeṣ.</i>” This is the dung collector; but some say it is the tanner. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, the Mishnah implies that this is the dung collector since we have stated: “The <i>meqammeṣ</i> and the tanner.”<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 77a" href="/Ketubot.77a">Babli, 77a</a>, explains the problem away that in the opinion of the dissenting <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:11" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.11">Tosephta (7:11</a>) there are different kinds of tanners, smelling differently.</i> “The brass refiner.” Samuel said, that is the one who smelts brass from its ore<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 77a" href="/Ketubot.77a">Babli, 77a</a>, this is only one opinion; Rav disagrees and holds that he repairs metal pots.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7">Tosephta 7</a>:11 [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 41:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.41.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 41(2</a>)] in this version only the person afflicted with <i>ritan</i> is required to divorce his wife for medical reasons. Another version in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 77b" href="/Ketubot.77b">Babli, 77b</a> [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 16:1" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.16.1"><i>Lev. rabba</i>16(1</a>)], requires all sufferers from boils to refrain from sexual activity.</i>: “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, I met an old man, smitten with boils, from Sepphoris. He told me, there are 24 kinds of boils; the worst one, and the one for which a woman is bad, is flowing boils<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Usually derived somehow from Greek ῥέω “to flow”.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Jonathan: With the latter kind, the evil Pharao was smitten<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">This is anonymous in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 41:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.41.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i>41(2</a>).</i>; that is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 12:17" href="/Genesis.12.17"><i>Gen.</i> 12:17</a>.</i>: “The Eternal smote Pharao and his house with great plagues,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">This is slightly distorted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 41:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.41.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 41(2</a>), correct in 52(14). It was read by H. Graetz as mixed <i>Aramaic</i>/Greek/Latin sentence: <i>dĕ-</i>ἐτόλμησεν <i>lĕmagga‘ ba</i>-σῶμα <i>dĕ</i>-matrona; where ἐτόλμησεν is aorist of τολμάω “to dare, to presume”.</i> Rebbi Berekhia said: Because he dared to touch the matron’s body. There are 24 kinds of cedar<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">This is added here because of the number 24. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 23a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.23a">Babli (<i>Roš Haššanah</i> 23a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 37a" href="/Sukkah.37a"><i>Sukkah</i> 37a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Taanit 25b" href="/Taanit.25b"><i>Ta‘anit</i> 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 80b" href="/Bava_Batra.80b"><i>Baba batra</i> 80b</a>) there are only 10 kinds mentioned, the 10 explained here, with sometimes different and multiple identifications. The original text seems to be in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 15:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.15.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 15(2</a>): “R. Samuel ben Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Jonathan: There are 24 kinds of cedar but only 7 are of the best kind.”</i>, and from all of them the verse mentioned only seven. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 41:19" href="/Isaiah.41.19"><i>Is.</i> 41:19</a>.</i>: “I shall give in the desert cedar, acacia, myrtle, and oil wood<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli identified as the balsamum shrub.</i>; I put in the prairie <i>beroš, tidhar,</i> and <i>teaššur</i> together. <i>Beroš</i> is cypress; <i>tidhar</i> is <i>idra</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">This Aramaic word for a tree has not been identified. In the Babli identified as ساج “teak”.</i>;<i>teasššur</i> is the box-tree<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πύξινον “box-tree”.</i>. They added to them<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">This expression is out of place here; it belongs to the tannaïtic tradition reported in the Babli that there are 10 kinds of cedar, with three added to the seven mentioned by Isaiah.</i> <i>’allonim, ‘armonim,</i> and <i>’almogim. ’Allonim</i> are oaks, <i>‘armonim</i> plane trees, <i>’almuggim</i> aloës.

Chapter 8



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman inherited property before she became preliminarily married, the Houses of Shammai and Hillel agree that if she sells or gives it away it is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">If she is an unmarried adult, she is fully capable of acting and does not need any male guardian or representative. “Properties” without further qualifications are real estate.</i>. If she inherited after she became preliminarily married, the House of Shammai say she may sell<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Up to the time of the definitive marriage. At the definitive marriage the husband becomes the administrator of the properties and receives their yield; he has no say in the matter before that date. Everybody agrees that after the definitive marriage the wife can sell only through her husband (unless a separation of property was stipulated before the definitive marriage. Since these are money matters, they are all subject to modification by the contracting parties.)</i>, the House of Hillel say she should not sell, but both of them agree that if she sold or gave it away it is valid. Rebbi Jehudah said: They said before Rabban Gamliel: If he obtained the right to the woman<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Since the preliminary marriage makes the bride a married woman in all aspects of criminal law, should the husband not also have acquired a say in her properties.</i>, should he not also acquire the right to the property? He said to them, are we not ashamed about the new [properties]<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Properties she inherits after the final wedding ceremony, of which <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.2.1">Mishnah 2</a> decrees that the husband can veto her sale. It seems not reasonable that the secondary interest of the husband in the yield of the properties should override the primary property rights of the wife in her inheritance.</i> and you want to burden us with the old ones<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The properties inherited before the final wedding date</i>?
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman inherited property,” etc. So is the Mishnah: Before she was preliminarily married<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">There seems to be no difference in meaning between t-reflexive <i>hit pa‘el</i> and n-reflexive <i>niph‘al.</i> J. N. Epstein (<i>loc. cit.</i> <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.1.6">Chapter 5, Note 33, p. 474</a>) sees in this sentence only the introduction to the following question since in all quotes of the Mishnah in other parts of the Yerushalmi the formulation of the Mishnah is used.</i>. What is the difference between before she was preliminarily married and after she was preliminarily married? Before she was preliminarily married, it fell to her; after she was preliminarily married it fell to her and him<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 78a" href="/Ketubot.78a">Babli, 78a</a>, has a slightly more careful formulation, that after the preliminary marriage the husband <i>might have</i> an interest.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is from <i>Peak</i> 6:2, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:5:2-8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.5.2-8.1">Notes 45–55</a> (variants <b>פ</b>).</i> Rebbi Phineas asked before Rebbi Yose, why did we not state it with the leniencies of the House of Shammai and the stringencies of the House of Hillel? He said to him, the Mishnaiot apply only to circumstances that are either stringent on both sides or lenient on both sides. But here it is a stringency on one side and a leniency on the other side. But did we not state: “The House of Shammai say, property abandoned to the poor [is abandoned]?” Is this not lenient for the poor and stringent for the householder, and it was stated! He said to him, it is lenient for the poor and not stringent for the householder, since he intentionally abandoned it. He said to him, did we not state: “If the sheaf that was near a closure, a stack, cattle, or vessels was forgotten,” is this not lenient for the householder and stringent for the poor, and it was stated! He said to him, it is lenient for the householder but not stringent for the poor, because they did not acquire it yet. You may also say here, it is lenient for the woman and not stringent for the husband since he did not yet acquire property rights to it. He said to him, since he became betrothed to her, the inheritance fell to both of them.
Rebbi Jehudah said, they argued before Rabban Gamliel: Because preliminarily married she is his wife and definitively married she is his wife; just as the sale by the latter is void, the sale by the former also should be void. He said to them, we are ashamed of the new ones, now you want to roll the new on over the old ones! The new ones, after the definitive marriage; the old ones before the definitive marriage, when she was married in the second ceremony.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she inherited property<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This word is in the text of the Mishnah, not in the quote in the Halakhah nor in any other known Mishnah or Talmud ms. This supports S. Lieberman’s opinion that the copyist of the Leiden ms. took the Mishnah text from a ms. different from the Talmud ms. before him.</i> after she was definitively married, both agree<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The Houses of Shammai and Hillel.</i> that if she sold or gave away the husband retrieves from the hand of the buyers<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the husband has the administration of the wife’s paraphernalia and receives their yield. This means that at the moment the wife acquires title to the property, the husband acquires title to its yield. Therefore, he can go to court and invalidate the real estate transaction which was done without his concurrence.</i>. [If she interited] before she was definitively married<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Even after she was preliminarily married; therefore this property does not become part of her dowry proper (mortmain) but remains the wife’s separate property as paraphernalia (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 7, Note 1</a>).</i> and [sold] after she was definitively married, Rabban Gamliel said if she sold or gave away it is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Since she could have sold before the final marriage, as staled in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>, the husband has no acquired rights in the property.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina ben Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">This name appears also in the Munich ms. and the Soncino print of the Babli. In most other sources: Aqabia.</i> said, they said before Rabban Gamliel: If he obtained the right to the woman, did he not also acquire the right to the property<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Since with the act of definitive marriage he acquires his wife’s mortmain properties, why are his rights over her paraphernalia properties not likewise absolute?</i>? He said to them, are we not ashamed about the new [properties]<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Properties she inherits after the final wedding ceremony, of which <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.2.1">Mishnah 2</a> decrees that the husband can veto her sale. It seems not reasonable that the secondary interest of the husband in the yield of the properties should override the primary property rights of the wife in her inheritance.</i>, and you want to burden us with the old ones<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The properties inherited before the final wedding date</i>?
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she inherited after she was definitively married,” etc. We did state: She<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">She inherited real estate before her definitive wedding.</i> may sell or give away and it is valid. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: She should not sell or give away, but if she sold or gave away it is valid. <sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 8:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).8.1">Tosephta 8:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 78b" href="/Ketubot.78b">Babli 78b</a>. In both of these sources the text seems to be more correct: The argument is inverted. If the husband has property rights after the definitive marriage, what does this prove for the preliminary?</i>”Rebbi Ḥanina ben Aqiba said, that is not what Rabban Gamliel gave as answer, but the following was his argument: No, if you have an argument about a preliminarily married one, where he has rights neither to what she finds, nor to her handiwork, nor to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">He has joint rights to dissolve the vows of the adolescent preliminarily married girl; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.10.1.1">Mishnah <i>Nedarim</i> 10:1</a>. He has no rights to dissolve the vows of his adult preliminarily married wife.</i>, what can you say about a definitively married one where he has rights to what she finds, to her handiwork, and to dissolve her vows? Let the proof be the case of one who [inherited] before the definitive marriage and then was definitively married, in which case he has rights to what she finds, to her handiwork, and to dissolve her vows, and you admit to us that she should not sell or give away. He said to them, I agree that she should not sell or give away, but if she sold or gave away it is valid..” There came a case before Rebbi Immi. He said, is not Rabban Gamliel’s an isolated opinion? One cannot rely on it. A <i>baraita</i> supports him<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel. The argument of R. Immi is faulty but his conclusion correct.</i> and disagrees with him: <sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 7:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).7.1">Tosephta 7:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 78b" href="/Ketubot.78b">Babli 78b</a>.</i>”Our teachers took up the case again, voted, and instructed about property which she inherited before the definitive marriage and then was definitively married, that she should not sell or give away, and if she sold or gave away it is invalid.” It disagrees<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">With Rabban Gamliel.</i> that the sale is invalid. It agrees that our teachers took up the case again, instructed, and voted. Before they voted, they did not disagree with him<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In his time, Rabban Gamliel represented the majority opinion; his rule was invalidated by a later generation.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Simeon differentiates between properties: Properties known to the husband she shall not sell and if she sold or gave away it is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is not practice, neither Talmud gives a reason. According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 8:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).8.1">Tosephta (8:1</a>), the husband can claim that he married her only because of the property he knew was coming to her and that, therefore, the validity of the marriage depends on his getting his hands on that property.</i>. Those unknown to the husband she shall not sell but if she sold or gave away it is valid.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Simeon differentiates between properties,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 78b" href="/Ketubot.78b">Babli, 78b</a>, this is attributed to R. Yose ben R. Ḥanina.</i> said, properties known to the husband are real estate, those not known to the husband are movables. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, properties known to the husband are those she inherited in the presence of the husband, those not known to the husband are those she inherited while her husband was overseas<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 78a" href="/Ketubot.78a">Babli, 78a</a>, R. Joḥanan holds that all properties discussed here are real estate; but properties unknown to the husband are what she inherits overseas. Since the husband cannot administer these properties, he cannot object to his wife’s selling the properties, turning them into money.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: The following are properties not known to the husband, what she inherited while her husband was overseas.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she inherited money; real estate should be bought<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is the husband’s duty to preserve his wife’s property. In the economic environment of the later Roman Empire, real estate was the only investment guaranteed to keep its value (investments appropriate for the guardian of widows and orphans). Simce the husband is required to pay for all her needs, she has no direct use for the cash she inherited.</i> with it and he eats its yield. For produce cut from the ground, real estate should be bought and he eats its yield; with produce connected to the ground, Rebbi Meïr says one has to estimate how much the property<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The field in which the crop is standing.</i> is worth with produce and how much without, for the difference real estate should be bought<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Meïr holds that a crop is yield only if it grew under his care.</i> and he eats its yield. But the Sages say, standing produce is his<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is yield.</i>, cut it is hers; real estate should be bought from it and he eats its yield.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she inherited money; real estate should be bought,” etc. Rebbi Jeremiah said, this is Rebbi Meïr’s opinion since Rebbi Meïr considers standing [produce] as if it were cut<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to Mishnah <i>Ševuot</i> 6:6. In rabbinic interpretation, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:8" href="/Exodus.22.8"><i>Ex.</i> 22:8</a> defines when an oath is required by the court: “About any criminal matter, about an ox, a donkey, a sheep, a garment, or anything lost, <i>if he agrees</i> <i>that this is it,</i> the suit shall be heard by the judges …” This is read to mean that an oath is needed if the defendant agrees that the plaintiff has a case but that he owes less than what is being claimed (cf. <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael, Mišpaṭim</i> 15). The part of the claim in dispute is what the claimant considers criminal withholding of his property by the defendant. If the defendant rejects the entire claim, the claimant has to prove his case by witnesses or documents; if the defendant admits part of the claim the claimant can request that he swear not to owe more. But since the examples given in the verse are all about movables, it is concluded that claims of real estate cannot be resolved by an oath (Mishnah <i>Ševuot</i>6:5). On that, R. Meïr states that “some things are on the ground but are not real estate”. The example given is that the claim is “I handed over to you (to harvest and make wine from) ten vines full of fruit” but the defendant claims “there were ony five.” In that case, R. Meïr requires the defendant to swear but the Sages hold that anything connected to the ground is like real estate.<br>Since the produce on the field is considered as the wife’s capital, not the husband’s produce, R. Jeremiah infers that the Mishnah does not represent practice since it follows R. Meïr in a case in which the majority disagrees.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, he did not hear that Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, Rebbi Meïr said this only for standing grain ready to be harvested and grapes ready to be harvested; therefore not unripe produce<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:3:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.3.9"><i>Yebamot</i> 15:3, Note 79</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 43a" href="/Shevuot.43a">Babli <i>Ševuot</i> 43a</a>.</i>. But here<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The case of the wife’s inheritance is not restricted to ripe produce.</i>, even unripe produce. Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This attribution is impossible. Rebbi Jeremiah cannot ask a question answered by his teacher’s teacher’s teacher R. Joḥanan. It might be Rav Jeremiah, one generation before R. Joḥanan.</i> asked, are not the arguments of Rebbi Meïr contradictory? There<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In Mishnah <i>Ševuot</i> 6:6.</i>, he did not consider standing [produce] as if it were cut, but here<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The case of the wife’s inheritance is not restricted to ripe produce.</i> he considers standing [produce] as if it were cut. Rebbi Joḥanan said, Rebbi Meïr does not consider standing [produce] as if it were cut. But if you see cut grain, you empower the woman<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Cut grain is as good as coin for an inheritance.</i>; if you see an unseeded field<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">This has to be tended; the husband will reap the fruits.</i>, you empower the man. In case of doubt you estimate how much it is worth unseeded and how much seeded. If before it was seeded it was worth (two denars)<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, the numbers have to be switched since 1 &lt; 2.</i> and when it was seeded (one denar), with that denar real estate should be bought and he reaps its yield.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Simeon says, in the circumstances where he was empowered at her entrance he was disabled at her exit, and in the circumstances where he was disabled at her entrance he was empowered at her exit. What was connected to the ground at her entrance is his and at her exit is hers, what was cut from the ground at her entrance is hers and at her exit is his<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">He follows the Sages in the previous Mishnah that produce she brings into the marriage as capital and real estate is given over to his administration. He adds that at a divorce (if she exits the marriage) he has to deliver the field as is at the moment the bill of divorce is delivered, with all the grain standing if it was not cut before the divorce but that all produce harvested before the moment of divorce is his; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:3:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.3.9"><i>Yebamot</i> 15:5, Notes 67–68</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Simeon says, in the circumstances where he was empowered,” etc. You say, at her entrance they are his: If she sold them they are not sold, if she gave them to a sharecropper he has the reward from it<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The text may mean: He takes it away from him. In the first interpretation, the standing crop given to the sharecropper is counted as part of the latter’s compensation.</i>, if she dedicated them as First Fruits they are not dedicated<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Since nobody can dedicate anything which is not his property and not in his possession.</i> You say, at her exit they are hers, if he sold them they are not sold, if he gave them to a sharecropper she has the reward from it, if he dedicated them as First Fruits, this is the disagreement of Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, since they disagreed: <sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The next few sentences are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.7"><i>Bikkurim</i> 1:6, Notes 119–121</a>.
