Cf. <i>Sifry Deut.</i> #301.</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:11" href="/Deuteronomy.26.11"><i>Deut</i>. 26:11</a>): ‘You shall enjoy all the good things that the Eternal, your God, gave to you and your house.’ This teaches that a person brings First Fruits from his wife’s property.” Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, after her death but not during her lifetime. Rebbi Joḥanan said, there is no difference, during her lifetime and after her death. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish follows his own opinion since he said, a person does not inherit from his wife as a biblical rule<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">This is the common Sadducee-Karaite opinion that the wife is never mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:7-11" href="/Numbers.27.7-11"><i>Num</i>. 27:7–11</a> (only that the children inherit from their mother, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 36:3" href="/Numbers.36.3"><i>Num.</i> 36:3</a>). In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 47b" href="/Gittin.47b">Babli, <i>Giṭṭin</i> 47b</a>. it is supposed that R. Simeon ben Laqish accepts that the wife is mentioned obliquely in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:11" href="/Numbers.27.11"><i>Num.</i> 27:11</a> and his disagreement with R. Joḥanan is about a technicality; the opinion attributed here to R. Simeon ben Laqish is attributed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 84a" href="/Ketubot.84a">Babli, 84a</a>, to Rav. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 52b" href="/Bekhorot.52b"><i>Bekhorot</i> 52b</a>, it is asserted without dissent that the husband’s right of inheritance is biblical. (Maimonides, <i>Hilkhot Naḥalot</i> 6:8, asserts that the husband’s right of inheritance from his wife is only rabbinic practice.)</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish it never was dedicated. In the opinion of Rebbi Joḥanan it is dedicated and the holiness is removed<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">If the First Fruits were dedicated during the marriage then the act of divorce removes the husband’s ownership and with it the dedication.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she inherited old male and female slaves, they should be sold and real estate bought with the proceeds, of which he eats the yield. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, she does not have to sell<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot sell her family’s slaves against her will.</i> because they are the glory of her father’s house.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she inherited male and female slaves,” etc. The Mishnah speaks of those who do not work enough<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">As <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 79b:13:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.79b.13.1">Tosaphot notes (79b, <i>s. v.</i> והרי</a>), if they cannot work at all they cannot be sold.</i> for their upkeep. But if they work enough for their upkeep, she does not have to sell<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Even according to the anonymous Tanna.</i> because the glory of her father’s house still exists.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she inherited old vines or olive trees, they should be sold for their wood and real estate bought with the proceeds, of which he eats the yield. Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that Alfassi reads “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel”, with the Munich ms. of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 38b" href="/Ketubot.38b">Babli (38b</a> in the Wilna edition.)</i> says, she does not have to sell<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot sell her family’s slaves against her will.</i> because they are the glory of her father’s house.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she inherited old vines or olive trees,” etc. Rav Abun in the name of the rabbis there<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 79b" href="/Ketubot.79b">Babli, 79b</a>, these Babylonian rabbis are Rav Cahana in the name of Rav.</i>: The Mishnah deals with the case that she inherited olive trees but not their ground, vines but not their ground<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, if one waits until the trees have died, all value from the inheritance is lost.</i>. But if she inherited olive trees with their ground, vines with their ground, she does not have to sell since her father’s house’s glory still exists<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">On condition that the orchard or the vineyard be generally known as “her father’s orchard or vineyard.”</i>. But the rabbis here say, even if she inherited olive trees with their ground, vines with their ground, did she not inherit the value of the olive grove, did she not inherit the value of the vineyard? A <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The remainder of this paragraph is from <i>Ma‘serot</i> 2:5, Notes 107,108. The quote is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Batra (Lieberman) 6:18" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Batra_(Lieberman).6.18">Tosephta <i>Baba Batra</i> 6:18</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 7a" href="/Bava_Batra.7a">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i>7a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 104a" href="/Bava_Metzia.104a"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 104a</a>.</i> supports the rabbis there: “ ‘I am selling you the vineyard’, this is a valid sale even if there are no vines since he sells him [the real estate] by description<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">If the lot was popularly known as “vineyard” or “olive grove”.</i>. ‘I am selling you the grove’, this is a valid sale even if there are no trees since he sells him [the real estate] by description.”

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody invests in his wife’s properties<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The paraphernalia properties which in case of a divorce have to be returned to the wife.</i>, if he invested much but it yielded little, or he invested little but it yielded much, what he invested he invested and what it yielded it yielded<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">He has no claim to be repaid for the excess of his investment over his gain.</i>. If he invested and had no yield, he shall swear how much he invested and get repaid<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">If he divorced his wife before he had <i>any</i> income from his investment, he can ask to be repaid.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody invests in his wife’s properties,” etc. Rebbi Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 80a" href="/Ketubot.80a">Babli, 80a</a>, he says “one date cake”.</i> in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi: Even if he ate only one basket of dates. Assi<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that he is the Babylonian, colleague of Rav; identified correctly in the Munich ms. of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 80a" href="/Ketubot.80a">Babli, 80a</a>.</i> said, that is, if the investment is greater than the increase in value. But if the increase in value is greater than the investment, one gives him the increase in value<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 80a" href="/Ketubot.80a">Babli, 80a</a>, two interpretations are given for Assi’s statement but in both of them, the husband is restricted to restitution of the amount he spent.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 8:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).8.3">Tosephta 8:3</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 39a" href="/Bava_Metzia.39a">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i>39a</a>.</i> with Assi: “In all cases<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Any person who has to return property to its rightful owner, including the husband who divorces his wife and has to return her paraphernalia properties in kind. If he returns a field before it is ripe, he can claim to be paid for his work only as sharecropper.</i> one evaluates it as for a sharecropper.” The <i>baraita</i> disagrees about planting; what Assi said was about a building. The <i>baraita</i> disagrees about planting, is that what Rebbi Abba said in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi: Even if he ate only one basket of dates<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Which is much less than the sharecropper’s part.</i>. He said to him, in one case if he ate, in the other if he did not eat.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah and Halakhah are also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.3.2-3"><i>Yebamot</i> 4:3</a>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:10:3-11:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.10.3-11.4">Notes 84–95</a> (variants noted י).</i> If a woman waiting for her levir inherited property, the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel agree that if she sells or gives away it is valid. If she died, what shall be done with her <i>ketubah</i> and the properties which enter and leave with her? The House of Shammai say, the husband’s and the father’s heirs shall split it. But the House of Hillel say, the properties are in the hands of the holders; the <i>ketubah</i> in the hands of the husband’s heirs and the properties which enter and leave with her in the hands of the father’s heirs.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If property came to a woman waiting for her levir,” etc. Here, you say “she may sell or give away and it is valid.” And you also say “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs!” Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, when do you say “she may sell or give away and it is valid”? If they came to her before she became a woman waiting for her levir. When do you say “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs”? If they came to her after she became a woman waiting for her levir. If they came to her before she became a woman waiting for her levir and produced revenue after she became a woman waiting for her levir, [that revenue is as if] they came to her after she became a woman waiting for her levir. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, the levir in this situation is a problem for the House of Shammai. If he is a husband, he inherits everything. If he is not a husband, he inherits nothing. Because of the doubt, “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs.” For the House of Hillel it is obvious that he is a husband and inherits everything. For even his brother had only the usufruct.
Rebbi Hoshaia stated: Her heirs, those who inherit her <i>ketubah</i> are obliged to bury her. Rebbi Yose said, if Rebbi Hoshaia had not stated this, we would have had a problem. If she had no <i>ketubah,</i> do they not have to bury her? This is difficult. If a woman has no <i>ketubah,</i> does she not have to be buried? A wife, even if she has no <i>ketubah,</i> must be buried. This one, if she has a <i>ketubah,</i> is entitled to burial costs. But here, if she does not have a <i>ketubah,</i> she is not entitled to burial costs.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If his brother left money, real estate should be bought with it and he eats its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Since the first husband’s inheritance is mortgaged to his widow as security for her <i>ketubah,</i> it is not available to the brother who marries the widow without due safeguards.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">These rules follow <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i> For produce cut from the ground, real estate should be bought and he eats its yield; connected to the ground, Rebbi Meïr says one has to estimate how much it is worth with produce and how much without, for the difference real estate should be bought and he eats its yield. But the Sages say, standing produce is his<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 82a" href="/Ketubot.82a">Babli (82a</a>) change the text of the Mishnah and require: “are hers” for the same reason given for money left by her husband.</i>, cut it is up for grabs<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This applies only if one follows the Mishnah that a <i>ketubah</i> is guaranteed only by real estate. The author of this part of the Mishnah must hold that the statement about money left was R. Meïr’s who holds that a <i>ketubah</i> can be guaranteed and paid for by movables.</i>. If he<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The levir as heir of his brother. It is clear that a person without claim (i. e., other than the widow, a brother, or a creditor) has no right to the produce.</i> took possession first, it is his; if she took possession first<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">It becomes property coming to the wife after the wedding, i. e., paraphernalia property.</i>, real estate should be bought for the proceeds and he eats its yield. <sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Yevamot 4:4" href="/Mishnah_Yevamot.4.4">Mishnah <i>Yebamot</i> 4:4, Note 96</a>.</i> If he married her, she is his wife in every respect<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">He can divorce and remarry her; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4">Halakhah <i>Yebamot</i> 4:4, Notes 97–100</a>.</i> except that her <i>ketubah</i> is a lien on the property of her first husband.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If his brother left money,” etc. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It is necessary, if the money was deposited with him<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah states at the end that the <i>ketubah</i> in a levirate marriage is guaranteed by the estate and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.11.1">Mishnah 11</a> states that all the property is under this lien, it seems superfluous to note that cash left by the first husband cannot be spent by the levir. Then it is noted that it is necessary to state that money deposited with the levir has to be accounted for and separated for the wife’s <i>ketubah.</i> In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 81b" href="/Ketubot.81b">Babli, 81b</a>, this is an explicit <i>baraita.</i></i>, that you would not let him say, since I am the heir it is mine.
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: One does not say “his”<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow’s <i>ketubah</i> is guaranteed by her first husband’s estate, there is no reason why the standing grain should go to the levir. If the husband had lived, it would have been his, but it could not be the levir’s before the latter actually married the widow. One has to correct the Mishnah to <i>hers</i> from <i>his.</i> This argument is R. Simeon ben Laqish’s in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 82a" href="/Ketubot.82a">Babli, 82a</a>.</i> but [ ]<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The word “hers” is missing in ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>; it is understood in the text.</i>. In which respect? In case the heir took it<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">If the levir harvested the grain without crediting it to the widow’s <i>ketubah</i> fund, she can go to court and have him acquire real estate for the corresponding amount.</i>, one removes it from his hand. Does one have the same rule for the creditor? Was it not stated: If either the heir or the creditor took it, one takes it from their hands<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.3.2-4">Halakhah 9:3</a>; there the scribe wrote: “one does not remove from their hands”, but the first corrector crossed out “not”. In both cases, the context implies that the scribe’s original text is the correct one. Since the heir does not have a claim on the standing grain, the heir’s creditor does not have one either.</i>? Rebbi Aḥa bar Ulla said, let us hear from the following: “If he dedicated 90 minas but his debt was 100 minas, [the creditor] adds another denar and redeems these properties.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">It is stated repeatedly in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 46a" href="/Yevamot.46a">Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 46a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 66b" href="/Yevamot.66b">66b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 40b" href="/Gittin.40b"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 40b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 59b" href="/Ketubot.59b"><i>Ketubot</i> 59b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 86b" href="/Nedarim.86b"><i>Nedarim</i> 86b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 90a" href="/Bava_Kamma.90a"><i>Baba Qama</i>90a</a>) that dedications to the Temple break contracts. This rule is not mentioned in the Yerushalmi and the latter’s position in this matter is not known. In Rashi’s interpretation, only dedications to the altar break contracts, not dedications which are purely monetary gifts to Temple or charity. Therefore, that principle does not apply here in any case.<br>The text is Mishnah <i>‘Arakhin</i> 6:2. There it is stated that if somebody dedicates his encumbered property, neither can the wife collect her <i>ketubah</i> nor a creditor his claim from Temple property which must first be redeemed. Then it is stated that if the creditor’s claim is at least equal to the appraised value of the property, he may lend another denar to the debtor and force him to redeem it to be able to foreclose the now secular property.</i>” Not necessarily a denar, but anything, that a dedication should not be seen to be profanated without redemption<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">This is a generally accepted principle; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 32b" href="/Arakhin.32b">Babli <i>Arakhin</i> 32b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 31a" href="/Pesachim.31a"><i>Pesaḥim</i>31a</a>. The redemption is purely symbolical since the debtor did not have the right to injure the creditor’s claim by dedication; therefore, the dedication is invalid.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: One would be guilty of complete larceny<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Me‘ilah</i> is larceny with Temple property which requires restitution in the amount of 125% and a sacrifice; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14-16" href="/Leviticus.5.14-16"><i>Lev.</i> 5:14–16</a>. R. Joḥanan implies that a person using the dedicated property for his personal advantage before it was redeemed is obligated for a sacrifice. On the other hand, it is sinful to offer unnecessary sacrifices which would be ”profane animals in the Temple courtyard.” If the sacrifice is valid then the dedication must be valid and could not be undone by a token amount but would require appraisal by a Cohen (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:11-14" href="/Leviticus.27.11-14"><i>Lev.</i> 27:11–14</a>).</i>. That is difficult. If one would be guilty of complete larceny, should if not be redeemed for its full value? If it can be redeemed for less than its full value, one should not be guilty of complete larceny! What are we talking about? If it is connected to the ground, can there be larceny about real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14" href="/Leviticus.5.14"><i>Lev</i>. 5:14</a> restricts <i>me‘ilah</i> to “the Eternal’s holy things”, which excludes real estate.</i>? But we talk about standing grain<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">This is not subject to <i>me‘ilah</i> when standing but will be subject once it is cut.</i>. Since if the administrator<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The Temple’s chief financial officer. Since the dedication was invalid when made for the field, he should not have cut the grain. But once it was cut, it becomes legitimate Temple property and can be sold for the Temple’s upkeep.</i> misbehaved and took it, one does not take it from his hand; the administrator and the heir follow the same rule<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This does <i>not</i> mean that the levir can take the standing grain, cut it, and keep it, but that the their’s standing vis-à-vis the creditor is like the administrator’s vis-à-vis the creditor. Since the creditor’s lien is on the real estate, it cannot cover the grain once it is cut and made movable. (Cf. the commentary <i>RYDBZ ad loc.</i> in the Wilna ed., and the novellae of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 40b" href="/Gittin.40b"><i>Rashba, Giṭṭin</i> 40b</a>, end.)</i>. Also if the heir misbehaved and took it, one does not take it from his hand. Rebbi Samuel, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The same rule holds for an ox. Can you say that an ox is real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Since the ox is movable, the dedication should be absolute.</i>? Rebbi Tanḥum bar Mari in the name of Rebbi Yose: They made the rules for an ox parallel those of dedications that lost their value<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rabbinical rule to protect the holders of chattel mortgages.</i>. Here, you say one takes it from his hand, but there you say, one does not take it from his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">This is the main question of this paragraph: Since the heir can cut the grain to the detriment of the lienholder, why can he not cut the grain to the detriment of the widow who also is a lienholder?</i>. Since you diminished the woman’s power in that her <i>ketubah</i> is a lien only on the properties of her first husband, you strengthened her power in this matter that if the heir came and took it, one removes it from his hand. It was stated thus: Trees and cutting, old or young, one removes from their hands.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The levir who marries his sister-in-law and whose brother’s inheritance is much larger than his wife’s <i>ketubah</i> cannot split the inheritance, reserve the amount necessary for the <i>ketubah</i> in a separate account, and use the remainder for his business. If he wants to commingle the inheritance with his own properties for his working capital, he has to pledge all his properties for her <i>ketubah</i>.</i> should not say to her “here your <i>ketubah</i> is lying on the table” but “all my properties are pledged for your <i>ketubah.</i>” If he divorced her, she has no <i>ketubah-</i> lien<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">After he paid her, he has unlimited use of the remainder of his brother’s inheritance.</i>. If he took her back, she is like all women who have a <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">This is explained in the Halakhah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">These two paragraphs constitute <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.2-12">Halakhah 4:4</a> in <i>Yebamot</i>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:11:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.11.5">Notes 97–101</a>.</i>“He should not say to her ‘here is your <i>ketubah</i>’”, etc. What does he do? “He marries her, he may divorce her and take her back, and she writes him a receipt for her <i>ketubah.</i>” Rebbi Yose said, the <i>baraita</i> has two possibilities. “Or she writes him a receipt for her <i>ketubah.</i>” Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Hamnuna: If he married her, divorced her, and took her back, if he wrote her a new <i>ketubah</i>, the lien is on his property; otherwise, it is on the property of her first husband. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said in the name of Rav Ḥisda, a Mishnah said so: “For he who takes back his wife, takes her back under the terms of her first <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The heads of the pre-Maccabean Ḥassidim sect; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 65:18" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.65.18"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 65(18</a>).</i>.” In the end, if he married her, divorced her, and took her back? He tells you something new. Even if he married her, divorced her, and took her back, if he wrote her a new <i>ketubah</i>, the lien is on his property; otherwise, it is on the property of her first husband.
Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Hamnuna said: A betrothed woman who died does not have a <i>ketubah</i> since she was not permitted to marry outside. That you should not say [the case] should be considered as if he divorced her and she should have a <i>ketubah</i>; therefore it was necessary to say that she does not have a <i>ketubah.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">A different version is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 82b" href="/Ketubot.82b">Babli, 82b</a>. It starts with a statement that women did not want to marry because their <i>ketubah</i> was unsecured and not privileged against the heirs.</i> In earlier times, her <i>ketubah</i> was deposited with her family; then it was easy for him to divorce her. They then instituted that her <i>ketubah</i> had to be deposited with her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: With her father-in-law. Since the money was ready, there was no difficulty in finding the money for a divorce.</i>; even so it was easy for him to divorce her. Then they instituted that a man should buy with his wife’s <i>ketubah</i> cups, plates, and bowls; that is what we did state: “He should not say to her ‘here your <i>ketubah</i> is lying on the table’ but all his properties are pledged for her <i>ketubah.</i>” Finally they instituted that a person should use his wife’s <i>ketubah</i> in business, then because he uses his wife’s <i>ketubah</i> in his business dealings he loses track of it and it becomes difficult for him to divorce her.
Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ decreed three things<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 14b" href="/Shabbat.14b">Babli, <i>Šabbat</i> 14b</a>, he is credited only with the institution of the <i>ketubah</i> and a decree about impurity of metal vessels (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:11:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.11.5">Note 102</a>). “The institution of the <i>ketubah</i>” probably means the formulation of the <i>ketubah</i> as a contract, which was unnecessary as long as the sum due was paid, or at least earmarked, as bride money. His decrees can be dated to the reign of his sister Shlomzion (Salome), widow of Alexander Yannai, 79–69 B.C.E.</i>: That a person should use his wife’s <i>ketubah</i> in his business dealings. And that children have to go to school<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 21a" href="/Bava_Batra.21a">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 21a</a>, universal mandatory schooling is attributed to the post-Herodian High Priest Joshua ben Gamla. The Babli also notes that before Joshua ben Gamla’s time there was organized higher instruction only for youths 16 years and older. This cannot refer to Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ’s institution reported in the Yerushalmi since by no stretch of the imagination can a 16 year old teenager be called תִּינּוֹק.</i>. Also, he decreed impurity for glass ware<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Biblical impurity applies only to kinds of vessels and implements mentioned in the rules of impurity: earthenware and metal (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:21" href="/Leviticus.6.21"><i>Lev.</i> 6:21</a>), leather and textiles (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13:49" href="/Leviticus.13.49"><i>Lev.</i> 13:49</a>), bone and wood (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 31:20" href="/Numbers.31.20"><i>Num.</i> 31:20</a>). Other vessels cannot become impure; to this fact one attributes the great number of stone vessels found on archeological sites of the Second Temple period. (Similarly intrinsically pure vessels made of cow dung have not survived for the archeological record.) The impurity of glass vessels, unknown to Moses, is purely rabbinical. One has to take the information that the impurity of glass ware “was decreed” by the head of the Synhedrion with a grain of salt. Most probably, he simply codified the rules which were popularly observed before, when the Pharisees obtained the leadership in the state. The reasons given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 16" href="/Shabbat.16">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 16a/b</a> for the rules are inconsistent since the rules, derived from popular observance without any scriptural basis, are inconsistent as a mixture of two different sets of rules. Glass vessels are compared to earthenware vessels since the former are made from sand, the latter from clay. They are also compared to metal vessels since if broken they can be melted down and made into new vessels.</i>. But did not Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Abuna say in the name of Rav Jeremiah: Yose ben Yo‘ezer from Ṣereda and Yose ben Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The heads of the pre-Maccabean Ḥassidim sect; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 65:18" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.65.18"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 65(18</a>).</i> from Jerusalem decreed impurity for Gentile lands<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Here also, a long-standing popular observance (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Amos 7:17" href="/Amos.7.17"><i>Amos</i> 7:17</a>) was codified which attributed to the earth of Gentile lands (within or without the Holy Land) the impurity of rotting human bodies.</i> and glass ware; Rebbi Yose said, Rebbi Jehudah bar Ṭabbai<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The co-head with Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ in the leadership of the Pharisees under Shlomzion.</i>? Rebbi Jonah said, Jehudah bar Ṭabbai and Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ decreed on metal vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The possible impurity of metal vessels is biblical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:11:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.11.5">Note 98</a>). Following the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 16b" href="/Shabbat.16b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 16b</a>, what they decreed was that metal impure by the impurity of the dead should not become pure by being melted down, but only by sprinkling with water containing ashes of the red cow. The political background of this decision (which seems to contradict biblical rules, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 31:22-23" href="/Numbers.31.22-23"><i>Num.</i> 31:22–23</a>) and the reliability of the Babli in this respect is difficult to establish.</i>; Hillel and Shammai decreed on the purity of hands<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">They codified the rules that hands which were not all the time consciously guarded from impurity after being washed are impure in the second degree and, therefore, impart impurity to fluids, heave, and sacrifices but not to solid profane food (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 2:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.2.3.1"><i>Demay</i> 2:3, Notes 136–137</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 14b" href="/Shabbat.14b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i>14b</a>).</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Chapter, the text is from <i>Ševi‘it</i> 1:7, following <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.8.1">Note 55</a> (variants noted <b>ש</b>).</i> Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Levi: That was the current practice; they forgot it<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">There was no rule-making authority in the time between the two Yoses and Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ and Jehudah ben Ṭabbai.</i>, but the later ones got up and agreed to the opinion of the earlier ones to teach you that everything the Court insists on will come to be in the end just as Moses was told on Sinai; as Rebbi Mana said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:47" href="/Deuteronomy.32.47"><i>Deut.</i> 32:47</a>): “For it is not an empty word, from you,” if it is empty it is from you because you do not exert yourself about it. “Because it is your life,” when is it your life? At the time that you exert yourself!

Chapter 9



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody writes to his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">After the preliminary but before the definitive marriage, when he does not yet have the administration of her properties.</i>: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties,” he receives their revenues and if she should die, he inherits from her. In this case, why did he write “I shall have nothing to do with your properties”? If she sold or gave away, it is valid. If he wrote to her: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties, nor with their revenues,” he does not receive their revenues during her lifetime but if she should die, he inherits from her. Rebbi Jehudah says, he continues to receive the investment results of her revenues<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife invests some or all of the revenue from her holdings, these new holdings are not referred to in the renunciation. They represent new paraphernalia and as such their administration is the husband’s, who receives their yield.</i> unless he writes: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties, nor with their revenues, nor with revenues derived from revenues, without limits<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., even the yield of the k-th re-investment of prior yields, k = 1,2, …, is excluded by this contract.</i>.” If he wrote “I shall have nothing to do with your properties, nor with their revenues, nor with revenues derived from revenues during your lifetime and after your death,” he does not receive the revenues during her lifetime and does not inherit from her after her death. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, if she dies, he should inherit from her since he made a condition contradicting what is written in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Since in rabbinic interpretation (disputed by Sadducees/Karaites) the husband inherits from his wife but the wife not from her husband; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 111b" href="/Bava_Batra.111b">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 111b</a>, <i>Sifry Num.</i> 134. In the opinion of R. Ismael, this cannot be established from the pentateuchal law of inheritance (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:7-11" href="/Numbers.27.7-11"><i>Num.</i> 27:7–11</a>) but from the books of <i>Josua,</i> 34:33, and 1<i>Chr.</i>2:22. According to R. Aqiba, the husband’s right of inheritance follows by twisting the text of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:11" href="/Numbers.27.11"><i>Num.</i> 27:11</a>.</i>, and anybody’s condition contradicting what is written in the Torah is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">As a general principle, this is Mishnaiot <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> 7:14, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.4.2-4"><i>Baba batra</i>8:5</a>. Quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 6:8:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.6.8.4"><i>Peah</i> 6:10 (Note 159</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.1.2-7"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:1</a> (50a 1.48), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2</a> (59c 1.40), <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> 7:10 (11c 1.11); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56" href="/Ketubot.56">Babli 56a/b</a>, 83b, 84a, and 7 other quotes.<br>As far as money matters go, his opinion is that of a minority of one; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.8.2">Chapter 5, Note 207</a>. He will agree that in matters of revenues, whose assignment to the husband is purely rabbinic usage, there are no restrictions in the freedom to contract.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody writes to his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">After the preliminary but before the definitive marriage, when he does not yet have the administration of her properties.</i>: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai: If he did not take her in<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The language quoted in the Mishnah is appropriate if the husband renounces his right to acquire the administration of his wife’s property. This must be done before the definitive marriage. The Babli agrees, also in the name of R. Yannai (83a).</i>. But if he took her in, nobody can lose his rights by these expressions<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since he did acquire the right of administration by the definitive marriage, a contract executed after this moment would have to contain language of transfer of rights (by gift or sale) to be legally actionable.<br>In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 8:1:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.8.1.2-5"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 8:1</a> (49b 1. 30 ff.) it is stated that the husband can deliver a bill of divorce to his wife by depositing it on her paraphernalia property only if previously he had validly renounced his rights to the income produced by that property because the right to income is an ownership right.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, this is the word of Rebbi Ḥiyya: He who says that “my hands are removed from this field, my feet are removed from this field<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">If he tells his wife that he does not want to take care of her properties, this has no legal consequences since he is obligated to work for her. The only way he can remove his obligation is by a formal transfer of his right to her as a gift.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 83a" href="/Ketubot.83a">Babli (83a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 95a" href="/Ketubot.95a">95a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 77a" href="/Gittin.77a"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 77a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 43a" href="/Bava_Batra.43a"><i>Baba batra</i> 43a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 49a" href="/Bava_Batra.49a">49a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 24b" href="/Keritot.24b"><i>Keritut</i> 24b</a>) notes that even between strangers such a formula would not transfer property rights.</i>,” did not say anything. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: Does a Mishnah imply that nobody can lose his rights by these expressions? Did we not state there<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.6.1">Mishnah 10:6</a>.</i>: “If somebody was married to two wives when he sold a field<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The field is mortgaged to both <i>ketubot</i>; if he dies and there is not enough money in his estate to satisfy the claims of both wives, the wives can reclaim the field from the buyer since their lien precedes his title.</i> and the first one wrote for the buyer: I have no claims on you<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">She agrees with the sale and promises not to sue the buyer.</i>, the second<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">She was no party to the transaction. If her claim to <i>ketubah</i> is not satisfied, she can repossess the field.</i> one can take it away from the buyer’s hands,” this implies, not the first one. He said to him, that text itself implies that nobody can lose his rights by these expressions, but here the second wife cannot take anything away from the first<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The second wife by her action does not diminish the claim of the first to the property.</i>, and why can the first one not take it away from the buyer’s hands? For she writes to him: For any complaint I shall have regarding this field, I shall have nothing against you<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">All the first wife agreed to was not to sue the buyer. This prevents her from going to court but has no influence on her rights vis-à-vis others. It is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.1.1">Mishnah 10:1</a> that the <i>ketubah</i> of a first wife has precedence over that of a second wife. Therefore, if the second wife recovers the field from the buyer, the first one may sue the second for the unsatisfied part of her own <i>ketubah.</i> Therefore, the first wife did not transfer any property rights by her statement to the buyer.</i>.
If he wrote for her and she wrote for him<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">She wrote him the same text he wrote her, that “she has nothing to do with his properties.”</i>. Just as he did not lose his rights so she did not lose her rights<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">If she becomes a widow or divorcee, she is not prevented from claiming his real estate as payment for her <i>ketubah.</i></i>. If he wrote to her “from preliminary and definitive marriage”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">“I shall have nothing to do with your properties, from preliminary and definitive marriage.” The question is, why did he mention preliminary marriage which gives him no rights of administration?</i>, that is the disagreement between the Houses of Shammai and Hillel<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.1.1">Mishnah 8:1</a>.</i>. In the opinion of the House of Shammai she shall sell<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Since the House of Shammai give the wife the right to sell any inheritance she received while preliminarity married, the mention of the preliminary with the definitive marriage can only mean that the husband invites his wife to dispose of her property after definitive marriage as if it were only after preliminary marriage.</i>; in the opinion of the House of Hillel she should not sell<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.1.1">Mishnaiot 8:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.9.1">9</a>:1 give only legal standing to the wife’s sales after the fact; they do not invite the wife to sell without her husband’s consent. For the House of Hillel, the husband mentions his disinterest in her properties after the preliminary marriage in order to give her the right to dispose of her properties without asking him, against the opinion of the House of Hillel. But this does not imply that after the definitive marriage he does not want to be asked, following <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.1.1">Mishnah 9:1</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">There are many different interpretations of this paragraph, detailed by R. Jehudah Rosanes in his Commentary מִשְׁנֶה לַמֶּלֶךְ to Maimonides, <i>Hilkhot Iššut</i> 23:1. The following explanation is simply one which seems reasonable to the author.</i> Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: If he wrote to her: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties,” and she inherited properties afterwards, what is the rule<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This question is very elliptic. It is not obvious whether the document was written before or after the definitive marriage and whether the inheritance was foreseeable or not. If the document was written before the definitive marriage and the wife was in line for the inheritance, there is no reason why the husband’s renunciation of his rights would not be valid since that essentially is the case of the Mishnah. In addition, it is the right of any person not to accept an inheritance. Therefore, in view of the answer given, it seems that one speaks of an inheritance which was unexpected, that at the moment of preliminary marriage the wife was not a probable recipient of the inheritance but that later some prospective heirs died which made the wife the next surviving kin. Since such an occurrence is not foreseeable, no contracts can be concluded about them. If the document was executed after the definitive marriage, it would require an additional statement in which the husband cedes his rights to future yield to his wife.</i>? Can a person put a condition on something not in existence<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">For example, in talmudic law a farmer cannot write a futures contract on his grain harvest before his seed has sprouted. Similarly, no contract can be written covering unexpected inheritances.</i>? Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said before Rebbi Ze‘ira: From his rights you can infer his obligations. If he had not written to her, would it make any difference, would he not receive its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>ketubah</i> contract gives the husband the right to the yield of any future properties coming to his wife during their marriage, whether foreseen or not, it follows that he can deprive himself of his right to yield, whether foreseen or not.</i>? That means, from his rights you can infer his obligations. Rebbi Levi bar Ḥaita asked: If he wrote to her: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties which you shall inherit in the future,” what is the rule? Can a person put a condition on something not in existence<sup class="footnote-marker">25,</sup><i class="footnote">If the succinct language proposed by R. Jeremiah is invalid, the more explicit language of R. Levi is also invalid. The objection of R. Abun bar Hiyya is irrelevant as far as a separate contract is concerned. But certainly it would be possible for the husband to renounce his right to yield in the ketubah document itself, since what he acquires by the ketubah he can renounce in the ketubah. In that case, his wife's hand in acquiring estates never was his hand and she does not need his renunciation.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In Nazir 2:5 (52b l. 41), the question is asked about a vow to pay for somebody's nazir sacrifices if a person will make a nazir vow in the future, an act over which the maker of the original vow has no control. The original vow is declared void since the text proposed by R. Levi ben Haita is also void.</i>?
If she sold produce connected to the ground<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement in the Mishnah that the wife’s sale is valid if the husband had written that he had nothing to do with her properties. Since he retains the right to the revenue, she certainly cannot sell harvested produce which is her husband’s property. May she sell produce still standing?</i>: Rav Aḥa said, as if she sold harvested [produce]<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The sale is invalid.</i>; Rebbi Yose said, as if she sold a tenth of the ground<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The sale is valid.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: If somebody writes a field over to his wife, she cannot sell the produce<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Since the field becomes paraphernalia property, he retains the right to its yield.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, a <i>baraita</i> says so<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 9:2" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).9.2">Tosephta 9:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 83b" href="/Ketubot.83b">Babli 83b</a>.</i> “What are revenues derived from revenues? He sells the produce, buys real estate, and eats its revenue<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Since the field bought with the sale price of the produce becomes the wife’s property, the revenue from revenue is revenue from the wife’s paraphernalia given to her by her husband and belongs to the husband. This is the case mentioned by Rav.</i>.” Rebbi Immi asked: If another person had written [real estate] over to her, would he<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The husband.</i> not receive the revenue? If he himself wrote, not so much more<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Why do we need Rav’s statement in this case?</i>!<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The preceding text is quoted in a slightly different form by Rosh (9:1):<br> רִבִּי זְעִירָא רַב יְהוּדָה בְשֵׁם רַב. הַכּוֹתֵב שָׂדֶה מַתָּנָה לְאִשְׁתּוֹ אֵין לוֹ אֲכִילַת פֵּירוֹת. אָמַר רִבִּי מַתָּנָה. מַתְנִיתָא לֹא אָֽמְרָה כֵן. אֵלּוּ הֵן פֵּירֵי פֵירוֹת. מוֹכֵר פֵּירוֹת וִילָּקַח בָּהֶן קַרְקַע וְהוּא אוֹכֵל פֵּירוֹת. לָאו כְּכוֹתֵב שָׂדֶה מַתָּנָה לְאִשְׁתּוֹ הוּא וְאַתְּ אָמַרְתָּ אֵין לוֹ לֹא פֵירוֹת וְלֹא פֵירֵי פֵירוֹת. רִבִּי אִמִּי בְעָא. אִילּוּ אַחֵר כָּתַב לָהּ יֵשׁ לוֹ אֲכִילַת פֵּירוֹת. הוּא כָתַב לָהּ לֹא כָל־שֶׁכֵּן. <br> Rebbi Ze'ira, Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: If somebody writes a field over to his wife, <i>he has no claim to its yield.</i> Rebbi <i>Mattanah</i> said, a baraita <i>does not say so</i>: "What are revenues derived from revenues? He sells the produce, real estate <i>should be bought from the proceeds,</i> and he eats its revenue." <i>Is that not as if he wrote a field over to his wife, and you say, he has neither revenue nor revenue from revenue!</i> Rebbi Immi asked: If another person had written [real estate] over to her, would he not receive the revenue? If he himself wrote, not so much more? <br> The <i>baraita</i> refers to the Mishnah, regarding property which the wife inherits during her marriage. Then the question is raised why does the husband eat the yield of property coming from others but not from his own gift. But in this version, the questions of R. Mattanah and R. Immi duplicate one another. The text of Rosh seems to be a contamination of the current and the following paragraphs.<br>The passive voice, real estate <i>should be bought,</i> is that of our Tosephta text, in contrast to the quotes from both Talmudim in which <i>he</i> buys the real estate. In that version, the investment decision is not the husband’s.</i> He said only “wrote over”, but not “sold”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband sold a field to his wife, he cannot claim the yield. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 51b" href="/Bava_Batra.51b">Babli, <i>Baba batra,</i> 51b</a>, also decides that the husband eats the yield of the field sold but not the one given as a gift.</i>. What is the difference between one who writes and one who sells? He tried to find a reason to hide food from the wife<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">He gives the field to his wife that she should sustain herself from its yield and he would no longer have to care for her; for this purpose it is obvious that he does not want to take the yield.</i>.
It is reasonable according to Rebbi Jehudah, if he wrote: “I shall have nothing to do with your properties and the revenues,” that he cannot take the revenues. Even if he wrote: “I shall have nothing to do with this field and its yield,” he cannot eat its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The statements are trivial since in the Mishnah both the rabbis and R. Jehudah agree that the husband has no right to the yields; their disgreement is whether the yield of any money saved from the revenues reverts to the husband or not.</i>. It is reasonable according to the rabbis; if he wrote: “I shall have nothing to do with this field and its yield,” can he eat its yield? Even if he wrote, “I shall have nothing to do with your properties and its yields,” can he eat its yield?<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The answer should be a trivial “no” since the rabbis assign to the wife even the compound yield which R. Jehudah gives to the husband.</i> Let us hear from the following, as Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Jehudah said in the name of Rav: If somebody writes a field over to his wife, he has no right to its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that he has no right to the yield which he disclaimed. It is claimed here also that he has no investment power over the part of the yield which his wife does not spend on herself; this explains why he has no right to revenues derived from revenues saved.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, a <i>baraita</i> says so<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 9:2" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).9.2">Tosephta 9:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 83b" href="/Ketubot.83b">Babli 83b</a>.</i> “What are revenues derived from revenues? He sells the produce<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Since he sells but not she, the Tanna of the <i>baraita</i> holds that the husband has investment power over the yield revenue which he cannot take for himself. (Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.1.5">Note 35</a>, last paragraph.)</i>, buys real estate, and eats its revenue.” Since he wrote, “I shall have nothing to do with your properties and their yields,” is that not as if he wrote a field over to his wife, and you say, he has neither revenue nor revenue from revenue! That means, there is no difference in the opinion of Rebbi Jehudah whether he wrote “I shall have nothing to do with this field and its yield,” or he wrote “I shall have nothing to do with your properties and their revenues,” he cannot take any revenue<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">According to R. Jehudah, the wife alone has investment powers for the savings part of the yield, but the husband has the right to the investment yield if not disavowed explicitly.</i>. Similarly, for the rabbis it makes no difference whether he wrote “I shall have nothing to do with your properties and their revenues,” or he wrote “I shall have nothing to do with this field and its yield,” he can take its yield<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">While he has no right to the yield from investments, he has the investment power unless explicitly disclaimed.</i>.
Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">This is the correct text from the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba batra</i> 8:6</a> (from a different editorial team). <i>Rav</i> Jeremiah was a contemporary of Rav, <i>Rebbi</i> Jeremiah lived about 100 years later.</i> Jeremiah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">This also is Rav’s position in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 83b" href="/Ketubot.83b">Babli, 83b</a>, but with a reasoning diametrically opposed to that of the Yerushalmi.</i>, but not in the matter of words<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh has a slightly different text: <br> רִבִּי יִרְמְיָה בְשֵׁם רַב. הֲלָכָה כְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל. שֶׁאִם מֵתָה יְרוֹשְׁתָהּ אֲבָל לֹא לְעִנְייָן דְּבָרָיו שֶׁאָמַר מִפֻּנֵי שֶׁהִתְנָה עַל מַה שֶׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה. וְכָל־הַמַּתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה תְּנָאוֹ בָטֵל. בִּתְנָאֵי גּוּף. וְהָכָא בִּתְנָאֵי מָמוֹן אָנוּ קַייָמִין. וְלָמָּה אָֽמְרוּ תְּנָאוֹ בָטֵל. שֶׁבְּסוֹף הוּא זָכָה בָהֶן. <br> Rav Jeremiah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel, <i>that</i> if she dies he inherits from her, but<i> not because of his</i> words, "since he made a condition contradicting what is written in the Torah, and anybody's condition contradicting what is written in the Torah is invalid," in personal matters. But here we deal with money matters! <i>Why did they say that the condition is invalid?</i> Because in the end he acquired it.</i>. Practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel for he said, if she dies he inherits from her, but in matters of words, “since he made a condition contradicting what is written in the Torah, and anybody’s condition contradicting what is written in the Torah is invalid,” in personal matters. But in money matters, one’s stipulations are valid<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">A generally agreed principle in the Yerushalmi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2</a> (59c 1.43), <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 7:10 (11c 1.11); in the Babli accepted with reservations in the name of R. Jehudah, 57a.</i> and that is a money matter! Why did we say that the condition is invalid? Because in the end he acquired it<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba batra</i> 8:6</a>, the reason is given the practice follows R. Joḥanan ben Baroqa who holds that wills can be written only in favor of people who could be heirs (if a number of closer relatives had died.) Then the law of inheritance is compulsory and falls under the category of personal matters.</i>. Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The law should have been that if she<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The definitively married wife should retain the right of disposal of her paraphernalia property since she retains sole ownership.</i> sold or gave it away it should be valid, for [the buyer] acquired it. Why did they say it is invalid? That a wife should not sell her husband’s property and say, it is mine<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">She could claim that mortmain property was really hers to dispose of.</i>.
Rebbi Justinus had a case<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">From the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba batra</i>8:6</a>. The reading here is יוסטתא which is inconsistent with the second mention of the name. {Both <i>Juste</i> and <i>Justine</i> probably are provincial forms of <i>Justus, Justinus</i> (E.G.).}</i> and he asked the rabbis who told him, leave you properties<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">He had no right to inherit from his wife.</i>. He asked Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, who told him, enter your properties<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">He confirmed him as his wife’s heir, acting as an appeals judge.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: Who are those rabbis? What about Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Declaring that practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel.</i>, Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Holding in <i>Baba batra</i> (Note 48) that the basic provisions of the biblical law of inheritance are a matter of persons, not money.</i>, and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish? He said to him, Rebbi Justinus’s rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The local court whose rulings were overturned.</i>.
They asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: Following the Sages, if she died who inherits from her<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah only states that if the husband had renounced his rights, he could not inherit from his wife living and dead. It does not state who inherits.</i>? Those, her brothers, inherit from her<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Here family certainly inherit from her but there seems to be no reason why they should not inherit as if she had been unmarried. The version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6"><i>Baba batra</i> 8:6</a> is more intelligible: Rebbi Joḥanan said, her father inherits from her [and after his death] her brothers inherit from her.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: If the brothers divided [the inheritance], the widow is supported by them<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.1">Mishnah 4:12</a>, the widow has the option not to take the <i>ketubah</i> money but to live in her deceased husband’s house and be supported by his estate. While the <i>ketubah</i> proper is a lien on the real estate, the widow’s (and her daughters’) support is not. This means that the brothers may divide the inheritance while their father’s widow is still living.</i>. For you should not say, they should be considered as if they had sold the properties and the widow would not be supported by these, since it is obvious that if they sold, they sold their own property<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">And the widow has no regress on the buyer if the husband’s heirs do not fulfill their duty towards her. The Babli (e. g., <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 107a" href="/Bava_Batra.107a"><i>Baba batra</i> 107a</a>) strongly disagrees and holds that brothers who divided an inheritance are like buyers from one another but that they are liable in common for the debts of the estate.</i>.
Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Abbahu: It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 36:4" href="/Numbers.36.4"><i>Num.</i> 36:4</a>. The argument of the tribe of Manasseh is that if Salpaad’s five daughters (representing most of the Cisjordanian tribe) would marry outside the tribe, their territory would be inherited by their husband’s tribes and be lost to Manasseh.</i>: “If the Jubilee will happen for the Children of Israel.” If the institution of the Jubilee exists<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., as long as the 12 tribes were living on their ancestral lands.</i>, inheritances return; if the institution of the Jubilee does not exist, inheritances do not return<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">From the moment that the tribes of Gad and Reuben were deported by the Assyrians, in all other parts of Canaan the land no longer had to be returned to its original owners by the buyers in the Jubilee year. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 1:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.1.5.2"><i>Ševi‘it</i>1:1, Note 7</a>.</i>. It is the opposite way, it comes to tell you that even if the institution of the Jubilee exists and inheritances return, inheritance by biblical law does not return<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">While the verse does not directly prove that the wife’s property is inherited by her husband, it certainly implies that it is given to her sons as ancestral lands.</i>!
<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The first sentences are quoted by Naḥmanides in מלחמות ה׳ (in the Wilna edition of Alfassi, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 22a" href="/Yevamot.22a"><i>Yebamot</i> 22a</a>).</i> Rebbi Hillel bar Pazi asked before Rebbi Yose: If he sold and then she died<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The husband sold of his wife’s paraphernalia property during her lifetime. Since he was not the owner, he could not sell; the sale is void even when he becomes the heir.</i>? He said to him, his sale<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Naḥmanides writes מכרו; that may have been a correct ms. or it may be his (obvious) correction of the text. In these details, a medieval quote is not a witness to the text.</i> is invalid; it is as if a son sold during his father’s lifetime and then the father died<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">While a son can legally sell his right of inheritance to a speculator (who would take the risk that the son might die before the father and his investment become worthless), the son cannot sell his father’s property before his father’s death; such a sale is void even after the son becomes the heir.</i>. If she sold and then he died<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">She sold of her paraphernalia properties, of which she is the owner, and her husband died during her lifetime. She sold irregularly since her husband had the administration of her properties during his lifetime but after her husband’s death the sale is valid.</i>? He said to him, her sale is valid; it is as if a father sold during his son’s lifetime and then the son died<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The father is not required to inconvenience himself to leave his properties for his heirs.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Marius asked before Rebbi Jonah: What is the situation if she sold to her husband? He said, since Ḥizqiah said, practice follows Rebbi Judah<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is not to R. Jehudah (bar Illaï) mentioned in the Mishnah but to Rebbi, R. Jehudah ben Rabban Simeon, quoted in the <i>baraita</i> later in this paragraph.</i>, this implies that her sale is a sale<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">As explained at length later, the temporary owner is a total owner and may sell at will. The question why she would want to sell is addressed below.</i>. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Batra (Lieberman) 8:4" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Batra_(Lieberman).8.4">Tosephta <i>Baba batra</i> 8:4</a> (fragmentary), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:8:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.8.2-6">Yerushalmi <i>Baba batra</i> 8:9</a> (16c 1.19); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 136b-137a" href="/Bava_Batra.136b-137a">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 136b/137a</a> (cf. R. Rabbinowicz, דקדוקי סופרים בבא בתרא. p. 374, Note ח).</i>: “If somebody says, my property should be given to X, if X died to Y, [if Y died to Z]<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">This clause appears in all texts mentioned in the preceding Note; it is necessary to introduce the third beneficiary of the will.</i>. If the first one died the properties should be given to the second, if the second died they should be given to the third. If the second one died during the first’s lifetime; since the second never acquired them, the third cannot acquire them<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">In the language of the Babli: If the second died while the first is alive, the properties should return to the first’s legal heirs (in Yerushalmi <i>Baba batra</i>: to the testator’s legal heirs).</i>.” He said to him, so did Rebbi Hoshaia<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 136b" href="/Bava_Batra.136b">Babli (<i>Baba batra</i> 136b</a>), he is called “Rav Hoshaia in Babylonia”.</i>, the father of the Mishnah, explain: After him to X, after him to Y; it is as if stated: if the third died during the second’s lifetime, since the second one did not acquire his heirs cannot acquire, one really could say: After him to X, after him to Y<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">As the Babli explains in the name of Rav Hoshaia, for him there is a difference between “it should be given to X, then to Y, then to Z” and “you should inherit, after you Y, after him Z.” In the first case, the properties are given in usufruct but have to be preserved. In the second case, the properties are given in possession; the owner receives title. The only claim the successor has is to the real estate which still is in the preceding heir’s hand at his death; Y cannot complain if X sells the properties. This is made clear in the following <i>baraita</i>.</i>. It was stated: “Rebbi says, the first one may sell the real estate and buy movables. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, he has only the usufruct.<sup class="footnote-marker">75,</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Batra (Lieberman) 8:4" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Batra_(Lieberman).8.4">Tosephta <i>Baba batra</i> 8:4</a> (fragmentary), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:8:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.8.2-6">Yerushalmi <i>Baba batra</i> 8:9</a> (16c 1.19); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 136b-137a" href="/Bava_Batra.136b-137a">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 136b/137a</a> (cf. R. Rabbinowicz, דקדוקי סופרים בבא בתרא. p. 374, Note ח).</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the position of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel is modified to mean that a sale is a breach of trust but not that it is void. Since a baraita which forces the Babli to its conclusion is not mentioned in the Yerushalmi, one has to assume that in its opinion for Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel there is no difference in the language of the will; in any case in which a succession of heirs is noted only usufruct is transferred and any sale of real estate is void.</i>” Ḥizqiah said, practice follows Rebbi. Rebbi Mana said, since Ḥizqiah said, practice follows Rebbi, that implies that he cannot dispose of it by a death-bed will<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Baba batra</i>, the text reads: “R. Yannai said, Rebbi agrees that he cannot dispose of it by a death-bed will. R. Joḥanan said, not even as a gift between the living.” The statement of R. Mana (I)/R. Yannai simply means that X, the first heir, cannot give the properties away in a will since the will becomes active only after X’s death and at that moment the real estate is already Y’s property (as explained in the Babli, <i>loc. cit</i>.). R. Joḥanan’s statement is explained by R. Eliahu Fulda, that X may <i>sell</i> for his own needs because he is the owner, but he cannot <i>give away</i> since the original will prescribes that after X it <i>must</i> be <i>given</i> to Y.</i>. So said Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">R. Mana II.</i> before Rebbi Yose: Since this woman’s upkeep is her husband’s responsibility, is it not like a gift of sick persons<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Why should the wife have the power to sell the real estate whose proceeds go to her husband? Is it not that she received the properties on condition that after her, they should be given to her husband or children?</i>? He said to him, her upkeep is what is necessary for her: food, oil, and salt. But she wants to sell and buy chickens<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">She may sell for expenses which the husband is not required to cover.</i>. This means that if the first one wanted to sell and buy chickens, he may sell<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">X may sell real estate only for his personal needs but the definition of personal need has to be very generous.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, her burial is equal to her upkeep. Since you said there<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta from <i>Baba batra</i>. The wife may also sell some of her property and buy herself a burial plot (which, if used, becomes forbidden for all usufruct.)</i>, he may sell real estate and buy food, so he may sell real estate and buy a burial.
Rebbi Yose said: Those who write “if she should die childless, her property should return to her father’s family” write a monetary condition which is a valid condition<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife should die childless, both her mortmain and her paraphernalia properties return to her father’s family. This text (and its ramifications in medieval rabbinic literature) has been studied by M. A. Friedman, <i>Jewish Marriage in Palestine</i> (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.8.5">Chapter 5, Note 226</a>), vol. 1, Chapter VE, pp. 391–418.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody died and left his wife, a creditor<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Who is secured by a mortgage lien on the deceased person’s real estate.</i>, and heirs, and he was owed a deposit or a debt by a third party<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Since a deposit is unsecured movable property, also the debt due to the deceased is presumed to be unsecured movable property.</i>, Rebbi Ṭarphon says, these should be given to the weakest among them. Rebbi Aqiba says, one does not show mercy in law! But these should be given to the heirs for all others have to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The widow who wants to receive her <i>ketubah</i> in cash (instead of being supported by the heirs for the rest of her life) has to swear that she did not receive anything during her husband’s lifetime. The creditor has to swear that his claim was not satisfied.</i>, only the heirs do not have to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Since as movable property the deposit or debt was not mortgaged, it becomes the heirs’ free property at the moment of death of the bequeather.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody died and left a wife,” etc. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, the weakest in his claim<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli according to Rashi, the creditor of a lower ranked mortgage; according to Alfasi any creditor because he can collect only if he proves his claim. The claim of a person giving money before witnesses is very weak since he loses his money if both the borrower and his witnesses die.</i>. For example, one lent before witnesses, the other lent on a mortgage document; it should be given to the one who lent before witnesses. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the weakest in his body<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The same statements are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 84a" href="/Ketubot.84a">Babli, 84a</a>. There, R. Joḥanan says explicitly that it should be given to the widow; his argument is buttressed by a <i>baraita</i>.</i>. Think about it, if he is rich<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">If the creditor is rich, even if he lent without a mortgage he does not need special protection.</i>, like those of the family Andreas. Rebbi Aḥa said, the weakest in his body and poor<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The woman has precedence only if she is poor.</i>. As the following: They gave to a relative of Rebbi Samuel bar Abba as the weakest<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">It is to be assumed that by the middle of the Third Century the common practice was to prefer R. Aqiba’s opinion over that of any of his colleagues. Nevertheless, there was a court which followed R. Ṭarphon in the interpretation of R. Joḥanan. [In the opinion of <i>Rosh</i> (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:3:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.3.4">Note 102</a>), the Gaonic decree that all <i>ketubot</i> have to be satisfied by movables changed practice in the Mishnah from R. Aqiba to R. Ṭarphon.]</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish brought slaves of Rebbi Jehuda the Prince<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">As head of the Patriarch’s court, he ordered the <i>familiares</i> of the Patriarch to seize what he considered assigned by an erring court.</i> and took it away from her. Rebbi Joḥanan was leaning on Rebbi Simeon bar Abba and said, what was done with that poor woman? He said to him, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish brought slaves of Rebbi Jehuda the Prince and took it away from her. Was he justified in doing this<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan holds that the Patriarch’s appeals court erred in reversing the lower court’s decision. It is also mentioned in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 84b" href="/Ketubot.84b">Babli, 84b</a>, that R. Simeon ben Laqish considers following R. Ṭarphon a reversible error.</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: Should we say that Rebbi Joḥanan follows his doctrine and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish his own? Since they disagree: Everybody agrees that if they<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">A lower court whose judgment was appealed to the Patriarch’s court. If it is a matter of weighing the evidence, the ruling of the lower court has to stand.</i> err in arguments, one does not reverse. In the words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">An error that even school-children can detect.</i>, one reverses. Where do they disagree? If one errs in a Mishnah, for Rebbi Joḥanan says, an error in Mishnah is like an error in arguments, but Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish says, an error in Mishnah is like an error in words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan’s position in this matter is not mentioned in the Babli; the opposing view is quoted as universally accepted in the name of Rav Sheshet and Rav Assi, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 6b</a>.</i>. What is said of the Mishnah is also said of words of the Elders<sup class="footnote-marker">101a</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i>, Rav Pappa accepts as non-reversible error only a judicial argument rejected by the appeals court but which does not contradict existing precedents.</i>.
Think of it, if they were exempt from swearing<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sefer</i> <i>Ha-iṭṭur</i> I, 23b (Note 16), followed by <i>Rosh</i> 9:2, the reading is הַגַּע עַצְמָךְ <b>שֶׁפְטָרוּם</b> מִן הַשְּׁבוּעָה “Think of it, if <i>he exempted them</i> from swearing”, i. e., the debtor agreed to a clause in the mortgage contract which exempted the creditor from swearing to his heirs. In the version of the ms., there are additional cases when the creditor is by law exempted from swearing; for example, if the due date is later than the debtor’s death (then the debt certainly was not paid) or if the debtor before his death acknowledged the debt.</i>? One is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Possession by the heirs is automatic by biblical law; all others have to prove their claims in court.</i>, the other is not biblical.

Halakhah 3
