<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he left produce taken from the ground<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Or any other movables not in the actual possession of the deceased.</i>, the one who takes them first<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">On condition that he have a legal claim on the estate, as widow or creditors do.</i> acquires them. If the widow acquired more than her <i>ketubah</i> sum, or the creditor more than his claim, the remainder, Rebbi Ṭarphon says, should be given to the weakest among them<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The excess over the claim has to be assigned by the court. A detailed study of the divergent interpretations of this Mishnah in Yerushalmi and Babli was made by I. Francus, שיטת הבבלי והירושלמי בתפיסת מטלטלין לגביית, <i>Sinai</i> 86 (1979/1980), 136–148.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba says, one does not show mercy in law! But it should be given to the heirs since all others have to swear, only the heirs do not have to swear.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he left produce taken<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">In this and the preceding Mishnah, the Mishnah text differs in a few details from the common reading of most Mishnaiot but the text quoted in the Halakhah is the standard Mishnah text.</i>,” etc. Both Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish say, if they were collected at a trading place<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">“A place of Saracens.” The problem discussed here is quite different from that discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 84b" href="/Ketubot.84b">Babli, 84b</a>, by the same authors. In the Yerushalmi, it is supposed that the acquirer removes the produce from the public place since it is obvious that it would not be his when left in the public place. But if the produce was already in a place belonging to the claimant, according to Rav and R. Simeon ben Laqish “a person’s courtyard acquires for him automatically” (Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 10b). For R. Joḥanan, “a person’s courtyard acquires for him only by a conscious act.” Therefore, in a situation where an unlearned person could think that anything in a private domain to which the owner has a claim is automatically his, we may assume that the conscious act of acquisition is missing. This argument assumes that the first part of the Mishnah is everybody’s opinion and the difference between R. Ṭarphon and R. Aqiba refers only to the excess.<br>In the Babli, the entire first part of the Mishnah is considered R. Ṭarphon’s and everybody agrees that “a person’s courtyard acquires for him automatically”; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.3.1">Note 106</a>.</i>. But if somebody collected it in his house, his house acquired for him. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even if he collected it in his house, his house did not acquire for him. For he thinks that they are his but they are not his. Does from this follow how the owner acquires his produce<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The ripe produce is ownerless by biblical decree. Naturally, the owner of the property has the same right to take it as does everybody else. Anybody but the owner acquires simply by taking. How does the owner acquire, that taking from him would be theft?</i> in a Sabbatical year? Rebbi Jeremiah wanted to say, from the moment he put them into his vessel. Rebbi Yose said, even if he put them into his vessel he did not acquire, for he thinks that they are his but they are not his<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">He can acquire only by a) putting the produce into his vessel and b) declaring that it is his.</i>.
That widow took a slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">She took her as a servant from her husband’s estate as part payment of her <i>ketubah</i>. The case is also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:3:2-14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.3.2-14"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:3</a> in the discussion whether slaves are acquired under the rules of movables or of real estate.</i>. The case came before Rebbi Isaac who said, what she took, she took. Rebbi Immi took her away, for she thought that she was hers but she was not hers<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">If the widow could not point to an act of acquisition, the fact that the girl served her when she was a wife and continued to serve her when she was a widow does not make her the widow’s peoperty.</i>. A similar case: The father of the sons of Shammai died and bequeathed a goat to them. The creditor came and took it. The case came before Rebbi Abbahu who said, he took his own property. Did we not state that if either an heir or a creditor came and took, one does [not]<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This word was written by the scribe; it was deleted by the first corrector and, therefore, is missing in <i>editio princeps</i>. But the partial quote in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:10:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.10.2-3">Halakhah 8:10</a> proves that the original text was correct.</i> remove from his hand; for they thought they were theirs but they were not theirs. Rebbi Jacob bar Zabdi said, Rebbi Abbahu agrees that if they<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The creditor can take an unsecured part of the debtor’s estate only if the heirs did not act as owners. The moment they acted as owners, and the father had not told them to liquidate his debts, the debtor can make himself paid only through regular foreclosure procedures in court.</i> sold it, or gave it as a pledge, or moved it to another place, if then the creditor came and took it one removes it from his possession.
Think of it, if they were exempt from swearing<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sefer</i> <i>Ha-iṭṭur</i> I, 23b (Note 16), followed by <i>Rosh</i> 9:2, the reading is הַגַּע עַצְמָךְ <b>שֶׁפְטָדוּם</b> מִן הַשְּׁבוּעָה “Think of it, if <i>he exempted them</i> from swearing”, i. e., the debtor agreed to a clause in the mortgage contract which exempted the creditor from swearing to his heirs. In the version of the ms., there are additional cases when the creditor is by law exempted from swearing; for example, if the due date is later than the debtor’s death (then the debt certainly was not paid) or if the debtor before his death acknowledged the debt.</i>? One is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Possession by the heirs is automatic by biblical law; all others have to prove their claims in court.</i>, the other is not biblical.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody engages his wife as grocer or appoints her as steward<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">To administer his properties. The word is the feminine form to masc. Greek ἐπίτροπος; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Bikkurim</i> 1:5</a>.</i>, he can make her swear any time he wants<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">That her accounts are honest.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer says, even about her distaff and her dough<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eliezer disagrees with the anonymous Tanna and holds that the husband can make his wife swear that she did not take anything for herself from any domestic work she performed for him. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 86b" href="/Ketubot.86b">Babli, 86b</a>, is unsure whether R. Eliezer disagrees with the anonymous Tanna or holds that if the wife handles large sums of money, the husband can also make her swear on minutiae. In the latter version, the rabbis hold that a wife would rather want a divorce than be married to such a nitpicker.)</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody engages his wife as grocer,” etc. Is Rebbi Eliezer not correct? What is the rabbis’ reason<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Why do the rabbis permit the husband to make his wife swear only if she is entrusted with large sums of money? What is the difference between a business account and household money? In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 86b" href="/Ketubot.86b">Babli, 86b</a>, the rabbis hold that a man who cannot trust his wife with household money should divorce her since “nobody lives with a snake in the same basket.”</i>? If you say so, there never would be peace in his house. If she broke vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">In the course of regular household duties.</i>, is she responsible as an unpaid or a paid trustee<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The legal categories are defined in terms of shepherds, to agree with the biblical verses. Mishnah <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 7:8, <i>Šebuot</i> 8:1: “There are four kinds of responsible people: Unpaid and paid watchmen, the borrower and the lessee. The unpaid watchman swears about everything (which is missing or broken, that it is not by his fault); the borrower pays for everything; the paid trustee and the lessee swear about broken, robbed, or dead (animals) and pay for what was lost or stolen (for if an animal is lost or stolen it is their fault since it was not guarded correctly.)”<br>If the wife were an unpaid trustee, she would have to pay for the damage unless she can swear that it was not her fault. The same holds for the paid trustee except that she would have to pay for inattention.</i>? It would be reasonable to consider her a paid trustee. They said, she is not even an unpaid trustee, for if you say so, there never would be peace in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The wife never pays for broken dishes.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he wrote to her<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">This continues <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>. If the wife refuses to conduct a business or a stewardship for him if he does not believe her accounts and will require her to swear, all depends on the language of the contract between husband and wife. This Mishnah is really one together with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.6.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i>: “I have no vow or oath against you,” he cannot make her swear, but he can ask an oath from the heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">If she died, he can make her sons swear who will inherit her <i>ketubah</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>) or eventually her family if she was childless (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:1:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.1.13">Note 87</a>). This “oath of heirs” is “that our mother did not tell us that the <i>ketubah</i> was paid, or that money of hers was due to others, etc.”</i> or her business associates<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">They can swear that none of the husband’s money is in their hands.</i>. “I have no oath against you, or your heirs, or your business associates,” he cannot ask an oath from her, or her heirs, or her business associates, but the heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The husband’s heirs, after the husband’s death.</i> can ask an oath from her, or her heirs, or her business associates.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he wrote to her: “I have no vow or oath against you,” etc. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose both say, not only about properties over which she exercised control during her husband’s lifetime but even about properties over which she exercised control after her husband’s death are the heirs prevented from making her swear<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is in the wrong place; it refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.6.1">Mishnah 6</a> where the husband exempts the wife and her heirs from any oath imposed by him and his heirs. In that case the wife is exempted as long as she acts within the powers entrusted to her by her husband.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">This entire paragraph is from <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:4, fol. 60b. Since at the end it treats a question from there which was not introduced here, it is clear that the text here is secondary.</i> There<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 3:3.</i>, we have stated: “If somebody leases a cow from another person and lends it to a third party; if it died naturally, the lessee has to swear that it died naturally<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Since the lessee does not have to pay for acts of God; Note 120.</i> and the borrower has to pay to the lessee.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The borrower has to pay for every defect that develops; Note 120. Agreed to in the Babli, <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i>29b. In 96b, this is a matter of dispute; the Tanna R. Yose holds there that the borrower pays the original owners.</i>” Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Only if he gave permission to lend to others<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise the lessee violates the terms of his lease and becomes liable for every defect which develops. In the Babli, <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 36a, this is a matter of dispute which is decided (36b) in conformity with the Yerushalmi.</i>. Also Rebbi Ḥiyya stated thus<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 3:1 (the first sentence only), also quoted in <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 3:3 (9a 1.51).</i>: “The borrower cannot lend, nor the lessee lease, nor the borrower lease, nor the lessee lend, nor the trustee give to another unless they received permission from the owners. And all who changed the titles without the owners’ knowledge are liable. But the borrower is liable even if he did not change.” But it is because we stated<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 7:13.</i>: “An unpaid watchman can stipulate to be exempt from an oath and the borrower may stipulate that he not have to pay.” This means that even if he stipulated to be exempt that he is obligated<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">If he deviated from the original terms; even if he later subleased with permission (unless he explicitly requested immunity also for the later change.)</i>. What if he wanted to let the borrower swear<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Can the original owner of the cow go to court against the borrower from the lessee to have him swear that the cow died a natural death and, if the borrower refuses to swear, collect the value of the cow from the lessee, or can the borrower claim that he is involved only with the lessee and is immune to suits from third parties?</i>? Let us hear from the following: “If he wrote to her: ‘I have no vow or oath against you,’ he cannot make her swear, but he can ask an oath from the heirs or her business associates.” This implies that if he<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The original owner, since the borrower is a business associate of his lessee.</i> wanted to make the borrower swear, he can force him to swear. The first case teaches about the second and the second about the first<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The first Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 9:5 and the second <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 3:3 with its Tosephta can be combined.</i>. The first case teaches about the second, that if he wanted to make the borrower swear, he can force him to swear. The second case teaches about the first, that if he wants to force the wife to swear, that he can make her swear<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Note 127; <i>editio princeps</i> reads here “that he cannot make her swear.” But the text is very clear, the fact that the husband freed his wife from having to swear about her fiduciary duties does not absolve her from responsibility and having to swear if she deviated from the framework of these duties.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina said, it is not necessary to derive the first case from the second, and what does one learn for the second case from the first? Following what Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Only if he gave permission to lend to others. And here, only if he gave permission to let her sons be stewards<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The wife can appoint others to fulfill part of her duties (in the example given, her adult sons from a prior marriage) only with her husband’s explicit agreement; they have to swear unless especially exempted (interpretation of Tosaphot 86b, <i>s</i>. <i>v</i>. נדר; <i>Sefer Ha‘iṭṭur</i> 23a, Note ג.)</i>. Rebbi Yose said, he has to pay the lease all the time it is leased to him<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This refers back to Mishnah <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 3:1. Even if the original owner gave permission to the lessee to lend out his cow, the lessee is responsible for paying his lease the whole time the cow is in the hands of the non-paying borrower.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked Rebbi Abuna: If the owners borrowed it and it died<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Is this true even if the original owners borrowed it back?</i>? He said to him, in that case we say, they ate it. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, if they ate it, they ate their own property<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">In that case, the lessee does not have to pay.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Yasa: How does one act<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the problem dealt with in <i>Qiddušin</i> 60b 1. 48: Rav Jehudah sent to R. Eleazar: A person having responsibility who handed it over to another (and something happened, who is responsible)? He said to him, the first one has to pay. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the second one has to pay; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, the second one has to pay. (The following argument shows that one has to read that R. Joḥanan holds the first one has to pay.) In <i>Qiddušin</i> there follows the discussion of this paragraph, which shows that R. Yannai and R. Ḥiyya (the Elder) both agree with R. Eleazar and R. Joḥanan.<br>The Babli, <i>Baba qama</i> 11b, attributes to R. Eleazar the opinion that the first one is free from paying if he did not have to pay under the original arrangement; in practice it is decided that the first one always has to pay unless the original owner agreed to the new arrangements.</i>? He said to him, there are two<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">The quote should have been: R. Eleazar says in the name of the Elder R. Ḥiyya, R. Joḥanan says in the name of R. Yannai (which is the quote of the latter in <i>Baba qama</i> 115a.)</i> against four; one does not act following the argument. He said to him, they are two against two! Rebbi Eleazar is the elder Rebbi Ḥiyya’s student; Rebbi Joḥanan is Rebbi Yannai’s student<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">A lengthy discussion of this text is in R. Bezalel Ashkenazi, שיטה מקובצת כתובות (reprint Tel Aviv, n/d) p. 221 a/b. However, probably the text is not based on an original ms. since it is Babylonized, remarkable for such a careful author.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> “I have no vow or oath against you, neither I, nor my heirs, nor my business associates, against you, or your heirs, or your business associates,” he cannot ask an oath from her, neither he, nor the heirs, nor the business associates, from her, or her heirs, or her business associates.<br>If she went from her husband’s grave to her family<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Then she requires that the full <i>ketubah</i> be paid to her immediately on the basis of the <i>ketubah</i> document which is as good as a mortgage coming due.</i>, or she remained in her in-law’s family<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">She prefers not to collect her <i>ketubah</i> but to be supported by her husband’s family for the foreseeable future; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.9.1">Mishnaiot 12:3–4</a>.</i> but was not appointed as steward, the heirs cannot make her swear. But if she was appointed as steward, the heirs can make her swear for the future<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Since they now are the owners and cannot be bound by their father’s dispositions.</i>, but they cannot make her swear about the past<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible to explain this statement as a new paragraph, referring to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>: Even a woman who was not appointed as steward, or whose stewardship ceased with her husband’s death, and who was not granted exemption from swearing, cannot be made to account under oath for the expenses of her husband’s burial.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> ““I have no vow or oath against you,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">A lengthy discussion of this text is in R. Bezalel Ashkenazi, שיטה מקובצת כתובות (reprint Tel Aviv, n/d) p. 221 a/b. However, probably the text is not based on an original ms. since it is Babylonized, remarkable for such a careful author.</i> Rebbi Jonah said, only if she was made a steward during her husband’s lifetime. But if she was appointed as a steward after her husband’s death, the heirs can(not)<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Probably this should be deleted since the husband cannot give her immunity if he appoints her as testamentary executor unless he makes the appointment valid “one hour before my death”.</i> make her swear. That is the Mishnah: if she was not appointed a steward, the heirs cannot make her swear<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">If she is not the executor of her husband’s will and the husband had freed her from swearing about what she had overseen for him, the heirs cannot ask for an accounting of the past.</i>. If she was appointed a steward, the heirs can make her swear for the future<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Since they now are the owners and cannot be bound by their father’s dispositions.</i>, but they cannot make her swear about the past. What is “about the past”? From the time of death to the time of burial<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">As explained at the end, it is not desirable that the widow should hand over the estate to the heirs before her husband’s burial. Therefore, before the burial she is the husband’s agent and not the heirs’. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 87a" href="/Ketubot.87a">Babli agrees, 87a</a>.</i>. And Rebbi Yose said, even if he appointed her as steward after her husband’s death, the heirs can make her swear<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Probably some addition is missing such as “only for the future”. The entire sentence is a corrector’s addition.</i>. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>, speaking of a woman who was freed by her husband from the obligation to swear, who resigned her stewardship at the time of her husband’s burial.</i>: “If he did not appoint her as steward, the heirs cannot make her swear. If he appointed her as steward, the heirs can make her swear for the future but cannot make her swear for the past.” He explains it about the first case<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Even in the case of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>, the widow cannot be made to swear about the expenses of the funeral. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 87a" href="/Ketubot.87a">Babli agrees, 87a</a>.</i>. But if it is about the first case, Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose both say, not only about property over which she had control during her husband’s lifetime but even about property over which she acquired control after her husband’s death the heirs cannot make her swear. Explain it, from the time of death to the time of burial. For Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The heirs cannot make her swear from the time of death to the time of burial<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible to explain this statement as a new paragraph, referring to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>: Even a woman who was not appointed as steward, or whose stewardship ceased with her husband’s death, and who was not granted exemption from swearing, cannot be made to account under oath for the expenses of her husband’s burial.</i>. Bar Qappara stated: That she should not abandon him and leave for her family<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The heirs, the beneficiaries of the estate, have the duty to bury the husband. It would be very bad for the reputation of the family if the widow would return to her own family before the burial because she fears to be accused by the heirs that she spent too much money on her husband’s burial. Therefore, she is prevented from resigning her stewardship before the burial and, in exchange, is freed from having to provide an accounting of the burial costs under oath.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she had compromised her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">She had signed a receipt for part of the <i>ketubah</i>, as explained in the next Mishnah.</i>, she shall not be able to collect without an oath<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">She can collect the remainder of the <i>ketubah</i> only in a court proceeding in which she will have to swear to the amount of the <i>ketubah</i> which still is unpaid.</i>. If one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">A single witness cannot legally prove anything (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>). That rule is stated for criminal proceedings. In money matters, it is a rabbinic institution that the testimony of a single witness creates a presumption that he testified truthfully. The opposing party therefore either has to produce a witness who contradicts the first, or she can swear that her claim is not satisfied.</i> testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid, she shall not be able to collect without an oath. From orphans’ property<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Since the heirs are not usually cognizant of all business dealings between their deceased father and his wife (who might not be their mother), she has to swear that she did not receive any valuables on account of the <i>ketubah.</i></i>, or from encumbered property<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband sold real estate after the date of his wedding, the sale did not remove the <i>ketubah</i> lien on the property. If the <i>ketubah</i> cannot be paid by the estate, the widow has regress on the buyer. Clearly, the buyer can require the widow to swear for the same reason the heirs of the estate can.</i>, in his<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband sends his wife a bill of divorce from abroad, the court handling the delivery of the bill of divorce to the wife will require her to swear that no part of the <i>ketubah</i> had been paid before overseeing the payment of the <i>ketubah.</i><br>The Mishnah is repeated in <i>Šebuot</i>7:7.</i> absence she shall not be able to collect without an oath.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she went from her husband’s grave to her family,” etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">This quote has nothing to do with the Halakhah which discusses only <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.1">Mishnah 8</a>.</i> Rebbi Ze‘ura said, this came down in the manner of a biblical oath. The <i>ketubah</i> is acknowledged in her hand for collection; it is as if collected. But since with the document of 200 there is an acknowledment of payment and she says, one mina [is due to her], she cannot be paid without an oath<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">He discusses the first case of the Mishnah, if she had compromised the <i>ketubah</i> by signing a receipt for partial payment without specifying the amount. The basic biblical text is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:8" href="/Exodus.22.8"><i>Ex.</i>22:8</a>: “About any guilty behavior, about an ox, or a sheep, or a garment, or anything lost, if he agrees that this is it, the case of the two parties shall come before <i>Elohim.</i>” This is explained as follows (<i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael,</i> ed. Horovitz-Rabin p. 301; <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon bar Ioḥai</i> ed. Epstein-Melamed p. 203; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 107a" href="/Bava_Kamma.107a">Babli <i>Baba Qama</i> 107a</a>, <i>Baba Me</i>ṣ<i>i‘a</i> 5a,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 98a" href="/Ketubot.98a">98a</a>): The paragraph speaks in vv. 6–7 about a person who holds another’s property without being paid for his services, who will not have to pay if the property is stolen and the holder never used it for his own purposes. Then v. 8 continues about <i>any</i> behavior implying monetary obligation, i. e., any monetary claim of one person against another, and requires first that the object of the claim be well defined (an ox, a sheep, etc.) and that the defendant of the suit agree that “this is it”, i. e., that there is a case, then there shall be a trial before a judge acting as <i>Elohim,</i> as a representative of God as judge. <i>In praxi</i> this means that if the claimant cannot prove his case by witnesses or documents, the defendant can free himself from paying by swearing while holding a copy of the Torah and being subject to all the rules of judicial oaths. But if the claim is for one thing (e. g., an ox) and the defendant agrees only that something else is owed to the claimant (e. g., a sheep), or if the defendant disputes the entire claim, he cannot be forced to swear and the claimant loses his case.<br>R. Ze‘ura notes that the case of the damaged <i>ketubah</i> has most of the features of a case requiring an oath by biblical standards, even though it seems otherwise since the divorced wife claims the remainder of the <i>ketubah</i> but the husband claims that all was paid. For that he argues that everybody knows that a <i>ketubah</i> becomes payable at the moment of divorce. Therefore, the husband is considered to have paid the <i>ketubah</i> sum and now he requests to get his money back, and the ex-wife disputes part of his claim. (In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 48b" href="/Shevuot.48b">Babli, <i>Šebuot</i> 48b</a>, 81a, this is held only by the House of Shammai; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.5">Note 178</a>.) There are two points why the case does not fit the framework of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:8" href="/Exodus.22.8"><i>Ex.</i>22:8</a>: The person who swears a biblical oath does not have to pay, but in the case under discussion the wife swears in order to collect money. This is by rabbinic tradition. Second, since the <i>ketubah</i> is a mortgage lien (or: in talmudic times was a mortgage lien), the suit is about real estate and real estate claims cannot be settled by oaths (Mishnah <i>Šebuot</i> 6:5). This argument is explicit in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 87b" href="/Ketubot.87b">Babli, 87b</a>, where the place of R. Ze‘ura is taken by (the slightly younger) Rami bar Ḥama.</i>.
It was stated “compromised”. Not that she reduced her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is quoted in <i>Šebuot</i> 7:7 (38a 1. 25), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:6:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.6.2-12"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 8:6</a> (26b 1. 49); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 87b" href="/Ketubot.87b">Babli 87b</a>.</i><i>.</i> If her <i>ketubah</i> was 200 but she claims a mina, she is paid without an oath<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is made more explicit: If her <i>ketubah</i> was 1000 <i>zuz,</i> the husband claims that it was paid but he has no receipt, the divorced wife states that she received nothing but that her claim was only a mina, this is <i>not</i> conceding part of the husband’s claim (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.2">Note 166</a>) and she collects without an oath. It seems that the Yerushalmi would agree to that interpretation.<br>On documents which show that 200 <i>zuz</i> written in the <i>ketubah</i> might mean 100 <i>zuz</i> in actual money (and the standards by which the value of a <i>zuz</i> is determined), cf. M. A. Friedman, <i>loc. cit.</i> Note 87.</i>. What is the difference between one who compromises and one who claims less? Rebbi Ḥanina said, if she compromises there was a transaction between them<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, the oath is required if only to protect creditors with claims against the estate.</i>; if she claims less there was no transaction between them<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">At least, there is no presumption of any transactions between her and her husband regarding her <i>ketubah</i> during her marriage. Therefore, anybody claiming that there was such a transaction in order to impose an oath on the widow would have to prove his case in court.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Since we stated there: “If one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid, she shall not be able to collect without an oath,” should it be similar that if one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was reduced, she shall not be able to collect the reduced sum without an oath? Rebbi Yose said, at the moment that one witness testifies that the amount should be reduced, he is like a single witness who contradicts the testimony of two [witnesses]<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The two witnesses who signed the <i>ketubah</i> document.</i> but no single witness can contradict the testimony of two<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">There can never be an oath imposed for a lesser claim in the settlement of a <i>ketubah</i> since the preceding paragraph dealt with the case of no witnesses and there can be no oath if there are two witnesses.</i>.
It was stated: If an heir’s father held a compromised promissory note, the son collects without swearing<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">If the father had indicated that a certain part of the note was paid, and both the lender and the borrower had died, the lender’s son collects the remainder from the borrower’s son without swearing that no more than the sum indicated had been paid (assuming that the borrower’s son cannot produce a document or witnesses that more had been paid than was claimed), since he could not collect if he had to swear that he was 100% sure that his claim was in the correct amount.</i>. In that the son’s power is greater than the father’s, since the son collects without swearing while the father can collect only by swearing<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">If the borrower had died.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 48a" href="/Shevuot.48a">Babli, <i>Šebuot</i> 48a</a>. It is in the heirs’ power to swear that <i>according to their best knowledge</i> the claim is justified.</i>, nevertheless he has to execute an heir’s oath, “that our father did not charge us, that our father did not tell us, that we did not find a document among our father’s documents that this note was paid.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Šebuot</i> 7:7.</i>” Rebbi Hoshaia asked, does the <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The one mentioned at the start of this paragraph, and also the Mishnah (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.2">Note 166</a>).</i> follow the House of Shammai? For the House of Shammai say, “she collects her <i>ketubah</i> and does not drink.”<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.2.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 4:3</a>, about a woman whose husband, having no witnesses, formally accused her of adultery but died before he could bring her to the Temple for the cleansing ceremony. Since the verse requires the presence of the husband at the Temple ceremony (Yerushalmi <i>Soṭah,</i> p. 180, Note 14), the woman is prevented from clearing her name. The House of Hillel hold that she cannot collect her <i>ketubah</i> since she cannot prove her innocence to the heirs (<i>loc. cit.</i> p. 185, Note 38) based on the general principle that “the burden of proof is on the claimant.” Since the House of Shammai also agree to that principle, it must follow that for them the <i>ketubah</i> is as good as paid and the heirs are the claimants who want to have the money back but who cannot prove their case. This shows that for the House of Shammai the <i>ketubah</i> is the widow’s property from the moment of the husband’s death.</i> Rebbi Yose said, there the reason of the House of Shammai is: Bring my husband and I shall drink<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">The preceding argument is invalid. The House of Shammai may not hold that the <i>ketubah</i> is the widow’s property from the moment of the husband’s death, but they hold that if the woman was ready to clear her name, any impediment which is not her fault cannot be held against her. The House of Hillel hold that the heirs do not have to pay her <i>ketubah;</i> since she brought the problem on herself by being seen with another man after having been duly warned by her husband in front of two witnesses; she cannot collect except by successfully clearing her name. The problem is discussed in similar terms in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.1.3"><i>Soṭah</i> 4:1, Notes 13–16</a>.</i>! But here, it would be in order that even his father would not have to swear. They instituted a rule that he has to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">His oath is a purely rabbinic institution for the prevention of fraud. Since it is rabbinic, it cannot be enforced if it would prevent anybody from collecting what is rightfully his.</i>. They instituted that for him, but not for his son<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, it could not be instituted as a burden on his son.</i>. When he died, you put his son on the biblical rule.
If a father became obligated to swear in court<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The context shows that the oath is a rabbinic one imposed on the person who wants to collect money.</i> and died, his son cannot collect. If it were otherwise, what could we say? Can a man let his son inherit an obligation to swear<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Since he lacks the knowledge about the details of his father’s business transactions, he can only swear a disclaimer of knowledge (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.5">Note 177</a>) but not the required positive statement. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 48a" href="/Shevuot.48a">Babli, <i>Šebuot</i> 48a</a>, this is a common formal statement by Rav and Samuel, not an obvious fact.</i>? Rebbi Avin said, you mean, if a man compromised his document in court, his son cannot collect. Rav Ḥisda asked: Because he walked those two steps, he loses? If he compromised it outside the court, he collects. Because he compromised it in court, he cannot collect<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 48a" href="/Shevuot.48a">Babli, <i>Šebuot</i> 48a</a>, R. Eleazar holds (with Rav Ḥisda here) that the heirs swear the heir’s oath (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.5">Note 177</a>) in any case. R. Abin’s statement is rejected.</i>?
“If she had compromised her <i>ketubah,</i> she shall not be able to collect without an oath,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah is repeated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:3:2-9:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.3.2-9.7"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:3</a>, <i>Šebuot</i> 7:9.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said in the name of Rebbi Yannai: One pays from an orphan’s property only a document on which interest is due<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">To preserve the orphan’s property. In the Babli, <i>‘Arakhin</i> 22a, this opinion is ascribed to Rav Assi.</i>, and some say<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">In the almost parallel text in <i>Šebuot</i> 7:9, this is attributed to R. Nathan [who is called “some say” in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Horayot 13b" href="/Horayot.13b">Babli (<i>Horaiot</i> 13b</a>)]; in the Babli (<i>loc. cit.</i>) it, together with R. Yannai’s explanation, appears in R. Joḥanan’s name.</i>, also a woman’s <i>ketubah.</i> Rebbi Yannai said, because of her sustenance. Rebbi Mattaniah said, who is worried about sustenance? Rebbi Simeon! Since Rebbi Simeon said, it depends on the collection<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.2.1">Mishnah 11:2</a> states that a married woman, for whose upkeep the husband is responsible, and whose husband does not fulfill his support duty, may sell from the estate without court supervision. The same holds for the estate after the husband’s death as long as the <i>ketubah</i> was not paid. R. Simeon grants this right only to the definitively married woman and the wife who becomes a widow after definitive marriage, but not to the preliminarily married who cannot claim support but only <i>ketubah</i> if widowed or divorced. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.1.1">Mishnah 11:1</a> gives the estate the right to the widow’s earnings in exchange for the support; it is held that R. Simeon thinks that, in general, the amount needed for her support is greater than her prospective earnings (Babli <i>loc. cit.</i>).</i>. What about it? For attraction, that everybody should jump to marry her<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Since in those times a single woman had few possibilities of earning a living, if the heirs were not her children she needed the <i>ketubah</i> as dowry to attract a new husband.</i>. Some say, also for robbery and torts<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">If the father had been found guilty of robbery or causing damage but died before he paid the sums assessed by the court.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, we stated both of these. Robbery from the following: “If it was mortgageable, he has to pay.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.10.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Qama</i> 10:1</a>: “If somebody robbed and used the proceeds to feed his children, [if the father died] they do not have to pay. But if it was mortgageable [real estate], they have to pay.”</i>” For torts from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.2.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:2</a>.</i>: “One pays from an orphan’s property only from the least valuable.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">An estate’s real estate holdings are classified by their values per unit of area. It is assumed that the higher the unit value, the easier it is to sell the property. The debtor in general will try to satisfy his obligations with real estate of the lowest quality. The property which per unit area is valued highest is called עידִית “elite”, the average בֵּינוֹנִית “medium”, and the lowest זִיבּוֹרִית “stony field”. These categories are not absolute; they refer to the holdings of an individual.</i>” So is the Mishnah: One pays for torts from an orphan’s property only from the least valuable<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">This statement was not discussed by J. N. Epstein in his treatment of כֵּינִי מַתְנִיתָא (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.8.2">Note 199</a>). The statement should not be considered as emendation. A simple reading of the text will require that the statement apply to all cases in which an orphan’s real estate is to be alienated. In the opinion of both Talmudim (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.1.2-11"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 48b-50a" href="/Ketubot.48b-50a">Babli 48b–50a</a>; <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 9:14, 12b 1. 11) rabbinic practice demands that tort judgments have to be satisfied by best quality, financial debts by medium quality, and <i>ketubah</i> by lowest quality. In the opinion of most authorities, biblical law requires only minimal quality for the settlement of financial obligations. The rabbinic upgrading was a necessity to make it easier for people to get a loan. Since this argument is irrelevant for orphans, one does not need the Mishnah to know that mortgage debts paid by an estate are settled by low quality real estate. Where the Mishnah is really needed is payment for torts for which (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:4" href="/Exodus.22.4"><i>Ex.</i> 22:4</a>) “the best of his fields or the best of his vineyards” are required. The statement therefore should be read: One pays <i>even for torts</i> from an orphan’s property only from the least valuable; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 84a:16:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.84a.16.1"><i>Tosaphot</i> 84a, <i>s. v.</i>לכתובת אשה</a>.</i>. But was it not stated: If the son took his father’s place, one estimates torts from the most valuable land, creditors from average quality, and a woman’s <i>ketubah</i> from the least valuable<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">The rules for the adult heir are the same as they would have been for the bequeather.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, here<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">The rules for the adult heir are the same as they would have been for the bequeather.</i> about an adult orphan, there about an underage orphan.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she had compromised her <i>ketubah,</i> how is that? If her <i>ketubah</i> was 1‘000 <i>zuz</i> and he said to her, you received your <i>ketubah,</i> but she says, I received only one mina, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.<br>If one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid, how is that? If her <i>ketubah</i> was 1‘000 <i>zuz</i> and he said to her, you received your <i>ketubah,</i> but she says, I received nothing, and one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.<br>From encumbered property, how is that? If he sold his real estate to others and she collects from the buyers, she shall not be able to collect without an oath. From orphans’ property, how is that? If he died and left his estate to the orphans, if she is paid out by the orphans she shall not be able to collect without an oath. Not in his presence, how is that? If he went overseas<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband sends his wife a bill of divorce from abroad, the court handling the delivery of the bill of divorce to the wife will require her to swear that no part of the <i>ketubah</i> had been paid before overseeing the payment of the <i>ketubah.</i><br>The Mishnah is repeated in <i>Šebuot</i>7:7.</i> and she collects in his absence, she shall not be able to collect without an oath. Rebbi Simeon says, any time she asks for her <i>ketubah,</i> the heirs can require an oath from her. If she does not ask for her <i>ketubah</i>, the heirs cannot require an oath from her<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">If the widow prefers to be supported by the estate for an unlimited period, the heirs can never ask for an oath that she did not receive part payment of the <i>ketubah</i> (which would disqualify her from being supported) during her husband’s lifetime. But if she asks for her <i>ketubah,</i> they do not have to pay unless she swears, even if her husband had freed her from any obligation to swear. R. Simeon disagrees with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.5.1">Mishnaiot 5</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:1:1-7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.1.1-7.1">6</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she had compromised her <i>ketubah,</i> how is that? If her <i>ketubah</i> was l‘000 zuz,” etc. “If one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid,” etc. So is the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">J. N. Epstein, <sup>2</sup>מבוא לנוסח המשנה p. 475 notes that this כיני מאתניתא is not an emendation but simply a quote from the third Mishnah which belongs to this Halakhah.</i>: “If she collects in his absence, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.”
“If she collects in his absence, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah (after the introductory paragraph) appears also in <i>Šebuot</i> 7:7; it seems to be closer to the original form. That text for the main section is given here in smaller type; it is taken as basis of the translation, with the deviations from the text in <i>Ketubot</i> noted in the Commentary.<br>The quote from the Mishnah is not in <i>Šebuot</i> since the Mishnah there deals with creditors in general, not only the divorcee or widow. Since the text from <i>Šebuot</i> has all the characteristics of being the original, the discussion of the Halakhah refers to contracts in general, not only to <i>ketubot.</i></i>” Can one collect from a person in his absence<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">It is a general principle in Jewish law that זָכִי‌ן לָאָדָם שֶׁלֹּא בְפָנָיו וְאֵין חָבִין לָוֹ אֶלָּא בְפָנָיו “one may benefit a person without his knowledge but one may not obligate him without his knowledge,” <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:6</a>. Since a <i>ketubah,</i> and also a loan document in general, is executed as a lien on all of the debtor’s properties, not on a specified piece of real estate, it cannot be foreclosed without court proceedings in the presence of the debtor or his representative.</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah says, explain it about a contract for which interest is due<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">In that case the court will act for the benefit of the debtor if this satisfies the creditor.</i>. Would the court collect interest<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Since taking interest among Jews is forbidden, the court will not enforce any interest clause in a contract.</i>? Explain it that it was guaranteed for a Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">If the Jewish defendant is sued as guarantor for a Gentile from whom the Jewish creditor may take interest legally, the court will recognize the contract as valid.</i>.
Alexis said before Rebbi Mana: We act much better than you do<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>Ketubot</i> text, R. Mana speaks to the Gentile Alexis. In that text it is not always clear who is the speaker.</i>. We send edicts<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Greek διατάγματα; in Roman praxis referring to edicts of the emperor or the provincial prefect. The corresponding Aramaic word דִּין מוּגְמָרִין in the <i>Ketubot</i> text, if it is not simply a corruption, means “judgment that cannot be appealed.” Since the prefect also was the chief judge of the province, there is really no difference between the Roman administrative edict and the Jewish court’s letter of summons.</i>. If he<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">The debtor who refuses to appear in court for foreclosure proceedings.</i> comes, it is good. If he does not come, we irrevocably give away his properties. He answered him, we also act in this way, we have the herald announce for thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">The verb כרז “to announce” is formed from Greek κῆρυξ “herald”. Public announcements were usually made Mondays and Thursdays, the market days.</i>. If he comes, it is good. If he does not come, we irrevocably give away his properties. He said to him, think of it, if he was in distant corners. He said to him, we send three letters, one after thirty days, one after the next thirty days, and one after the next thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">This was Roman practice in Egypt, cf. R. Taubenschlag, <i>The Law of Graeco-Roman Egypt in the Light of the Papyri,</i> New York 1944, p. 383. In Jewish Babylonia, the person who did not obey the first summons was put in the ban (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 88a" href="/Ketubot.88a">Babli, 88a</a>; against <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 88a:10:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.88a.10.1"><i>Tosafot s. v</i>. ורבא</a>).</i>. If he comes, it is good. If he does not come, we irrevocably give away his properties. Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Ketubot</i>: R. Mattaniah.</i> said, that is, if he was present at the trial and then fled<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Once the validity of a claim has been established in court, the execution of the court order may proceed in the absence of the debtor.</i>. But if he was not present at the trial, we<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Ketubot</i>: “they” (third person).</i> cannot irrevocably give away, but only announce.
You find that one may say that Ḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.1.1">Mishnah 13:1</a>. If a man travelled overseas and his wife asks permission from the court to sell of his property for her upkeep, Ḥanan says that she can sell and only swears at the end, if either the husband returns or notice of his death is received, that she did not retain any of the husband’s property over and above the amount she was entitled to. Ḥanan’s opponents also require her to swear before permission is granted by the court.</i> and Rebbi Simeon said the same thing<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">He admits the widow’s oath only if she demands her <i>ketubah.</i> The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 88b" href="/Ketubot.88b">Babli, 88b</a>, rejects this statement and finds other cases to which R. Simeon may refer. It therefore also rejects the conclusion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.8.5">Note 216</a>) reached here.</i>. Just as Ḥanan said, she shall swear only at the end, so Rebbi Simeon says, she shall swear only at the end. Just as you say, practice follows Ḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.1.1">Mishnah 13:1</a>, on the highest authority of R. Joshua.</i>, so here practice follows Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">By inference from the decision of Ḥanan.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she produced her bill of divorce without a <i>ketubah,</i> she collects her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">The obligatory minimum amount of the <i>ketubah</i> due the divorcee. She has to sign a receipt or the bill of divorce has to be torn up to prevent her from collecting again in another court.</i><i>.</i> A <i>ketubah</i> without the bill of divorce when she says, I lost my bill of divorce but he says, I lost my receipt; similarly, the holder of an instrument of debt not accompanied by a <i>prozbol</i><sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">If the debt documented in the instrument runs beyond a Sabbatical year, the debt is cancelled unless secured by a <i>prozbol</i>; cf. <i>Ševi‘it</i> 10:3 ff., pp. 650 ff.</i>; these shall not be paid. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, since the times of the persecution<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The Hadrianic decrees in Palestine in the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba when all Jewish ritual was prohibited. In those times, the <i>prozbol</i> and the distinctively Jewish bill of divorce had to be torn up as soon as they had been delivered. After the decrees were lifted in the reign of Antoninus Pius, the <i>status quo ante</i> was not restored. The fact of a divorce could be established by witnesses; the existence of a <i>prozbol</i> was assumed.</i>, a woman collects without the bill of divorce and the creditor collects without <i>prozbol</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “From encumbered property, how is that?” Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If somebody disputes a court document, he is not trustworthy<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">A document made in one court will be accepted by another court as valid.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">He is the same R. Ḥiyya who stated the thesis; it is recounted how he was convinced to attribute the statement to R. Joḥanan.</i> said to him: Is that not the Mishnah? “If she produced her bill of divorce without a <i>ketubah,</i> she collects her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Since the bill of divorce is a court document but the <i>ketubah</i> a private one, the court document which proves her status as a divorcee is enough to have another court direct that she be paid the divorce settlement. If divorce and payment were handled by the same court, she would not have to present anything.</i>”! Rebbi Joḥanan said to him: Babylonian, after I removed the clay from the pearl, you say to me: Is that not the Mishnah? Rav said, at a place where one does not write a <i>ketubah.</i> But at a place where one writes a <i>ketubah,</i> what she produces she collects<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">This is all part of R. Joḥanan’s argument, that the Mishnah does not prove anything since Rav gave it an interpretation which has nothing to do with the divorce bill being a court document. Rav declares that there are places where one would not write a <i>ketubah</i> if the amount stipulated in it did not exceed the legal minimum. Since legally required terms do not have to be written in the <i>ketubah</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.4.1">Mishnaiot 4:7–12</a>), the amount itself does not have to be written (4:7) for the marriage to be legal.</i>. He changed his mind and said, she collects even at a place where one writes a <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan asserts that Rav in the end did agree with him. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 89a" href="/Ketubot.89a">Babli disagrees, 89a</a>, and asserts that Rav restricts the Mishnah to cases in which no <i>ketubah</i> was written; R. Joḥanan’s opinion there is attributed to Samuel.</i>; let anyone powerful object to this! Rebbi Yose objected: Was it not stated: She might collect on her divorce document, hide her <i>ketubah,</i> and collect a second time<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 16b" href="/Ketubot.16b">Babli, 16b</a>. This must be part of a <i>baraita</i> which explains the precautions necessary to prevent that the same claim could be presented in different jurisdictions.</i>? If those died. Are there not witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">In case no receipt was written or the document presented for payment was shredded.</i>? Bring them! They went overseas. Is there not an agreement<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὁμολογία “consensus”, a joint statement of payor and payee.</i>? Is there no registrar of agreements? There is a registrar of agreements; as you say, if a document is lost, one writes a replacement<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that it is a replacement has to be stated in the new document. Therefore, the new document cannot be used fraudulently as an original.</i>. This is what one says, if the <i>ketubah</i> was lost, one writes a new one<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that it is a replacement has to be stated in the new document. Therefore, the new document cannot be used fraudulently as an original.</i>. Rebbi Abba objected: Was it not stated, she might collect on her divorce document, hide her <i>ketubah,</i> wait until he dies, and collect a second time<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">From the heirs, as a widow.</i>? Rebbi Yose bar Abun said to him: Would she not have to prove that she lived with him until he died?
Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Abuna in the name of Rav: At a place where one writes <i>ketubah</i> documents, if he says I wrote, but she says you did not write, the burden of proof is on her to prove that he did not write. But at a place where one does not write <i>ketubah</i> documents, if he says I wrote, but she says you did not write, the burden of proof is on him to prove that he wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 89a" href="/Ketubot.89a">Babli, 89a</a>, this is an inference of Rav Anan from a statement of Samuel. Local usage is always <i>prima facie</i> evidence in questions of existence of documents.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba found Rebbi Jonathan’s <i>prozbol</i> and ran to give it to him<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Ḥiyya is two generations younger than R. Jonathan, this must have been a very young R. Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i>. He said to him, I do not need it<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 37b" href="/Gittin.37b">Babli, <i>Giṭṭin</i> 37b</a>, this is a statement of Rav Naḥman, that Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s elimination of the requirement to produce a bill of divorce or <i>prozbol</i> is permanent.</i>, as it was stated: The creditor can be believed if he says, I discarded this document<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>prozbol.</i></i> and tore it up. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya: The Mishnah says so: “Since the times of the persecution, a woman collects without the bill of divorce and the creditor collects without <i>prozbol.</i>” Is that not impossible? I tore it without discarding<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot possibly ask for payment if he does not claim to have had a <i>prozbol</i> to discard.</i>? Here, I discarded and tore it<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">This includes the claim that a <i>prozbol</i> was in existence when needed.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two bills of divorce and two <i>ketubot</i>, she collects two <i>ketubot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">She was twice married and twice divorced from the same man. After the first divorce, she did not collect her <i>ketubah.</i> When he married her the second time, he wrote her a new <i>ketubah</i> (which he did not have to do, as explained in the Mishnah.) Then the new <i>ketubah</i> is a new obligation, additional to the old one, not superseding it.</i><i>.</i> Two <i>ketubot</i> and one bill of divorce, or one <i>ketubah</i> and two bills of divorce, or one <i>ketubah,</i> and a bill of divorce, and death; she collects only one <i>ketubah</i> since a person who divorces his wife and takes her back, takes her back on the basis of her prior <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Without documentary proof to the contrary, a man married twice to the same woman is presumed to owe only one <i>ketubah.</i></i>. If a minor was married off by his father, [his wife’s] <i>ketubah</i> is valid since he kept her by that understanding<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">A minor cannot legally take on obligations. The <i>ketubah</i> becomes only valid at the moment the minor becomes an adult and stays married to his wife.</i>. If a proselyte converted together with his wife, her <i>ketubah</i> is valid since he kept her by that understanding<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbinic court will enforce all obligations the groom had undertaken for his bride in Gentile law.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she produced her bill of divorce without a <i>ketubah,</i> she collects her <i>ketubah</i>,” etc. “Two bills of divorce and two <i>ketubot</i>” etc. But only if the bill of divorce is dated between the two <i>ketubot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise the second <i>ketubah</i> was only intended to replace the first which was thought to be lost; a similar argument is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90a" href="/Ketubot.90a">Babli, 90a</a>.</i><i>.</i> So far if they are equal. If one was for a mina, the other for 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the second case, that the divorcee presents two <i>ketubot</i> and one bill of divorce. If the amounts are equal, the second bill replaces the first. If they are unequal, they cannot replace one another.</i>? Rav Huna and Rav Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Probably it should read: Rav Huna in the name of Rav Jeremiah; otherwise, the name of a first generation Amora should not appear between the names of two second generation Amoraim.</i> and Rav Ḥisda. One said, she collects the first one. The other said, she collects the second one and the excess<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the first <i>ketubah</i> should be larger, it now is a lien on the husband’s real estate only from the date of the second. Any real estate sold between the dates of the two <i>ketubot</i> cannot be taken by the divorcee. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 43b" href="/Ketubot.43b">Babli, 43b</a>, Rav Huna states that if she only claims the smaller amount she collects from the date of the first <i>ketubah,</i> otherwise from the time of the second.</i> she collects from the date of the second.
Rebbi Ḥanaiah said before Rebbi Mana: Does this not mean that if a person borrows from another, and then he borrows again, he has to declare “in addition to the first paper you have on me”<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Would two commercial contracts be considered under the same rules as <i>ketubot</i>?</i>? It is frequent that a woman says, my <i>ketubah</i> is lost, write me another<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">The husband would have to oblige, leaving the wife with two documents.</i>. Is it frequent that a man say, my paper is lost, write me another<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">The debtor does not have to oblige; if he agrees in order to retain the possibility of future loans, the new contract will certainly be written so that the prior contract would be invalidated.</i>? But it is possible that he should declare for him<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Instead of writing in the contract, the debtor could declare his multiple indebtedness in front of witnesses.</i>.
Rebbi Yudan from Sicily<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Or, “son of Sicinius” (E. G.).</i> brought this case<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">The statement that a man remarrying his divorcee can do that on the basis of the prior <i>ketubah.</i></i> before Rebbi Yose: Did not Rebbi Abbahu<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>Baba Me</i>ṣ<i>i‘a</i> 17a, R. Assi (Yasa) in the name of R. Joḥanan.</i> say in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Nobody should use a paper on which he borrowed and paid the loan back to take out another loan on the same day<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">If the loan was paid back the day it was taken out (otherwise the paper would be predated and invalid). The reason given in the Babli is that the rights given by the borrower to the lender by handing over the contract to the lender were annulled by the repayment and cannot be resurrected.</i>? He said to him, here if he had paid back, there if he did not pay back<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, if the <i>ketubah</i> was paid after the divorce, at the remarriage the husband has to execute a new <i>ketubah.</i> The Mishnah refers only to the case that the husband prefers to remarry instead of paying up.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">This text is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 6:2:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.6.2.11"><i>Demay</i>6:3, Notes 88–89</a>. It refers to the validity of the <i>ketubah</i> for the remarried divorcee. From the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90a" href="/Ketubot.90a">Babli, 90a</a>, one might be led to read this statement as belonging to the next paragraph, about the <i>ketubah</i> of a minor’s wife, but this does not fit the interpretation given the statement in <i>Demay.</i></i> Rebbi Ḥanin stated before Rebbi Hila: Two Amoraïm, one said for <i>ketubah</i> but not for individual stipulations, the other said, both for <i>ketubah</i> and for individual stipulations.
One understands a proselyte<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">He contracted the marriage as an adult. His conversion cannot invalidate his contractual obligations.</i>. A minor<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot enter into valid contracts. If he dies, how can his wife enforce her claims against the minor’s heirs whose rights are biblical?</i>? Can a minor divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Since a minor cannot act in law, he cannot divorce his wife and her <i>ketubah</i> cannot become due.</i>? Rebbi Ḥaggai said, I explained it following what Rebbi Eleazar said in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Only if he slept with her when he regained sight or became sane mentally<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.2.6">Chapter 1, Note 146</a>. The wife of a deaf-mute or insane man can collect a <i>ketubah</i> only if for some period she lived with him while he was legally competent. At that time, their marital relations validate the contract.</i>. And here, if he slept with her after he reached adulthood.

Chapter 10



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to two women when he died, the first one<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The wife whose <i>ketubah</i> is dated earlier.</i> precedes the second<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Since a <i>ketubah</i> is a mortgage lien, the holder of the earlier mortgage has the right to foreclose any real estate before the holder of the later mortgage may foreclose. The rules of this Chapter are in essence rules of privileged creditors in bankruptcy proceedings since they become irrelevant if the estate is large enough to satisfy everybody.</i>, and the heirs of the first precede the heirs of the second<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">If the wives die before they have collected their respective <i>ketubot,</i> the heirs collect these from the estate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>).</i>. If the first one he had married died<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The husband then inherits his deceased wife’s property; only after his death can the first wife’s children claim her <i>ketubah</i> as inheritance.</i>, then he married the second one and he himself died, the second and her heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The widow is a mortgage holder, a creditor of the estate; the first wife’s children are heirs. The heirs can lay their hands on the estate only after all outstanding obligations are paid. If the widow dies before she is paid, her claim passes to her heirs.</i> precede the heirs of the first.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody was married to two women,” etc. The Mishnah refers to <i>ketubah,</i> but for sustenance both are equal<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">If both widows prefer not to receive their <i>ketubah</i> but to be sustained by the estate, they have to be treated equally. The statement is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 10:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).10.1">Tosephta 10:1</a>.</i>. Between <i>ketubah</i> and burial, what has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The estate is only sufficient either for the expenses of the man’s burial or his widow’s <i>ketubah.</i> The question is not answered, maybe because it never arose in practice. Since the deceased has to be buried before questions about payment are asked, it seems that the burial is charged to public welfare.</i>? Between <i>ketubah</i> and a loan attested to by witnesses, what has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Tarphon in Mishnaiot 9:2–3, the creditor has precedence since he depends on the testimony of witnesses who might die but the widow depends on the written <i>ketubah.</i></i>? Between <i>ketubah</i> and daughters’ dowry, what has precedence? For him who says<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥanina in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.2-4">Halakhah 6:6</a>, against R. Joḥanan (Notes 93, 96–97). The disagreement is also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 13:3:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.13.3.2-6">13:3</a> (36a 1. 15).</i>, one collects for dowry from mortgaged property, daughters’ dowry has precedence. But for him who says, one does not collect for dowry from mortgaged property, daughters’ dowry does not have precedence.
It says only, “she died”. Therefore, if she was divorced, her status is that of a creditor<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">If the first one was divorced, her claim has preference over the claims of the second and her heirs.</i>. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 10:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).10.1">Tosephta 10:1</a>.</i>: “He married a woman and wrote her a <i>ketubah.</i> He divorced her but did not pay the <i>ketubah.</i> He married another woman and wrote her a <i>ketubah.</i> He took back the first one and wrote her a <i>ketubah</i> in addition to the first <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Then the husband died and his estate is not sufficient to satisfy all three <i>ketubot.</i></i><i>.</i> The [second <i>ketubah</i>] of the first [wife] has precedence over that of the second [wife] and her heirs, and the second [wife] and her heirs have precedence over the heirs of the first.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">That text is elliptic but its meaning is clear; it is not necessary to assume that the original text was that of the Tosephta and was shortened in transmission. The Tosephta reads: “The first <i>ketubah</i> of the first [wife] has precedence over the second and her heirs; the second and her heirs have precedence over the second <i>ketubah</i> of the first.” Any prior document has precedence over any later one.</i>”
Ben Azay<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Later in the discussion, the author is called Ben Nanas in ms., <i>editio princeps,</i> and all ms. sources of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90b" href="/Ketubot.90b">Babli, 90b</a>. However, in the Constantinople edition with the commentary of Joshua Benvenist, the name is Ben Azay in both occurrences. Ben Nanas is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i> says<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the second case in the Mishnah, where the first wife died and the second becomes a widow. In that case, the husband inherited the first wife’s property; the first wife’s children have claim to inherit their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> only by rabbinic institution, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>, whereas the widow (or her children in her stead) has a contractual claim on the estate. If the estate is larger than the sum of the two <i>ketubot</i> by at least “one excess denar”, there is no problem. All children can inherit their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> and part of the remainder.
