But if the estate is not sufficient and payment of the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” instituted in 4:10 would eliminate biblical inheritance rules, the question is whether rabbinic inheritance can or cannot supersede biblical inheritance (which would treat all children equally except that a male firstborn counts for two.)</i>, the heirs of the first say to the heirs of the second: If you are creditors, take what is yours and leave<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbinic institution of “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” eliminates the biblical laws of inheritance. The sons of the second wife take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> as inheritance from their mother, not their father; what remains of the estate is taken by the sons of the first wife as “<i>ketubah</i> of male children”. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 10:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).10.1">Tosephta 10:1</a>, this is presented as anonymous rule: “If there is an excess denar, both parties take their mothers’ <i>ketubot</i> and the remainder is split evenly; if there is no excess denar, the second wife or her heirs take her <i>ketubah</i> and the remainder is divided evenly.</i>; otherwise let us split evenly between yourselves and us<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If the sons of the second wife want to deprive the sons of the first of their “<i>ketubah</i> of male children”, they lose their own <i>ketubah</i> and everybody becomes an heir in biblical law. Since this would be to the detriment of the sons of the second wife, the first alternative is operative.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba said to him: Biblical inheritance “jumped” on the sons of the second; they take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> and come back to split<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The sons of the second wife take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> under the rules of creditors and the remainder is biblical inheritance split among all sons since rabbinic inheritance decrees cannot eliminate biblical rules if the estate is too small.</i>. Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">R. Mana II, contemporary of R. Yose ben R. Abun.</i> said, they disagree if there is an excess denar<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">It is very difficult to accept that the second marriage invalidates the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” of the first marriage.</i>. But if there is no excess denar, even Rebbi Aqiba will agree with Ben Nanas<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Later in the discussion, the author is called Ben Nanas in ms., <i>editio princeps,</i> and all ms. sources of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90b" href="/Ketubot.90b">Babli, 90b</a>. However, in the Constantinople edition with the commentary of Joshua Benvenist, the name is Ben Azay in both occurrences. Ben Nanas is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i> that both parties split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">It is equally difficult to accept that the <i>ketubah</i> of the second has the status of a creditor’s claim only for the widow but not for their heirs. Since the argument of R. Yose ben R. Abun is reasonable, there seems to be no possibility to claim a copyist’s corruption.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to him, a situation which was stated without disagreement you turn into a disagreement. They must disagree if there is no excess denar. But if there is an excess denar even Ben Nanas<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Later in the discussion, the author is called Ben Nanas in ms., <i>editio princeps,</i> and all ms. sources of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90b" href="/Ketubot.90b">Babli, 90b</a>. However, in the Constantinople edition with the commentary of Joshua Benvenist, the name is Ben Azay in both occurrences. Ben Nanas is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i> agrees with Rebbi Aqiba that biblical inheritance “jumped” on the sons of the second; they take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> and come back to split<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The sons of the second wife take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> under the rules of creditors and the remainder is biblical inheritance split among all sons since rabbinic inheritance decrees cannot eliminate biblical rules if the estate is too small.</i>.
Debts diminish and, equally, debts add<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In determining whether an estate is larger than the sum of the <i>ketubot</i> due, one deducts debts payable by the estate and adds debts due to it. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 90b" href="/Ketubot.90b">Babli agrees, 90b</a>.</i>. How is this? If there was a field which in the future would return in the jubilee year, you consider it virtual<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The example is purely theoretical since the institution of the jubilee disappeared under the Israelite monarchy; cf. Introduction to Tractate Ševi‘it. The practical implication is that the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” is due even if the estate reaches the required size only by counting contracts far into the future.</i> [property].
How is that<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence does not refer to anything; it seems to be a copyist’s error.</i>? If he preliminarily married Rachel, definitively married Leah<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">By combining preliminary and definitive marriage (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.5">Chapter 1, Note 24</a>).</i>, and only then definitively married Rachel. In the opinion of the rabbis, Rachel has precedence; in the opinion of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah she does not have precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.1.1">Mishnah 5:1</a>, R. Eleazar ben Azariah holds that a <i>ketubah</i> becomes executable only after definitive marriage; therefore, Leah’s <i>ketubah</i> in effect should predate Rachel’s even though Rachel’s was executed earlier, at the time of her preliminary wedding. For the rabbis, the date of the contract is the determining factor.</i>. They say, even Rebbi Eleazar will agree that since in the end he definitively married Rachel, Rachel has precedence<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar ben Azariah agrees that if both contracts are executable, the dates of the contracts determine precedence. He only holds that before definitive marriage the contract is not executable.</i>. To what can this be compared? To one who took out a loan from another person and said to him, if I have not paid it back by twelve months, all my properties shall be mortgaged to you. If the twelfth month arrived and he has not paid back, his properties become mortgaged from that moment on<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The moment of the loan. If the debtor had sold any real estate in the meantime, the creditor can have regress on it since the contract predates the sale even if it becomes executable only later.</i>. But if he said, all my properties shall be mortgaged to you <i>only</i> after twelve months, they become mortgaged only after twelve months. The status of the days in between<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The days between the signing of the contract and the end of 12 months when the contract becomes executable.</i> is in dispute between Rebbi Meïr and the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">There are many disputes between R. Meïr and the other rabbis and it is a matter of conjecture to which dispute this refers. R. Moses Margalit points to a <i>baraita</i> quoted in the Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 13b, in which R. Meïr states that a loan contract allows regress on alienated property only if this was stated in the contract; but the rabbis hold that such regress is a matter of law and does not have to be stated explicitly.</i>. In Rebbi Meïr’s opinion, the properties became pledged by the document<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The alienation clause becomes activated only after 12 months; it cannot apply to properties sold during these months.</i>. In the rabbis’ opinion, the properties became pledged by the money<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The moment the loan money changed hands, the alienation clause became executable whether written or not.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to two women who both died, and then he died, and the orphans demand their mothers’ <i>ketubot</i>, if [the estate] is sufficient only for both <i>ketubot</i> they split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If there are <i>n</i> sons, the estate is divided into <i>n</i> equal parts. If one of the children is a male firstborn, the estate is divided into <i>n</i>+1 parts and the firstborn takes two. If there are no sons, only <i>n</i> daughters, the estate is divided into <i>n</i> equal parts.</i>. If there was an excess denar, these take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> and those take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The remainder is split evenly between the heirs.</i><i>.</i> If the orphans say<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>ketubot</i> were unequal, the sons of the mother with the larger <i>ketubah</i> would be interested to receive the <i>ketubah</i> rather than the inheritance. Similarly, if the <i>ketubot</i> were equal but one wife had few sons, the other many, the few sons would gain if they could split their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> between them and not have to share with their many halfbrothers. These are willing to take some property at an inflated value in order to receive more than the other woman’s sons.</i>, we accept the properties of our father for the value of an extra denar in order to take their mother’s <i>ketubah</i>; one does not listen to them but one appraises the properties in court.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody was married to two women,” etc. That refers to what Rebbi Immi said, that a man should be induced to give generously to his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.2">Halakhah 4:12, Note 238</a>.</i>. If that is so, then even if there is no excess denar<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">If the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” was instituted so that people would increase their daughters’ dowries in the knowledge that the money will be transferred to their grandchildren, it does not seem reasonable to restrict the rules to sufficiently large estates.</i>? Rebbi Abun said, in case you can uphold their words with the words of the Torah, you uphold their words with the words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">If the estate is large enough, one can distribute the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” and still have an estate which is distributed according to biblical law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num.</i> 27:6–11</a>). Cf. M. A. Friedman, <i>Jewish Marriage in Palestine</i>, Tel Aviv 1980, vol. I, pp. 381 ff.</i>. But in case you cannot uphold their words with the words of the Torah, you disregard their words and uphold the words of the Torah.
Rebbi Judah bar Pazi in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: If one of the brothers died, they all split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">If he dies without issue, all his paternal brothers inherit from him.</i>. Rebbi Mana said, that is necessary if they did not yet divide the estate. You should not say that he should be considered nonexistent and his house should inherit from him<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">If the estate had been distributed by the time of his death, this would be a simple case of inheritance; in the absence of children his maternal brothers would inherit. But if the estate was not yet distributed, the question is whether the heirs are considered to have acquired their part at the moment of their father’s death or whether they acquire only at the time of the actual distribution. Clearly, for the part of the estate which is distributed under biblical law, all surviving full and halfbrothers inherit equally. But for the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children”, in the second case, only the maternal brothers share his part, while in the first they all share. R. Mana states here that an inheritance is acquired at the time of death of the bequeather. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 107a" href="/Bava_Batra.107a">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 107a</a>, this latter opinion is attributed to Rav; Samuel holds that “brothers at the distribution of the estate have the status of buyers from one another”, i. e., their status is determined only at the time of distribution. Since the Babli follows Samuel in money matters, it will deny R. Mana’s assertion.</i>. If there was a (male) firstborn, you say the firstborn takes a double portion<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:16-17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.16-17"><i>Deut.</i> 21:16–17</a>. In that example, the firstborn takes <sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> since there are only two sons.</i>. What does he take? A double portion among his house or among all brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Is the “<i>ketubah</i> of male children” of the other wife exempt from the biblical rule of the firstborn?</i>? Rebbi Hoshaia stated: If there were two groups of daughters, they all split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>:10 refers only to male children. If all children are female, they each receive an equal share of the estate.</i>. If there was a firstborn, you say the firstborn takes a double portion. What does he take? A double portion among his house or among all <i>ketubot</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear why this question is repeated since R. Hoshaia does not deal with sons at all and a female firstborn has no special rights.</i>
At which point in time does one appraise? The students of Rebbi Mana say, at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">At the time of distribution.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to them, are you not those who speak in the name of your teacher, “that is necessary if they did not yet divide the estate”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">If the share of each son in the “<i>ketubah</i> of male sons” is determined at the moment of their father’s death, the value of the estate must be determined at that moment since the “<i>ketubah</i> of male sons” depends on that value.</i>? But one assesses from the first moment<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The moment of the father’s death. This is asserted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 91" href="/Ketubot.91">Babli, 91a/b</a>, by Rav Naḥman, the highest authority in money matters. In his opinion, the status of the estate is not connected with the point in time at which the heirs take possession of their inheritance.</i>!

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the estate contained expected property, it does not have the status of property in actual possession<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">If the expected inheritance from a grandfather would bring the father’s estate over the limit for distribution of the “<i>ketubah</i> of male sons”, it cannot be counted until it becomes due. Similarly, the double portion of a male firstborn is restricted to “all that is present with him” at his father’s death (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.17"><i>Deut.</i> 21:17</a>); the firstborn has no special rights to any inheritance from other members of their family coming to the sons after the father’s death.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, even if there was no mortgageable property<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Movables.</i>, it does not count unless there is mortgageable property<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate. R. Simeon holds that a <i>ketubah</i> is a mortgage lien and, therefore, cannot be satisfied by movable property.</i> in the value of at least a denar more than the two <i>ketubot.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the estate contained expected property,” etc. Rebbi Mana said, they disagree about the basic claim of the two <i>ketubot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">It is not totally clear what “the basic claim of the <i>ketubah</i>” means. Is it only the required 100/200 <i>zuz</i> or is it that amount plus any dowry which became the husband’s property, to exclude any sum the husband wrote into the <i>ketubah</i> in excess of minimum and dowry? The second version is preferred by the classical commentators.</i><i>.</i> Rebbi Simeon says, real estate, but the rabbis say, movables. But for the excess denar everybody agrees that it is movable. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, everybody agrees about the basic claim of the two <i>ketubot</i> that it must be real estate. Where do they disagree? About the excess denar, where Rebbi Simeon says, real estate, but the rabbis say, movables. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda in the name of Rav: But in Syria they routinely collect from bronze and bedspreads<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Articles of trade, at places were Jews were not traditionally land owners.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Only from bedspreads of that night<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">He wants to restrict the recovery of the <i>ketubah</i> to the articles of the dowry brought by the bride.</i>. Rav Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The people in Arabia routinely collect from camels and spices<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Since they are bedouin traders, they do not possess any real estate; their equivalent of real estate are camels (affirmed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 67a" href="/Ketubot.67a">Babli, 67a</a>, by the same authors); their object of trade is spices.</i>. Similarly, only from spices of that night<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Since it would be nonsensical to require the spices brought by the bride to be available to the widow; the condition about bedspreads is also nonsensical.</i>? Rebbi Ḥuna’s widow collected from movables following her place’s custom<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The famous Gaonic decree that <i>ketubot</i> be paid from movables is nothing but an application of the Yerushalmi rule that local conditions overrule general statements.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to three women when he died, the <i>ketubah</i> of one was a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">100 <i>zuz.</i></i>, of the other one 200, and of the other one 300. If the estate is only 100, they divide equally. If it was 200, the one who claims a mina takes 50, and those who claim 200 and 300 each take three gold denars<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">1 gold denar was worth 25 silver denars. 3 gold denars equal 75 <i>zuz</i>, 6 gold denars 150 <i>zuz.</i></i>. If it was 300, the one who claims a mina takes 50, the one who claims 200 takes a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">100 <i>zuz.</i></i>, and the one who claims 300 takes six gold denars<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">1 gold denar was worth 25 silver denars. 3 gold denars equal 75 <i>zuz</i>, 6 gold denars 150 <i>zuz.</i></i>. Similarly, if three who invested together lost or gained they would split in this manner<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the proportional distribution of the last case. Loss and gain of a stock company are distributed per share.</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah poses difficult problems. First, it deals with a scenario that cannot arise since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> stated that a <i>ketubah</i> which precedes in time has to be satisfied from the estate before the later <i>ketubah</i> can be claimed. Therefore, the case of the Mishnah presupposes that the husband married three woman simultaneously. While this is possible in theory, it is excluded in practice. The problem is a practical one if applied to the case that the amount available in bankruptcy proceedings is not sufficient to cover all claims of equal rank.<br>At first glance, it seems that the Mishnah is inconsistent, applying three different rules to three different cases. Since the Mishnah must guide the judge to correctly apportion payment of claims <i>c</i><sub>1</sub>, <i>c</i><sub>2</sub>,<i>c</i><sub>3</sub> if the available amount <i>a &lt; c</i><sub>1</sub><i>+ c</i><sub>2</sub><i>+ c</i><sub>3</sub>, for all <i>a</i> between 0 and <i>c</i><sub>1</sub><i>+ c</i><sub>2</sub><i>+ c</i><sub>3</sub>, it is obvious that the Mishnah has to be explained by one single consistent formula or algorithm. In addition, the algorithm must be applicable to any number <i>n</i> of claims.<br>In the tenth Century, Saadya Gaon suceeded in reducing the number of different rules employed in the Mishnah to two (<i>Oṣar Hageonim Ketubot</i> p. 310). A complete discussion of the Geonic treatment of the Mishnah was given by I. Francus, שיטת הגאונים בפירוש משנה וברייתא, סיני פכו-פכז (תשס-תשסא) קצה-ריב (M. H. Katzenellenbogen Memorial Volume).<br>The first complete solution of the problem of finding a uniform rule for all three cases was given by R. J. Aumann and M. Maschler, Game Theoretic Analysis of a Bankruptcy Problem from the Talmud, <i>J. Econom. Theory</i> <b>36</b>(1985) 195–213. In the framework of the theory of cooperative games, the authors show that the distribution of the Mishnah corresponds to the <i>nucleolus</i> strategy in game theory. Using only elementary mathematics, a single distribution formula covering all cases was given by M. Balinski in: Quelle équité, <i>Pour la science</i> <b>311</b> (September 2003) 82–87; What is Just? <i>Am. Math. MONTHLY</i> <b>112</b>(2005), 502–511. While these authors succeed in explaining the Mishnah in itself, they do not explain the interpretation given to the Mishnah by the Talmudim. Nor do they explain why in both Talmudim the Mishnah is rejected out of hand. The explanation of the Babli is in language close to the Yerushalmi but translated into mathematical formulas the results are quite different; in both Talmudim the proposed explanation results in a procedure which is not monotone; i. e., it is possible that if the available amount <i>a</i> is increased, the payouts for some claimants are decreased. The solutions both of Aumann/Maschler and Balinski are monotone, increasing with <i>a.</i><br>Balinski shows that the Mishnah can be understood in terms of a different distribution problem in Mishnah <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> 1:1, as indicated by Alfasi (<i>Ketubot</i> 10, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51b" href="/Ketubot.51b">51b</a> in the Wilna ed.). Since this problem is also the basis of the arguments in both Talmudim, Balinski’s method is explained first. In <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> there are two claimants for an amount of 1. The first claims it all, the second claims ½. Both claims are of the same status. Then the first is awarded <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub>, the second <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub>. While the claims are in ratio 2:1, the awards are in ratio 3:1. The reason given is the rule ascribed to Symmachos, a student of R. Meïr, that “money in doubt is split evenly” [Babli <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> 2b, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 35b" href="/Bava_Kamma.35b"><i>Baba qama</i> 35b</a>; Yerushalmi <i>Baba meṣiʻa</i> 8:5 (11d 1. 18); cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.1.3">Chapter 2, Notes 9</a> ff.]. Since the second claimant asks only for ½, the other half is awarded to the first claimant. The first half is in doubt; therefore it is split evenly between the two parties, resulting in the awards mentioned.<br>In order to arrive at a mathematical formulation, assume that <i>n</i> claims <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> are advanced,<br><i>c</i><sub>1</sub><i>&lt; c</i><sub>2</sub> <i>&lt; … &lt; c</i><sub>n</sub><i>.</i><br>If several claims were identical they would be consolidated into a single claim and the award split evenly between the participants. For any amount <i>a</i> available for distribution, the payout for claimant <i>i</i> is p<sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>,</i><br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>+ p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>+ …</i> <i>+ p</i><sub>n</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= a.</i><br>We also introduce the sum of the claims, S =<i>c</i><sub>1</sub> <i>+ c</i><sub>2</sub><i>+ … + c</i><sub>n</sub> and M= S/2. For <i>n</i> = 2, Symmachos’s argument determines the payouts uniquely:<br>If <i>a ≤ c</i><sub>1</sub><i>,</i> the entire sum is in dispute,<br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= a</i>/2<i>.</i><br>Therefore, <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>c</i><sub>1</sub>)<i>= p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>c</i><sub>1</sub>)<i>= c</i><sub>1</sub>/2<i>.</i><br>If c<sub>1</sub> &lt; <i>a ≤ c</i><sub>2</sub>, the amount <i>a - c</i><sub>1</sub> belongs to claimant 2 and<br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= c</i><sub>1</sub>/2,<br><i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= a-c</i><sub>1</sub><i>+c</i><sub>1</sub>/2<i>= a-c</i><sub>1</sub>/2,<br>and p<sub>1</sub>(c<sub>2</sub>) = <i>c</i><sub>1</sub>/2,<i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>c</i><sub>2</sub>)<i>= c</i><sub>2</sub><i>-c</i><sub>1</sub>/2<i>.</i><br>If <i>c</i><sub>2</sub><i>&lt; a</i>, both claimants have equal rights to the excess over <i>c</i><sub>2</sub>,<br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= c</i><sub>1</sub>/2<i>+</i>(<i>a - c</i><sub>2</sub>)/2<br><i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>a</i>) <i>= c</i><sub>2</sub><i>-c</i><sub>1</sub>/2<i>+</i>(<i>a-c</i><sub>2</sub>)/2<i>=</i>(<i>a+c</i><sub>2</sub><i>-c</i><sub>1</sub>)/2<i>.</i><br>If <i>a = c</i><sub>2</sub><i>+c</i><sub>1</sub> = S, all claims are satisfied in full. Using the function min(<i>x,y</i>) = smaller of <i>x</i> or y<i>,</i> Balinski did express the formulas given above by<br>(1) <i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i>) = min(<i>c</i><sub>i</sub>/2, λ) where λ is chosen so that <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>+ p</i><sub>2</sub>(<i>a</i>)<i>= a</i>;<i>i =</i> 1,2.<br>An inspection of the formulas shows that the distribution is symmetric about the middle value of the claims:<br>(2) <i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>M-x</i>)<i>+ p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>M+x</i>)<i>= c</i><sub>i</sub>.<br>This means that the distribution for <i>M ≤ a ≤ S</i> is determined if it is determined for 0 ≤ <i>a</i>≤<i>M.</i> In the Mishnah here, it should be sufficient to indicate the distribution up to an estate of 300 if the sum of claims is 600. But the generalization of the procedure for <i>n</i> = 2 to <i>n</i> &gt; 2 is not trivial. As Balinski points out, an arbitrary distribution function which yields the given values for <i>a = c</i><sub>i</sub> and satisfies (2) is compatible with the Mishnah. His own solution is to postulate (1) for <i>i</i> = 1, … <i>n.</i> Then (2) is satisfied and the distribution is monotone. For example,<br>{<i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(400),<i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(400),<i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(400)} = {100-<i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(200),200-<i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(200),300-<i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(200)} = {50,125,225}.<br>The problem with this solution, as with most other solutions proposed in the last 1000 years, is that the Talmudim take another view. The solution of the Babli is easily described as a recursive computational procedure. We assume that <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>),…,<i>p</i><sub>i-</sub><sub>1</sub>(<i>a</i>) have been determined; leaving an amount <i>a</i><sub>i</sub> to be distributed. We determine <i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>). If <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> ≥ <i>a</i><sub>i</sub>, <i>p</i><sub>j</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>) = <i>a</i><sub>i</sub>/(<i>n-i</i>) for <i>j</i> = <i>i</i>, … <i>n</i>. Otherwise, all claims larger than <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> are consolidated into one claim <i>C</i><sub>i</sub> = <i>c</i><sub>i</sub><sub>+1</sub> + … + <i>c</i><sub>n</sub> and <i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>) is the payout assigned to claimant #<i>i</i> in the two-person distribution problem for claims <i>c</i><sub>i</sub>, <i>C</i><sub>i</sub> and amount <i>a</i><sub>i</sub>. The fictitious second claimant then receives <i>P</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>) = <i>a</i><sub>i</sub><sub>+1</sub> and the process continues.<br>In the example of the Mishnah, <i>c</i><sub>1</sub> = 100, <i>c</i><sub>2</sub> = 200, <i>c</i><sub>3</sub> = 300. For <i>a</i> = 100, by the first alternative <i>p</i><sub>j</sub>(100) = 100/3 for all <i>j</i>. For <i>a</i> = 200, <i>c</i><sub>1</sub> = 100, <i>C</i><sub>1</sub> = 400. Therefore, 100 is assigned to the second party and 100 is split evenly. This yields <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(200) = 50, <i>P</i><sub>1</sub>(200) = 150. Since 200 &gt; 150, the latter amount is split evenly, resulting in <i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(200) = <i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(200) = 75. For <i>a</i> = 300, one sees that <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(300) = 50, <i>P</i><sub>1</sub>(300) = 250; <i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(300) = 100 = 200/2, <i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(300) = 50 + 200/2 = 150. This explains the numbers stated in the Mishnah, but what about <i>a</i> = 101? In that case, <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(101) = 50, <i>P</i><sub>1</sub>(101) = 51; <i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(101) = <i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(101) = 51/2 = 25.5. This clearly is unacceptable; the procedure of the Mishnah has to be rejected.<br>The explanation of the Yerushalmi (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.4.3">Note 69</a>) is not so clearly stated but it seems to be the following: The procedure also is recursive. If <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> ≥ <i>a</i><sub>i</sub><sub>,</sub><i>p</i><sub>j</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>) = <i>a</i><sub>i</sub>/(<i>n-i</i>) for <i>j</i> = <i>i</i>, … <i>n</i>. Otherwise, one considers all two-person problems between claimants <i>i</i> and <i>i</i>+1,…, <i>n</i>. <i>In praxi</i>, this means that one has only to split between <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>n</sub>. If <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> &lt; <i>a</i><sub>i</sub> &lt; <i>c</i><sub>n</sub> then <i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(a<sub>i</sub>) = <i>c</i><sub>i</sub>/2. If <i>c</i><sub>n</sub> &lt; <i>a</i><sub>i</sub> then write <i>a</i><sub>i</sub> = <i>c</i><sub>n</sub> + δ. Claims <i>n</i> and <i>i</i> overlap to the amount <i>c</i><sub>i</sub> - δ. This means that<br><i>p</i><sub>i</sub>(<i>a</i><sub>i</sub>) = δ + (<i>c</i><sub>i</sub> - δ)/2 = (<i>c</i><sub>i</sub> + δ)/2.<br>For <i>a</i> ≤ <i>M</i>, the numbers obtained for Babli and Yerushalmi coincide; the Yerushalmi’s method also is not monotone. The results for <i>a</i> &gt; <i>M</i> disagree. For example, for the data of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>, the Yerushalmi gives<br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(400)=100, <i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(400)=100, <i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(400)=200 while the Babli gives<br><i>p</i><sub>1</sub>(400)=50, <i>P</i><sub>1</sub>(400)=350; <i>p</i><sub>2</sub>(400)=100, <i>p</i><sub>3</sub>(400)=250.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody was married to three women,” etc. Samuel said, sharpness of the judges<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel seems to indicate that the court has to investigate and choose the method of distribution which seems most appropriate for the case before them, to whom to give real estate and to whom money or securities.<br>The translation of שוחדא is tentative. In the Babli, the word appears as שודא which either is derived from the Aramaic root שדי “to throw” (interpreted to mean that the court may “throw” the properties to the party it feels has the best claim) or it is identical with Galilean שוחדא because of the disappearance of ح in Babylonian speech. I am proposing to derive שוחד̇א from Arabic شحذ “to sharpen (a knife)”, Mishnaic Hebrew שחז.</i>. As in the case of two mortgages written on one field, to whom the court wants to hand it over in possession they hand it over<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">If the field is too small to be useful as property if divided up. The holder of the second mortgage (assuming both were written on the same day) has to be indemnified with money; this is Samuel’s position in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 94a" href="/Ketubot.94a">Babli 94a</a>.</i>. The Mishnah disagrees with Samuel: “If the estate is only 100, they divide equally.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Does this not indicate that all three women have to be treated exactly equally?</i>” Was this said for the sharpness of the judges<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah speaks only about the value, not about the mode of distribution.</i>? And did we not state: If the heirs inherited an instrument of indebtedness, the male firstborn takes a double portion<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Since a documented claim is as good as collected, such a document is counted as ready money, not as future claim (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.3.1">Note 50</a>). In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 124a" href="/Bava_Batra.124a">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 124a</a> and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bekhorot 6:5-9" href="/Tosefta_Bekhorot.6.5-9">Tosephta <i>Bekhorot</i> 6:17</a> the firstborn is given the right to refuse a double portion of secured future claims and then not pay double part of future secured claims against the estate.</i>; and if an instrument of indebtedness was presented to them, the male firstborn pays a double portion. Was this said for the sharpness of the judges<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">This is not a case that allows of judicial discretion.</i>? Rebbi Abin in the name of Samuel: There is no difference, whether two mortgages were written on one field or one mortgage was written on two fields, on whom the court decide they hand it over in possession.
Samuel said, if they empower one another<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">To deal separately with the co-wife claiming the smallest amount. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 93a" href="/Ketubot.93a">Babli, 93a</a>, Samuel explains that the second wife empowered the third to represent her also; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.4.1">Note 62</a>. Unless all parties agree to the procedure, the estate has to be distributed proportional to the claims. It is difficult to see why all parties should agree; the procedure of the Mishnah is eliminated from practical use.</i>. If the third empowered the second to deal with the first. She said to her, is not a mina due to you<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">If the amount available is larger than a mina, the first has to split the mina only with one co-wife.</i>? Take 50 and leave!
“Similarly, if three who invested together lost or gained they would split in this manner.” <sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph has a differently worded parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 4:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.4.1.2-7"><i>Baba qama</i> 4:1</a> (by a different editorial team) which explains the somewhat cryptic wording here:<br>תַּמָּן תְּנִינָן. הָאַחֲרוֹן נוֹטֵל מְנָה וְשֶׁלְּפָנָיו חֲמִשִּׁים זוּז וּשְׁנַיִם הָרִאשׁוֹנִים דִּינָרֵי זָהָב. רִבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בְּשֵׁם רִבִּי זְעֵירָא, וְכֵן לְשָׂכָר. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי. הָדָא דְּרִבִּי זֵירָא פְּלִיגָא עַל דְּרַבִּי לָעָזָר. אָמַר רַבִּי מַנִּי. קַשְׁיָתָהּ קוֹמֵי רְבִּי יוּדָן. אָמַר לִי. לֹא מוֹדֶה רְבִּי לָעָזָר שֶׁאִם הִתְנוּ בֵּינֵיהֶן שֶׁזֶּה נוֹטֵל לְפִי כִּיסוֹ וְזֶה נוֹטֵל לְפִי כִּיסוֹ. שְׁוָרִים כְּמֻתָּנִים הֵן. חָזַר וְאָמְרָה קוֹמֵי רְבִּי יוֹסֵי. אָמַר לֵיהּ. בְּפִירוּשׁ פְּלִיגֵי. רִבִּי לָעָזָר אָמַר. סְתַמָּן חוֹלְקִין בְּשָׁוֶה. רְבִּי זְעֵירָא אָמַר, סְתַמָּן זֶה נוֹטֵל לְפִי כִּיסוֹ וְזֶה נוֹטֵל לְפִי כִּיסוֹ.<br> וְכֵן שְׁלֹשָׁה שֶׁהִיטִּילוּ לַכִּיס פָּחֲתוּ אוֹ הוֹתִירוּ כָּךְ הֵן חוֹלְקִין. אָמַר רִבִּי בּוּן. נִרְאִין דְּבָרִים אִם נָֽטְלוּ מַרְגָּלִית. דְּיָכוֹל מֵימַר לֵיהּ אִילּוּלֵי עֲשַׂרְתָּא דֵינָרַיי לֹא הֲוִיתָה מְזַבִּין כְּלוּן. אֲבָל דָּבָר שֶׁדַּרְכּוֹ לֵחָלֵק מֵבִיאִין לָאֶמְצָע וְחוֹלְקִין. אָמַר רִבִּי לָֽעְזָר וַאֲפִילוּ דָּבָר שֶׁדַּרְכּוֹ לֵחָלֵק. דְּיָכִיל מֵימַר לֵיהּ אַתְּ פְּרַגְמָטַּיָּא דִידָךְ סַגִּין וְאַתְּ מַנְעָא מַזְבִּנְתָּא. אֲנָא פְּרַגְמָטַּיָּא דִידִי קָלִיל וַאֲנַא הֲפַךְ וּמִתְהַפֵּךְ בְּדִידִי וּמַטִּי בָךְ. עַד כְּדוֹן בְּשֶׁהָייְתָה פְּרַגְמָטַּייוֹ נְתוּנָה כָאן. תָֽיְתָה פְּרַגְמָטַּייוֹ נְתוּנָה בְּרוֹמֵי. דְּיָכִיל מֵימַר לֵיהּ. עַד דְּאַתְּ סְלִיק לְרוֹמֵי אֲנַא הֲפַךְ וּמִתְהַפֵּךְ בְּדִידִי וּמַטִּי בָךְ. <br>"Similarly, if three who invested together lost or gained they would split in this manner." Rebbi Abun said, the statement looks reasonable if they bought a precious stone because he can say to him, without my ten denars you could not have bought anything. But anything that usually is split {smaller units that can be bought with less capital) one adds together and splits (proportionally to the capital invested). Rebbi Eleazar says, even things that usually are split [are divided evenly], because he can say to him, you have a lot of merchandise and you have difficulty selling it. 1 have little merchandise and turn it over rapidly and make as much as you do. So far if his merchandise was here. What if his merchandise was in Rome? He can say to him, by the time you went to Rome, I turn mine over rapidly and make as much as you do.<br>There, we have stated: “If [the ox] gored an ox worth 200, the last one takes 100, the one before him 50, and the two first ones a gold denar.” Rebbi Samuel in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira: The same holds for earnings. Rebbi Yose said, the statement of Rebbi Ze‘ira disagrees with Rebbi Eleazar. Rebbi Mani said, <i>I asked this</i> before Rebbi Yudan. <i>He said to me:</i> does Rebbi Eleazar not agree if they contracted between themselves that each can take according to his contribution? Oxen are as if contracted. He turned around and said <i>this before Rebbi Yose, who answered him</i>, they disagree explicitly: Rebbi Eleazar said, if nothing was said, they split evenly; Rebbi Ze‘ira said, if nothing was said, each takes according to his contribution. {This paragraph is a direct quote from <i>Ketubot</i> since the quote from “there” refers to here, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 4:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.4.1.2-7"><i>Baba qama</i> 4:1</a>}.</i> Rebbi Eleazar said: You say that in case the tetradrachma lost or added value. But for earnings or losses they split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Only results of financial operations are split per share. Results of personal effort by the shareholders are split evenly; they are <i>socii</i> <i>pro</i> <i>aequa parte</i> of Justinian’s legislation.</i>. That is difficult! One gave 100 denars and the other gave ten, and you say so? The colleagues say, he may say to him, by my contribution the merchandise rose. So far, if they ran after little merchandise<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Expensive items, as explained in the parallel text.</i>. If there was much merchandise? Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said, he may say to him, by the time you sold one piece, I am selling ten. That is, at a nearby place. If it was far away? Rebbi Hila said, he may say to him, by the time you go and return once, I am going and returning ten times. There<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Baba qama</i> 4:1</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:35" href="/Exodus.21.35"><i>Ex</i>. 21:35</a> decrees that if an ox kills another ox, the owner of the attacking animal and the owner of the victim become co-owners of both the living and the dead animal. If the attacking ox attacks another one before it can be slaughtered, its co-owners now become co-owners with the owner of the second victim. The case quoted in the Mishnah is about an ox worth 200 <i>zuz</i> which attacks three oxen, each of which was worth 200 <i>zuz</i> but whose carcasses are not worth anything after the attack. Then the owner of the ox which was killed last takes half the combined value of the attacker and its victim as prescribed in the verse, 100 <i>zuz</i>. The owner of the second ox has a claim of 50% of the value of the combined value of the attacker and its victim. But since only 100 <i>zuz</i> remain of the value of the attacker and the victim is not worth anything, the second owner gets only 50 <i>zuz</i>. By the same argument, the owner of the first ox gets 25 <i>zuz</i>, the same amount as the owner of the attacker retains.</i>, we have stated: “If [the ox] gored an ox worth 200, the last one takes 100, the one before him 50, and the two first ones a gold denar.” Rebbi Samuel in the name of Rebbi [Ze‘ira]: The same holds for earnings<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ze‘ira interprets the Mishnah in <i>Baba qama</i> that in the company created by the attacking ox, the owner of the third victim contributed 200, the owner of the second 100, the owners of the first and of the attacker 50 each, and 50% of the value was lost as prescribed in the verse. Therefore, the Mishnah precribes proportional appropriations for a case which is not a financial operation; the Mishnah in <i>Ketubot</i> can be interpreted that in a company, all gains and losses have to be distributed in proportion to the capital invested.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the statement of Rebbi Ze‘ira disagrees with Rebbi Eleazar. Rebbi Mana said before Rebbi Yudan: Does Rebbi Eleazar not agree if they contracted between themselves that each can take according to his contribution<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Since in money matters, biblical law is not prescriptive.</i>? Oxen are as if contracted. He turned around and said, they disagree explicitly: Rebbi Eleazar said, if nothing was said, they split evenly; Rebbi Ze‘ira said, if nothing was said, each takes according to his contribution<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Ze‘ira is the later and higher authority, the Yerushalmi decides that all distributions must be proportional. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 93b" href="/Ketubot.93b">Babli, 93b</a>, quotes the opinion attributed here to R. Eleazar in the name of Samuel as interpreted by Rav Hamnuna, it clearly decides that all distributions must be split equally.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to four women when he died, the first one<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The wife whose <i>ketubah</i> is dated earlier.</i> precedes the second<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Since a <i>ketubah</i> is a mortgage lien, the holder of the earlier mortgage has the right to foreclose any real estate before the holder of the later mortgage may foreclose. The rules of this Chapter are in essence rules of privileged creditors in bankruptcy proceedings since they become irrelevant if the estate is large enough to satisfy everybody.</i>, the second the third, and the third the fourth. The first one swears to the second<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">She has to swear that during their husband’s lifetime she did not receive any downpayment on the <i>ketubah</i>, so that she is fully entitled to the sum she is receiving from the executors of the estate. The second wife can demand this oath because every penny the first one receives dimishes her chances of being fully paid by the remaining estate.</i>, the second to the third, and the third to the fourth; the fourth is paid out without an oath<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">No oath is due to any co-wife since all had been paid in full; she might have to swear to the heirs.</i>. Ben Nanas said, should she be preferred because she is the last one? She also should be paid only after an oath<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">There is a possibility that the prior wives might be disadvantaged if the fourth is paid too much: If any <i>ketubah</i> was satisfied by transfer of title of a field that turned out to be mortgaged and was repossessed by the lender, that wife then has regress on the remainder of the estate and, therefore, has a vital interest that the fourth wife not be paid too much. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 94a" href="/Ketubot.94a">Babli, 94a</a>, has some additional reasons for Ben Nanas’s opinion.</i>. If all [<i>ketubot</i>] were executed on the same day, one who precedes another one even if only by an hour has acquired [precedence]; therefore in Jerusalem one used to note hours<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Not only the date but also the hour of the signing of a contract were written into the document.</i>. If [the documents] were all executed at the same hour and there is only one mina, they split evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">As already noted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody was married to four women when he died,” etc. Rebbi Abuna in the name of Rebbi Samuel: Following Ben Nanas, if one document was produced against (the wife) buyers, they all divide evenly<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence makes no sense; the word האשה clearly is wrong. In the absence of parallel sources, the exact wording cannot be reconstrued. The consensus of the commentators is that one must read approximately: “if one document was produced against [several] buyers, they all divide evenly”. The deceased husband had taken a loan which cannot be satisfied by a single property; if the mortgage document is presented after the wives’ <i>ketubot</i> were satisfied, they all have to contribute equally to the satisfaction of the mortgage.<br>Clearly, the title “Rebbi” given to Samuel here is misplaced. A similar statement is attributed to Samuel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 94a" href="/Ketubot.94a">Babli, 94a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This seems to be a scribal error.</i> said before Rebbi Mana: Does this not disagree with Rebbi Samuel, since Samuel said, sharpness of the judges<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel seems to indicate that the court has to investigate and choose the method of distribution which seems most appropriate for the case before them, to whom to give real estate and to whom money or securities.<br>The translation of שוחדא is tentative. In the Babli, the word appears as שודא which either is derived from the Aramaic root שדי “to throw” (interpreted to mean that the court may “throw” the properties to the party it feels has the best claim) or it is identical with Galilean שוחדא because of the disappearance of ح in Babylonian speech. I am proposing to derive שוחד̇א from Arabic شحذ “to sharpen (a knife)”, Mishnaic Hebrew שחז.</i>? As in the case of two mortgages written on one field, to whom they want to hand it over in possession they hand it over<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">If the field is too small to be useful as property if divided up. The holder of the second mortgage (assuming both were written on the same day) has to be indemnified with money; this is Samuel’s position in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 94a" href="/Ketubot.94a">Babli 94a</a>.</i>. And here, he says so<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Should the court not direct the claimant to one field, with the other buyers contributing money?</i>? Not with two mortgages, what about one<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In his opinion, the case of one claimant against multiple owners is not covered by Samuel’s original statement.</i>? He did not hear what Rebbi Abin said in the name of Samuel: There is no difference, whether two mortgages were written on two fields or two mortgages were written on one field<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the deviation of this quote from the original in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 10:3:2-4:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.10.3.2-4.4">Halakhah 4</a> is a scribal error, but this cannot be proved. Samuel’s statement can easily be applied to our case of a single document covering a multiplicity of real estate.</i>, to whom the court decide they hand it over in possession. Rebbi instituted that one follows Ben Nanas in matters of <i>annona</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>annona</i>, the prestations in kind required by the Roman army in the provinces; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.18"><i>Peah</i> 1, Note 85</a>. It is not clear what the relationship is between the statement of Ben Nanas and the collection of taxes. Since the tax was imposed on the community to be repartitioned by the local person responsible, the latter could impose an oath on the tax payer that he declared his situation honestly.</i>, head taxes, and real estate taxes<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἀναφορά “report, listing”. In the opinion of A. Gulak, this is the yearly tax which people paid who had the right to farm imperial domains in perpetuity; cf. S. Lieberman, תוספתא כפשוטה מעשר שני, p. 710.</i>.
As the following<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph refers to the Mishnah which states that the date of a document determines its status in foreclosure proceedings.</i>. Relatives of Rebbi Yose bought fields from the family of Bar Tapqan. Those from the family of Bar Tapqan went and married women, and gave them <i>šeqi‘in</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The word שקיעין as designation of a document appears only in this paragraph. Since שקע means “to sink, to go down”, it is reasonable to assume that שקיעין are mortgages on real estate the usufruct of which is given to the creditor to reduce the amount due and finally to retire the mortgage. This is called מַשְׁכַּנְתָּא דְּסוּרָא“Suran mortgage” in the Babli (<i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 67b, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 110a" href="/Ketubot.110a">110a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 35b" href="/Bava_Batra.35b"><i>Baba batra</i> 35b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 38a" href="/Bava_Batra.38a">38a</a>), and corresponds, in the interest-charging Gentile environment, to the ἀντίχρησις of the Digests (20,1,11,1) and the Egyptian papyri (P. Gron. 11), “substitution of usufruct for interest”.<br>It seems that the men gave their brides documents on the fields they had sold which were predated before the date of the sale.</i>. They came and wanted to attack the relatives of Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">To take the usufruct of the fields for a fixed number of years.</i>. Rebbi Mana said to them: I know that at the moment at which you bought these fields, these <i>šeqi‘in</i> were not before you<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A predated document is invalid.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to two wives when he sold his field and the first wife wrote to the buyers “I have no claims against you”, the second takes from the buyer, the first from the second, and the buyer from the first<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died and his estate did not suffice to satisfy the second wife’s <i>ketubah</i>, she can have regress on the field since she did not sign away her rights. Since the first wife’s <i>ketubah</i> has to be satisfied before the second wife has any claim, the first can take the field which by the action of the second was no longer the buyer’s property but becomes part of the estate. But since the first had given up any claim to that field, the buyer can claim it back from the first. Therefore, all three claimants are forced to agree to a compromise to have <i>any</i> use of the property.</i>; they go on in circles until they compromise between them. The same holds for a creditor<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">If a loan was given in the value of two fields which the borrower then sold, and the creditor wrote to the second buyer that he would not exercise his rights against him; if the loan is foreclosed, the creditor can take the first field; the first buyer can indemnify himself by taking the second field; the creditor can take it from the first buyer but the second buyer can reclaim it from the creditor, etc.</i> and a woman who is a creditor<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">An only wife whose <i>ketubah</i> was secured by two fields which were sold by her husband, and who wrote to the second buyer that she would not exercise her claim against him. In the last two cases it is necessary that the renunciation be for the second buyer since if it were for the first, the second would have no regress on the first.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody was married to two wives,” etc. Rebbi Yose said, this means that if somebody borrowed from two persons and the second comes and says to him, get up and let us settle<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">He realizes that the borrower is not in a position to repay the entire loan. Since his loan is an essentially unsecured second mortgage, he can settle with the borrower to receive part of the mortgaged property. Even if the secured first mortgage giver will in the end foreclose, the second has the usufruct in the meantime and will have saved something.</i>, and [the borrower] says, will not in the end the first hear of it and come to foreclose, he [the second lender] may say let us settle, and if he forecloses, he forecloses. If he settled<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">In the text, either מן is superfluous or a word is missing and it should read מן השני.</i>, one may assume that the first will come and foreclose. If he settled with the first<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The first, secured, mortgage holder settled with the borrower and in the foreclosing took only part of the field while he could have taken all of it. The question now is whether the piece of land is remaining in the borrower’s hand or if it was assumed to be foreclosed and then returned to the borrower. In the second case, the borrower took possession after the date of the second mortgage and the second lender has no regress. In the first case, the second lender may foreclose.</i>, Rebbi Phineas said, such a case came before Rebbi Jeremiah who said, he settled<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The second lender may not foreclose.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, did he not write “what I shall acquire”<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">If the loan contract stipulated that all the borrower’s present and future real estate holdings are mortgaged, there should be no difference in the status of the property left after a compromise with the first mortgage holder.</i>? It happens only with an heir<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">If the future clause really was in the contract, the second mortgage holder can foreclose from the original borrower. But if the borrower died and the heir settled with the holder of the first mortgage, the remaining land was acquired by the heir, not the borrower, and is not subject to the second mortgage.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina said, even with a creditor it can happen if he did not write “anything I shall acquire”, or if he said, “you shall not be paid except from this.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">If the mortgage was written on a specific piece of land, the lender cannot foreclose anything else.</i>” Rav Mattaniah said, this follows him who said, for <i>ketubah</i> but not for stipulations<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The court stipulations required for any <i>ketubah</i> as enumerated in Chapter 4, in particular the “<i>ketubah</i> of male sons”. Whether this stipulation can be satisfied by foreclosure is discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 55a" href="/Ketubot.55a">Babli, 55a</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:5:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.5.2-6">Yerushalmi, <i>Baba batra</i> 8:6</a> (16b 1.23).<br>The answer is positive in the Yerushalmi, negative in the Babli. For the Yerushalmi, the renunciation by the mother of her claim against the buyer is not valid for her heirs; they are free to foreclose in any case.</i>. But for him who said, for <i>ketubah</i> and for stipulations, does it not return?

Chapter 11



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a widow is supported by the orphans’ property<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The widow who chose to be supported by the estate (as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.1">Mishnah 4:12</a>) rather than taking her <i>ketubah</i>.</i>, she has to work for them but they are not obligated to bury her<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If they are not her heirs, she has to keep house for them anyway. The husband whose wife dies before him must bury her since he is the heir of her property. If she died childless after her husband, the heirs of her side of the family have to bury her. Similarly, if she sold her future rights to a <i>ketubah</i> and died after her husband, the speculator who bought her <i>ketubah</i> has to bury her (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.3.1">Note 57</a> and S. Lieberman, תוספתא כפשוטה כתובות p. 329).</i>. Her heirs, the heirs of her <i>ketubah</i>, are obligated to bury her.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a widow is supported by the orphans’ property,” etc. Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">He is the author of the same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96a" href="/Ketubot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>.</i>, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: What she finds belongs to herself. If she had sustenance left over? Since her finds belong to her husband, the married woman’s leftover sustenance belongs to her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65b" href="/Ketubot.65b">Babli, 65b</a>. (In <i>Nazir</i> 24b it is explained that the husband’s property is the household money which she did not spend on food, rather than actual food she saved when being on a diet. The editing of <i>Nazir</i> seemingly is different from that of most Babli Tractates.)</i>. Since a widow’s finds belong to herself, her leftover sustenance belongs to herself. Her worn-out clothing belongs to her<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 65b" href="/Ketubot.65b">Babli, 65b</a>, rejected there.</i>. Since even a married woman, whose leftover sustenance belongs to her husband, keeps her worn-out clothing to herself, the widow, whose leftover food belongs to herself, her worn-out clothing so much more! There, she needs them for the time of her period. Here also, she needs them for the time of her period<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A woman never has worn-out clothes since she always has occasion to wear rags. The Babli rejects this argument since in the absence of her husband she does not need a wardrobe of second rate dresses; she can wear real rags.</i>.
Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: Also she does not perform for them services of intimacy. What are services of intimacy? She rubs their bodies, washes their faces, or mixes their cup<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different list is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96a" href="/Ketubot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>, also in the name of R. Yose ben Ḥanina. It is understood that the heirs have the right to expect from her all services a wife does for her husband, except those that are preliminaries to sexual relations.</i>.
One adds to her sustenance: A married woman has no wine<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:11:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.11.3">Chapter 5, Note 251</a>.</i>, a widow has wine. If a married woman said, my earnings should be counted against my sustenance, one does not listen to her<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">She keeps all of her earnings and the husband does not have to pay for her (he still has to provide for her lodging.) The Babli emphatically permits such an arrangement by the wife’s initiative (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 58b" href="/Ketubot.58b">58b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 70a" href="/Ketubot.70a">70a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 82b" href="/Ketubot.82b">82b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 107b" href="/Ketubot.107b">107b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 40b" href="/Bava_Kamma.40b"><i>Baba qama</i> 40b</a>; <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 49b), i. e., against the husband’s will. Since this is a money matter, the Yerushalmi will accept it in case of mutual agreement.</i>; if a widow said, my earnings should be counted against my sustenance, one listens to her<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Even against the heirs’ opposition.</i>.
Rav said, if a dying person said, do not bury me, he is buried as a charge on public charity. Rebbi Immi asked, how could one think that others are provided for by his property and he is buried as a charge on public charity<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">This is the unanimous opinion of the Babli.</i>? The Mishnah disagrees with Rav: “Her heirs, the heirs of her <i>ketubah</i>, are obligated to bury her.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This is an obligation independent of the wishes of the deceased.</i>” Explain it, if they inherited real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Since usually a <i>ketubah</i> is payable in real estate.</i>. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).9.3">Tosephta 9:3</a>.</i>: “If he left male and female slaves, mortgages, and movables, anybody<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Anybody with a claim sustainable in court, the widow for her <i>ketubah</i> or a creditor.</i> who takes them first acquires them and<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">If nothing is left of his estate.</i> he shall be buried by public charity.” Because he took it first<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If the estate already had disappeared before the burial.</i>. Therefore, if he did not take it first one removes from his hand. Explain it, if he said, bury me<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">If the deceased had requested a burial before he died, the burial expenses are privileged.</i>. As Rebbi Yose said in the name of the rabbis: If a dead person was buried who had not said “bury me”, even though others came and took [of his property] one removes from their hands. If they took real estate. In fact, what you say, one removes from their hands, if they took real estate. But if they took movables, one does not remove from their hands, if it was a loan by witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, time is of the essence since any one of the witnesses could die anytime. But real estate can be foreclosed only by a regular court procedure.</i>. But for a documented loan, whether they took real estate or movables one does not<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that this is a scribal error and one should read: מוציאין “one does remove”. Since the claim is documented, there is no need for the creditor to resort to self-help.</i> remove from their hands. For<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This is an unnecessary word; R. Abba explains general principles about the legal standing of death-bed requests.</i> Rebbi Abba, the son of Rav Huna, said<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 152a" href="/Bava_Batra.152a">Babli (<i>Baba batra</i> 152a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 175a" href="/Bava_Batra.175a">175a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 13a" href="/Gittin.13a"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 13a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 15a" href="/Gittin.15a">15a</a>) this is an undisputed statement of Rav Naḥman.</i>: They made the words of a bedridden person equal to those of a healthy person who wrote and delivered<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The legal forms of a valid gift.</i>. But only if he died from that illness, not if he recovered. And if he was explicit and said, give field X to Y. If he said, give field X to Y<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that one has to read: Give field X to Y and Z. It is understood that each one gets half a field but the method of subdivision of the field was not indicated.</i>? Is it as if he was explicit or only if he said, the Northern half, the Southern half?<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">No answer is given since it is clear that the bequest cannot be enforced against the legal heirs; the burden of proof being on the claimants, who would have to prove in court that the method of division is that intended by the donor; this is impossible after the latter’s death.</i> Rebbi Yudan asked: If he said, burn me by pagan rites and give half of field X to Y. Since they do not burn, do they give?<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Since the first half of the request is clearly illegal, can the second half be legal?</i> Rebbi Ḥaggai asked: A sick person who said, my daughters shall be supported. Would the daughters not be supported anyway<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Since daughters’ right to sustenance is a standard condition of the <i>ketubah</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:11</a>), what did the mention of the daughters add to their rights?</i>? No, it is necessary, for otherwise would they be supported from pledged real estate or would they be supported from movables<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">At places where the <i>ketubah</i> could be taken only in real estate, the daughters could be supported only by real estate.</i>? Rebbi Yudan [ ]<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The words בָּרַח לְנוֹי “he fled to beauty” do not make sense here.</i> there came a case before Rebbi Yose about a bedridden person who had said, my documents shall be given to X. He said to him, the bedridden can only transfer property which is acquired either by a document <i>or</i> by taking hold<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">By bodily possession.</i>. But these are acquired by a document <i>and</i> by taking hold. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kiddushin (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Kiddushin_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:7</a>.</i>: “A ship is acquired by taking hold in the opinion of everybody. Rebbi Nathan says a ship and documents are acquired by a document <i>and</i> by taking hold. <sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This last sentence is not in the Tosephta or in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 76a" href="/Bava_Batra.76a">Babli (<i>Baba batra</i>76a</a>); R. Yose’s ruling is rejected by Rav Naḥman (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.1.5">Note 22</a>) who validates the transfer of documents by death-bed declaration.</i> If he wrote and did not take hold, or took hold without writing [a transfer document] he did not do anything unless he both writes and takes hold.”

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A widow, whether after preliminary or definitive marriage, may sell without court supervision<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The woman who becomes a widow before her definitive wedding may have a claim to <i>ketubah</i>; the widow after definitive marriage has a choice of either taking her <i>ketubah</i> or being sustained by the estate. Both Talmudim explain that nobody will want his family’s honor compromised by forcing his widow into court; therefore, it is understood that he wrote the <i>ketubah</i> with the idea that it should be liquidated, if possible, in private.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, after definitive marriage she may sell without court supervision; after preliminary marriage, she may sell only under court supervision since she has no sustenance and any person who has no claim to sustenance may sell only under court supervision.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A widow, whether after preliminary or definitive marriage,” etc. Rebbi Simeon is of the opinion that everything depends on sustenance. If he had agreed to sustain her after preliminary marriage, she may sell without court supervision If he had agreed to sustain her after definitive marriage, she may sell only under court supervision<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If she is widowed before definitive marriage.</i>. The words of the Sages? Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥinena in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: A person is concerned for his widow’s dignity<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">That she should not have to appear before an all-male court. This is also R. Joḥanan’s opinion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 97b" href="/Ketubot.97b">Babli, 97b</a>, where it is not the only explanation.</i> whether after preliminary or after definitive marriage.
Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel: The one who renounced her <i>ketubah</i> in favor of the orphans is sustained by them. This is difficult. If there were a woman without <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Cf <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.2.1">Mishnah 5:2</a>; it is a matter of dispute whether a woman may donate her <i>ketubah</i> to her husband.</i>, does she not have claim to sustenance? A woman without <i>ketubah</i> has claim to sustenance<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is entitled to sustenance for the work she does in keeping house. The problem could not arise before the husband’s death (hinted at in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 53a" href="/Ketubot.53a">Babli 53a</a>).<br>Many commentators want to emend the text; these emendations have to be rejected since the text as it stands is quoted in <i>Sefer Ha‘iṭṭur</i> vol. 2, 32d, at <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.1.5">Note 23</a>.</i>. But here is it not enough that she renounced her <i>ketubah</i> in favor of the orphans, that you want to cheat her of her sustenance?
Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 54a" href="/Ketubot.54a">Babli (<i>Ketubot</i> 54a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 25a" href="/Gittin.25a"><i>Giṭṭin</i>25a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 22a" href="/Arakhin.22a"><i>Arakhin</i> 22a</a>): Samuel.</i>: If she requested her <i>ketubah</i> in court<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Not if the request is made in private.</i>, she lost her claim to sustenance<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow is entitled either to be paid her <i>ketubah</i> or to be sustained by the estate.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, but only from a clear mind; not if forced. As in the case of the widow of Rebbi Eudaimon from Mozva to whom they<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The heirs informed her falsely that a rabbi of reputation wanted to marry her.</i> said, Rebbi Abba bar Cohen wants you. She requested her <i>ketubah</i> and lost her sustenance. After the matter became known<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Fraudulent information by an interested party is counted as forced deal for the victim.</i>, it was brought before Rebbi Yose and she returned to her sustenance.
Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Zimra: A widow who lived two or three months without asking for sustenance, loses the sustenance of these three months<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 97a" href="/Ketubot.97a">Babli, 97a</a>, “two or three years”.</i>. That is, if she did not take a loan. But if she took out a loan, she collects. If there is no pledge in her hand. But if she has a pledge in her hand, she collects even if she did not take a loan<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Any action she takes earlier to show that she is aware of her claim validates the claim later.</i>. Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: That is what they said, at the start one sells for sustenance of twelve months but one gives her sustenance for 30 days<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">If the widow goes to court to sell from the estate’s real estate, it cannot be sold in small portions. One therefore sells to cover her sustenance for twelve months but the moneys are delivered to her in monthly installments since, as explained in the next paragraph, money delivered to the widow for her sustenance cannot be taken back (even if she remarries).<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 97a" href="/Ketubot.97a">Babli, 97a</a>, the time frame for which one sells is a matter of dispute.</i>. If at the end of thirty days they say, we gave, but she says, I did not receive<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Who carries the burden of proof? Is it the widow because she is the claimant, or is the <i>ketubah</i> considered as if collected in the widow’s hand and the heirs want to deprive her of it and have to bring proof?</i>, it would be similar to what Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If one took a loan of 12’000 for a year in order to repay one gold denar<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Under the Augustan monetary system, a gold denar was worth 25 silver denars. The present statement must have been formulated during the inflation of the Military Anarchy when the debased “silver” denars had even lost their name. In <i>Ma‘aśer Šeni</i> 4:1 (Notes 23, 24) there is mention of an <i>aureus</i> worth 2’000. Cf. D. Sperber, <i>Roman Palestine</i>200–400<i>, Money &amp; Prices,</i> 1974, Chapter II.</i> per month. It is obvious that he gave for the first month<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Since this was due at the beginning of the contract, it may be presumed that payment was made. In this case, the burden of proof is on the recipient.</i> and did not give for the last<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since nobody can be presumed to pay before due date; if the payor claims to have paid before that day, the burden of proof is on him.</i>. About the days in between they said, not at the start<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">While in general in disputes about the fulfillment of contracts the burden of proof is on the claimant, in matters of payments to the widow the burden of proof is on the payor except for the first installment.</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu quoted in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted in the preceding paragraph in the name of R. Yasa, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.2.5">Note 45</a>. אתא here corresponds to גופא in the Babli as back reference.</i>: At the start one sells for sustenance of twelve months but one gives her sustenance for 30 days. Why should they sell for the sustenance of 12 months? Not to disadvantage the woman<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">She does not have to run after her sustenance every month.</i>. Why do they give her sustenance for 30 days? If you said otherwise, you would act in detriment of the orphans, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96a" href="/Ketubot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>.</i>: If a widow took possession even of 1’000 <i>zuz</i> for her sustenance, one does not take it away from her. What could one say to her? “Show<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Reading הוי as equivalent of Babylonian חוי.</i> what is in your hands!<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">One might think that she can collect for next month’s sustenance only after having accounted for the expenses of the past, reducing next month’s payment by the amount not spent in the preceding.</i>” The students of Rebbi Mana said to her, “show what is in your hands.” Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to them, since in the end she will have to swear about anything in her hands<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">If in the end she decides to take her <i>ketubah,</i> she has to deliver an accounting about any estate property in her hands.</i>, one says to her, let it be so.

Halakhah 3
