<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she sold<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">She sells her future right to the sum promised her in the <i>ketubah</i> to a speculator who assumes the risk that she might die before her husband and the <i>ketubah</i> become void.</i> her <i>ketubah</i> entirely or partially, or donated her <i>ketubah</i> to another, entirely or partially, she cannot sell the remainder except under court supervision<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">This belongs to R. Simeon’s statement from the preceding Mishnah.</i>. But the Sages say, she may sell even four or five times<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">She may sell small portions of the <i>ketubah</i> without damaging her powers.</i>, and may sell for sustenance without court supervision but writes in the document that “I sold for sustenance.” A divorcee may sell only under court supervision<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The divorcee can sell her former husband’s property only if he sent her the bill of divorce from far away. In that case, the court supervision is justified to preserve the estate.<br>The Babli explains that the husband does not care if his divorcee has to apply to the court to collect her dues. The Yerushalmi rejects this argument in the second paragraph.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she sold her <i>ketubah</i> entirely or partially,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 11:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).11.1">Tosephta 11:1</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 96b" href="/Ketubot.96b">Babli 96b</a>.</i>: “She sells and writes ‘this I sold for <i>ketubah</i>’ and ‘this I sold for sustenance,’ the words of Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Yose said, she sells and writes non-specifically; in this she is empowered.” If a loan before witnesses [comes due], she says, I sold for sustenance<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If the loan was executed after the date of her marriage, she can claim that the real estate is mortgaged to her <i>ketubah.</i> If there is no unincumbered real estate, the creditor is prevented from foreclosing. A verbal loan executed before witnesses cannot be used to foreclose property sold after the loan was made.</i>. If a loan by contract [comes due], she says, I sold for my <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">If no real estate is left in the estate, the creditor cannot foreclose from the buyers if his contract was dated later than her <i>ketubah.</i></i>. And even if a loan before witnesses [comes due], she sells for sustenance and turns around and forecloses it for her <i>ketubah</i>; could one not say to her, show your sale<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">In the first case (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.3.2">Note 62</a>), could not the amount of the sale and its circumstances inform a competent appraiser whether it was for sustenance or <i>ketubah</i>? Since a sale for sustenance is a sale on credit, to be paid over a 12 months’ period, should it not bring a premium price?</i>? Explain it, if the object increased in value<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">And today it is impossible to determine the fair value at the time of sale.</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Just as a man is concerned about his widow’s honor so he has to be concerned about his divorcee’s honor<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This disagrees with the Mishnah.</i>, as <sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">From here on, more wordy parallels are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 17:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.17.3"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 17(3</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 34:14" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.34.14"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 34(14</a>); <i>Yalqut Šim‘oni Torah</i> #23, 665, <i>Is.</i> #492; it is hinted at in <i>Tanna dBe Eliahu rabba</i> 27.</i> Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, “do not hide yourself from your flesh”<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 58:7" href="/Isaiah.58.7"><i>Is.</i> 58:7</a>.</i>, that refers to one’s divorcee. Rebbi Yose the Galilean’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Gen. rabba</i> she is referred to as his niece, his sister’s daughter, whom to marry is considered meritorious by Pharisees based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 58:7" href="/Isaiah.58.7"><i>Is.</i> 58:7</a> (but sinful by Sadducees, <i>CD</i> V 7–10).</i> did mistreat him badly. Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah went to him and told him, rabbi, send her away, for she does not treat you with the honor due to you. He said to him, her <i>ketubah</i> is too large for me. He said to him, I shall give you the <i>ketubah</i> and send her away. He gave him the <i>ketubah</i> and he divorced her. She went and married the city treasurer<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Musaphia identifies the word טסורא with Greek θησαυριστής “collector”. The parallel words in the Midrashim seem to be corrupted.</i>. That one lost his property and became blind. She took him around the town and led him. Once they went around the entire town and nobody gave him anything. He said to her, is there not another neighborhood? She said to him, there is the neighborhood of my divorcer; it is beyond my powers to bring you there. He started hitting her. Rebbi Yose the Galilean passed by and heard them demeaning one another in public. He took them, brought them to one of his houses, and provided them with food all the days of their lives, because “do not hide yourself from your flesh”, that refers to one’s divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Here end the parallels.</i>. Nevertheless they quarelled loudly in the night and her voice was heard saying, the pain she suffered outside her body was easier to bear than that inside her body<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">She preferred being beaten by her current husband to the mental pain inflicted on her by her ex-husband’s generosity</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a widow’s <i>ketubah</i> was 200 and she sold<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">She sold her husband’s property not under the supervision of the court.</i> either the worth of a mina for 200<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">She received what was due her.</i> or the worth of 200 for a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">It is her fault if she had sold too cheaply; from the estate she received real estate in the valuie of her <i>ketubah.</i> While she was within her rights to sell the property, she could have chosen the process of judicial appraisal which would have shielded her against any claims by the heirs or their guardians.</i>, her <i>ketubah</i> was paid. If her <i>ketubah</i> was for a mina and she sold the worth of a mina and a denar for a mina, her sale is void<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Since she had the right only to sell for the payment of her <i>ketubah</i>, any excess is an unauthorized sale and invalidates the entire transaction.</i>. Even if she says, I shall return the denar to the heirs, her sale is void<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">An unauthorized transaction cannot be validated after the fact.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a widow’s <i>ketubah</i> was 200,” etc. We understand worth a mina for 200<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 98" href="/Ketubot.98">Babli, 98</a> ab, does not hold that it is trivial that the widow is not rewarded for getting such a good deal; it concludes that an agent by his office is always required to look for the best possible deal and the widow sells as an agent for the estate.</i> or worth 200 for a mina. In any case, she made the orphans lose a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">That she receives only 100 <i>zuz</i> for her <i>ketubah</i> if she sells real estate too cheaply is not a matter of the laws of <i>ketubah</i> but of torts in general; the person who causes damage has to pay for it.</i>. [If it was worth] a mina [and she sold it] for 200, would the sale not be invalidated as erroneous buy<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:14" href="/Leviticus.25.14"><i>Lev</i>. 25:14</a>: “If you sell a sale to you neighbor or buy from your neighbor’s hand, do not overcharge one another.” Rabbinic interpretation holds that an overcharge of a sixth, 16<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>/<sub>3</sub>%, entitles the injured party to rescind the transaction.</i>? Explain it that the property increased in value<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">And the fair value on the date of transaction can no longer be determined.</i>. Rebbi Abin said, this supports Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, since Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, real estate buys are never under the laws of overcharging. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if the transaction was excessive, it comes under the law of overcharging. The Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 4:9.</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “The following do not fall under the laws of overcharging: Slaves, securities, real estate, and redemptions<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate is excluded in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:14" href="/Leviticus.25.14"><i>Lev</i>. 25:14</a> since it is not bought “from his hand”; slaves are excluded since they are traded under the rules of real estate; securities are excluded since what one buys “from the neighbor’s hand” is the paper, but what is intended are the rights given by the paper and these are immaterial. The Temple is excluded in its transactions since it is not “a neighbor” (Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i>56b).</i>.” He explains it, unless it was excessive<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that any transaction is void in which the profit margin is 100% of the fair value. Tosaphot (<i>s. v</i>. ,אלמנה 98a) find the same opinion expressed by Rav Naḥman in the Babli, <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 57a.</i>. If he redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">He had donated something (other than a sacrificial animal) to the Temple. The redemption rules are based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:11-25" href="/Leviticus.27.11-25"><i>Lev</i>. 27:11–25</a>.</i> what was worth a mina by 200, Rebbi Joḥanan said, it is not redeemed, but Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it is redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The standard commentators agree to switch the places of “mina” and “200 <i>zuz</i>”. Since the Yerushalmi never quotes Samuel’s statement in the Babli (<i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 57a and 7 other instances) that a redemption of dedicated items worth a mina by a <i>peruṭa</i> is valid (i. e., in ratio 19200: 1), there is no reason to assume that there should be any difference in the rulesfor overpaying or underpaying.</i>. A <i>baralta</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: If he said, this toga instead of this donkey, the latter becomes profane<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">He substitutes a toga for the dedicated donkey (which is redeemable since it is not a sacrificial animal) and presumably the donkey is worth at least two togas.</i>. And its end disagrees with Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: It is necessary to compute the value<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">It is a biblical requirement that dedications can be redeemed only after their value has been determined (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:12" href="/Leviticus.27.12"><i>Lev</i>. 27:12</a>). The presumption is that the statement means not only that the value has to be determined but also that it has to be paid in full.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the <i>baraita</i> itself implies that it is necessary to compute the value. Where do they disagree? To bring [a sacrifice to atone for] larceny<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Unauthorized use of Temple property is sinful and has to be atoned for by a special sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14-16" href="/Leviticus.5.14-16"><i>Lev</i>. 5:14–16</a>). If the redemption of the donkey was valid, no sacrifice is due for using the donkey even if there remains the additional obligation to make up the difference in price between toga and donkey. If the redemption is invalid because the difference in price between the dedicated and the substitute values is too large, a sacrifice is due. The Babli, <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i>57a/b, is not quite sure to whom to attribute which opinion in this dispute.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he has to bring a sacrifice for larceny; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, he does not have to bring a sacrifice for larceny.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, her sale is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah is the direct continuation of the preceding one; in most Mishnah mss. it is part of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel holds that the sale, about which the heirs claim that the widow sold too cheaply, is valid if the field which would have remained in the heirs’ hands would not have qualified as an independent piece of agricultural real estate. Mishnah <i>Baba batra</i> 1:10 gives minimal measures for different kinds of real estate; if these measures are not reached, the real estate cannot be subdivided. Therefore, if the parcel, which the heirs claim should not have been sold, would be one that could not be sold under the rules of <i>Baba batra</i>, the widow cannot be faulted if she gave it away essentially for free; it is not a case of over- or undercharging.</i> unless there would have been left a field [for sowing] nine <i>qab</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">The standard unit for agricultural land is <i>bet se’ah</i>, a plot of land on which in normal practice of extensive agriculture one would sow one <i>se’ah</i> of seed grain, which by tradition is fixed at 2500 square cubits (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 2:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.2.1.9"><i>Peah</i> 2:1, Note 31</a>). One <i>se’ah</i> equals 6 <i>qab</i>; the field of 9 <i>qab</i> then is 3750 square cubits. In the opinion of R. Jehudah, half of this area is a tradeable field.</i>, and in a garden<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">A garden is intensively worked, irrigated property. The area for half a <i>qab</i> would then be 2500:12 = 208 1/3 square cubits, and a quarter <i>qab</i> 104 1/6.</i> half a <i>qab</i>, or following the words of Rebbi Aqiba, a fourth. If her <i>ketubah</i> was 400 <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence refers back to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>, and is not only Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s. If one of several connected transactions is declared invalid, the others are not affected.</i> and she sold to one person worth 100, to a second 100, to a third 100, and to the last the value of a mina and a denar for a mina, the last transaction is invalid but all others are valid.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, her sale is valid,” etc. That is, if she sold them in four contracts<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah deals only with the last case mentioned in the Mishnah, that the widow overstepped her authority only in part of the sale of property. If the legal and illegal contracts were executed separately, there is no reason to invalidate the earlier contracts because of the (necessarily last) invalid contract.</i>. If she sold them in one contract, there is disagreement between Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, as they disagreed<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The same text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.1.2-11"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:1</a> (43a 1. 54) <b>גי</b> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Makkot 1:7:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Makkot.1.7.3"><i>Makkot</i> 1:16</a> (31b 1. 26) <b>מ</b>; it is quoted in Alfasi <i>Makkot</i> 1, #1063 and discussed by his commentators R. Nissim Gerondi and Naḥmanides.</i>: If somebody wrote all his property over to two persons in one document<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">His will.</i> and the testimony of the witnesses was valid for one but invalid for the other<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Relatives are not admitted as witnesses even in civil proceedings.</i>. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Yasa: Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagreed; one said, since it is invalid for one it is invalid for the other, but the other said, it is valid for one and invalid for the other. Rebbi Mana did not specify; Rebbi Abin specified: Rebbi Joḥanan said, since it is invalid for one it is invalid for the other<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that testimony, even if in writing, is one whole; either it is valid or invalid. If it is invalid in one case, it must be invalid in general.</i>; but Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it is valid for one and invalid for the other<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The testimony has to be separated from its application. If the witnesses are known not to be felons, their testimony is valid. In the case of a relative, it is not applicable.</i>. Rebbi Elazar said, a Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Makkot</i> 1:12. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:6" href="/Deuteronomy.17.6"><i>Deut</i>. 17:6</a> reads: “By the testimony of two witnesses or three witnesses the guilty person shall be condemned to death; he cannot be condemned by the testimony of a single witness.” The question is raised, if two witnesses are sufficient, why are three mentioned? The answer given in the Mishnah is that since two witnesses are both disqualified if one of them is disqualified (in which case the remaining witness becomes a single witness), a group of three (or 100) witnesses who all testify to exactly the same effect is disqualified if one of them is disqualified. The witnesses signing a document necessarily all testify to exactly the same facts. (Alfassi #1062 notes that the Geonim restrict the Mishnah to criminal cases.)</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: “Since testimony of two [witnesses] is invalid if one of them turns out to be related or disqualified, so also of three [witnesses] it is invalid if one of them turns out to be related or disqualified. From where even 100? The verse<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:6" href="/Deuteronomy.17.6"><i>Deut</i>. 17:6</a>.</i> says, ‘witnesses’”. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, Rebbi Ḥananiah the colleague of the rabbis and the rabbis disagree. One says, the argument of Rebbi Eleazar is correct, but the other says, the argument of Rebbi Eleazar is not correct. For him who says, the argument of Rebbi Eleazar is correct, it is as if there was one testimony about one person. For him who says, the argument of Rebbi Eleazar is not correct, it is as if two groups of witnesses came, valid for one and disqualified for the other<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Since practice is not decided either way, the legal heirs can successfully attack the validity of the will, and the guardians of the orphans the validity of the entire sale by the widow.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the judges estimated one sixth too little or too much, their sale is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since any overcharging of at least one sixth empowers the injured party to annul the transaction.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, their sale is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">If they followed the rules of public sales detailed in Tractate <i>Arakhin</i>.</i>; otherwise, what is the court’s power worth? But if they offered public tender<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">They made a written public announcement of a public sale and invited tenders and then sold to the highest bidder. The actual bids received are the best estimate of the value of real estate and override expert testimony as to the intrinsic value of the land.<br>Following Rashi, אִיגֶּרֶת בִּיקּוּרֶת is a circular inviting people to visit (בִּיקּוּר) the property and make their offers.</i>, even if they sold either the worth of a mina for 200 or the worth of 200 for a mina, their sale is valid.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the judges estimated one sixth too little or too much,” etc. As you say for a private person, in real estate up to one third<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan was reported to say in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.4.2">Halakhah 4</a> that in real estate the deviation must be 100%. This is interpreted here to mean than the overcharge cannot be more than 100% of the undercharge, 150% <i>vs</i>. 50%, giving a ratio of 3 to 1 (<i>Pnei Mosheh</i>)..</i>, in movables up to one sixth<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:14" href="/Leviticus.25.14"><i>Lev</i>. 25:14</a>: “If you sell a sale to you neighbor or buy from your neighbor’s hand, do not overcharge one another.” Rabbinic interpretation holds that an overcharge of a sixth, 16<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>/<sub>3</sub>%, entitles the injured party to rescind the transaction.</i>. And similarly, for Temple property, in real estate up to one sixth, in movables up to [one in] twelve<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">For redemption of property dedicated to the Temple, all terms are halved or doubled to the advantage of the Temple as exemplified in the Mishnah, next Note.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Arakhin 6:1" href="/Mishnah_Arakhin.6.1"><i>Arakhin</i> 6:1</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 11:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).11.3">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 11:3</a>.</i>, we have stated: “The estimation for orphans is thirty days, the estimation for Temple property sixty days, and one publicly announces mornings and evenings<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The court’s herald announces the sale twice daily in public.</i>.” And why thirty? In order to empower the orphans. Why should they not announce longer? Up to thirty days you empower the orphans, more than that you diminish their power<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">In less than 30 days one is not sure that all potential buyers hear of the sale; a shorter period would diminish the number of bidders. If the process is drawn out too long, people lose interest and one diminishes the number of buyers.</i>. Why do you not say that for Temple property? Temple property is different because each offer made is firm<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Each offer made to the Temple administration obliges the bidder to act on his bid until he is notified that he was released from his obligation because a higher bid was accepted. The Temple does not have to worry that it would lose bidders in a drawn out process.</i>. Then they should announce forever! If suffices for the Temple that it should be twice that of a private person. Rebbi Yudan said, since you say that Temple property is different because each offer made is firm, this implies that if they find their estimation they do not continue but close the deal<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">If the administration had decided on an adequate price, the first bidder meeting this price can immediately be given possession and the public announcements stopped, since the Temple will get its full price. The sixty day period is a possibility, not a necessity.</i>.
“And one announces mornings and evenings,” at the time when [agricultural] workers go out or come back, and he mentions the field and its description<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 21b" href="/Arakhin.21b">Babli <i>Arakhin</i> 21b</a>. As explained there, the landlord can then tell his workers to look up the property offered and to report back in the evening.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, if they do not get their estimated price<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">After the 30 days of public announcement. (The Babli in the end substitutes 8 weeks of announcement on market days for the 30 days of daily announcement.)</i>, they can conclude the sale. Is that the Mishnah, “if the judges estimated one sixth too little or too much, their sale is invalid”? Becausethey sold too low or too high, but if they found their estimate they close the deal<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Even before the 30 days are up.</i>. Rebbi Ḥananiah said before Rebbi Mana: What can you say, we deal with the case that they did not announce in public<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The disagreement between the rabbis and Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel is only in the absence of a public tender.</i>! From what is said afterwards: “Except if they offered public tender.” What is public tender? Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi said, announcement<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted by Rashi in his commentary to the Mishnah.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:4:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.4.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 4:4</a> (75b 1. 22), noted <b>מ</b>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:36-45" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.36-45"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:3</a> (19b 1.6), noted <b>ס</b>.The origin is in <i>Sanhedrin</i> since only there one finds the <i>baraita</i> which is explained by Ulla: “The following are not subject to public tender: Slaves, securities, and movables.”</i> Ulla bar Ismael said, slaves lest they flee, securities and movables lest they be stolen<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Since the owner has to be mentioned, thieves would be informed that it is worth while to break into that house.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Cohen asked before Rebbi Yose: Does this not imply that a slave is redeemed in front of three people<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">If a slave was dedicated to the Temple and then redeemed by his owner, this should be a private procedure.</i>? He answered him, yes. He said to him, but did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:1-4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.1-4.2">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:3</a>, determining the number of jurors in judicial cases.</i>: “Real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate dedicated to the Temple and redeemed following the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:22-23" href="/Leviticus.27.22-23"><i>Lev</i>. 27:22–23</a>.</i> nine persons and a Cohen, and a human<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">A person who dedicates his own worth and finds it impossible to give the prescribed value; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:8" href="/Leviticus.27.8"><i>Lev</i>. 27:8</a>. In both cases, the Cohen’s determination has to be made in public; the definition of “public knowledge” is “known by at least 10 people.”</i> by the same rule”? He answered him, the human here is a free person.
<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">With slight changes in names this is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 100a" href="/Ketubot.100a">Babli, 100a</a>.</i>Ḥananiah bar Šelemiah in the name of Rav: A case came before Rebbi, who wanted to act following the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">A case was appealed to him, in which the local court had sold property, deviating more than a sixth from the appraised value. He wanted to annul the sale.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar ben Proteus, the grandson of Rebbi Eleazar ben Proteus<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Who can be dated to the first half of the Second Century.</i>, said to him: Did you not teach us in your old man’s<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">For זקיניך as “your father” cf. S. Lieberman, תיקוני ירושלמי <i>Tarbiẓ</i> 4(1933), p. 378.</i> name, “except if they offered public tender”<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In this interpretation, the last sentence of the Mishnah is Rabban Simeon’s and is disputed by the rabbis. This disagrees with the findings above, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.6.3">Note 116</a>. In the Babli, the entire case dealt with a sale without public announcement which Rebbi refrained from annulling.</i>? He accepted it; Rebbi changed his mind and acted following Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Neither the orphan<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The orphaned underage girl who was married off by her mother or brothers, who repudiated her husband before reaching adulthood (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:2, Note 118</a>). By walking out, she (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:4:1-5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.4.1-5.2"><i>Yebamot</i> Mishnah 13:4</a>).<br>In all Babli mss. and in all Mishnah mss. of the Babylonian tradition, instead of “the orphan” one reads outright הַמְמָאֵנֶת “the repudiating”. Cf. <i>The Babylonian Talmud with Variant Readings, Kethuboth II</i>, p. תיד, Note 59. The Yerushalmi version must have been the original one since the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 100b" href="/Ketubot.100b">Babli, 100b</a>, discusses whether the Mishnah implies that no minor can claim a <i>ketubah</i>.</i>, nor the secondarily prohibited<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">She is her husband’s relative but not a close one; her marriage is valid by biblical standards but considered incestuous by rabbinical rules; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i>2:4, Note 67</a>. But since the marriage is valid by biblical standards, her children are not bastards. She is denied a <i>ketubah</i> in order to induce her to refuse the marriage from the start.</i>, nor the she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The infertile female who lacks secondary female sex characteristics; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:1, Note 65</a>. If she was married underage and failed to become an adult physically, the husband may claim that he entered the marriage thinking that she was fully female and that, therefore, the marriage transaction was in error and invalid.</i> may claim <i>ketubah</i>, or usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">The husband does not have to return the usufruct he had from her dowry during the existence of the marriage.</i>, or sustenance, or depreciation<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">He is not responsible to replace depreciated goods brought as her dowry.</i>. But if he married her from the start as a she-ram, she has claim to her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Not only <i>ketubah</i>, but all other payments due to the divorcee or widow, since the marriage certainly was valid.</i>. A widow [married] to the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The High Priest is forbidden to marry her (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>); she is not forbidden to marry him but she is barred from eating sanctified food and her children are desecrated from the priesthood. By biblical decree, she and her children are desecrated. This is punishment. Her marriage is biblically valid; there is no rabbinic reason to deny her the <i>ketubah</i> and the benefits accruing automatically to a wife.</i>, a divorcee or one who had received <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to a common priest<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">He is forbidden to marry her (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>); she is not forbidden to marry him but she is barred from eating sanctified food and her children are desecrated from the priesthood.</i>, a bastard or Gibeonite girl to an Israel, an Israel girl married to a bastard or Gibeonite<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The bastard is forbidden by biblical law to marry an Israelite girl (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3"><i>Deut</i>. 23:3</a>, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.5.2"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:5 Note 176</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:8:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.8.15">4:15 Note 211</a>), the Gibeonite by an old popular tradition ascribed to King David (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4, Note 72</a>). By <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:14</a>, in both cases the children inherit the status of the partner with the lower status.</i>, have claim to <i>ketubah</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Neither the orphan girl, nor the secondarily prohibited, nor the she-ram,” etc. One understands the secondarily prohibited and the she-ram. The orphan? Does an orphan not have <i>ketubah</i>? Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi J̣oḥanan: Explain it for an orphan who repudiated<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The orphaned underage girl who was married off by her mother or brothers, who repudiated her husband before reaching adulthood (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.1"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:2, Note 118</a>). By walking out, she (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:4:1-5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.4.1-5.2"><i>Yebamot</i> Mishnah 13:4</a>).<br>In all Babli mss. and in all Mishnah mss. of the Babylonian tradition, instead of “the orphan” one reads outright הַמְמָאֵנֶת “the repudiating”. Cf. <i>The Babylonian Talmud with Variant Readings, Kethuboth II</i>, p. תיד, Note 59. The Yerushalmi version must have been the original one since the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 100b" href="/Ketubot.100b">Babli, 100b</a>, discusses whether the Mishnah implies that no minor can claim a <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. Rebbi Ayvo bar Naggari, Rebbi Immi: Just as they fined her, so they fined him. In which respect? That if he preliminarily married her by [giving her] a pound of gold, he loses it all.
<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, this is Halakhah <i>Yebamot</i> 9:4, variant readings noted <b>י</b>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:1:5-2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.1.5-2.6">Notes 31–53</a>.</i>“No usufruct.” Rebbi Jeremiah said, that he has from her only the usufruct. Rebbi Yose the Sidonian stated before Rebbi Jeremiah, in disgreement with Rebbi Jeremiah: “He has the right to what she finds and earns, and to dissolve her vows.” What means “no usufruct”? That she cannot reclaim from him the usufruct he had [from her property].
Rebbi Yose said: All the time my teacher Rebbi Hila told me, state in your <i>baraita</i> that he inherits from her and defiles himself for her. We have also stated so: A man defiles himself for his qualified wife but does not become defiled for his disqualified wife.
Rebbi Reuben asked before Rebbi Mana: May the slaves of a secondarily forbidden [wife] eat heave? He said to him, be quiet, it is better for you. She eats but her slaves do not eat.
There, we have stated: “A forced bill of divorce is valid in Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The heirs informed her falsely that a rabbi of reputation wanted to marry her.</i>; it is invalid from Gentiles.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Fraudulent information by an interested party is counted as forced deal for the victim.</i>” Samuel said, it is invalid and disqualifies for the priesthood. Samuel said, one does not force, only disqualify. Samuel said, one does not force except for example a widow married to a High Priest, a divorcee or one freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a simple priest. But did we not state: “Secondarily forbidden”? Did he not say “for example”? But did we not state: “A person who by a vow forbids his wife to have any usufruct from him, up to 30 days he shall appoint a caretaker; after 30 days he shall divorce her and pay <i>ketubah</i>”! We heard that he shall divorce; did we hear that one forces him?
What is the difference between these and those? Since these are words of the Torah and the words of the Torah [do not]<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in <i>Ketubot</i>; considered a scribal error since it is implied by the later quote.</i> need support, therefore they have <i>ketubah</i>. Those, because they are words of the Sopherim and the words of the Sopherim need support, therefore they do not have <i>ketubah</i>. Some want to say since these are punished together with the child, they did not fine them, therefore they have <i>ketubah</i>. Those, since they are not punished together with the child, they fined them, therefore they do not have <i>ketubah</i>. What is the difference between them? He who remarried his divorced wife after she had remarried. For him who says since these are words of the Torah, and this case is a word of the Torah, therefore she has <i>ketubah</i>. For him who says since these are punished together with the child, this one, since neither she nor the child is punished, therefore, she has no <i>ketubah</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said that Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Hila say that they differ about sustenance. Rebbi Joḥanan said, she may demand sustenance. Rebbi Eleazar said to him, one says to him, divorce her! And you say so? They wanted to say, for him who says they differ about the conditions attached to a <i>ketubah</i>, Rebbi Joḥanan said, she has the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations. Rebbi Eleazar said to him, everybody agrees that she cannot claim support since they even punished her heirs, so much more herself. But for him who says that they differ about sustenance, it follows that they do not differ about the stipulations of a <i>ketubah</i>. They fined her, but did not fine her heirs.

Chapter 12



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody marries a woman and contracts with her to sustain her daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">From a prior marriage.</i> for five years, he is obligated to sustain her for five years<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Even if he divorces her mother before the end of the five years, since his obligation is towards the daughter, and obligations towards minors cannot be renegotiated.</i>. If [the mother] was married<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">During the five years from her marriage to the first.</i> to another man who contracted with her to sustain her daughter for five years, he is obligated to sustain her for five years. The first one cannot say, if she will come to live with me I shall sustain her, but he has to bring her support to her place<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Who is with her mother, in the second husband’s house.</i>. Similarly, the two cannot say we shall support her in common, but one of them sustains her and the other gives the money equivalent to her sustenance.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody marries a woman and had contracted with her,” etc. How does he become indebted to her<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since obviously the intention of the groom was to feed the daughter with her mother in his house; if he had known that he would divorce the mother before the daughter reached marriageable age he would not have agreed to these terms. Can he not claim now that he entered the obligation in error?</i>? Do not Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 101b" href="/Ketubot.101b">Babli, 101b</a>, he is reported to hold that an obligation entered into voluntarily cannot be repealed, as pointed out by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 102a:10:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.102a.10.1">Tosaphot, 102a <i>s</i>. <i>v</i>. אליבא</a>.</i> and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, if somebody writes a debenture for another person under the assumption that he owes him and it turns out that he does not owe, he does not have to give to him<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Chapter 5, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:1:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.1.2-4">Halakhah 1</a>.</i>! Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they gave it the status of an addition to the <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">A voluntary addition by the groom to the minimal amounts of the <i>ketubah</i>, which is protected by all privileges given to the <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. Then he should have to pay in the end<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Not at the end of five years but at the end of the marriage, when the entire <i>ketubah</i> becomes due immediately. But the Mishnah lets him pay off his obligation for the remainder of the five years.</i>! They gave it the status of the gift for a woman’s preliminary marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This is an awkward formulation of the answer given to the question in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 102a" href="/Ketubot.102a">Babli (102a</a>): The mother acquires the rights for her daughter under the special rules for acquisition by the children of sums promised by the respective parents when they decide on the marriage pact, cf. 5:1 (Notes 15,16), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.2.2">6:2 (Note 29</a>). The acquisition of rights by mother and daughter as a consequence of the oral promise of the groom.</i>. Then he should pay up front<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Anything promised for preliminary marriage has to be delivered at the preliminary marriage.</i>! They treated it as when one marries a woman preliminarily by promising to give her twelve silver denars within one year by delivering one silver denar’s worth every month<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The husband delivers by taking the daughter to live in his house together with her mother.</i>.
It was stated: He supports her the first five years, whether in inflation or in deflation. If [living expenses] were high and became low, if he was the cause<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">If he divorced the girl’s mother by his own initiative before the end of the contracted years.</i>, he pays the high rate, if she was the cause, he pays the low rate. If they were low and became high, whether he was the cause or she was the cause, he pays the low rate<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">He obligated himself only for living expenses which were the going rate at the time the contract was signed.</i>. That is, “the daughter neither ascends nor descends.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:6:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.6.5">Chapter 5:6, Note 154</a>.</i>”
There<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.12.1">Mishnah 4:13</a>.</i>, we have stated: “The female children you will have by me shall live in my house and be supported by my estate,” and it was stated about this: They will be clothed with garments supplied by me<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">One should not interpret מזוֹנוֹת narrowly as “food” but more generally as “sustenance” (but excluding rent.)</i>. For whom does the daughter work? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.2.1">Mishnah 12:2</a>, about the wife’s daughter who marries while her mother’s (ex-)husbands continue to support her.</i>: “The husband has to sustain her and they pay the cost of her sustenance.” This means, he feeds her but she works for her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">And if the daughter is still unmarried, she works for herself.</i>. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh (Chapter 12, #1) reads: Rebbi Assi; this means that he read here רִבִּי יָסָא; an unlikely reading.</i> said, this means that if somebody had agreed to sustain his daughter-in-law, he has to sustain her, but she works for his son. If he wants her to be with him<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of his divorcee, in the case that her mother did not remarry.</i> but she does not want to, the law is with her, as we have stated: “They pay the cost of her sustenance.” If she fell ill, it is as if she had married. If she died, is it as if she had married<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Is the husband’s obligation one that the wife’s daughter’s heirs can collect?</i>? If she died, she already is dead<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The obligation ends with the daughter’s death. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 140a" href="/Bava_Batra.140a">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 140a</a>, this is considered to be obvious.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The one mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i> married, the husband has to sustain her and they pay the cost of her sustenance. If they died<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The mother’s husband and/or ex-husband.</i>, their daughters are supported from unincumbered property but she is supported from mortgaged property since her status is that of a creditor<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Her claim is that of her mother’s <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. The intelligent ones did write: On condition that I support your daughter for five years the entire time you are with me<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Then the daughter’s claim is terminated if either the mother is divorced or the mother or the husband died.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the daughter married, the husband has to sustain her,” etc. What is the status of the <i>ketubah</i> stipulations if he wrote them in the document<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">All the stipulations enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.7.1">Mishnaiot 4:7</a> ff. are enforceable even if they are not written in the <i>ketubah</i>. What is the legal difference between a <i>ketubah</i> in which the stipulations are explicit and one in which they are implicit?</i>? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagree. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he wrote them for emphasis<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Without legal consequences. (In Rashi’s interpretation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 102b" href="/Ketubot.102b">Babli, 102b</a>, Rav Ashi agrees.)</i>; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, he wrote them to collect from encumbered property. Rebbi Jeremiah switched the traditions<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">He switched the attributions to R. Joḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish. Therefore, the discussion proceeds without referring to names.</i>. Rebbi Yudan said, a Mishnah supports him who said, he wrote them for emphasis, since we stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.3.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:3</a>.</i>: “One does not foreclose from mortgaged property to indemnify for produce or investment<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody sold a field, the title to which was later disputed and the court awarded the title to another person who then takes the field away from the buyer. The innocent buyer then has regress on the fraudulent seller. Real estate is always sold with a title guarantee; therefore the value of the field can be taken from the seller’s mortgaged property (depending on the time of sale). But both the value of the standing crop which the buyer lost, and the value of the investments the buyer made in the property cannot be recovered from mortgaged property. The main difference is that the privileged amount, the value of the field, is a well-defined sum written in the sales contract, whereas the rest are open-ended obligations which cannot be foreseen and whose inclusion in the causes for foreclosure would bring all real estate transactions to a halt.</i>, or sustenance of widow and daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">These also are open-ended obligations which cannot be estimated beforehand; they cannot be enforced against mortgage holders, in contrast to the <i>ketubah</i> sum which is well-defined.</i>, in order not to impede the economy.” Are [the first categories] not based on a document? Here also based on the document<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Since the regress of the buyer on the fraudulent seller is based on the sales contract, and it turns out that only part of the claim can be satisfied by foreclosure, it shows that the <i>ketubah</i> document also has parts which have the status of certificates of indebtedness and other parts which cannot be enforced by foreclosure.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanania said, “since her status is that of a creditor”! Is that not based on a document? Here also based on the document<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The wife’s daughter’s claim is also based on her mother’s <i>ketubah</i> document and is enforceable as a creditor’s claim but her mother’s own claim to sustenance as a widow is based on the same document and not thus enforceable.</i>.
If she dies she is not with him<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the stipulation of the “intelligent” who limit their liability.</i>. If she was divorced she is not with him. If he took her back<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Without writing a new <i>ketubah</i> document, as authorized in Mishnah 9:13 (Note 240).</i>? One says, this was stated for the <i>ketubah</i> but not for the stipulations; one says, both for the <i>ketubah</i> and the stipulations, which opinion is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">R. Nissim Gerondi (commentary on the Mishnah) has a smoother text: מָאן דְּאָמַר. לִכְתוּבָּה אֲבָל לֹא לִתְנָאִין הָכָא לִתְנָאִין. הָכָא נַמֵּי. נַמֵּי. מָאן דְּאָמַר. בֵּין לִכְתוּבָּה בֵין “Following the one who says, this was stated for the <i>ketubah</i> but not for the stipulations, it is clear; following the one who says, both for the <i>ketubah</i> and the stipulations, it is clear.” But since הָכָא נַמֵּי is purely Babylonian style, his text is a paraphrase, not a variant reading.</i>? “The intelligent ones did write: On condition that I support your daughter for five years the entire time you are with me;” on that it was stated: Only for the first marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Even if in general stipulations are re-instated with remarriage, this particular condition has been permanently terminated by the divorce. It could only be re-instated by a separate document.</i>. This parallels what Rebbi Ḥanina said, if somebody marries off his son in a house, the latter acquires the house, but only for a first marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">He gives them a house to live in alone during their wedding week; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.1.4">5:1 Note 23</a> (Babli 144a). For the Babli, there would be no parallel since there, R. Ḥanina assigns the house only to the oldest son who marries a virgin, and a woman with a daughter by another man is not a virgin.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the widow said, I cannot move from my husband’s house, the heirs cannot say to her, go to your father’s house and we shall support you there, but they support her and give her a dwelling commensurate with her honor.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">41a</sup><i class="footnote">The following Halakhah in its entirety is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:3:3-17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.3.3-17">Halakhah <i>Kilaim</i> 9:4 (Notes 70–136</a>). The ms. readings from <i>Kilaim</i> are printed in Frank-Rühl typeface in the variant readings.</i>“If the widow said, I cannot move from my husband’s house,” etc. It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 88:6" href="/Psalms.88.6"><i>Ps</i>. 88:6</a>): “Among the dead is freedom.” When a person dies he becomes free from the Commandments.
Rebbi commanded three things on his death-bed: My widow should not move from my house; do not eulogize me in small towns; and he who served me during my lifetime should also serve me in death. “My widow should not move from my house,” is that not a Mishnah? “The widow who said, I cannot possibly move from my husband’s house …” Rebbi Dositheos said, that they should not say, this is the house of the patriarchate and must serve the patriarchate. Rebbi Eleazar bar Yose said, as we have stated: “She lives in the houses just as she lived while her husband was overseas, she uses silver and gold vessels just as she used to while her husband was overseas, she is fed just as she was fed while her husband was overseas.” “Do not eulogize me in small towns” because of the quarrels. “He who served me during my lifetime should also serve me in death;” Rebbi Ḥananiah from Sepphoris said, for example Yose Ephrati and Joseph from Haifa. Rebbi Ḥizqiah added, do not use many shrouds on me and let my coffin have holes at the bottom. These words say that Rebbi was buried in a single shroud since Rebbi said, not as a man left, he will come. But the rabbis say, just as a man left, he will come. It was stated in the name of Rebbi Nathan: The garment that went with a person to the grave will come back with him. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:14" href="/Job.38.14"><i>Job</i> 38:14</a>) “The seal turns itself around like clay, they appear in dress.” Antoninus asked Rebbi, what is the meaning of what is written: “The seal turns itself around like clay?” He said to him, He Who brings the generation clothes it.
Rebbi Joḥanan commanded: Dress me in beige, neither white nor black. If I rise among the just I shall not be ashamed, if I rise among the wicked I shall not be ashamed. Rebbi Joshia commanded: Dress me in clean white. They said to him, in what are you better than your teacher? He said to them, why should I be ashamed of my deeds? Rebbi Jeremiah commanded: Dress me in clean white, dress me in my socks, put my shoes on my feet and a walking stick in my hand, lay me on my side; when the Messiah comes I shall be ready.
The people from Sepphoris said: We shall kill anybody who tells us that Rebbi died. Bar Qappara associated with them, his head covered and his garments torn. He said to them: Earthlings and angels held the Tablets of the Covenant; the angels were stronger and they took away the Tablets. They said to him: Rebbi died. He said to them: You said it. They tore their clothes and the sound of the tearing was heard from the gate to a distance of three <i>mil</i>.
Rebbi Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Mana: Miracles happened that day. It was Sabbath eve and all the surrounding towns came together to eulogize him. They made him [Rebbi] rest in eighteen synagogues until they brought him to his resting place but the day extended for them until each one had time to get to his house, fill an amphora of water, and light the candles. When the sun set, the rooster crowed. They were anxious and said, maybe we did desecrate the Sabbath? There came a voice and said to them, every one who was not lazy for the eulogies of Rebbi shall be announced for the life of the Future World, except the fuller. When the latter heard this, he climbed on the roof, threw himself down, and died. There came a voice and said, including the fuller.
Rebbi dwelt in Sepphoris seventeen years and applied to himself (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 47:28" href="/Genesis.47.28"><i>Gen</i>. 47:28</a>): “Jacob lived in Egypt seventeen years,” Jehudah lived in Sepphoris seventeen years. Of these he suffered from toothache for thirteen years. {Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, all these thirteen years no woman lying-in died in the Land of Israel and no pregnant woman had a miscarriage in the Land of Israel.} Why did he have a toothache? Once he saw a calf to be slaughtered when it bellowed and said to him, Rebbi, save me! He said to it, for that you were created. At the end, how was he healed? He saw them killing a burrow of rats. He said to them, let them live, it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 145:9" href="/Psalms.145.9"><i>Ps</i>. 145:9</a>) “His mercy extends to all His creatures.”
Rebbi was very meek and said, all a man might ask from me I am ready to do, except what the Elders of Bathyra did for my ancestor: they divested themselves and appointed him. If Rav Huna, the Head of the Diaspora, came here I would let him sit higher than myself since he is from the tribe of Judah and I am from Benjamin, he is from the male line and I am from the female. Once, the elder Rebbi Ḥiyya visited him and said, Rav Huna is outside. The face of Rebbi became saffron-colored. He [R. Ḥiyya] said to him, it is his coffin. He [Rebbi] said to him, go outside and look who wants you there. He stepped outside and did not find anybody; he understood that he [Rebbi] was angry with him. He did not visit him again for thirty days. Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, in those thirty days did Rav learn from him [R. Ḥiyya] the principles of Torah. At the end of thirteen years and thirty days, Elijah visited him [Rebbi] in the likeness of the older Rebbi Ḥiyya. He said to him, how does my lord feel? He said to him, one tooth hurts me. He said to him, show it to me. He showed it to him, he put his finger on it and it was healed. The next day, the older Rebbi Ḥiyya came to him and asked him, how does Rebbi feel, what is with that tooth? He said to him, from the moment that you put your finger on it, it was healed. At that moment, he said, woe on you, lying-in women of the Land of Israel, woe on you, pregnant women of the Land of Israel! He [R. Ḥiyya] said to him, that was not me. From that moment on, he [Rebbi] treated him with honor. When he [Rebbi] went to the assembly hall, he said, may the older Rebbi Ḥiyya come inside. Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose asked, closer than me? He said, beware! The older Rebbi Ḥiyya inside, and Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose innermost. Rebbi used to state the praises of the older Rebbi Ḥiyya before Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose. {Once, he [R. Ismael ben R. Yose] saw him [R. Ḥiyya] in the bathhouse and he did not show him reverence. He [R. Ismael ben R. Yose] said to him [Rebbi], is that the one of whom you state praises? He said, what did he do to you? He said, I saw him in the bathhouse and he did not show me reverence.} He [Rebbi] said to him [R. Ḥiyya], why did you do that? He said to him, so much should come over me if I realized that I was washing myself, at that time my eyes were occupied with the allegorical interpretation of the entire book of Psalms. From that moment on, he [Rebbi] appointed two students to accompany him [R. Ḥiyya] because of the danger.
Rebbi Yasa fasted eighty days to see the old Rebbi Ḥiyya. In the end, he saw his bier and him sleeping on it. If you say that Rebbi Assi was an insignificant person, one tanner came to Rebbi Joḥanan and said, I saw the sky falling but one of your students supported it. He asked him, could you recognize him? He said, if I would see him, I would recognize him. He made all his students pass before him [the tanner], and he recognized Rebbi Assi. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish fasted three hundred fasts to see the old Rebbi Ḥiyya but did not see him. In the end, he started to feel badly and said, did he study Torah more than I did? They said to him, he spread Torah more than you did and in addition he went into exile. He said to them, did I not also go into exile? They said to him, you went into exile to study, he went into exile to teach.
When Rav Huna, the Head of the Diaspora, died they brought him here. They said, where shall we put him? They said, let us put him next to Rebbi Ḥiyya the elder for he is one of them. They said, who might want to bring him there? Rebbi Ḥaggai said, I shall go up to put him there. They said to him, you are looking for a pretext, for you are an old man and you want to go to rest there yourself. He said to them, put some string on my feet and when I shall be weak you pull. He went in and found the three arguing. “Jehudah my son, after you, and no more. Ḥizqiah my son, after you, and no more. Joseph ben Israel, after you, and no more.” He [R. Ḥaggai] lifted his eyes to look, it was said to him lower [your eyes], turn around. Rebbi Ḥiyya the elder [who said to] his son Jehudah, make space for Rav Ḥuna that he may rest there. But [Rav Ḥuna] did not accept this. They said, since he did not accept that one made space for him, so his descendants will never end. He [R. Ḥaggai] exited from there eighty years old and his years were doubled.
It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 47:30" href="/Genesis.47.30"><i>Gen</i>. 47:30</a>): “You shall carry me from Egypt and bury me in their burial place.” What would Jacob lose at any place he would prophesy? Rebbi Eleazar gave an inner reason, Rebbi Joshua ben Levi gave an inner reason, Rebbi Ḥanina gave an inner reason. What is the inner reason? Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 116:9" href="/Psalms.116.9"><i>Ps</i>. 116:9</a>) “I will walk before the Eternal in the Land of Life.” But the lands of life are only Tyre and its surroundings and Caesarea (maritima) and its surroundings; there is cheap (food), there is plenty. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish in the name of Bar Qappara, the Land whose dead will live again in the days of the Messiah. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 42:9" href="/Isaiah.42.9"><i>Is</i>. 42:9</a>) “He gives soul to the people on it.” That would mean that our teachers in Babylonia would lose out! Rebbi Simai said, the Holy One, praised be He, walks before them and they roll like wine barrels. When they arrive in the Land of Israel their souls are with them. What is the reason? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 36:24" href="/Ezekiel.36.24"><i>Ez</i>. 36:24</a>) “I shall bring you to your soil,” (37:14) “give My spirit into you, and you will live.”
Rebbi Berekhiah asked Rebbi Ḥelbo. Rebbi Ḥelbo asked Rebbi Immi. Rebbi Immi asked Rebbi Eleazar. Rebbi Eleazar asked Rebbi Ḥanina, some say Rebbi Ḥanina asked Rebbi Joshua: Even those like Jeroboam and his kind? He said to him, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 29:22" href="/Deuteronomy.29.22"><i>Deut</i>. 29:22</a>) “Sulphur and salt, conflagration throughout the country.” Rebbi Berekhiah said, one asked the other and we understand nothing from it. What does it mean? Since the Land of Israel was burned, judgment was executed on it. We have stated in the name of Rebbi Jehudah: Seven years was the Land of Israel burned; that is what is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 9:27" href="/Daniel.9.27"><i>Dan</i>. 9:27</a>) “The Covenant overtook the public for one week.” What did the secondaries in it do? Pieces, pieces and it was burned.
It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 20:6-7" href="/Jeremiah.20.6-7"><i>Jer</i>. 20:6–7</a>): “But you, Pashḥur, and all inhabitants of your house will go into captivity. You will come to Babylon, die there, and be buried there.” Rebbi Abba [bar Zemina] said, Rebbi Ḥelbo and Rebbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina. One of them said, if somebody dies there and is buried there, he has two [detriments] in hand. If he dies there and is buried here, he has one [detriment] in hand. The other one said, burial atones for their death.
Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rebbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina: A human’s feet bring him to where he is wanted. It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:20" href="/I_Kings.22.20"><i>1K</i>. 22:20</a>) “The Eternal said, who will seduce Ahab that he should go and fall in Ramot Gilead?” Might he not die in his house rather than there? Eliḥoref and Aḥiah were two of Solomon’s secretaries. He [Solomon] saw the Angel of Death looking at them and grinding his teeth. He said a word and put them into space. He [the Angel of Death] went and took them from there, then he came laughing before him [Solomon]. He said to him, just before you were grinding your teeth and now you are laughing at us? He said to him, the Merciful told me to take Eliḥoref and Aḥiah from space and I was wondering who would put them there where I was sent to take them; He put it into your mind to do so that I could complete my mission. I went and dealt with them there. The two sons of Rebbi Reuben ben Strobilos were students of Rebbi. He [Rebbi] saw the Angel of Death looking at them and grinding his teeth and said, let us exile them to the South, maybe the exile atones. He [the angel of death] went and took them from there.
Ulla was an emigrant. He was dying there and started to cry. They said to him, why are you crying? We shall bring you [to the Land of Israel]. He said to them, how does this help me? I am losing my pearl in an impure land. One cannot compare one who expires in the bosom of his mother to one who expires in the bosom of a strange woman. Rebbi Meïr was dying in Assos. He said, tell the people of the Land of Israel, there is your Messiah. With all that, he said to put his bier on the cape since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 24:2" href="/Psalms.24.2"><i>Ps</i>. 24:2</a>): “For He founded it on seas, based it on rivers.”
“Seven seas surround the Land of Israel: The ocean, lake Tiberias, lake <i>Samkho</i>, the salt sea, lake Ḥolata, lake Sheliat, lake Apamea.” But does there not also exist the lake of Ḥomṣ? Diocletian dammed up rivers and created it. It is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 21:20" href="/Numbers.21.20"><i>Num</i>. 21:20</a>): “Looking down on the desert.” Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, if one ascends the desert mountain one finds the likeness of a sieve in lake Tiberias, that is the well of Miryam. Rebbi Joḥanan bar Mara said, the rabbis estimated it and it is assessed opposite the middle gate of the old synagogue of <i>Imdvtgyn</i>.
Rebbi Bar Qiria and Rebbi Eleazar were taking a walk on the road when they saw coffins being brought into the Land from abroad. Rebbi Bar Qiria said to Rebbi Eleazar: What good is that going to do them? I am reading for them (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 2:7" href="/Jeremiah.2.7"><i>Jer</i>. 2:7</a>) “My inheritance your considered an abomination” during your lifetime, “you came and made My Land impure” in your death. He said to him, when they arrive in the Land, one takes a lump of earth and puts it on the coffin, as it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:43" href="/Deuteronomy.32.43"><i>Deut</i>. 32:43</a>) “His earth atones for His people.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The widow.</i> said, I cannot possibly move from my father’s house, the heirs can tell her: If you are with us, you are provided with sustenance, but if you are not with us, you are not provided with sustenance<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">If she does not want to keep house for them, she has to claim her <i>ketubah</i>.</i>. If she argues because she is young and they are young<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">As the Halakhah explains, if they lived together, people would start to talk that she was sleeping with her stepsons.</i>, one provides her with sustenance while she is in her father’s house.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she said, I cannot possibly move from my father’s house,” etc. “If she argues because she is young and they are young,” to avoid a bad reputation.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> All the time she lives in her father’s house, she always can collect her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since she was not sustained by the estate.</i>; if she she lives in her husband’s house, she can collect her <i>ketubah</i> for 25 years, for in 25 years she will have received benefits in the value of her <i>ketubah</i>, the words of Rebbi Meïr who spoke in the name of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. But the Sages say, all the time she lives in her husband’s house, she always can collect her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Since she has to keep house for the heirs, her sustenance is payment for her services and cannot be counted against her <i>ketubah</i>.</i>; if she lives in her father’s house, she can collect her <i>ketubah</i> for 25 years<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is not supported by the estate and has no connection with the heirs, one may assume that she has decided not to claim the <i>ketubah</i>; this is a statute of limitation for claims.</i>. If she died, her heirs can sell<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This reading is found in the Yerushalmi and two other Mishnah mss., as well as the <i>editio princeps</i> of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 12:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).12.3">Tosephta (12:3</a>). In the Halakhah it is quoted in the form of the Mishnah of the Babli and the great majority of Mishnah mss. and both Tosephta mss: מזכירין “they mention”. This refers to the rule explained in the second paragraph of the Halakhah, that any mention of the <i>ketubah</i> to the heirs stops the statute of limitations and begins a new period of 25 years. Therefore, it is even possible to sustain the reading of the Mishnah, that her heirs can sell her claim within 25 years since the notification of the stake of the claim to the heirs automatically starts a new period of 25 years.</i> her <i>ketubah</i> for up to 25 years.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “All the time she lives in her father’s house,” etc. For the good she received; her properties became delivered<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic Hebrew, חלט means not only “to parboil” but also “making a final decision”. Neither meaning fits the context here. It seems that the word is Arabic خلط “to mix something with something else”, meaning that her dowry was mixed with her husband’s property all the time.</i> during her husband’s lifetime and after 25 years she gave up the claim to her <i>ketubah</i>. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi La: One understands for a woman who has no <i>ketubah</i>. But should a woman who has a <i>ketubah</i> not be able to collect forever? He answered him, it tells you more: Even a woman who has a <i>ketubah</i> collects only up to 25 years<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 104b" href="/Ketubot.104b">Babli, 104b</a>, Rav Naḥman decides with Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi that the limitation imposed by the Mishnah refers only to a widow who has no <i>ketubah</i> document to present to the court.</i>. The statement of Rebbi Eleazar says<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 12:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).12.3">Tosephta 12:3</a> notes that the creditor (who is secured by a mortgage document) can foreclose forever, after the description of the difference between R. Meïr and the Sages, and a remark that R. Ismael sets the time limit at 30 years. (The first law enacted in the Roman Empire to set a time limit on the collection of debts seems to have been Theodosius II’s <i>praescriptio triginta annorum</i> of 424 C.E.). The (anonymous) Tosephta is ascribed here to one of the Tannaïm named R. Eleazar.</i>, the creditor collects forever. He said only, “the creditor”; but a woman can collect only up to25 years. Rebbi Abin said, this is reasonable only for a woman who is not being supported. But for a woman who is being supported, I say that she did not claim it because of her support<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 12:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).12.3">Tosephta 12:3</a> notes that the creditor (who is secured by a mortgage document) can foreclose forever, after the description of the difference between R. Meïr and the Sages, and a remark that R. Ismael sets the time limit at 30 years. (The first law enacted in the Roman Empire to set a time limit on the collection of debts seems to have been Theodosius II’s <i>praescriptio triginta annorum</i> of 424 C.E.). The (anonymous) Tosephta is ascribed here to one of the Tannaïm named R. Eleazar.</i>.
Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, not only that she claims, but even if she mentions [her claims], as we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Since this refers to the Mishnah of this Halakhah, “there” is out of place. Probably the Mishnah is correct as given and the quote here refers to a text similar to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 12:3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).12.3">Tosephta 12:3</a>.</i>: “If she died, her heirs can mention her <i>ketubah</i> for up to 25 years.” He tells you more: Even if she let 25 years minus one day go by before claiming, and then claimed, one gives her another 25 years<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The claim does not necessarily have to be a claim for payment but may be a reminder that the claim exists. This is sufficient to start a new period of limitation. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 104" href="/Ketubot.104">Babli agrees, 104</a> a/b, but in connection with the rule that a documented <i>ketubah</i> is not subject to a statute of limitations; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 12:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.12.5.2">Note 50</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: One stated this only for the <i>ketubah</i> of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The amount the husband has to promise from his own money.</i>. But a <i>ketubah</i> of 1’000 denar<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The greatest part of which is represented by the dowry, her own family’s contribution.</i> she collects forever<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Mortmain dowry is secured by a general mortgage on the husband’s properties; there seems to be no reason to treat this mortgage differently from the mortgage executed for a third party lender.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu quoted in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Even a <i>ketubah</i> of 1’000 denar she can collect only up to 25 years. This disagreement parallels the following disagreement, as was stated there: “Torts are estimated from choice land, creditor’s claims from average, and a woman’s <i>ketubah</i> from the least valuable.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:1</a>. Since mortgages were usually not written on specific parcels, there are general rules governing foreclosures if the debtor cannot pay cash. The categories mentioned here are explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.7">Chapter 9, Note 195</a>.</i>” Rebbi Jeremiah said to him, this was stated only for the <i>ketubah</i> of a mina or 200 [<i>zuz</i>], but a <i>ketubah</i> of 1’000 denar is evaluated in terms of average quality land<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Mortmain dowry is secured by a general mortgage on the husband’s properties; there seems to be no reason to treat this mortgage differently from the mortgage executed for a third party lender.</i>. But Rebbi Yose said, even a <i>ketubah</i> of 1’000 denar she collects only from the least valuable land. It turns out that Rebbi Yose follows Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Jeremiah Rebbi Joshua ben Levi. As we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Peah</i> 3:9, Note 151.</i>: “If somebody signs over his property to his sons and signs over some real estate to his wife, she lost her claim to <i>ketubah</i>.” <sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">This text is a slightly shortened version of a text in <i>Peah</i> 3:9, explained there in Notes 182–189.</i> Rav said, if he lets them acquire through her. Samuel says, if he distributes in her presence. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, they stated here a relaxation of the laws of <i>ketubah</i>. Rebbi Abba said, the reason of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina is that it applies not only to a <i>ketubah</i> of a mina or two hundred, but even regarding a <i>ketubah</i> of one thousand denar they proclaimed a relaxation of the laws of <i>ketubah</i>.

Chapter 13
